('36', 0, 2, 3, 51) SERVANTS OF INDIA FIRE RELIEF
('36', 0, 3, 4, 81) Contributions made in answer to the appeal of the Rt.
('36', 0, 3, 5, 135) Srinivasa Sastri total nearly Rs. 50,000. It should be remembered that two lacs at least are wanted to enable the Society to make a fresh start in respect of the interrupted activities.
('36', 0, 3, 6, 321) The weekly organ, The Servant of India, is being brought out under difficulties.
('36', 0, 3, 7, 402) It is to be hoped that the whole amount will be subscribed without delay irrespective of one’s politics.
('36', 0, 4, 8, 507) LIMITED SACRIFICE
('36', 0, 5, 9, 525) An ex principal of a national college, a master of arts, writes:
('36', 0, 6, 10, 590) Your article on sacrifice 1 is nearly heart rending.
('36', 0, 6, 11, 643) You seem to be expecting more sacrifice from those who are willing and have already done their best, and do not seem to take to task those pretending followers who have the effrontery of exploiting the national movement for their personal benefit.
('36', 0, 6, 12, 891) It would be doing greater service to the motherland if you try to get hold of rich people who will swear by you to maintain six good workers each who will take up village organization.
('36', 0, 6, 13, 1076) I have singled out the foregoing sentences from a longish letter.
('36', 0, 6, 14, 1142) In the first instance, there can be no limit to one’s sacrifice.
('36', 0, 6, 15, 1207) A sacrifice that calculates and bargains is hardly a sacrifice.
('36', 0, 6, 16, 1271) I have asked for no more than what has been given in other parts of the world where people have regained or retained their freedom; nor are instances of such uttermost sacrifice lacking even in our country.
('36', 0, 6, 17, 1478) That sacrifice comes from deep conviction and it is deep conviction that is just now wanted in the country.
('36', 0, 6, 18, 1586) In the second instance, one does not ask or expect anything from pretended followers.
('36', 0, 6, 19, 1672) The prevalent law throughout the world seems to be for those who give to give more and more.
('36', 0, 6, 20, 1765) They do so, not under compulsion, but voluntarily and joyfully.
('36', 0, 6, 21, 1829) And, at the end of the giving, they regret that they have not more to give.
('36', 0, 6, 22, 1905) In the third place, I do not know a single honest, industrious and intelligent worker who is starving for want of work.
('36', 0, 6, 23, 2025) The difficulty occurs when the worker dictates terms or has requirements which, if he
('36', 0, 7, 24, 2111) 1 Vide “Sacrifice”, 24 6 1926.
('36', 1, 0, 1, 2142) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 1, 1, 2, 2182) declined to be bound by custom or sentiment, would have no existence whatsoever.
('36', 1, 1, 3, 2263) After all, it is the few patriotic rich men in the country who are financing several public movements.
('36', 1, 1, 4, 2366) My own experience is that money enough has always been found wherever a just cause has been discovered to be backed by honest and able workers.
('36', 1, 1, 5, 2510) Young workers are more and more devoting themselves daily to village work, but ten times as many workers are required.
('36', 1, 1, 6, 2629) There is no dearth of money or work.
('36', 1, 1, 7, 2666) But there is dearth of men who are satisfied with a modest salary in keeping with the conditions of the country.

('36', 1, 2, 9, 2956) FROM THE FRYING PAN
('36', 1, 3, 10, 2976) The draft rules published by the Madras Government about spinning in primary schools show what can happen even under ‘responsible’ government when the government may afford to ignore public opinion.
('36', 1, 3, 11, 3175) What response can a government that is, say, dependent upon the votes of zamindars make to their voteless ryots?
('36', 1, 3, 12, 3288) When, therefore, there is only a caricature of responsible government, things can be much worse than under a frankly and purely autocratic government.
('36', 1, 3, 13, 3439) The latter, not depending upon the votes of any class, can afford to be impartial to all.
('36', 1, 3, 14, 3529) The former dare not.
('36', 1, 3, 15, 3550) The draft rules are naturally from the Education Minister who is considered to be responsible to the people, i.e., the select electorate.
('36', 1, 3, 16, 3688) But, having no knowledge evidently of rural conditions, he thinks that instruction in hand spinning in primary schools is unnecessary.
('36', 1, 3, 17, 3823) Instead, therefore, of frankly putting a ban upon it, he seeks to circu mvent it by ruling that “practical instruction should not be introduced in standards below the fourth without the previous approval of the Director of Public Instruction,” that it should “ordinarily have refe rence to the chief occupations or industries of the locality or the class of pupils,” and that “spinning by itself without provision for weaving should not form a subject for such institution”.
('36', 1, 3, 18, 4298) The last condition is enough to keep out spinning from the average primary school, if only because hardly a primary school can afford the expense of a weaving instructor and the floor space required for setting up a loom.
('36', 1, 3, 19, 4520) Indeed, even the spinning wheel has by experience been found to be too expensive and too large for the average school.
('36', 1, 3, 20, 4639) The All India Spinners’ Association is, therefore, advising all schoolmasters and
('36', 2, 0, 1, 4721) VOL. 36: 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 3
('36', 2, 1, 2, 4763) municipal councils to introduce the takli which is inexpensive, handy, requires no floor space to keep and does not easily go out of order.
('36', 2, 1, 3, 4903) It is surprising too that neither the Minister nor his advisers seem to realize that hand spinning cannot be and must not be put on a level with the other occupations.
('36', 2, 1, 4, 5071) As Sjt.
('36', 2, 1, 5, 5079) C. Rajagopalachari points out in his appeal to local bodies in the Madras Presidency, it is pre eminently a universal national occupation which, having all but died, needs to be revived and popularized.
('36', 2, 1, 6, 5282) It would be a useless waste of time and money to teach in primary schools living occupations which children can learn much better and much more quickly from their parents than from theoretical and indifferent teachers.
('36', 2, 1, 7, 5501) I am glad, therefore, that the Chittoor District Education Council has voted against the draft rules and hope that the other bodies will follow suit.
('36', 2, 2, 8, 5651) Young India, 8 7 1926
('36', 2, 3, 9, 5673) 2. ‘MORE ANIMAL THAN HUMAN’
('36', 2, 4, 10, 5701) A medical correspondent referring to the article ‘What is Natural?’ 1 in Young India of the 24th ultimo writes:
('36', 2, 5, 11, 5813) It is only in the mass that the people’s instinct of violence is aroused.
('36', 2, 5, 12, 5887) It is almost impossible to prevent the use of physical force under such circumstances and I wonder if it is altogether desirable to discourage it.
('36', 2, 5, 13, 6034) It is positively against man’s nature.
('36', 2, 5, 14, 6073) Man is animal first and human afterwards.
('36', 2, 5, 15, 6115) Just think of the ancestor of the Australian savage and his times when there was no art, no literature, no science, and when man was a hunter and communi cated with his fellows by means of gestures.
('36', 2, 5, 16, 6314) Our ethical code is a thin veneer and the passions of the brute are still lurking within us.
('36', 2, 5, 17, 6407) It is not natural to man to find and know God, much less to worship him.
('36', 2, 5, 18, 6480) In an individual naturally brought up, educated in an unbiassed and non theological atmosphere, the idea ofworshipping God will be quite unnatural.
('36', 2, 5, 19, 6628) Millions of educated adults in the world never enter a church, mosque or temple.
('36', 2, 5, 20, 6709) God worship is an acquired habit.
('36', 2, 5, 21, 6743) The question of virtue and vice has nothing to do with God.
('36', 2, 5, 22, 6803) Morality arises from the necessities of group life, and it has its sanctions in the social needs of man rather than in a capricious divine will.
('36', 2, 5, 23, 6948) Man is not made in the image of God; it is God who is made in the image of man.
('36', 2, 5, 24, 7028) Your moral code would not be debased if you regarded the ape as your remote cousin.
('36', 2, 5, 25, 7112) Eating, drinking, and sexual gratification are absolutely natural to man.
('36', 2, 5, 26, 7186) There are

('36', 3, 1, 2, 7274) limits of course, but they are perfectly physiological and partly conventional.
('36', 3, 1, 3, 7354) How can you preach this doctrine of complete renunciation of sexual desire?
('36', 3, 1, 4, 7430) Don’t you think that we cannot possibly attain complete renunciation of the desire except through an exhaustive fulfilment of it?
('36', 3, 1, 5, 7560) You say, ‘Man’s nature is not himsa but ahimsa.’ But even your own programme of the boycott of the
('36', 3, 2, 6, 7659) British goods, if it had been successful, could have resulted in nothing but violence to the British workers.
('36', 3, 2, 7, 7769) Starving a man is as much violence as hitting him with a lathi.
('36', 3, 2, 8, 7833) Your soul force or love force is a figment of imagination.
('36', 3, 2, 9, 7892) Ahimsa is the creed of civilization, but is not man’s nature.
('36', 3, 2, 10, 7954) I have very much condensed the medical practitioner’s letter.
('36', 3, 2, 11, 8016) The confidence with which it is written takes one’s breath away.
('36', 3, 2, 12, 8081) And yet the correspondent, who appears to be a practitioner of long standing and who has an English degree, represents a large number of educated men.
('36', 3, 2, 13, 8232) I must confess, however, that he does not convince me.
('36', 3, 2, 14, 8287) Let us examine his arguments.
('36', 3, 2, 15, 8317) He says that non violence cannot be attained by the mass of people.
('36', 3, 2, 16, 8385) And, yet, we find that the general work of mankind is being carried on from day to day by the mass of people acting in harmony as if by instinct.
('36', 3, 2, 17, 8531) If they were instinctively violent, the world would end in no time.
('36', 3, 2, 18, 8599) They remain peaceful naturally and without any police or other compulsion.
('36', 3, 2, 19, 8674) It is when the mass mind is unnaturally influenced by wicked men that the mass of mankind commit violence.
('36', 3, 2, 20, 8781) But they forget it as quickly as they commit it, because they return to their peaceful nature immediately the evil influence of the directing mind is removed.
('36', 3, 3, 21, 8940) Hitherto, one has been taught to believe that a species is recognized and differentiated from the rest by its special characteristics.
('36', 3, 3, 22, 9075) Therefore, it would be wrong, I presume, to say that a horse is animal first and horse after.
('36', 3, 3, 23, 9169) He shares something in common with the other animals, but he dare not shed his horseliness and yet remain an animal.
('36', 3, 3, 24, 9286) Having lost his special virtue, he loses also his general status.
('36', 3, 3, 25, 9352) Similarly, if a man lost his status as man and began to grow a tail and walk on all fours, lost the use of his hands, and, more than that, lost the use of his reason, would he not lose with the loss of his status as man his status also as animal?
('36', 3, 3, 26, 9599) Neither the ox nor the ass, neither the sheep nor the goat will claim his as theirs.
('36', 3, 3, 27, 9684) I would suggest to the medical friend that man can be classed as animal only so long as he retains his humanity.
('36', 3, 4, 28, 9797) Neither is there any force in referring me to the Australian savage.
('36', 3, 4, 29, 9866) Even that Australian savage was fundamentally different from
('36', 4, 0, 1, 9927) VOL. 36: 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 5
('36', 4, 1, 2, 9969) the brute, because the brute always will remain brute, whereas the savage has in him the capacity for developing to the fullest height attainable by man.
('36', 4, 1, 3, 10123) We need not go to the Australian savage.
('36', 4, 1, 4, 10164) Our Indian ancestors also were at one time, it will hardly be disputed, just as good and noble savages as the Australians.
('36', 4, 1, 5, 10287) I entirely endorse the remark of the correspondent that even in our so called civilized state, we are not far removed from savages.
('36', 4, 1, 6, 10419) But he is willing to allow that at least we, the civilized descendants of our savage ancestors, may be differentiated from the brute creation.
('36', 4, 1, 7, 10562) It is natural for the brute to be brutal.
('36', 4, 1, 8, 10604) We would resent the adjective if it was applied to us.
('36', 4, 2, 9, 10659) The corespondent apologizes for suggesting that I might regard myself as a ‘remote cousin of the ape’.
('36', 4, 2, 10, 10762) The truth is that my ethics not only permit me to claim but require me to own kinship with not merely the ape but the horse and the sheep, the lion and the leopard, the snake and the scorpion.
('36', 4, 2, 11, 10955) Not so need these kinsfolk regard themselves.
('36', 4, 2, 12, 11001) The hard ethics which rule my life, and I hold ought to rule that of every man and woman, impose this unilateral obligation upon us.
('36', 4, 2, 13, 11134) And it is so imposed because man alone is made in the image of God.
('36', 4, 2, 14, 11202) That some of us do not recognize that status of ours makes no difference, except that then we do not get the benefit of the status, even as a lion brought up in the company of sheep, may not know his own status and, therefore, does not receive its benefits; but it belongs to him, nevertheless, and the moment he realizes it, he begins to exercise his dominion over the sheep.
('36', 4, 2, 15, 11579) But no sheep masquerading as a lion can ever attain the leonine status.
('36', 4, 2, 16, 11651) And to prove the proposition that man is made in the image of God, it is surely unnecessary to show that all men admittedly exhibit that image in their own persons.
('36', 4, 2, 17, 11816) It is enough to show that one man at least has done so.
('36', 4, 2, 18, 11872) And, will it be denied that the great religious teachers of mankind have exhibited the image of God in their own persons?
('36', 4, 3, 19, 11994) But, of course, my correspondent even contends that it is not natural to man to find and know God and; therefore, he says ‘man makes God in his own image’.
('36', 4, 3, 20, 12150) All I can say is that the whole of the evidence hitherto produced by travellers controvert this astounding proposition.
('36', 4, 3, 21, 12270) It is being more and more demonstrated that it is the worship of God, be it in the crudest manner possible, which distin guishes man from the brute.
('36', 4, 3, 22, 12419) It is the possession of that additional quality which gives him such enormous hold upon God’s creation.
('36', 4, 3, 23, 12523) It is wholly irrelevant to show that millions of educated people never
('36', 5, 0, 1, 12594) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 5, 1, 2, 12634) enter a church, mosque or temple.
('36', 5, 1, 3, 12668) Such entry is neither natural nor indispensable for the worship of God.
('36', 5, 1, 4, 12740) Those even who bow their heads before stocks and stones, who believe in incantations or ghosts, acknowledge a power above and beyond them.
('36', 5, 1, 5, 12879) It is true that this form of worship is savage, very crude; nevertheless, it is worship of God.
('36', 5, 1, 6, 12975) Gold is still gold though in its crudest state.
('36', 5, 1, 7, 13023) It merely awaits refine ment to be treated as gold even by the ignorant.
('36', 5, 1, 8, 13096) No amount of refinement will turn iron ore into gold.
('36', 5, 1, 9, 13150) Refined worship is doubtless due to the effort of man.
('36', 5, 1, 10, 13205) Crude worship is as old as Adam, and, as natural to him as eating and drinking, if not more natural.
('36', 5, 1, 11, 13306) A man may live without eating for days on end, he does not live without worship for a single minute.
('36', 5, 1, 12, 13407) He may not acknowledge the fact as many an ignorant man may not acknowledge the possession of lungs or the fact of the circulation of blood.
('36', 5, 2, 13, 13548) The correspondent puts sexual gratification on a level with eating and drinking.
('36', 5, 2, 14, 13629) If he had read my article carefully he would have avoided the confusion of thought that one traces in the thing quoted by him.
('36', 5, 2, 15, 13756) What I have said and repeat is that eating for pleasure, for the gratification, of the palate, is not natural to men.
('36', 5, 2, 16, 13874) But eating to live is natural.
('36', 5, 2, 17, 13905) And so is the sexual act, but not gratification, for the sake of perpetuation of the species, natural to man.
('36', 5, 3, 18, 14015) I fear I shall preach to the end of my days complete renunci ation of sexual desire.
('36', 5, 3, 19, 14100) And this correspondent is the first medical man to tell me that such renunciation is not possible except through ‘our exhaustive fulfilment of the sexual desire’.
('36', 5, 3, 20, 14263) On the contrary, medical authorities tell me that ‘an exhaustive fulfilment leads not to renunci ation, but to ruinous imbecility.
('36', 5, 3, 21, 14394) Complete renunciation of the desire no doubt requires an effort, but is it not worth the prize?
('36', 5, 3, 22, 14490) If a lifetime may be devoted to the exploration of the properties of sound or light and heat, which after all only show us the phenomenal world to advantage, is it too much to expect an equal effort to attain complete renunciation which leads to self realization, or, in other words, to a certain knowledge of God?
('36', 5, 4, 23, 14805) And one who is fairly on the road to renunciation will not need to be told that ahimsa (love), not himsa (hate), rules man, I was almost about to say, the world.
('36', 5, 4, 24, 14967) Illustrations that the correspondent gives to prove my own himsa betrays his ignorance of my writings.

('36', 6, 1, 2, 15247) one ventures to criticize them.
('36', 6, 1, 3, 15279) I have advocated boycott only foreign cloth and there is no violence done to the British workers who may be thrown out of employment because of the boycott of cloth manufa ctured by them, for the simple reason that purchase of foreign cloth is not an obligation undertaken by India.
('36', 6, 1, 4, 15562) Violence is all the other way.
('36', 6, 1, 5, 15593) It is done to India in the name and on behalf of British workers by imposing British cloth upon India.
('36', 6, 1, 6, 15696) A drunkard does no violence to the owner of a drink shop when he becomes a teetotaller.
('36', 6, 1, 7, 15784) He serves both the publican and himself.

('36', 6, 3, 12, 16136) 3. ‘TOWARDS MORAL BANKRUPTCY’ II
('36', 6, 4, 13, 16169) “In the wake of abortion,” says M. Bureau, “come infanticide, incest, and crimes that outrage nature.
('36', 6, 4, 14, 16271) There is nothing special to say about the first, except that the crime has become more frequent in spite of all the facilities offered to unmarried mothers and of the extension of anti conceptionist practices and abortion.
('36', 6, 4, 15, 16494) It no longer arouses the same reprobation among so called ‘respectable’ people and juries usually return a verdict of ‘not guilty’.” M. Bureau devotes a full section to the growth of pornographic literature.
('36', 6, 4, 16, 16702) He defines it as the exploitation, with an erotic or obscene intention, of the resources which literature, the drama, and place pictures at men’s disposal for their mental refreshment and repose.
('36', 6, 4, 17, 16898) And he adds:
('36', 6, 5, 18, 16911) In every branch of its business it has secured markets, the extent of which may be gauged by the ingenuity and excellent commercial organization of the directors, the enormous amount of capital, the unexampled perfection of the methods employed .
('36', 6, 5, 19, 17158) The impression has been so strong and so unique that the whole psychological life of the individual is affected by it, a sort of secondary sexual life, which exists wholly in the imagination, is created.
('36', 6, 5, 20, 17362) M. Bureau then quotes this pathetic paragraph from M. Ruvsen:
('36', 6, 6, 21, 17424) All pornographic and sadistic literature secures in this psychological law the most powerful enticement which it exerts over an innumerable number of readers, and the flourishing circulation of this literature shows beyond dispute that those who live a secondary sexual life through their imagination
('36', 7, 0, 1, 17725) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 7, 1, 2, 17765) are legion, not to mention those in lunatic asylums —especially in a period like our own, when the abuse of newspapers and books creates around all consciences what W. James calls ‘a plurality of under universe’, in which each can lose himself, and forget along with himself the duties of the present hour.
('36', 7, 1, 3, 18072) These disastrous consequences, it should never be forgotten, are a direct result of one single fundamental error, namely, that sexual indulgence for its own sake is a human necessity and that without it neither man nor woman reaches their full growth.
('36', 7, 1, 4, 18324) Immediately a person becomes possessed of such an idea and begins to look upon what in his estimation was one time a vice as a virtue, there is no end to the multiplication of devices that would excite animal passions and help him to indulge in them.
('36', 7, 1, 5, 18575) M. Bureau then gives chapter and verse to show how the daily press, the magazine, the pamphlet, the novel, the photograph and the theatre increasingly pander to and provide for this debasing taste.
('36', 7, 1, 6, 18773) But the reference hitherto has been to the decay of morals amongst unmarried people.
('36', 7, 1, 7, 18858) M. Bureau next proceeds to show the measure of moral indiscipline in the married state.
('36', 7, 1, 8, 18946) He says:
('36', 7, 2, 9, 18955) Among the aristocracy, the middle class, and the peasants vanity and avarice are responsible for a vast number of marriages.
('36', 7, 2, 10, 19080) marriage is entered upon also to obtain an advantageous post to join two properties, especially two landed estates, to regularize a former connection or to legitimatize a natural child; to provide unfailing and devoted attentions for a man’s rheumatics and old age, to be able to choose the place of his garrison at the time of conscription, also to put an end to a life of vice, of which they are beginning to weary and to substitute another form of sexual life.
('36', 7, 2, 11, 19544) M. Bureau then cites facts and figures to show that these marriages, instead of reducing licentiousness actually promote it.
('36', 7, 2, 12, 19669) This degradation has been immensely helped by the so called scientificor mechanical inventions designed to restrict the effect of the sexual act without interfering with the act itself.
('36', 7, 2, 13, 19855) I must pass by the painful paragraphs regarding the increase in adultery and startling figures regarding judicial separations and divorces which, during the last twenty years, have more than doubled themselves.
('36', 7, 2, 14, 20066) I can also make only a passing reference to the extension of unrestricted freedom for indulgence to the female sex on the principle of ‘the same moral standard for the two sexes’.
('36', 7, 2, 15, 20246) The perfection of the anti conceptional practices and the methods of bringing about abortion have led to the emancipation of either sex from all moral restraint.
('36', 7, 2, 16, 20408) No wonder marriage itself is laughed at.
('36', 7, 2, 17, 20449) Here is a passage M. Bureau quotes from a popular author: Marriage is always according to my judgment one of the most barbarous institutions ever imagined.
('36', 7, 2, 18, 20605) I have no doubt that it will be abolished
('36', 8, 0, 1, 20647) VOL. 36: 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 9
('36', 8, 1, 2, 20689) if the human race makes any progress towards justice and reason.
('36', 8, 1, 3, 20754) But men are too gross and women too cowardly to demand a nobler law than that which rules them.
('36', 8, 1, 4, 20850) The results of the practices referred to by M. Bureau and of the theories by which the practices are justified are minutely examined.
('36', 8, 1, 5, 20984) He explains: We are, then, being carried away by the movement of moral indiscipline towards new destinies.
('36', 8, 1, 6, 21091) What are they?
('36', 8, 1, 7, 21106) Is the future that opens before us one of progress and light, of beauty and growing spirituality, or of retrogression and darkness, of deformity and animalism that is ever demanding more?
('36', 8, 1, 8, 21294) Is the indiscipline which has been established one of those fruitful revolts against antiquated rules, one of those beneficent rebellions which posterity remembers with gratitude because they were, at certain epochs, the necessary preliminary to its progress and the rise, or is it not rather the old Adam which rises up within us against the rules whose cry strictness is indispensable if we are to withstand the thrust of its bestial appeal?
('36', 8, 1, 9, 21738) Are we face to face with an evil revolt against the discipline of safety and life?
('36', 8, 1, 10, 21821) Then M. Bureau cites overwhelming testimony to show that hitherto the results have been disastrous in every respect.
('36', 8, 1, 11, 21938) They threaten life itself.

('36', 8, 5, 15, 22048) MY DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('36', 8, 5, 16, 22084) 1 I understand all you say, appreciate it too, but, you cannot realize my helplessness.
('36', 8, 5, 17, 22172) Just for the present moment, I am not despondent.
('36', 8, 5, 18, 22222) I feel certain that things will be better, but, at the present moment, the fury, I fear, must be allowed to spend itself.

('36', 8, 5, 21, 22522) It all seems inevitable.
('36', 8, 5, 22, 22547) Of course, do not think that because I do not write or speak, I am doing nothing.

('36', 12, 3, 17, 28574) But we must put up with the circumstances in which we find ourselves.
('36', 12, 3, 18, 28644) In a way, none of us deserves his position but from another point of view, it can be said that those who devote themselves to their jobs come to deserve their positions.
('36', 12, 3, 19, 28814) Only they are worthless who though knowing their duty do not wish to fulfil it and deliberately spoil the work allotted to them.

('36', 21, 6, 14, 44164) He gave me his permission to mention this matter to you.
('36', 21, 6, 15, 44221) I cannot recall a single instance when I have either been cool or unmindful of you or your work.
('36', 21, 6, 16, 44318) On the contrary, ever since I had the pleasure of knowing you, I have valued your great ability, integrity, your patriotism and your gentlemanliness.
('36', 21, 6, 17, 44468) Our differences of opinion have made not the slightest difference in the estimation in which I have held you.
('36', 21, 6, 18, 44578) Please, therefore, disabuse your mind of any such feeling that Mr. Bharucha reports you to have expressed to him.

('36', 22, 7, 10, 45334) 25. HOW SHOULD SPINNING BE DONE?
('36', 22, 8, 11, 45367) A gentleman has sent yarn which is untidy, badly spun, badly rolled.
('36', 22, 8, 12, 45436) He has not measured its length and he writes:
('36', 22, 9, 13, 45482) As you want many voluntary spinners for the Spinners’ Association, I too wish to spin.
('36', 22, 9, 14, 45569) Kindly let me know the length of the yarn I am sending; if it is too little, I will make up the deficiency.
('36', 22, 9, 15, 45677) Slivers are not easy to get here; could you send me some?
('36', 22, 9, 16, 45735) Suppose we did not make our own chapatis in the country but ate delicate, beautifully shaped and coloured, artistically made chapatis imported from Japan.
('36', 22, 9, 17, 45890) Suppose, further, that someone with a little foresight saw in this practice the ruin of the country and, since we had forgotten how to prepare and bake chapatis, he suggested a chapati yajna and appealed to all to send their contribution towards it.
('36', 22, 9, 18, 46140) If, now, some patriot, bursting with enthusiasm, obtained a roll of dough from someone and sent me triangular, half done, half burnt chapatis soiled in transit, together with a note which read: “In response to your appeal for chapati yajna I, too, have decided to contribute to it.
('36', 22, 9, 19, 46422) I am sending a few today; please count them and let me know if they are too few, so that I may send more.
('36', 22, 9, 20, 46528) Rolls of dough are not easy to get here, could you send me some?” If anyone wishing to join the chapati yajna wrote to me to this effect, those who knew anything about making chapatis would all laugh at him and say that the gentleman no doubt loved India but did not know how to show his love in action.
('36', 22, 9, 21, 46832) Everyone, I am sure, can see the point of what it say about chapati yajna, but all will not immediately see that the gentleman who sent his contribution towards the spinning yajna has acted exactly as our imaginary volunteer for chapati yajna.
('36', 22, 9, 22, 47076) This is a sign of want of thought resulting from a mental habit of long standing.
('36', 22, 9, 23, 47158) We have forgotten all about the spinning wheel, so that,
('36', 23, 0, 1, 47215) 24 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 23, 1, 2, 47256) while we all see that, if we forget the art of making chapatis, we would starve, we do not see as readily that we are starving today because we have given up the spinning wheel.
('36', 23, 1, 3, 47434) That is the truth.
('36', 23, 1, 4, 47453) Spinning does not mean drawing out bits of yarn of any sort as if we were merely playing at spinning.
('36', 23, 1, 5, 47555) Spinning in fact, means learning all the preliminary processes—sitting down properly, with a mind completely at rest, and spinning daily for a fixed number of hours good, uniform and well twisted yarn, spraying it, measuring its length and taking its weight, rolling it neatly, and, if it is to be sent out to some other place, packing it carefully and sticking a label on it with details of the variety of cotton used, the count, the length and weight of the yarn, and tying a tag on it with particulars of the contributor’s name and address in clear handwriting; when all this is done, one will have completed the spinning yajna for the day.
('36', 23, 1, 6, 48199) Two essential processes, ginning and carding, precede spinning.
('36', 23, 1, 7, 48263) In the analogy between spinning yajna and chapati yajna, ginning corres ponds to milling the wheat—and one may not mind where this is rare—and carding to kneading the flour and making rolls.
('36', 23, 1, 8, 48454) Just as we may not have rolls made from dough at any place we choose but should make them on the spot where the chapatis are being prepared, so carding also should be done at the place where the spinning is done.
('36', 23, 1, 9, 48667) The only latitude which may be permitted is that in a family one person makes the dough and the rolls, while others make and bake the chapatis.
('36', 23, 1, 10, 48811) If they go beyond this, the chapatis would be spoiled and the chapati yajna ruined.
('36', 23, 1, 11, 48895) Similarly, carding may be done, for the sake of convenience, by one person at the same place where others are doing spinning.
('36', 23, 1, 12, 49021) If they go beyond this, the yarn would be spoiled and the spinning yajna, too, would be ruined.
('36', 23, 1, 13, 49117) Carding is a very easy process, and the carding bow can be easily made and is available too.
('36', 23, 1, 14, 49210) At any place where bamboo is easily available, a carding bow for use at home can be made in no time.
('36', 23, 1, 15, 49311) However one for whom the spinning yajna has not become a passion may buy a bow for one’s use, but every spinner must learn carding.
('36', 23, 1, 16, 49443) Carding, I need not add, includes the making of slivers from the cotton carded.
('36', 23, 1, 17, 49523) Such cotton corresponds to the dough and the slivers to rolls.
('36', 23, 1, 18, 49586) All others whose attitude to spinning has been like that of the correspondent above will, I trust, understand henceforth what spinning means.
('36', 23, 2, 19, 49728) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 11 7 1926
('36', 24, 0, 1, 49765) VOL. 36: 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 25

('36', 24, 5, 11, 50160) 27. LETTER TO D. B. KHOJA
('36', 24, 6, 12, 50186) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, July 11, 1926
('36', 24, 7, 13, 50223) BHAISHRI DHARAMSHI BHANJI,
('36', 24, 8, 14, 50250) It is only today 2 I am able to answer your tenacious questions.
('36', 24, 8, 15, 50315) It is not right, I think, to discuss so many questions in Navajivan.
('36', 24, 8, 16, 50384) I am quite pleased with your questions.
('36', 24, 8, 17, 50424) I now answer them one by one.
('36', 24, 8, 18, 50454) One who is ready to immolate himself for the sake of truth should not bother about protecting his body, but he should do so to the extent necessary for the purpose of realizing truth.
('36', 24, 8, 19, 50638) I do not think it wrong to take the weight of the body, and so on, with a view to studying the physical effects of a fast undertaken for a moral purpose.
('36', 24, 8, 20, 50792) But it is possible that in so doing one may succumb to temptation.
('36', 24, 8, 21, 50859) God alone knows whether I have ever fallen a prey to temptation.
('36', 24, 8, 22, 50924) My renunciation of activities is only in the interest of health.
('36', 24, 8, 23, 50989) If it is incorrect to call it renunciation of activities where a person has limited his activities to a certain field, let us call it limitation of sphere.
('36', 24, 8, 24, 51145) This limitation is not based on moralconsiderations; hence there is no room for any illusion either gross or subtle.
('36', 24, 8, 25, 51262) We cannot know the outcome of many things, and yet we experiment with them; so too with diet.
('36', 24, 8, 26, 51356) Even from the point of view of abstention there is full scope for discrimination in regard to diet.
('36', 24, 8, 27, 51456) My service to India includes service to all creatures, because
('36', 24, 9, 28, 51519) 1 The identity of the addressee, who was in Ceylon, is not known.
('36', 24, 9, 29, 51585) 2 Gandhiji had received from the addressee a letter dated May 21, 1926.
('36', 25, 0, 1, 51657) 26 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 25, 1, 2, 51698) mine is a non violent service.
('36', 25, 1, 3, 51729) One who serves another selflessly and without any attachment serves all.
('36', 25, 1, 4, 51802) It is not for me to permit anyone to fight.
('36', 25, 1, 5, 51846) I would only show to those who want to fight what, I think, their duty is.
('36', 25, 1, 6, 51921) I agree, one gets results according to one’s prarabdha 1 but as we cannot peep into the future, let us put forth our best efforts regardless of results.
('36', 25, 1, 7, 52074) When the rule of the just prevails, it would be my duty to earn my living and be a burden to none.
('36', 25, 1, 8, 52173) I know of no religion which cannot be put into practice.
('36', 25, 1, 9, 52230) Instead of modifying dharma to suit the ways of the world, why not change these to conform to dharma?
('36', 25, 1, 10, 52332) All practices that are contrary to dharma deserve to be abjured.
('36', 25, 1, 11, 52397) What I regard as the truth is not dependent on its acceptance as such by the world.
('36', 25, 1, 12, 52481) That alone I believe [as truth] which I have experienced myself.
('36', 25, 1, 13, 52546) A Shastra which condones adharma while upholding dharma is to that extent unworthy of honour.
('36', 25, 1, 14, 52640) I believe some rare persons can know the nature of the universe and of its Ruler; but none can describe it.
('36', 25, 1, 15, 52748) That being so, I think, theological differences will persist.
('36', 25, 1, 16, 52810) If a man who has many wives frees himself of passions, etc., and regards them all as his mothers or sisters, he can certainly qualify himself for moksha.
('36', 25, 1, 17, 52964) The passion that dwells in the senses is contrary to human nature and should therefore be abandoned.
('36', 25, 1, 18, 53065) Man and woman are both born free.
('36', 25, 1, 19, 53099) Hence when one is overwhelmed by passion and loses oneself, what else shall we call it if not going astray?
('36', 25, 1, 20, 53207) If a man and his wife cannot get on after marriage, is that reason enough for a divorce?
('36', 25, 1, 21, 53296) The bond between father and son does not come to an end on account of disagreement; I regard the bond between husband and wife as similar.
('36', 25, 1, 22, 53435) If they cannot see eye to eye, they may well have recourse to non co operation.
('36', 25, 1, 23, 53515) But once the marital bond has been established, it can never be dharma to act contrary to it.
('36', 25, 1, 24, 53609) That a man may indulge in sex pleasures with one woman and none other and that too for the sake ofprogeny and similarly a woman with one man is, I believe, the farthest limit that he or she can have.
('36', 25, 1, 25, 53809) Time goes on doing its work.
('36', 25, 1, 26, 53838) Our manliness lies in foreseeing its changes and putting in the right efforts.
('36', 25, 2, 27, 53917) 1 Fruits of accumulated deeds of previous births
('36', 26, 0, 1, 53966) VOL. 36: 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 27
('36', 26, 1, 2, 54009) It is quite possible that those whom we regard as having attained moksha might not in fact have attained it.
('36', 26, 1, 3, 54118) But those who have really attained moksha are a manifestation of God Himself, because they cannot be thought of as apart from Him.
('36', 26, 1, 4, 54249) I am not able to understand your next question.
('36', 26, 1, 5, 54297) I am against purdah for women because it shows man’s meanness and his oppression of the weaker sex.
('36', 26, 1, 6, 54397) It is quite possible that the steps I take or advocate may in future prove disastrous instead of being beneficial.
('36', 26, 1, 7, 54512) Of course my own conviction is that each and every step of mine will turn out to be beneficial in the end.
('36', 26, 1, 8, 54619) If I do not have this faith I shall be doing offence to my truth and I should as well end my life.
('36', 26, 1, 9, 54718) For, even if I may choose to be quiet I would still go on seeing visions of many worlds.
('36', 26, 1, 10, 54807) In prophet Mohammed’s life, we come across many acts of kindness.
('36', 26, 1, 11, 54873) I do not know if Lord Mahavir has laid down two distinct standards—one for dharma and the other for worldly life.
('36', 26, 1, 12, 54987) So far as I understand Jainism, I think it has no such compartments.
('36', 26, 1, 13, 55056) Passages which are apparently suggestive of different standards can be interpreted to agree with what I say; for example, the mahavrat 1 and Anuvrat 2. Religion exhorts us all clearly to follow only the Mahavrat; but if we cannot do it, we should at least follow the Anuvrat instead of resigning ourselves to a life of sin.
('36', 26, 2, 14, 55380) A gun manufacturer is certainly responsible for the destruction caused by the guns he makes.
('36', 26, 2, 15, 55473) The object of a man’s life is said to be realization of the self.
('36', 26, 2, 16, 55539) A convention which runs counter to human nature certainly deserves to be broken.
('36', 26, 2, 17, 55620) Even otherwise it is bound to go.
('36', 26, 2, 18, 55654) If an infant tries to hold a fire brand, its parents and the world have a right to check it.
('36', 26, 2, 19, 55747) Nobody has any further right.
('36', 26, 3, 20, 55777) Since God has not endowed man with the power of creating even a single life, how at all can he have the right to inflict capital punishment?
('36', 26, 3, 21, 55918) I have remained absolutely free from the habit of masturbation.
('36', 26, 3, 22, 55982) Even today I am not able to understand it.
('36', 26, 3, 23, 56025) I shudder at the thought of it.
('36', 26, 3, 24, 56057) I have no doubt whatever that a man who practises it would become weak in body and mind.
('36', 26, 3, 25, 56146) I know of manysuch cases.
('36', 26, 3, 26, 56172) The remedy for it is that those who wish to reform themselves should shun solitude and as far as possible keep both their hands as well as
('36', 26, 4, 27, 56311) 1 Literally, major vows in Jainism, ahimsa, satya, asteya, brahmacharya, aparigraha, practised by ascetics
('36', 26, 5, 28, 56418) 2 Literally, minor vows in Jainism, those practised by householders
('36', 27, 0, 1, 56486) 28 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 27, 1, 2, 56527) their body busy.
('36', 27, 1, 3, 56544) They should take sattvika 1 food, which is easy to digest, go for walks in the open air and repeat Ramanama.
('36', 27, 1, 4, 56653) Marriage is no remedy for bad habits.
('36', 27, 1, 5, 56691) A child of five, seven or ten years contracts a bad habit; is it due to want of the married state?

('36', 27, 8, 18, 57414) 29. LETTER TO AMBALAL SARABHAI
('36', 27, 9, 19, 57445) THE ASHRAM, July 11, 1926
('36', 27, 10, 20, 57471) DEAR FRIEND, I have your long letter.
('36', 27, 10, 21, 57509) I read the whole of it with care.
('36', 27, 10, 22, 57543) I am glad that you wrote it.
('36', 27, 10, 23, 57572) I liked it very much, since you have poured out your heart in it.
('36', 27, 10, 24, 57638) I take it, moreover, as a sign of friendship that you took all this trouble to arrange your ideas and put them compactly before me.
('36', 27, 10, 25, 57770) I, therefore, welcome your letter from every point of view.
('36', 27, 11, 26, 57830) 1 Pure and wholesome 2 The addressee had suggested in his letter of June 18, 1926 that the English rendering of Gandhiji’s autobiography which was being serially published in Young India had better be done by Valji Govindji Desai.
('36', 28, 0, 1, 58061) VOL. 36: 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 29
('36', 28, 1, 2, 58104) I am replying in Gujarati, since I shall never have the courage to write to a Gujarati in English, and I am dictating the letter since otherwise you would find difficulty in reading my handwriting and I would be going against doctors’ advice that I should do as little writing as possible with my hand.
('36', 28, 1, 3, 58407) Please rest assured that the views I had formed about you long ago remain unaltered.
('36', 28, 1, 4, 58492) You have not changed; if anyone, I have changed, though I think I too have not.
('36', 28, 1, 5, 58572) How could all that was in me come out at one time, without the circumstances to draw it out?
('36', 28, 1, 6, 58665) Circumstances made me a non co operator.
('36', 28, 1, 7, 58706) To others, that may appear as a change in me.
('36', 28, 1, 8, 58752) But so far as I am concerned, I was being true to myself and, therefore, my non co operation was but a manifestation of my real self in relation to particular circumstances.
('36', 28, 1, 9, 58926) One may see me bare bodied in summer and wrapped up in clothes in winter and might think that I had changed.
('36', 28, 1, 10, 59035) The truth is that I have not changed at all.
('36', 28, 1, 11, 59080) I merely responded in the appropriate manner to changed circumstances.
('36', 28, 1, 12, 59151) However, no matter what differences of opinion arise between us, I shall always feel the attraction of your virtues which first drew me towards you.
('36', 28, 2, 13, 59300) From some of my actions you have reached the conclusion that I would use any means to gain my end.
('36', 28, 2, 14, 59399) It is absolutely against my nature to act in that manner.
('36', 28, 2, 15, 59457) I have stated time and again, and proved through my actions, that I believe means and ends to be intimately inter connected.
('36', 28, 2, 16, 59582) That is, a good end can never be achieved through bad means.
('36', 28, 2, 17, 59643) I had given the most careful thought to the problem of the Khilafat before making the cause my own.
('36', 28, 2, 18, 59743) If I had not believed in its justice, I would never have lent my support to the Muslims.
('36', 28, 2, 19, 59832) This of course does not mean that it was, or is, necessary for me, for the sakeof my dharma, to support the Khilafat movement, but I certainly held, and I still hold, that the Muslim claim was just from their own point of view and that, from the standpoint of morality, there was nothing objectionable in it.
('36', 28, 2, 20, 60141) I, therefore, believed it to be the moral duty of every Hindu to stand by them in their suffering.
('36', 28, 2, 21, 60240) I still cling to these views and do not repent having helped the Muslims in their fight for the Khilafat.
('36', 28, 2, 22, 60346) Nor do I believe that Hindus have suffered by having helped them.

('36', 35, 3, 6, 72323) 37. A GREAT HEART
('36', 35, 4, 7, 72341) Newspapers tell us that Miss Emily Hobhouse is no more.
('36', 35, 4, 8, 72397) She was one of the noblest and bravest of women.
('36', 35, 4, 9, 72446) She worked without ever thinking of any reward.
('36', 35, 4, 10, 72494) Hers was service of humanity dedicated to God.
('36', 35, 4, 11, 72541) She belonged to a noble English family.
('36', 35, 4, 12, 72581) She loved her country and because she loved it, she could not tolerate any injustice done by it.
('36', 35, 4, 13, 72678) She realized the atrocity of the Boer War.
('36', 35, 4, 14, 72721) She thought England was wholly in the wrong.
('36', 35, 4, 15, 72766) She denounced the war in burning language at a time when England was mad on it.
('36', 35, 4, 16, 72846) She went to South Africa and her whole soul rose against the barbarity of the concentration camps which Lord Kitchener thought were necessary if the war was to be won.
('36', 35, 4, 17, 73014) It was then that William Stead led prayers for English reverses.
('36', 35, 4, 18, 73079) Emily Hobhouse, frail as her body was, went again to South Africa at great personal risk to court insults and worse.
('36', 35, 4, 19, 73196) She was imprisoned and sent back.
('36', 35, 4, 20, 73230) She bore it all with the courage of a true heroine.
('36', 35, 4, 21, 73282) she steeled the hearts of Boer women and told them never to lose hope.
('36', 35, 4, 22, 73353) She told them that though England had gone mad, there were Englishmen and English women whose sympathies were with the Boers and that some day their voice would be heard.
('36', 35, 4, 23, 73524) And so it was.
('36', 35, 4, 24, 73539) Sir Henry Campbell Bannerman swept the board at the general election of 1906 and made to the wronged Boers such reparation as was possible.
('36', 35, 4, 25, 73679) It was after the war and when satyagraha was going on that I had the privilege of being known to Miss Hobhouse.
('36', 35, 4, 26, 73791) The acquaintance ripened into a life long friendship.
('36', 35, 4, 27, 73845) She played no mean part at the settlement of 1914. She was General Botha’s guest.
('36', 35, 4, 28, 73927) Now General Botha had uniformly repelled my advances for an interview.
('36', 35, 4, 29, 73998) Every time he referred me to the Home Minister.
('36', 35, 4, 30, 74046) But Miss Hobhouse insisted on General Botha seeing me.
('36', 35, 4, 31, 74101) And so she arranged for a meeting between the General, his wife and herself and me at the General’s residence in Cape Town.
('36', 35, 4, 32, 74225) Hers was a name to conjure with among the Boers.
('36', 35, 4, 33, 74274) And she made my way smooth among them by throwing in the whole weight of her influence with the Indian cause.

('36', 36, 1, 3, 74598) She herself had full strength for such sacrifice.

('36', 36, 3, 15, 75393) 38. STUDENTS AND NON CO OPERATION
('36', 36, 4, 16, 75427) A student in a national college has written a long letter of which I give the substance as follows:
('36', 36, 5, 17, 75527) You are aware that in the year 1920 many students all over India left Government controlled institutions.
('36', 36, 5, 18, 75633) Several national institutions were started.
('36', 36, 5, 19, 75677) Some have already gone under.
('36', 36, 5, 20, 75707) The one that I know is a poor affair.
('36', 36, 5, 21, 75745) It may be called a foreign imitation under national control minus discipline.
('36', 36, 5, 22, 75823) Many of our teachers do not know the distinction between khaddar and foreign or mill made cloth.
('36', 36, 5, 23, 75920) They dress likeSahebs and though themselves dressed in foreign cloth would not mind talking to us about swadeshi.
('36', 36, 5, 24, 76034) They remind one of drunkards advising others to give up liquor.
('36', 36, 5, 25, 76098) They talk of the spirit of sacrifice and the value of joining national institutions when they send their own sons or other relatives to Government controlled schools or colleges.
('36', 36, 5, 26, 76277) In fact, there is very little love lost between them and us.
('36', 36, 5, 27, 76338) Do you wonder at many students having gone back to Government institutions?
('36', 36, 5, 28, 76414) A few of us however still remain out.
('36', 36, 5, 29, 76452) But how long can we do so?
('36', 36, 5, 30, 76479) I would like to prosecute my studies in Germany, but my pecuniary circumstances do not allow me to do so.
('36', 36, 5, 31, 76585) Can you not send me to the Berlin or any other European University?
('36', 37, 0, 1, 76653) 38 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 37, 1, 2, 76694) The writer has given me his own full name and the name of the institution and all other available particulars.
('36', 37, 1, 3, 76805) I have purposely refrained from giving the name of the institution and further particulars.
('36', 37, 1, 4, 76897) For, I do not know enough of it and I could not be party to the specific condemnation of any institution without having studied it.
('36', 37, 1, 5, 77029) Public purpose is sufficiently served by publishing the general complaint so that those institutions to which the complaint may be applicable may examine themselves and remove all cause of complaint.
('36', 37, 1, 6, 77229) There is no doubt that in several national institutions things have not been as they should have been and that the professors or teachers have not conformed to the elementary requirements of the Congress programme in so far as it is applicable to national institutions.
('36', 37, 1, 7, 77499) Teachers who themselves do not believe in non violence or truth or non co operation cannot impart to their students the spirit of any of these things.
('36', 37, 1, 8, 77650) If they send their children to Government schools, they may not expect to enthuse their pupils over national institutions.
('36', 37, 1, 9, 77773) Nor may they expect to infect their pupils with love of the charkha or khaddar, if they will not spin themselves or wear khaddar.
('36', 37, 1, 10, 77903) It is hardly necessary to remark that all national institutions do not deserve the description that the writer gives of the one to which he has belonged.
('36', 37, 1, 11, 78057) But, the point I desire to emphasize in connection with this letter is that there should be no sorrow felt over one’s sacrifice.
('36', 37, 1, 12, 78186) That sacrifice which causes pain loses its sacred character and will break down under stress.
('36', 37, 1, 13, 78280) One gives up things that one considers to be injurious and therefore there should be pleasure attendant upon the giving up.
('36', 37, 1, 14, 78404) Whether the substitute is effective or not is a different question altogether.
('36', 37, 1, 15, 78483) If the substitute is effective, it is no doubt well, but it is well also even if the substitute is ineffective.
('36', 37, 1, 16, 78595) It must lead to an effort to procure a better substitute, but surely not to a return to what has been given up after full knowledge and experience of its harmful character.
('36', 37, 1, 17, 78768) This hankering after going to Berlin or to some other European University is not a sign of the spirit of non co operation.
('36', 37, 1, 18, 78891) It is on par with substituting Japanese cloth for the English manufacture.
('36', 37, 1, 19, 78966) We give up English cloth not because it is English, but because it robs the poor of their hereditary employment and therefore makes them poorer still.
('36', 37, 1, 20, 79117) The Japanese substitute robs the poor no less than the English cloth.
('36', 37, 1, 21, 79187) Similarly, we give up Government institutions because of their harmful character.
('36', 37, 1, 22, 79269) We may not therefore reproduce the same thing under a different name and hug to ourselves the belief that we are non co operators.
('36', 37, 1, 23, 79400) Non co operation means co operation with all
('36', 38, 0, 1, 79445) VOL. 36: 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 39
('36', 38, 1, 2, 79488) that is best in the Indian spirit.
('36', 38, 1, 3, 79523) We cannot cultivate that taste by being in Berlin.

('36', 38, 3, 11, 80317) 39. ‘TOWARDS MORAL BANKRUPTCY’ III
('36', 38, 4, 12, 80352) It is one thing when married people regulate, so far as it is humanly possible, the number of their progeny by moral restraint, and totally another when they do so in spite of sexual indulgence and by means adopted to obviate the result of such indulgence.
('36', 38, 4, 13, 80609) In the one case, the people gain in every respect.
('36', 38, 4, 14, 80660) In the other there is nothing but harm.
('36', 38, 4, 15, 80700) M. Bureau has produced figures and diagrams to show that the increasing use of contraceptives for the purpose of giving free play to animal passions and yet obviating the natural results of such indulgence has resulted in the birth rate being much lower than the death rate, not in Paris only, but in the whole of France.
('36', 38, 4, 16, 81022) Out of 87 areas into which France is divided, in 68 the birth rate is lower than the deathrate.
('36', 38, 4, 17, 81118) In one case, i.e., Lot, deaths were 162 against 100 births.
('36', 38, 4, 18, 81178) The next comes Tarn et Garonne with 156 deaths against l00 births.
('36', 38, 4, 19, 81245) Even out of 19 areas where the birth rate is higher than the death rate, the difference is negligible in several cases.

('36', 38, 4, 21, 81418) The lowest death rate, that is 72 against l00 births, occurs in Morbihan and Pas de Calais.

('36', 42, 1, 4, 89933) ‘Fewer births and more fine men” was the watch word, which had something enticing about it for those who, shut up in their materialistic conception of individual and social life, thought they could assimilate the breeding of men to that of sheep or horses.

('36', 42, 3, 10, 91594) The worst of it is that this cowardly calculation almost succeeds while our conduct is as yet an abnormal and exceptional act; then, proud of our success, we persevere in our attitude, and when there is occasion we come—and this is our supreme punishment–to believe it lawful.

('36', 43, 1, 2, 92132) others”, and our neighbour, tired of being duped, is now in a hurry to imitate us.

('36', 47, 2, 3, 100543) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI , July 15, 1926
('36', 47, 3, 4, 100581) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter and the paper prepared by you.
('36', 47, 3, 5, 100644) Do you not read Young India?
('36', 47, 3, 6, 100673) It gives facts and figures showing the progress of khadi during the last five years.
('36', 47, 3, 7, 100758) If you will only take up your Young India file for the current year, you will find all figures there.
('36', 47, 3, 8, 100860) To collect all the statistics from the pages of Young India here would be to put an extra tax on the energies of those who have little time to spare from their daily labour.
('36', 47, 3, 9, 101034) The experiment that is being scientifically conducted in schools is the one in the 24 schools conducted under superintendence of Shrimati Anasuya Bai.
('36', 47, 3, 10, 101185) These schools have an attendance of 1600 boys and girls.
('36', 47, 3, 11, 101242) Spinning is all done by the takli.
('36', 47, 3, 12, 101277) Though all the teachers of the schools know spinning on the takli they are obliged to spin as well as the children.
('36', 47, 3, 13, 101393) A fixed time is set apart for spinning by them.
('36', 47, 3, 14, 101441) And the yarn so spun is turned out into khadi which in many cases is used by the children themselves.
('36', 47, 3, 15, 101543) Experience has taught us that takli is the best thing to be introduced in schools.
('36', 47, 3, 16, 101626) It is handy.
('36', 47, 3, 17, 101639) It does not go out of order.
('36', 47, 3, 18, 101668) It is cheap, occupies no room and thousands can spin at the same time; and, whilst the output per hour on a single takli is much less than on the spinning wheel, the collective result of takli spinning in schools is much greater than that of the spinning wheel for the simple reason that it is impossible to make all the boys to spin on the wheel at the same time.
('36', 47, 3, 19, 102033) There can only be a limited number of wheels supplied in a school.
('36', 47, 4, 20, 102100) Yours sincerely, SJT.
('36', 47, 4, 21, 102122) KURUR NILAKANTAN NAMBUDRIPAD TRICHUR (COCHIN STATE)

('36', 50, 11, 17, 105859) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, Thursday, July 15, 1926
('36', 50, 12, 18, 105906) BHAI BALWANTRAI, It seems you are rolling in wealth.
('36', 50, 12, 19, 105959) It also seems that you are not able to come to a decision.
('36', 50, 12, 20, 106018) Copies of the Ashram rules are exhausted, but the daily routine is as under: Rising at 4 o’clock.
('36', 50, 12, 21, 106116) Attending prayers till five.
('36', 50, 12, 22, 106145) Private studies till 6. Those who cook their own meals do so at this hour.
('36', 50, 12, 23, 106220) At seven commences work in which everyone joins.
('36', 50, 12, 24, 106269) It includes cleaning latrines, spinning, weaving, sweeping roads, cooking and numerous
('36', 51, 0, 1, 106356) 52 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 51, 1, 2, 106397) other similar activities.
('36', 51, 1, 3, 106423) Lunch bell at half past ten.
('36', 51, 1, 4, 106452) Everyone finishes his lunch before twelve, when work is resumed and it goes on up to half past four.
('36', 51, 1, 5, 106553) Cooking and meals again between half past four and seven.
('36', 51, 1, 6, 106611) Prayers a second time, starting at seven and going on up to eight.
('36', 51, 1, 7, 106678) Then one hour for study and reflection.
('36', 51, 1, 8, 106718) Retiring for the day at nine.
('36', 51, 1, 9, 106748) Those who live in the Ashram should strive to observe, in thought, word and deed, the vows of truth, non violence, non posse ssion, non stealing, brahmacharya, etc.
('36', 51, 1, 10, 106913) They should observe the vow of wearing khadi, spin for at least half an hour daily by way of yajna, refrain from the practice of untouchability as contrary to dharma, and so on.

('36', 52, 10, 22, 109493) 1 Esther Menon’s daughter

('36', 53, 1, 3, 109568) In my opinion, the scheme you have sent me shows the academy to be a demi official institution.
('36', 53, 1, 4, 109664) But, really speaking, you should be best judge of what you should do.

('36', 53, 1, 6, 109818) The secret of our non co operation is to renounce the benefits of the system, which we need not receive.

('36', 53, 1, 8, 110033) Educational institutions were one such thing.

('36', 53, 4, 19, 110897) 54. LETTER TO D. N. BAHADURJI
('36', 53, 5, 20, 110927) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI , July 16, 1926
('36', 53, 6, 21, 110965) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('36', 53, 6, 22, 110998) I have nothing like a guide that would tell you how to arrive at the required strength.
('36', 53, 6, 23, 111086) But the easiest method of testing the strength of the twist is to make your cone as you are spinning as tight as possible.
('36', 53, 6, 24, 111209) Now a tight core is an impossibility if the yarn so spun is not strong enough to bear the strain.
('36', 53, 6, 25, 111307) It is hardly necessary to count the revolutions.
('36', 53, 6, 26, 111356) After testing the yarn in the manner I have suggested, you will instinctively spin strong yarn.
('36', 54, 0, 1, 111452) VOL. 36: 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 55
('36', 54, 1, 2, 111495) doubt revolutions increase a spinner’s speed, not necessarily the strength of his yarn.
('36', 54, 1, 3, 111583) The strength depends upon the deliberation and the tension with which you draw the thread.
('36', 54, 1, 4, 111674) And the twist is given as it is drawn.
('36', 54, 1, 5, 111713) A final turn or two of the wheel finishes the twist, before you wind the yarn round the spindle.
('36', 54, 1, 6, 111810) The eye is the only guide to evenness.
('36', 54, 1, 7, 111849) Fineness depends upon the fineness of the spindle and the staple of cotton, as also the manner in which slivers are made.
('36', 54, 1, 8, 111971) As you are doing your spinning with scientific precision, I would suggest your learning carding.
('36', 54, 1, 9, 112068) Carding is, in my opinion, a fine occupation, though strenuous.
('36', 54, 1, 10, 112132) Your account of how you came to spin is deeply interesting.
('36', 54, 1, 11, 112192) Whatever your ulterior object, what prompts you to spin should be all suffering for everybody.
('36', 54, 1, 12, 112287) I am glad too that you appreciate the economic value of the spinning wheel for the dumb millions.
('36', 54, 1, 13, 112385) You will not hesitate to send me your yarn for testing whenever you feel inclined.
('36', 54, 2, 14, 112468) Yours sincerely, D. N. BAHADURJI, ESQ.

('36', 60, 1, 2, 122175) 63. A DIFFICULT QUESTION
('36', 60, 2, 3, 122200) A teacher asks: 1
('36', 60, 3, 4, 122218) I venture to answer this question because I am myself a sort of teacher and because I have carried out, and am still carrying out, several experiments in that field.
('36', 60, 3, 5, 122384) This question has been raised by a fellow teacher.
('36', 60, 3, 6, 122435) This and similar other questions have been pending with me for a long time now.
('36', 60, 3, 7, 122515) The friend in question does not insist on the reply being given through Navajivan.
('36', 60, 3, 8, 122598) Considering, however, that a number of teachers seek help from me in solving such difficulties, and some of them may find guidance from my ideas on this subject, I have thought it fit to answer it through Navajivan.
('36', 60, 4, 9, 122814) Personally, I believe in the Puranas as sacred books and also in gods and goddesses.
('36', 60, 4, 10, 122899) But I do not believe in them in the same way as the interpreters of the Puranas do and want others to do.
('36', 60, 4, 11, 123005) I know too that I do not believe in them as society in general does at present.
('36', 60, 4, 12, 123085) I do not believe that gods like Indra, Varuna, and others reside in the sky and that they are separate individuals, or even that goddesses like Saraswati and others are separate entities.
('36', 60, 4, 13, 123273) But I certainly believe that gods and goddesses represent the various powers.
('36', 60, 4, 14, 123351) Their descriptions are sheer poetry.
('36', 60, 4, 15, 123388) There is a place for poetry in religion.
('36', 60, 4, 16, 123429) The Hindu religion has lent to everything that we believe in a scriptural form.
('36', 60, 4, 17, 123509) In a way, all those who believe that God has innumerable powers may be said to believe in gods and goddesses.
('36', 60, 4, 18, 123619) Just as God has innumerable powers, He has innumerable forms also.
('36', 60, 4, 19, 123686) One should worship Him by the name and in the form one likes.
('36', 60, 4, 20, 123748) I do not think there is anything wrong in that.
('36', 60, 4, 21, 123796) Whenever and wherever necessary, the symbols and metaphors may be explained and their inner meaning made clear to the children.
('36', 60, 4, 22, 123924) I for one would not feel any hesitation in doing so.
('36', 60, 4, 23, 123977) I have not known any harmful result flowing from this.
('36', 60, 4, 24, 124032) I would certainly not lead the children in any wrong direction.
('36', 60, 4, 25, 124096) I find no difficulty in accepting that the Himalayas are God Siva and that the Ganga, in the form of Parvati, rises and flows from his matted hair.
('36', 60, 4, 26, 124244) Not only that, these ideas strengthen my belief in God and it enables
('36', 60, 5, 27, 124314) 1 The questions are not translated here.
('36', 60, 5, 28, 124355) They are related to the symbolism behind the Puranic stories of gods and goddesses and the attitude which teachers should adopt in regard to these legends.
('36', 61, 0, 1, 124511) 62 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 61, 1, 2, 124552) me to understand better that everything is pervaded by God.
('36', 61, 1, 3, 124612) One may interpret stories like the churning of the ocean and so on in the way one likes.
('36', 61, 1, 4, 124701) Care should, however, be taken to see that the interpretation offered helps in inculcating good morals and noble conduct.
('36', 61, 1, 5, 124823) Scholars have indeed offered such interpretations according to their intelli gence.
('36', 61, 1, 6, 124907) But it is not to be supposed that these are the only interpreta tions possible.
('36', 61, 1, 7, 124987) Just as there is a process of development in man, even so there is a process of development in the meaning of words and sentences.
('36', 61, 1, 8, 125118) As our intelligence and heart develop, the meaning of words and sentences must also develop and so it does.
('36', 61, 1, 9, 125226) Where people limit the meaning within narrow confines and build walls all round, it cannot but decay and deteriorate.
('36', 61, 1, 10, 125344) The meaning and its interpreter both develop together.
('36', 61, 1, 11, 125399) And everybody will continue, according to his feeling, to draw his own meaning.
('36', 61, 1, 12, 125479) Those whose minds are impure will see in the Bhagavata the delineation of promiscuity, while it was only a vision of the atman alone that Ekanath could get out of it.
('36', 61, 1, 13, 125646) I firmly believe that the author of the Bhagavata did not write it to encourage promiscuity.
('36', 61, 1, 14, 125739) But if those of the present day find in it anything repugnant to their moral sense, they should certainly reject it.
('36', 61, 1, 15, 125856) To believe that all that is in print—especially if it is in Sanskrit—is true religion is nothing but blind superstition or stupidity.
('36', 61, 1, 16, 125990) Therefore, I know but one golden rule by which to solve this problem and I place it before teachers: We must reject everything—be it in the Vedas, the Puranas, or any other religious book—that is in our view inconsistent with truth, or is likely to encourage vice.
('36', 61, 1, 17, 126255) I may mention here an experience that I had while in jail.
('36', 61, 1, 18, 126314) I had often heard people praising the Gita Govinda of Jayadeva.
('36', 61, 1, 19, 126378) I wished to read it some day.
('36', 61, 1, 20, 126408) This poem might have provided enjoyment to many, but for me its reading proved a torture.
('36', 61, 1, 21, 126498) I did read it but its description pained me.
('36', 61, 1, 22, 126543) I would not at all hesitate to admit that the fault might have been entirely mine.
('36', 61, 1, 23, 126626) But I have stated my position merely for the satisfaction of the reader.
('36', 61, 1, 24, 126699) Since the Gita Govinda did not produce a good effect on my mind, it became unreadable for me and I could reject it because I had my own independent standard to go by in such circumstances.
('36', 61, 1, 25, 126888) Only those things are to be deemed religiously instructive which make for the elimination of evil thoughts and for the lessening of passions like hatred, only those things whose study would make one stick to truth even when mounting the gallows.
('36', 61, 1, 26, 127134) The Gita Govinda did not pass this test and therefore it became for me a book to be rejected.
('36', 62, 0, 1, 127228) VOL. 36: 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 63
('36', 62, 1, 2, 127271) There are today amongst us a number of youths and even old people who think that a thing is worth doing merely because it has been laid down in the Shastras.
('36', 62, 1, 3, 127429) This will easily lead to our moral degradation.
('36', 62, 1, 4, 127477) We do not even know what exactly can be called the Shastras.
('36', 62, 1, 5, 127538) If we believe that whatever goes on in the name of the Shastras is dharma and carry on accordingly, it is bound to lead to undesirable results.
('36', 62, 1, 6, 127682) Take Manusmriti only, for example, I do not know which of its verses are genuine and which are interpolations.
('36', 62, 1, 7, 127793) But there are quite a few which cannot be defended as religious in their import.
('36', 62, 1, 8, 127874) We must reject such verses.
('36', 62, 1, 9, 127902) I am a great admirer of Tulsidas.
('36', 62, 1, 10, 127936) And I consider the Ramayana to be the greatest work.
('36', 62, 1, 11, 127989) But I cannot subscribe to the idea contained in the couplet: “The drum, the village fool, the Sudras, animals, women—all these are fit to be beaten.” Because Tulsidas, influenced by the ideas prevalent in his time, has expressed this view, it would not be just for me to take to beating the so called Sudras or my wife or even the animals whenever I find them not submitting to my control.
('36', 62, 1, 12, 128379) Now I think that the answer to the question raised above becomes clear.
('36', 62, 1, 13, 128451) I do not see the slightest difficulty in narrating the story of the gods and goddesses to the extent that it helps in promoting good conduct.
('36', 62, 1, 14, 128593) I do not say that if the symbol is laid bare and the inner meaning brought out, the children lose interest in the stories.
('36', 62, 1, 15, 128716) Assuming, however, that they do lose interest, I cannot approve of the practice of sustaining interest at the cost of truth.
('36', 62, 1, 16, 128841) We should place before children whatever rasa there is in truth.
('36', 62, 1, 17, 128906) It is my experience that this rasa can be expressed and communicated.
('36', 62, 1, 18, 128976) First the children must be told clearly that there has never yet been in the world a ten headed demon and that there is no possibility of one occurring hereafter.
('36', 62, 1, 19, 129139) When this has been made clear, it will be no repudiation of truth or loss of interest if we narrate the story of Ravana as if he really did once exist.
('36', 62, 1, 20, 129291) The children do understand that the ten headed monster Ravana is no other than the evil desires inside us which have not only ten but a thousand heads.
('36', 62, 1, 21, 129443) In Aesop’s Fables birds and animals speak.
('36', 62, 1, 22, 129486) The children know that birds and animals cannot speak and yet their delight in his stories is not one whit the less on that account.
('36', 62, 1, 23, 129619) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 18 7 1926
('36', 63, 0, 1, 129656) 64 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 63, 1, 2, 129697) 64. QUALITY AND STRENGTH OF YARN
('36', 63, 2, 3, 129730) I have stated before that just as, in respect of yarn count we have progressed from three to eighty, and in respect of spinning speed from 200 yards to 800 yards an hour, and are also better now at preparing skeins of the yarn spun, so it is essential to improve the strength and texture of the yarn.
('36', 63, 2, 4, 130031) With improvement in yarn strength and texture, weaving would become easier and, therefore, cheaper.
('36', 63, 2, 5, 130131) We must improve in these respects so far, at any rate, that weavers will buy hand spun as readily as they buy mill made yarn.
('36', 63, 2, 6, 130257) Our ideal should be to make hand spun yarn more even in texture and more durable than mill yarn.
('36', 63, 2, 7, 130354) With this end in view experiments are at present being carried out in Gujarat to improve the quality of yarn, and in quite a short time some of us have achieved near perfection in regard to both texture and strength.
('36', 63, 3, 8, 130571) I have received figures regarding the quality of yarn from eight institutions producing khadi with aid from the Gujarat Khadi Pracharak Mandal.
('36', 63, 3, 9, 130715) The yarn received by the Mandal was from voluntary spinners who spin in the spirit of a yajna.
('36', 63, 3, 10, 130810) 1 I have with me a statement showing the quality of yarn contributed by 71 persons belonging to Kathlal, Nadiad, Dharmaj, Bhadran, Napad, Varad, Sarbhon and Ahmedabad.
('36', 63, 3, 11, 130978) All of them seem to have used slivers made from cotton carded with a big carding bow.
('36', 63, 3, 12, 131064) The varieties of cotton used were vankad, goji, deshi of Nadiad, Bardoli and Surati.
('36', 63, 3, 13, 131149) The highest level attained by any of the samples in respect of strength was found to be 52_ degrees.
('36', 63, 3, 14, 131250) Some fell to as low a figure as 15, and the highest average figure in this respect was that of Ahmedabad, 42. None of the 71 spinners reached a figure higher than 52_.
('36', 63, 3, 15, 131418) Most of them, in fact, are below 40. This degree of strength is very low.
('36', 63, 3, 16, 131492) It is very difficult to weave yarn of less than 50 degrees in strength.
('36', 63, 3, 17, 131564) Sixty degrees should be the minimum, and 70 should be regarded as normal.
('36', 63, 3, 18, 131638) The average in respect of texture comes to 42_, and the maximum goes up to 50, which is nearly the highest possible.
('36', 63, 3, 19, 131755) This degree of evenness of texture is quite good.
('36', 63, 3, 20, 131805) The lowest figure for texture was found to be 13, which is low indeed.
('36', 63, 3, 21, 131876) It should never fall below 40, for it is extremely difficult to weave yarn of that degree of texture, indifferently thick and thin.
('36', 63, 3, 22, 132008) Only rope can be made out of such yarn.
('36', 63, 4, 23, 132048) 1 Vide “A Correction,” 1 8 1926.
('36', 64, 0, 1, 132081) VOL. 36: 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 65
('36', 64, 1, 2, 132124) The experiment carried out in Gujarat has resulted in the strength of yarn reaching the figure 104, which is higher than that of the strongest mill yarn.
('36', 64, 1, 3, 132278) The details of this experiment will be published in a short time.
('36', 64, 1, 4, 132344) Meanwhile, however, all those doing sacrificial spinning should remember that it is essential to pay great attention to improving the quality of yarn.
('36', 64, 1, 5, 132495) Anyone who is anxious to effect such improvement must keep two things in mind.
('36', 64, 1, 6, 132574) In the first place, one should not at present think of rejoining the broken thread.
('36', 64, 1, 7, 132658) When both the hands work in unison, the thread will never break; in any case, it is essential, if the quality of yarn is to improve, that the broken thread should be removed.
('36', 64, 1, 8, 132833) If the hank is rolled tight, the strength of the yarn will be known, because the stretching of the yarn in tight rolling necessarily tests the strength of the yarn.
('36', 64, 1, 9, 132998) If the thread breaks while stretching, it may be assumed that it has not been well twisted.
('36', 64, 1, 10, 133090) The yarn wound on the reel should never be removed from it without first blowing water spray on it.
('36', 64, 1, 11, 133190) After the spraying it should be allowed to dry, so that the moisture is absorbed by the yarn and strengthens it.
('36', 64, 1, 12, 133303) This blowing moistens every fibre in the thread.
('36', 64, 1, 13, 133352) Uneven spraying will not serve the purpose.
('36', 64, 1, 14, 133396) The yarn should be properly moistened.
('36', 64, 1, 15, 133435) Perhaps the best way of ensuring this is to wind the yarn on a separate reel and dip the latter into water and let it remain in water till the yarn is moistened, that is, for two or three minutes.
('36', 64, 1, 16, 133632) Anyone who can think of other easier methods may certainly try them.
('36', 64, 1, 17, 133701) The main point which I have explained should, however, be borne in mind.
('36', 64, 1, 18, 133774) I hope that no one will at any rate try the experiment of removing the yarn from the reel and dipping it into water, for if the yarn is removed from the reel without being sprayed, it may become looser in twist, and the loss cannot be repaired by blowing water spray into the yarn afterwards.
('36', 64, 1, 19, 134067) The blowing is intended to make the twist strong enough so that it will last, and this can be done only by doing the blowing while the yarn is on the reel.
('36', 64, 1, 20, 134223) Finally, let all those who do sacrificial spinning remember that on their efficiency depends improvement in the quality of yarn spun by others who work for wages and that improvement in the quality of their yarn will mean increased earnings for these others.
('36', 64, 2, 21, 134482) [From Gujarati]
('36', 64, 3, 22, 134498) Navajivan, 18 7 1926

('36', 65, 2, 3, 134570) STOCKING OF COTTON IN PANCHTALAVADA
('36', 65, 3, 4, 134606) Sarvashri Chhaganlal and Maneklal are working in Panchtal avada on behalf of the Kathiawar Political Conference.
('36', 65, 3, 5, 134719) They have sent the following account of the work done: Their work is spread over 32 villages, in which 745 maunds of cotton was stocked.
('36', 65, 3, 6, 134856) Out of this, 216 maunds of cotton was ginned by hand and 529 in the factories.
('36', 65, 3, 7, 134935) From this, 2681 vejans 1 of cloth was woven, that is, 53,620 yards of khadi was produced: Even now a subsidy of Rs. 20 had to be given.
('36', 65, 3, 8, 135071) Many of them worked efficiently and economically and did not need help.
('36', 65, 3, 9, 135143) Apart from this, 2,588 yards of khadi was produced from yarn spun and woven for payment.
('36', 65, 3, 10, 135232) The quantity of cotton mentioned above was stocked by 640 families.
('36', 65, 3, 11, 135300) The stocking of this gave work to 20 carders and 100 weavers.
('36', 65, 3, 12, 135362) The carders received about Rs. 1,200 and the weavers Rs. 4,000. The sums were paid by the cultivators them selves.
('36', 65, 3, 13, 135477) Out of the 640 families, only seven 2 families availed themselves of the help provided.
('36', 65, 3, 14, 135565) Commenting on this, the two workers say that the success of our work depends on inducing cultivators to stock cotton, for in this way we get a real idea of thepoverty of our country.
('36', 65, 3, 15, 135748) We realize, they say, that our real work lies in villages, and that while doing this work we can also do other social work among the villagers.
('36', 65, 3, 16, 135892) By popularizing the use of the spinning wheel we can convince people what a terrible disease their idleness is.
('36', 65, 3, 17, 136004) Wherever the volunteers work in a spirit of service, they succeed in creating a sense of brotherhood among the people.
('36', 65, 3, 18, 136123) And the difficulty of selling khadi, they point out, is avoided by following the method of getting people to stock their own cotton [and produce khadi for their needs].
('36', 65, 3, 19, 136292) Apart from this work of persuading people to stock cotton, these brothers got 100 women to work for wages.
('36', 65, 3, 20, 136399) The rate of payment was 6 pies per count.
('36', 65, 3, 21, 136441) Each woman earned between Rs. 2 8 as.
('36', 65, 3, 22, 136479) per mound and Rs. 3 a month.
('36', 65, 3, 23, 136508) They spun yarn of 4 to 8 counts.
('36', 65, 3, 24, 136541) Two carders worked for supplying the slivers required by these women.
('36', 65, 3, 25, 136611) Twenty weavers were at work weaving the yarn produced.
('36', 65, 3, 26, 136666) The rate of payment for carding was Rs. 2 10 as.
('36', 65, 3, 27, 136715) per maund.
('36', 65, 3, 28, 136726) The weavers were paid Rs. 8 per maund of khadi of between 24 and 27 inches in width and Rs. 10 per maund for khadi of 30 inches width.
('36', 65, 3, 29, 136861) They were paid
