('36', 68, 1, 2, 140256) 69. LETTER TO NANABHAI BHATT
('36', 68, 2, 3, 140285) THE ASHRAM, Monday, July 19, 1926
('36', 68, 3, 4, 140319) BHAI NANABHAI, Your letter is an exercise for me.
('36', 68, 3, 5, 140369) Narahari has quoted to you from Shri Mahadev’s reply to his letter.
('36', 68, 3, 6, 140437) Narahari had said that neither pupils nor parents cared for our education and that by and by all of them would join Government schools, that they did not seem keen on wearing khadi or enthusiastic about our aims.
('36', 68, 3, 7, 140650) My reply to this argument was that, if in any school pupils refused to abide by our rules, they should leave it.
('36', 68, 3, 8, 140763) The rules include wearing of khadi, observance of the practice of untouchability, etc.
('36', 68, 3, 9, 140850) I had these circumstances in mind when I asked Mahadev to write and say that Narahari had remained in Surat of his own free will.
('36', 68, 3, 10, 140980) I had askedfor his services for only three or four months.
('36', 68, 3, 11, 141039) I know Narahari’s unsteady nature.
('36', 68, 3, 12, 141074) Following the principle that one’s own sphere of work, though small, is good for one’s spiritual development, I said that Sarbhon 1 was the right place for him, but that, if he preferred, he could remain in Surat.
('36', 68, 3, 13, 141288) After this, my responsibility was over.
('36', 68, 3, 14, 141328) I do not order, I only advise.
('36', 68, 3, 15, 141359) I have left it to you to order.
('36', 68, 3, 16, 141391) I explained what I would do if I were a teacher.
('36', 68, 3, 17, 141440) Others may follow that course and do the best they can, or do nothing if they can do no more.
('36', 68, 3, 18, 141534) I have done my duty in offering the bride to the groom at the wedding; it is none of my business to run the house for her.
('36', 68, 3, 19, 141657) As the bride’s father, however, I may certainly advise her from time to time.
('36', 68, 3, 20, 141735) But I have understood the difference between your point of view and mine.
('36', 68, 3, 21, 141809) You believe in national education plus khadi, etc.
('36', 68, 3, 22, 141860) I say that national education itself means khadi and the other things.
('36', 68, 3, 23, 141931) This is for the first time that you have mentioned this difference.
('36', 68, 3, 24, 141999) What you understand by national education, apart from these three things, you may explain to me when you are here.
('36', 68, 3, 25, 142114) Or you may write to me about it.
('36', 68, 3, 26, 142147) I would not adopt the method of the missionaries nor that which is supposed to be followed in Islam.
('36', 68, 3, 27, 142248) Our religion teaches me a third way.
('36', 68, 3, 28, 142285) I would show the article I offered and state its price, leaving it to the people to buy it at that price.
('36', 68, 3, 29, 142391) This course decides the question of fitness, and the foundation remains firmly that of truth.
('36', 68, 3, 30, 142485) The measure of my right angle does not vary according to circumstances;
('36', 68, 4, 31, 142557) 1 A village in Surat district where a small Ashram was established
('36', 69, 0, 1, 142624) 70 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 69, 1, 2, 142665) if, however, people cannot fit themselves in it, the fault is not mine, nor with the right angle nor with those people.
('36', 69, 1, 3, 142785) But all this is neither here nor there.
('36', 69, 1, 4, 142825) Consider my views, but decide for yourself and act accordingly.
('36', 69, 1, 5, 142889) If Narahari wishes, he can remain in Surat.
('36', 69, 1, 6, 142933) You may insist on khadi to the limit you and he think best.
('36', 69, 1, 7, 142993) My views will remain what they are, till you can change them.
('36', 69, 1, 8, 143055) Mama is wonderful.
('36', 69, 1, 9, 143074) Write and explain to him that in a sense the issue is, and in a sense it is not, one between agriculture and other work.
('36', 69, 1, 10, 143195) I can have no prejudice against agriculture.
('36', 69, 1, 11, 143240) But I do not look upon agriculture as a necessary part of our service of the Antyajas, and so I cannot but feel when even one pice has to be spent on agriculture, since in spending it we leave our sphere of work.
('36', 69, 2, 12, 143453) BAPU [PS.] If the handwriting is illegible, send for me to help you read it when airplanes come into use.
('36', 69, 2, 13, 143559) You can send this letter to Narahari.
('36', 69, 2, 14, 143597) To Mama, only this paragraph.

('36', 70, 1, 2, 144117) 71. LETTER TO C. V. RENGANCHETTY
('36', 70, 2, 3, 144150) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, July 20, 1926
('36', 70, 3, 4, 144187) DEAR FRIEND, I have the spinning wheel and your bill.
('36', 70, 3, 5, 144241) In accordance with the terms of my first letter to you, asking for the charkha, I shall have to return it.
('36', 70, 3, 6, 144348) But, before I do so, I want to give you my views upon it so as not to do you an injustice.
('36', 70, 3, 7, 144439) The charkha is a flimsy thing.
('36', 70, 3, 8, 144470) The woodwork is all right, but the wire spokes and the wire stays are perfectly useless because they are not of steel.
('36', 70, 3, 9, 144589) The wires easily bend under the slightest pressure whereas, in the Khadi Charkha, they are all steel wires.
('36', 70, 3, 10, 144697) The axle does not lie evenly on the poles.
('36', 70, 3, 11, 144740) The result is that the wheel string stays not in the centre, but on one side of the wheel.
('36', 70, 3, 12, 144831) The spindle isperfectly useless, because instead of sloping away from one end, it is a straight pointed wire on either end.
('36', 70, 3, 13, 144955) You cannot spin on it easily.
('36', 70, 3, 14, 144985) The pulley is perfectly useless.
('36', 70, 3, 15, 145018) There is no handle rod provided.
('36', 70, 3, 16, 145051) The spinning wheel, therefore, that you have sent me is not only not superior to the Khadi Pratishthan [one] as you claimed, but it is altogether inferior to it.
('36', 70, 3, 17, 145213) I had sent for your charkha in order to test its quality, because the price you quoted was surprisingly low.
('36', 70, 3, 18, 145322) The price of the Khadi Pratishthan Charkha was fixed in consultation with me after much deliberation and after arriving at the net cost.
('36', 70, 3, 19, 145459) You have no notion how much it costs when the details about fittings are to be made scrupulously correct as they are in the Khadi Pratishthan Charkha.
('36', 70, 3, 20, 145610) Every part is tested before it is sent out.
('36', 70, 3, 21, 145654) It is evident to me that you do not yourself handle spinning wheels, one could be easily deceived by a superficial similarity.
('36', 70, 3, 22, 145781) You will now tell me what to do with your charkha.
('36', 70, 3, 23, 145832) I do not want you to be out of pocket by a single pice.
('36', 70, 3, 24, 145888) I will, therefore, gladly send the charkha back to you.
('36', 70, 3, 25, 145944) But if you want me to send it somewhere else, I shall gladly do so at my cost.
('36', 70, 3, 26, 146023) Or, if you want me to try this charkha in any other manner, I would gladly do so.
('36', 70, 3, 27, 146105) And, if it can at all prove satisfactory, I should keep it and discharge your bill.
('36', 70, 4, 28, 146189) Yours sincerely, C. V. RENGANCHETTY NARAYANAVARAM
('36', 70, 5, 29, 146239) From a microfilm: S.N. 11204
('36', 71, 0, 1, 146268) 72 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 71, 1, 2, 146309) 72. LETTER TO SIR HAROLD MANN
('36', 71, 2, 3, 146339) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, July 20, 1926
('36', 71, 3, 4, 146376) MY DEAR SIR HAROLD MANN, I thank you for your letter 1 inviting me to demonstrate hand spinning at the forthcoming exhibition in Poona.
('36', 71, 3, 5, 146512) I should love to do so, but for two reasons.
('36', 71, 3, 6, 146557) Up to the 20th of December, I am under avow not to leave Ahmedabad except upon some pressing unforeseen public call or for reasons of health.
('36', 71, 3, 7, 146699) Secondly, I want to move slowly and, therefore, I do not want to identity myself so much with functions which, though they may be unofficial, may have an official colouring or patronage.
('36', 71, 3, 8, 146886) It is more truthful for me to do so so long as I suspect the existing system as an evil.
('36', 71, 3, 9, 146975) I know I can write thus freely and frankly to you without being considered in any way discourteous.
('36', 71, 3, 10, 147075) You will find, however, that the party of demonstrators that will be sent to you will be thoroughly effective and the demonstration itself will be given in a scientific manner.
('36', 71, 3, 11, 147252) Because we are experimen ting upon this in a scientific manner, not one of the principal workers has 2 any preconceived notions or prejudice one way or the other.
('36', 71, 3, 12, 147415) It is because we feel that the charkha is the one thing that can save the sinking peasantry from extinction that we are devoting all our energy to its improvement and success.
('36', 71, 3, 13, 147591) I have been brooding over the Dairy scheme that you have kindly sent me.
('36', 71, 3, 14, 147664) There seems to be no land near Ahmedabad that I can get, but if you could send the expert you have in view, he will see the land near the Ashram that we have got and, if he thinks that a Dairy could be established here on an unambitious scale, a portion of the land can be set apart for the purpose.
('36', 71, 3, 15, 147964) And, if that proves unsatisfac tory, I must confer with him about securing a plot of land some distance from Ahmedabad.
('36', 71, 3, 16, 148084) I am running a little Dairy here myself.
('36', 71, 3, 17, 148125) Perhaps, it may be extended.
('36', 71, 3, 18, 148154) Nothing, however, can be done without a personal conversation with one who knows all about dairying.
('36', 71, 3, 19, 148255) Yours sincerely, SIR HAROLD MANN DIRECTOR OF AGRICULTURE B. P., POONA
('36', 71, 4, 20, 148325) From a microfilm: S.N. 11205
('36', 71, 5, 21, 148354) 1 Writing on July 14, Mann had considered a spinning demonstration by Gandhiji “the most effective means of pushing the use of hand spinning by the rural classes that could be devised” (S.N. 11200).
('36', 71, 5, 22, 148553) 2 The source has “have”.

('36', 73, 9, 15, 150635) 76. LETTER TO C. F. ANDREWS
('36', 73, 10, 16, 150663) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, July 20, 1926
('36', 73, 11, 17, 150700) MY DEAR CHARLIE,
('36', 73, 12, 18, 150717) I was reading up your article on the coming conference in South Africa for Young India yesterday and I felt that the article was not well considered.
('36', 73, 12, 19, 150867) You have evidently felt it yourself and so, in order to tone down the impression left on your readers, you have added six lines in your own hand.
('36', 73, 12, 20, 151013) But that has merely made the position worse.
('36', 73, 12, 21, 151058) Your theme is that the cause of prejudice in South Africa is solely colour.
('36', 73, 12, 22, 151134) If you will review the whole of
('36', 73, 13, 23, 151166) 1 Vide the succeding item.
('36', 74, 0, 1, 151193) VOL. 36: 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 75
('36', 74, 1, 2, 151236) your experience, you will find that this is only half truth.
('36', 74, 1, 3, 151297) If it was the whole truth, Round Table Conference would be no remedyfor it.
('36', 74, 1, 4, 151373) We must then, whilst there is yet time, clear every Indian from South Africa.
('36', 74, 1, 5, 151451) It is due to the whites and it is due to ourselves.
('36', 74, 1, 6, 151503) If the sayings that you have quoted of two Europeans are the typical and almost universal sentiment amongst the average white man in South Africa, is it right to resist that sentiment?
('36', 74, 1, 7, 151688) Can the Government, no matter how powerful it may be, do otherwise than pass progressively drastic legislation?
('36', 74, 1, 8, 151800) The sentiment may be altogether bad.
('36', 74, 1, 9, 151837) But, can a man overcome his prejudice?
('36', 74, 1, 10, 151876) And, if the average.
('36', 74, 1, 11, 151897) white man in South Africa, more especially in Natal as you say, has that prejudice, isn’t it the duty of those like you and me who want to serve truth before anything else to face that fact squarely in the face and pave the way for a dignified and honourable withdrawal of every single Indian from South Africa?
('36', 74, 1, 12, 152209) If I was convinced, as you are convinced, of this colour prejudice, I would certainly advocate withdrawal even if mine was the only voice.
('36', 74, 1, 13, 152348) But, of course, I do not share your conclusions.
('36', 74, 1, 14, 152397) In the first instance, I do not regard human nature in South Africa to be so badly debased.
('36', 74, 1, 15, 152489) I think that the prejudice is very much mixed.
('36', 74, 1, 16, 152536) As a matter of fact, if the prejudice was as great as you imagine, the Europeans would make it so hot for Indians that they could not possibly live there for a single minute.
('36', 74, 1, 17, 152711) No legislation would be needed for that purpose.
('36', 74, 1, 18, 152760) Remember that even now Indian trade is dependent upon European patronage.
('36', 74, 1, 19, 152834) The colour prejudice is no doubt universal in social life.
('36', 74, 1, 20, 152893) That is a barrier which time alone will break.
('36', 74, 1, 21, 152940) No legislation is necessary for breaking that barrier.
('36', 74, 1, 22, 152995) For that matter that barrier is far worse, perhaps, here than in South Africa.
('36', 74, 1, 23, 153074) But I do not want to carry the argument any further.
('36', 74, 1, 24, 153127) All I want to say is you should put a curb upon your pen, for, anything you write must have and has its effect.
('36', 74, 1, 25, 153239) This article of yours is so terrible.
('36', 74, 1, 26, 153277) I return it to you so that you can refresh your memory.
('36', 74, 1, 27, 153333) If I am wrong, you will correct me.
('36', 74, 1, 28, 153369) I have suppressed also the article you sent me on ‘Opium’; That article was too hurriedly written to be of any value.
('36', 74, 1, 29, 153487) It was too scrappy, did not even give sufficient information.
('36', 74, 1, 30, 153549) But both these articles indicate extreme fatigue of mind.
('36', 74, 1, 31, 153607) Will you not restrain yourself a bit, or, do you think that it is God’s call that your pen must be ever running?
('36', 74, 1, 32, 153720) Gregg has summed up this writing disease of yours in one single line.
('36', 74, 1, 33, 153790) He says, ‘The insect bite poisoning was a godsend for you, because, it obliged you to put away your pen.’ Anyway, I absolve you from all obligation to write for Young India till you have
('36', 75, 0, 1, 153977) 76 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 75, 1, 2, 154018) had some rest.
('36', 75, 1, 3, 154033) And, if you want such discharge from the other newspapers, I undertake to procure it for you.
('36', 75, 1, 4, 154127) And I give you my assurance that the world will not go to pieces for the suspension of your writings, because, there is hardly a paper I am opening in which I do not see long articles from you on the same subject.
('36', 75, 1, 5, 154341) If they cannot exist without you, let them die.
('36', 75, 1, 6, 154389) I feel grieved to find that you must be continually writing when there is no necessity for it.

('36', 75, 8, 21, 155091) 78. LETTER TO PARAMANAND KUNVARJI
('36', 75, 9, 22, 155125) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, Tuesday, Asadha Sud 10, July 20, 1926
('36', 75, 10, 23, 155186) BHAISHRI PARAMANAND, I have your letter.
('36', 75, 10, 24, 155227) I understand your point about the use of
('36', 76, 0, 1, 155268) VOL. 36: 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 77
('36', 76, 1, 2, 155311) words and am well aware of the value of precision.
('36', 76, 1, 3, 155362) The use of the same word in different senses leads to a good deal of misunder standing, but I think it is not difficult to understand the general purport of my writings.
('36', 76, 1, 4, 155532) In regard to Madhuri, you are to blame.
('36', 76, 1, 5, 155572) Having placed our children in a certain atmosphere, is it not surprising indeed that we believe or wish that they will remain untouched by it?
('36', 76, 1, 6, 155715) I come across instances of this everywhere.
('36', 76, 1, 7, 155759) You should now remove Madhuri and place her in an atmosphere of simplicity, if you do not wish her to become fashion loving.
('36', 76, 1, 8, 155884) But to keep her where she is and then insist that she should not wear foreign cloth has a strong smell of coercion about it.
('36', 76, 1, 9, 156009) On the issue of principle which you have raised in connection with Madhuri, my view is that parents should exercise control over children.
('36', 76, 1, 10, 156148) We cannot let them do everything they will.
('36', 76, 1, 11, 156192) Our wisdom lies in keeping them under control with the least restraint over them.
('36', 76, 1, 12, 156274) If a child runs in the direction of a well, or wants to eat a rich and stimulating preparation or would indulge in overeating, if it asks for bhajiyan 1 and puri 2 when it is running a temperature—in all such instances we should resist the child’s wish.
('36', 76, 1, 13, 156528) This is also true about matters involving moral principles.
('36', 76, 1, 14, 156588) But the problem of husband and wife is on a different footing, and an extremely difficult one to solve.
('36', 76, 1, 15, 156692) What happens when, in a non vegetarian family, the husband becomes a vegetarian as a matter of religious principle?

('36', 82, 2, 3, 166995) SABARMATI, July 21, 1926
('36', 82, 3, 4, 167020) DEAR SHRI PRABHUDAS BHIKHABHAI, I have your letter.
('36', 82, 3, 5, 167072) I believe it is possible to conserve the vital fluid by learning to control one’s breath, but that does not solve the problem of brahmacharya.
('36', 82, 3, 6, 167215) Brahmacharya means control of all the senses.
('36', 82, 3, 7, 167261) Perhaps you do not know that medical scientists in this ageperform a surgical operation which prevents the emission of the vital fluid; would you call a person so operated upon a brahmachari?
('36', 82, 3, 8, 167453) A shastri explained to me the meaning of conservation of the vital fluid, and said that in Sanskrit the phrase viryanigraha has reference to the sublimation of the vital fluid so that it flows upwards.
('36', 82, 3, 9, 167655) And then he told me that Krishna whose doings are described by the author of the Bhagavata was a person in whom the vital fluid was sublimated in this manner, and so he was free to have relations with any number of women.
('36', 82, 3, 10, 167877) Are you prepared to look upon such a person as a brahma chari?
('36', 82, 3, 11, 167940) You will now see that the brahmacharya achieved through mere breath control is of little value.
('36', 82, 3, 12, 168036) The real value of brahmacharya lies in the expenditure of the great energy required for mastering the senses; when, through such expenditure, the senses become atman oriented, the power which is generated by the effort can pervade the entire universe.
('36', 82, 3, 13, 168288) It is my unshakable conviction that such cannot be achieved by methods of purely external control.
('36', 82, 3, 14, 168387) In the second chapter [of the Gita] 1, Shri Krishna, who had the wisdom of experience, says that fasting may calm a man’s desires, but that his pleasure in objects of the senses does not disappear completely.
('36', 82, 3, 15, 168596) It disappears only when he has realized God, and he will have to strive during life after life before he realizes God.
('36', 82, 3, 16, 168715) Remember what Shankaracharya said in this connection.
('36', 82, 3, 17, 168769) If a man, sitting on the shore, attempts the impossible task of emptying the sea by taking out the water drop by drop, on a blade of grass, he may, if he has the necessary patience and if he can find an empty hollow large enough, succeed in transferring the water after millions Of years the number of which can be calculated arithmetically; to realize God requires more patience than this, and, according to the Lord, achieving brahma charya means realizing God.
('36', 82, 3, 18, 169233) Please understand that in saying all this I
('36', 83, 0, 1, 169277) 84 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 83, 1, 2, 169318) am not at all underestimating the value of breath control.
('36', 83, 1, 3, 169377) I believe it to be an aid in our effort, but by itself it is not enough.
('36', 83, 1, 4, 169450) It can be a stage, and not a very advanced one at that, in the difficult journey towards the goal of brahmacharya.
('36', 83, 1, 5, 169565) My only complaint against you is that you seem to attach more importance to it than it deserves.

('36', 87, 1, 3, 178597) Virginity is a physical, moral, and intellectual safeguard to young men.”

('36', 88, 1, 2, 181237) to add many others, let us quote the resolution unanimously voted at Brussels in 1902 by the 102 members present at the second General Congress of the International Conference of Sanitary and Moral Prophylaxis, a congress which assembled together the most competent authorities on the subject throughout the world: “Young men must above all be taught that chastity and continence are not only not harmful, but also that these virtues are among those to be most earnestly recommended from the purely medical and hygienic standpoint.”

('36', 114, 5, 9, 226136) 129. THE HYDRA HEADED MONSTER
('36', 114, 6, 10, 226166) A friend has sent me a gist of what appears in the Southern vernacular press from the pen of a learned Pundit.
('36', 114, 6, 11, 226277) He summarizes the Pundit’s plea for untouchability in this fashion:
('36', 114, 7, 12, 226345) (1) The fact that once Adi Shankara asked a Chandala to be aloof from him, and the fact that Trishanku when he was condemned to be a Chandala was
('36', 114, 8, 13, 226491) shunned by all people, prove that untouchability is not of recent growth.
('36', 114, 9, 14, 226565) (2) The Chandalas are the outcastes of the Aryan society.
('36', 114, 10, 15, 226623) (3) The untouchables themselves are not free from the sin of untouchability.
('36', 114, 11, 16, 226700) (4) The untouchables are so because they kill animals and because they have constantly to do with flesh, blood, bones and night soil.
('36', 114, 12, 17, 226834) (5) The untouchables must be isolated even as slaughter houses, toddy shops and houses of ill fame are or should be.
('36', 114, 13, 18, 226951) (6) It should be enough that untouchables are not denied the privileges of the other world.
('36', 114, 14, 19, 227043) (7) A Gandhi may touch these people, but so can he fast.
('36', 114, 14, 20, 227100) We may neither fast nor touch the untouchables.
('36', 114, 15, 21, 227148) (8) Untouchability is a necessity for man’s growth.
('36', 114, 16, 22, 227200) (9) Man has magnetic powers about him.
('36', 114, 16, 23, 227239) This sakti is like milk.
('36', 114, 17, 24, 227264) will be damaged by improper contacts.
('36', 114, 17, 25, 227302) If one can keep musk and onion together, one may mix Brahmans and untouchables.
('36', 114, 17, 26, 227382) These are the chief points summarized by the correspondent.
('36', 114, 17, 27, 227442) Untouchability is a hydra headed monster.
('36', 114, 17, 28, 227484) It is therefore necessary,
('36', 115, 0, 1, 227511) 116 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 115, 1, 2, 227553) each time the monster lifts its head, to deal with it.
('36', 115, 1, 3, 227608) The stories told in the Puranas are some of them most dangerous if we do not know their bearing on the present conditions.
('36', 115, 1, 4, 227731) The Shastras would be death traps if we were to regulate our conduct according to every detail given in them or according to that of the characters therein described.
('36', 115, 1, 5, 227898) They help us only to define and argue out fundamental principles.
('36', 115, 1, 6, 227964) If some well known character in religious books sinned against God or man, is that a warrant for our repeating the sin?
('36', 115, 1, 7, 228084) It is enough for us to be told, once for all, [that] Truth is the only thing that matters in the world, that Truth is God.
('36', 115, 1, 8, 228207) It is irrelevant to be told that even Yudhishthira was betrayed into an untruth.
('36', 115, 1, 9, 228288) It is more relevant for US to know that when he spoke an untruth, he had to suffer for it that very moment and that his great name in no way protected him from punishment.
('36', 115, 1, 10, 228460) Similarly, it is irrelevant for us to be told that Adi Shankara avoided a Chandala.
('36', 115, 1, 11, 228544) It is enough for us to know that a religion that teaches us to treat all that lives as we treat ourselves cannot possibly countenance the inhuman treatment of a single creature, let alone a whole class of perfectly innocent human beings.
('36', 115, 1, 12, 228782) Moreover, we have not even all the facts before us to judge what Adi Shankara did or did not do.
('36', 115, 1, 13, 228879) Still less do we know the meaning of the word Chandala where it occurs.
('36', 115, 1, 14, 228951) It has admittedly many meanings, one of which is a sinner.
('36', 115, 1, 15, 229010) But if all sinners are to be regarded as untouchables, it is very much to be feared that we should all, not excluding the Pundit himself, be under the ban of untouchability.
('36', 115, 1, 16, 229184) That untouchability is an old institution, nobody has ever denied.
('36', 115, 1, 17, 229251) But, if it is an evil, it cannot be defended on the ground of its antiquity.
('36', 115, 2, 18, 229328) If the untouchables are the outcastes of the Aryan society, so much the worse for that society.
('36', 115, 2, 19, 229424) And, if the Aryans at some stage in their progress regarded a certain class of people as outcastes by way of punishment, there is no reason why that punishment should descend upon their progeny irrespective of the causes for which their ancestors were punished.
('36', 115, 3, 20, 229686) That there is untouchability even amongst untouchables merely demonstrates that that evil cannot be confined and that its deadening effect is all pervading.
('36', 115, 3, 21, 229843) The existence of untouchability amongst untouchables is an additional reason for cultured Hindu society to rid itself of the curse with the quickest despatch.
('36', 115, 4, 22, 230002) If the untouchables are so because they kill animals and because
('36', 116, 0, 1, 230067) VOL. 36: 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 117
('36', 116, 1, 2, 230111) they have to do with flesh, blood, bones and night soil, every nurse and every doctor should become an untouchable and so should Christians, Mussalmans and all so called high class Hindus who kill animals for food or sacrifice.
('36', 116, 1, 3, 230339) The argument that because slaughter houses, toddy shops, and houses of ill fame are or should be isolated, untouchables should likewise be isolated betrays gross prejudice.
('36', 116, 1, 4, 230512) Slaughter houses and toddy shops are and should be isolated.
('36', 116, 1, 5, 230573) But neither butchers nor publicans are isolated.
('36', 116, 1, 6, 230622) Prostitutes should be isolated because their occupation is revolting and detrimental to the well being of society.
('36', 116, 1, 7, 230737) Whereas the occupation of ‘untouchables’ is not only desirable but a necessity for the well being of the society.
('36', 116, 1, 8, 230851) To say that ‘untouchables’ are not denied privileges of the other world is the acme of insolence.
('36', 116, 1, 9, 230949) If it was possible to deny them the privileges of the other world, it is highly likely that the defenders of the monster would isolate them even in the other world.
('36', 116, 1, 10, 231114) It is throwing dust in the eyes of the people to say that ‘a Gandhi may touch the “untouchables”, not so other people,’ as if the touching and service of ‘untouchables’ was so injurious as to require for it men specially proof against untouchable germs.
('36', 116, 1, 11, 231368) Heaven only knows what punishment is in store for Mussalmans, Christians and others who do not believe in untouchability.
('36', 116, 1, 12, 231490) The plea of animal magnetism is altogether overdone.
('36', 116, 1, 13, 231543) The high class men are not all sweet smelling like musk, nor are untouchables foul smelling like onion.
('36', 116, 1, 14, 231647) There are thousands of untouchables who are any day infinitely superior to the so called high class people.
('36', 116, 1, 15, 231755) It is painful to discover that even after five years of continuous propaganda against untouchability, there are learned people enough found to support such an immoral and evil custom.
('36', 116, 1, 16, 231939) That belief in untouchability can co exist with learning in the same person adds no status to untouchability, but makes one despair of mere learning being any aid to Character or sanity.
('36', 116, 2, 17, 232126) Young India, 29 7 1926
('36', 116, 3, 18, 232149) 130. REASON v.
('36', 116, 3, 19, 232164) AUTHORITY
('36', 116, 4, 20, 232174) The teacher who taught his pupils to spin because it was “Mahatmaji’s order” writes:
('36', 117, 0, 1, 232259) 118 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 117, 1, 2, 232301) On reading your article on “Mahatmaji’s order” in Young India dated
('36', 117, 2, 3, 232369) 24th June 1926, the following doubts have arisen in my mind:
('36', 117, 3, 4, 232430) You assign a great place to reason.
('36', 117, 3, 5, 232466) Have you not also written in the pages of Young India or Navajivan that reason is like the King of England
('36', 117, 4, 6, 232573) entirely in the hands of its ministers the senses.
('36', 117, 4, 7, 232624) Does not man often reason in the direction the senses guide him?
('36', 117, 4, 8, 232689) How then can you take reason to be the guide?
('36', 117, 4, 9, 232735) Have you not said that argument follows conviction?
('36', 117, 4, 10, 232787) If then one has not the heart to spin one will find reasons against spinning.
('36', 117, 4, 11, 232865) How far is it advisable to tax the reason of little children?
('36', 117, 4, 12, 232927) That great educational reformer Rousseau said that childhood was the sleep of reason.
('36', 117, 4, 13, 233013) He therefore advocated merely the teaching of good habits during that age.
('36', 117, 4, 14, 233088) And surely to teach children to obey the orders of a Mahatma especially when they involve physical labour is to cultivate a good habit.
('36', 117, 4, 15, 233224) When the children grow up, they will find out the reasons for spinning.
('36', 117, 4, 16, 233296) But is it wrong till then to inculcate that spirit of ‘blind hero worship’ as you prefer to call it?
('36', 117, 4, 17, 233397) Have we not made a fetish of reason in these day?
('36', 117, 4, 18, 233447) For simple little things we undergo long and laborious processes of reasoning and do not even then feel satisfied.
('36', 117, 4, 19, 233562) Reason, no doubt, has its place, but, surely much below the rank that we now give it.
('36', 117, 5, 20, 233648) It is wrong to quote a person against himself unless one is sure of what he has said and under what circumstances.
('36', 117, 5, 21, 233763) All the statements the correspondent ascribes to me have undoubtedly been made by me at some time or other, but under totally different circumstances.
('36', 117, 5, 22, 233914) Where it is perfectly possible to reason out a thing to the satisfaction even of children, there is no occasion for quoting authority and asking them to obey it.
('36', 117, 5, 23, 234076) Very often it is a misleading process.
('36', 117, 5, 24, 234115) Everyone has his likes and dislikes.
('36', 117, 5, 25, 234152) And when a man has begun to believe in a hero, he gives his reason the go by and makes of his hero a fetish.
('36', 117, 5, 26, 234261) This, I consider, is blind heroworship.
('36', 117, 5, 27, 234301) Hero worship is a fine quality.
('36', 117, 5, 28, 234333) No nation or individual can make progress who has no hero for their model.
('36', 117, 5, 29, 234408) The hero serves as an inspiration.
('36', 117, 5, 30, 234443) He makes action possible which, in our weakness, is otherwise impossible.
('36', 117, 5, 31, 234517) He helps us out of the Slough of Despond.
('36', 117, 5, 32, 234559) The memory of his deeds enables us to go through endless sacrifice.
('36', 117, 5, 33, 234627) But, he must not be allowed to warp our judgment and paralyse our reason.
('36', 117, 5, 34, 234701) The sayings and actions of the tallest among us must bear a most searching scrutiny, for, heroes are mortals.
('36', 117, 5, 35, 234811) They are as liable to mistakes as the weakest among us.
('36', 117, 5, 36, 234867) Their strength lies in their decision and power for action.
('36', 117, 5, 37, 234927) They are therefore terrible when they make mistakes.
('36', 117, 5, 38, 234980) They bring woe to the man or the nation that go in for blind hero worship and slavishly accept all the
('36', 118, 0, 1, 235083) VOL. 36: 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 119
('36', 118, 1, 2, 235127) acts and sayings of their heroes without question.
('36', 118, 1, 3, 235178) Blind hero worship is, therefore, worse than blind worship of reason.
('36', 118, 1, 4, 235248) Indeed, blind worship of reason is a misnomer.
('36', 118, 1, 5, 235295) But the correspondent’s warning about reason serves one useful purpose.
('36', 118, 1, 6, 235367) Seeing that reason in the vast majority of cases is the only guide to conduct, we must have for her pure and obedient ministers.
('36', 118, 1, 7, 235496) The senses must therefore be brought under control and subjected to the severest discipline so that they may be willing instruments in the hands of reason instead of reason being their helpless slave.
('36', 118, 1, 8, 235697) The reason of little children is, no doubt, asleep, but, a vigilant teacher would gently coax it and, waking it, teach the children habits of discipline so that their reason, being freed from the control of their senses, would become from the very child.
('36', 118, 1, 9, 235952) hood their guide.
('36', 118, 1, 10, 235970) It is no discipline to tell the children to follow a hero.
('36', 118, 1, 11, 236029) No habit is cultivated thereby.
('36', 118, 1, 12, 236061) The children who are taught to slavishly do things become sluggish.
('36', 118, 1, 13, 236129) And if perchance another schoolmaster displaces from the throne of their hearts the hero, presented to them by his predecessor, they are likely to become unhinged and useless in after life.
('36', 118, 1, 14, 236319) Whereas, If from the very commencement whatever is placed before them is reasoned out for them, and then examples of great men having done noble deeds placed before them to strengthen their resolve or support their reason, they are likely to develop into strong hardy citizens who, under difficult circumstances, will be able to render a good amount of themselves.

('36', 120, 3, 8, 240525) 132. ‘TOWARDS MORAL BANKRUPTCY ’ V
('36', 120, 4, 9, 240560) After dealing with the physiological benefit of chastity, M. Bureau quotes the following passage from Professor Montegazza on its moral and intellectual advantages:
('36', 120, 5, 10, 240725) “All men, and young men in particular, can experience the immediate benefit of chastity.
('36', 120, 5, 11, 240814) The memory is quiet and tenacious, the brain lively and fertile, the will energetic, the whole character gains a strength of which libertines have no conception; no prism shows us our surroundings under such heavenly colours as that of chastity, which lights up with its rays the least objects in the universe, and transports us into the purest joys of an abiding happiness that knows neither shadow nor decline.” And the author adds: “The joy, the cordial merriment, the sunny confidence of vigorous young men who have remained chaste .
('36', 120, 5, 12, 241352) are an eloquent contrast to the restless obsessions and feverish excitement of their companions who are slaves to the demands of sensuality.” He then compares the benefits of chastity with ‘the miserable consequences of lust and debauchery’.
('36', 120, 5, 13, 241594) “No disease,” the author states, “could ever be quoted as the result of continence; who is not aware of the frightful diseases of which moral indiscipline is the source?” “The body .
('36', 120, 5, 14, 241777) finds itself converted into an indescribable state of rottenness.
('36', 120, 5, 15, 241843) Nor can we forget the worse defilement of imagination, heart and understanding.
('36', 120, 5, 16, 241923) On every side we hear complaint of the lowering of the character, the unbridled lust of youth, the overflowing of selfishness.” So much for the so called necessity of sexual indulgence and the consequent liberty taken by the youth before marriage.
('36', 120, 5, 17, 242171) The protagonists of the doctrine of such indulgence further contend that restraint of the sexual passion is a restraint upon ‘the freedom to dispose of one’s body’.
('36', 120, 5, 18, 242336) The author shows by elaborate argument that restraint on individual freedom in the matter of sexual indulgence is a sociological and psychological necessity.
('36', 120, 5, 19, 242494) The author says,
('36', 121, 0, 1, 242511) 122 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 121, 1, 2, 242553) In the eyes of sociologists, social life is nothing but a net work of multiform relations, nothing but an interlacing of actions and reactions, in the midst of which an activity, isolated and really separated from the rest, is unthinkable.
('36', 121, 1, 3, 242793) On whatever step we resolve, whatever action we attempt, solidarity unites our resolution and our action to those of our brothers; and not even our most secret thought or most fugitive wish fails of an echo so distant that the mind is for ever incapable of measuring the distance.
('36', 121, 1, 4, 243074) The social quality is not, in man, an adventitious or merelyaccessory quality: it is immanent, part of his humanity itself; he is a social being because he is a man.
('36', 121, 1, 5, 243240) There is no other field of our activity so truly our own: physiology and morality, economics and politics, the intellectual and aesthetic domains, the religious and the social, are all conditioned by a universal system of mysterious bonds and undefined relations.
('36', 121, 1, 6, 243504) The bond is so firm, the net so closely meshed, that sometimes the sociologist stands in real trouble before this immensity which unfolds itself before him, across all time and space; he measures in one glance how great, under certain circumstances, is the responsibility of the individual, and how he risks becoming petty by a liberty which some social circles might be tempted to grant him.
('36', 121, 2, 7, 243897) The author further says,
('36', 121, 3, 8, 243922) If we can say that under certain circumstances I am not at liberty to spit in the street .
('36', 121, 3, 9, 244013) how can I claim the much more important right of disposing of my sexual energy as I like?
('36', 121, 3, 10, 244103) Does that energy by a unique privilege escape the universal law of solidarity?
('36', 121, 3, 11, 244182) Who does not see, on the contrary, that the sovereign importance of the function only increases the social reaction of the individual acts?
('36', 121, 3, 12, 244322) Look at this young man and this girl who have just established that false union of which the reader knows the character; they are persuaded that the agreement concerns nobody but themselves.
('36', 121, 3, 13, 244513) They shut themselves up in their independence, and pretend to believe that their intimate and secret action has no interest for society and is altogether beyond its control.
('36', 121, 3, 14, 244687) A childish illusion!
('36', 121, 3, 15, 244708) The social solidarity which unites the people of one nation, and, beyond the individual nations, all humanity, finds no difficulty in passing through all walls, even those of the secret chambers, and a terrible interrelation joins that supposed private action to the most distant series of actions in that social life which it helps to disorganize.
('36', 121, 3, 16, 245057) Whether he wills it or not, every individual who asserts his right to temporary or sterile sexual relations, who claims the liberty to use the reproductive energy with which he is endowed merely for his own enjoyments, spreads in society the germs of division and disorder.
('36', 121, 3, 17, 245331) All, deformed as they are by our selfishness and our disloyalties, our social institutions still take for granted that the
('36', 122, 0, 1, 245454) VOL. 36: 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 123
('36', 122, 1, 2, 245498) individual will accept with goodwill the obligations inherent in the satisfaction of the reproductive appetite.
('36', 122, 1, 3, 245610) It is by discounting this acceptance that society has built up its countless mechanisms of labour and property, of wages and inheritance, of taxation and military service, of the right of parliamentary suffrage and civil liberties.
('36', 122, 1, 4, 245842) By his refusal to: take his share the individual disorganizes everything at one stroke, he violates the social pact in its very essence, and while he makes the burden heavier on others’ shoulder, he is no better thanan exploiter and a parasite, a thief and a swindler.
('36', 122, 1, 5, 246111) We are responsible in the face of society for our physiological energy, as for all our energies, and, it might be said, even more than for all the others, since a society unarmed and almost wholly without external pressure, is obliged to remit to our goodwill the care to use that energy judiciously, and conformably to the social good.
('36', 122, 2, 6, 246448) The author is equally strong on the psychological ground:

('36', 122, 3, 8, 246594) That is precisely its grandeur.

('36', 126, 4, 5, 255587) THE ASHRAM,

('36', 126, 6, 7, 255624) DEAR FRIEND, Whilst doing whatever I can to promote brotherly feelings amongst all the different nations, I am chary of belonging to any association which I do not know intimately.
('36', 126, 6, 8, 255805) An Asiatic Federation will be a federation of one physically strong race and other physically weak races.
('36', 126, 6, 9, 255911) Much though there is to admire in the Japanese progress, you will pardon me for saying that I am not enamoured of it.

('36', 126, 9, 14, 256383) 136. LETTER TO H. KALLENBACAH
('36', 126, 10, 15, 256413) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI,
('36', 126, 11, 16, 256436) JULY 29, 1926 Of course you rarely write to me and I do likewise.

('36', 141, 8, 17, 281408) 158. SIGNIFICANCE OF VOWS
('36', 141, 9, 18, 281434) A student writes: 2
('36', 141, 10, 19, 281454) Everyone is impelled sometimes to ask this question.
('36', 141, 10, 20, 281507) Nevertheless it is based on a misunderstanding.
('36', 141, 10, 21, 281555) A vow has the effect of raising us exactly because, in spite of it, there is a chance of our falling.
('36', 141, 10, 22, 281657) If there was no such danger, there would be no scope for striving.
('36', 141, 10, 23, 281724) A vow serves the same purpose as a lighthouse does.
('36', 141, 11, 24, 281776) 1 Last stage of meditation 2 The letter is not translated here.
('36', 141, 11, 25, 281840) Stating that he lacked firmness of mind, the correspondent had asked Gandhiji if there was any way by following which he would always be able to keep a vow.
('36', 142, 0, 1, 281997) VOL. 36: 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 143
('36', 142, 1, 2, 282041) If we keep our eyes fixed on it, we shall come safe through any storm.
('36', 142, 1, 3, 282112) The lighthouse itself cannot quieten the storm, yet it guides sailors caught in a storm and helps them to fight it, even so a vow is a kind of powerful force which saves a human being from the innumer able waves raging in the heart.
('36', 142, 1, 4, 282345) This being the case, no way has been found, or is likely to be found, by following which a person taking a vow can be assured that he will never fall.
('36', 142, 1, 5, 282496) And this is as it should be; otherwise the moral injunctions about truth and so on will lose the great value which is attached to them.
('36', 142, 1, 6, 282632) One has to exert oneself so much to acquire ordinary knowledge or raise a few lakhs of rupees for a fund.
('36', 142, 1, 7, 282738) There are many who do not mind risking their lives merely to be able to see a lifeless spot like the North Pole.
('36', 142, 1, 8, 282851) Why should we, then, wonder or be unhappy if we have to put in a thousand times more difficult effort in order to conquer our powerful foes such as anger, malice and so on.
('36', 142, 1, 9, 283024) Our success lies in the very struggle for this deathless glory.
('36', 142, 1, 10, 283088) The effort itself is victory.
('36', 142, 1, 11, 283118) If those who sail to the North Pole fail in their object, their effort may be considered to have been wasted, but every effort we make in our life to conquer these foes) attachment and aversion will have taken us forward.
('36', 142, 1, 12, 283340) Thus, no effort, however slight, towards such an end is ever wasted that is the Lord’s assurance.
('36', 142, 1, 13, 283438) 1 The only encouragement, therefore, which I can give this student is that he should go on striving and never lose heart.
('36', 142, 1, 14, 283560) He should never abandon the vow.
('36', 142, 1, 15, 283593) He should banish from his dictionary the word “impossible”.
('36', 142, 1, 16, 283653) If he forgets his vow at any time, he should do prayaschitta 2 and remind himself of the vow.
('36', 142, 1, 17, 283747) Every time he violates it, he should start again, and have complete confidence that he is bound at last to succeed.
('36', 142, 1, 18, 283863) No man of spiritual illumination has ever told us of his experience that untruth had ever triumphed; on the contrary every such person has unanimously proclaimed most emphatically his experience that in the end truth triumphs.
('36', 142, 1, 19, 284090) We should keep the experience of these persons in mind, and entertain no doubts of any kind when striving for a good end or be afraid to take a vow with a virtuous aim.
('36', 142, 1, 20, 284259) Pandit Rambhuj Datt Chaudhari has left us a poem in Punjabi with the following refrain: “Never accept defeat, though you lose your life.”
('36', 142, 2, 21, 284397) [From Gujarati]
('36', 142, 3, 22, 284413) Navajivan, 1 8 1926

('36', 144, 4, 9, 287656) 160. A CORRECTION
('36', 144, 5, 10, 287674) In the article captioned “Quality and Strength of Yam” which appeared in Navajivan of July 18, it was stated in the second paragraph that “the yarn received by the Mandal was from voluntary spinners”.
('36', 144, 5, 11, 287875) I had concluded this from the leaflet which I had received, but now I have come to know that the details given related to yarn produced by wage earners and not by voluntary spinners.
('36', 144, 5, 12, 288058) The reason why it is considered necessary to correct this misstatement is the fact that the yarn spun by wage earners is inferior in quality almost everywhere.
('36', 144, 5, 13, 288218) There has been unexpected improvement only in the quality of yarn produced by voluntary spinners, and that is but natural.
('36', 144, 5, 14, 288341) These spinners have a certain aim in spinning.
('36', 144, 5, 15, 288388) They feel sympathy for the poor, and that is why they take care to improve the quality of their yarn day by day.
('36', 144, 5, 16, 288501) Wage earners, on the other hand, neither have the foresight to understand their own interest nor the intelligence to learn the art of improving the quality and strength of yarn.
('36', 144, 5, 17, 288679) And, therefore, though they have been spinning for many years now, it will be a long time before they show improvement in their work.
('36', 144, 5, 18, 288813) Voluntary spinners, on the other hand, started spinning only recently, and yet they can make rapid progress if they but choose.
('36', 144, 5, 19, 288941) This is the great value of voluntary spinning and an argument to prove its necessity.
('36', 144, 5, 20, 289027) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 1 8 1926
('36', 144, 6, 21, 289063) 161. MENDICANT SADHUS
('36', 144, 7, 22, 289085) The term “mendicant” would perhaps be considered derogatory to the sadhus.
('36', 144, 7, 23, 289160) But in this age sadhus mean men in ochre robes, no matter whether their hearts are of that colour, whether
('36', 145, 0, 1, 289267) 146 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 145, 1, 2, 289309) straightforward or crooked.
('36', 145, 1, 3, 289337) Really speaking a sadhu means a person with a heart which is sadhu, pure.
('36', 145, 1, 4, 289411) But we hardly ever know such sadhus, whereas we come across ochre robed sadhus, and some who are the opposite of sadhus, even begging on the streets.
('36', 145, 1, 5, 289561) I have, therefore, used the term “mendicant”‘ to describe them.
('36', 145, 1, 6, 289625) A friend writes about them: 1
('36', 145, 2, 7, 289655) This is an excellent suggestion.
('36', 145, 2, 8, 289688) But who will respond to it?
('36', 145, 2, 9, 289716) To introduce the spinning wheel amongst mendicant sadhus is much more difficult than to introduce it among the poor.
('36', 145, 2, 10, 289833) It requires changing the religious beliefs of the people.
('36', 145, 2, 11, 289891) Today the well to do believe that when they have put some money in the bag of the poor they have done a charitable deed, something meritorious.
('36', 145, 2, 12, 290035) Who will explain to them that by doing this they do not serve but harm those whom they want to help, that, in the name of dharma, they support evil and encourage hypocrisy?
('36', 145, 2, 13, 290208) If the fifty six lakh mendicant sadhus in the country should be inspired with the spirit of service and decide to maintain themselves by working, the country would get an efficient army of volunteers.
('36', 145, 2, 14, 290409) It is almost impossible to explain this to the ochre robed sadhus who go about.
('36', 145, 2, 15, 290489) There are three types of characters among them.
('36', 145, 2, 16, 290537) A large majority of them are impostors who want a well fed do nothing life.
('36', 145, 2, 17, 290613) The second type are stupid people who believe that ochre robes and work go ill together.
('36', 145, 2, 18, 290702) The third type, which is a very small group, are men of genuine renunciation, but they are so bound by tradition that they feel that a sannyasi cannot work even to serve others.
('36', 145, 2, 19, 290880) If this small group realize the importance of working, realize that, whatever may have been the practice in the past, in the present age it is necessary for sannyasis to work, as an example to other people if for no other reason, we can manage the other two groups easily enough.
('36', 145, 2, 20, 291160) But it is very difficult to convince them of this point of view.
('36', 145, 2, 21, 291225) We shall succeed in the task if we work in patience; the sannyasis will understand the truth only through experience, thatis, when the spinning wheel comes to enjoy sover eignty in the country the sannyasis will submit to its rule.
('36', 145, 2, 22, 291457) Sovereignty of the spinning wheel means the sovereignty of love, and that means an awakening of the religious spirit.
('36', 145, 2, 23, 291575) When such an awakening takes place, this small group of sannyasis will not fail to recognize it.
('36', 145, 2, 24, 291672) It is, moreover, as difficult to convince the rich as it is to
('36', 145, 3, 25, 291735) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('36', 145, 3, 26, 291772) The correspondent had suggested that Gandhiji should invite mendicant sadhus to take up spinning.
('36', 146, 0, 1, 291870) VOL. 36: 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 147
('36', 146, 1, 2, 291914) convince the sannyasis.
('36', 146, 1, 3, 291938) If the former understand their dharma and stop encouraging idleness, give work and not food, to those who beg, the empire of the spinning wheel would be established right now.
('36', 146, 1, 4, 292114) But can we expect this from the rich?
('36', 146, 1, 5, 292152) The rich themselves are, by and large, somewhat at lazy; at any rate they encourage laziness.
('36', 146, 1, 6, 292246) Whether they know it or not, their cannot but encourage idle beggars.

('36', 146, 1, 8, 292438) I do not mean that we should make no effort in that direction because of the difficulty.
('36', 146, 1, 9, 292527) We should indeed go on working.

('36', 159, 6, 10, 316521) Gangadharrao Deshpande sends me regarding his khaddar activities a letter which I condense below: 1
('36', 159, 7, 11, 316621) The problem of inducing paid spinners to improve their yarn and weavers to take up hand spun yarn is causing difficulty every where.
('36', 159, 7, 12, 316754) Patience and perseverance combined with acquisition of scien tific knowledge about the methods of improving handspun yarn is the only remedy.
('36', 159, 7, 13, 316896) Weavers will readily take up hand spun yarn if it is even, strong and properly hanked.
('36', 159, 7, 14, 316983) They have no time for thinking of patriotism, all of their time being used up in keeping the wolf from the door.
('36', 159, 7, 15, 317096) They, therefore, seek the easiestwork.
('36', 159, 7, 16, 317135) And unless we make weaving of hand spun yarn as easy as that of mill spun, we must not expect many weavers to take it up.
('36', 159, 7, 17, 317257) The secret, therefore, lies in hand spun yarn being improved in quality.
('36', 159, 7, 18, 317330) And, this is only possible, when we have an army of expert voluntary spinners who know all about spinning, who know a good spinning wheel from bad, and who, having love for the semi starved spinners, will go to them, patiently reason with them and finally steel into their hearts, so as to induce the spinners to make the necessary improvement in their wheels and understand the method of drawing finer, stronger and more even yarn.
('36', 159, 7, 19, 317763) The thing is difficult.
('36', 159, 7, 20, 317787) It is not impossible.
('36', 159, 7, 21, 317809) But, the difficulty of the task and the extent it covers make it a matter of first class national importance.
('36', 159, 7, 22, 317919) And, as it admits of immediate returns, and therefore its accomplishment is within reach, it does not need unlimited capital.

('36', 160, 1, 2, 318347) 180. ‘TOWARDS MORAL BANKRUPTCY’ VI
('36', 160, 2, 3, 318382) After having insisted on chastity before and during marriage and shown by overwhelming proof that not only is self restraint not impossible, not harmful, but perfectly possible and wholly beneficial both to the mind and the body, M. Bureau devotes a chapter to the value and possibility of perpetual continence.
('36', 160, 2, 4, 318694) The following opening paragraph is worth reproducing:
('36', 160, 3, 5, 318748) In the first rank of these liberators, these heroes of the true sexual emancipation, it is only right to name the young men and women who, the better to devote themselves to the service of a great cause, choose to remain all their life in chastity, and renounce the joys of marriage.
('36', 160, 3, 6, 319032) The reasons for their resolve vary according to circumstances: one feels it a duty to remain with an infirm father or mother; another takes the place, to orphaned brother and sisters, of the departed parents; another desires to devote himself or herself entirely to the service of science or art, of the poor or the sick, or to a work of moral education or of prayer.
('36', 160, 3, 7, 319400) Similarly, the merit of the voluntary sacrifice may be greater or less; some, thanks to the benefits of a wise protective education and the practice of a good moral hygiene, are almost without sensual temptations; other, more advanced in the path of virtue, have succeeded, it may be at the cost of sharp conflicts of which they alone know the hardness, in mastering the beast and taming the flesh.
('36', 160, 3, 8, 319799) On any supposition, the final resolve is the same: the men and women have been led to think that the best way for them to serve is not to marry; and they have entered into an engagement, it may be with themselves, it may be with God, to remain in the perfect chastity of the celibate life.
('36', 160, 3, 9, 320089) However definite and undoubted may be the duty of marriage, as we shall see under certain circumstances, all these resolutions are legitimate, because they are inspired by a noble and generous purpose.” Painting is a jealous mistress who suffers no rival,” replied Michael Angelo when marriage was suggested to him; and how many after him have had a like experience!
('36', 160, 4, 10, 320456) I can corroborate this testimony from the experience of European friends of almost every description given by M. Bureau, friends who exercised perpetual restraint.
('36', 160, 4, 11, 320620) It is only in India that from childhood we must hear of marriages.
('36', 160, 4, 12, 320687) Parents have no other thought, no other ambition save that of seeing their children well married and provided for.
('36', 160, 4, 13, 320802) The one thing brings premature decay of mind and body and the other induces idleness and often makes of one a parasite; We exaggerate the difficulty of chastity and voluntary poverty and impute extraordinary merit to them, reserve them for
('36', 161, 0, 1, 321042) 162 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 161, 1, 2, 321084) mahatmas and yogis and rule the latter out of ordinary life, forgetting that real mahatmaship and yoga are unthinkable in a society where the ordinary level is brought down to the mudbank.
('36', 161, 1, 3, 321273) On the principle that evil, like the hare, travels faster than good which like the tortoise, though steady, goes slow, voluptuousness of the West comes to us with lightning speed and with all its variegated enchantment dazzles and blinds us to the realities of life.
('36', 161, 1, 4, 321540) We are almost ashamed of chastity and are in danger of looking upon self imposed poverty as a crime in the fate of the Western splendour that descends upon us from minute to minute through the cable and day to day through the steamers that discharge their cargo on our shores.
('36', 161, 1, 5, 321817) But the West is not wholly what we see in India.
('36', 161, 1, 6, 321866) Even as the South African Whites ill judge us when they judge us through the Indian settlers, so shall we ill judge the West through the human and the other western cargo that delivers itself to us every day.
('36', 161, 1, 7, 322075) There is in the West a small but inexhaustible reservoir of purity and strength which those who have eyes of penetration may see beneath the deceptive surface.
('36', 161, 1, 8, 322235) Throughout the European desert there are oases from which those who will may drink the purest water of life.
('36', 161, 1, 9, 322344) Chastity and voluntary poverty are adopted without brag, without bluster, and in all humility by hundreds of men and women, often for no other than the allsufficing cause of service of some dear one or of the country.
('36', 161, 1, 10, 322562) We often prate about spirituality as if it had nothing to do with the ordinary affairs of life and had been reserved for anchoriteslost in the Himalayan forests or concealed in some inaccessible Himalayan cave.
('36', 161, 1, 11, 322773) Spirituality that has no bearing on and produces no effect on everyday life is ‘an airy nothing’.
('36', 161, 1, 12, 322871) Let young men and women for whose sake Young India is written from week to week know that it is their duty if they would purify the atmosphere about them and shed their weakness, to be and remain chaste and know too that it is not so difficult as they have been taught to imagine.
('36', 161, 2, 13, 323152) Let us further listen to M. Bureau:
('36', 161, 3, 14, 323188) In proportion as it (modern sociology) follows the evolution of our manners, and as methodical study digs more deeply the soil of social realities, the better is the value perceived of the help which the practice of perpetual chastity brings to the great work of the discipline of the senses.
('36', 161, 3, 15, 323481) If marri age is the normal state of life for the immense majority of people, it cannot be that all can, or ought to marry.
('36', 161, 3, 16, 323604) Even putting aside the exceptional vocations of which we have just spoken, there are at least three classes of celibates who cannot be blamed for not being married: the young people of both sexes who
('36', 162, 0, 1, 323804) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 163
('36', 162, 1, 2, 323849) for professional or economic reasons think it a duty to defer their marriage; the people who are involuntarily condemned to celibacy because they cannot find a suitable partner; finally, those who ought to abstain from marriage in consequence of their physiological defects that could be transmitted, and in some who are strictly bound to renounce all idea of it.
('36', 162, 1, 3, 324213) Is it not evident, then, that the renunciation made by these people, doubly necessary both for their own happiness and the interests of society, will be rendered so much the less painful and so much the more cheerful, because they will find beside them others who, in full possession of their physical and intellectual vigour and sometimes with abundant means have declared their firm resolution to remain celibate all their lives?
('36', 162, 1, 4, 324645) These voluntary and choice celibates, who have willed to consecrate themselves to God without reserve, to prayer and to the training of the souls, declare that in their eyes celibacy, far from being a reduced condition of life, is on the contrary a superior state, in which man asserts, in its plenitude, the mastery of the will over instinct.
('36', 162, 1, 5, 324989) The author says:
('36', 162, 2, 6, 325006) To young people of both the sexes, who are still too young to marry perpetual cilibacy shows that it is possible to pass one’s youth chastely; to the married it recalls the duty which lies upon them to maintain exact discipline in their conjugal discipline and never to allow a consideration of self interest however legitimate it be in itself, to prevail over the higher demands of moral generosity.
('36', 162, 2, 7, 325407) Foerster says:
('36', 162, 3, 8, 325422) The vow of the voluntary celibate far from degrading marriage, is on the contrary the best support of the sanctity of the conjugal bond, since it represents in a concrete form man’s freedom in the face of the pressure of his nature.
('36', 162, 3, 9, 325655) It acts like a conscience with regard to passing whims and sensual assault.
('36', 162, 3, 10, 325731) Celibacy is also a protection to marriage in the sense that its existence prevents married people from looking upon themselves in their mutual relations as mere slaves to obscure natural forces, and it leads them to take openly in the face of nature, the position of free beings who are capable of mastery.
('36', 162, 3, 11, 326038) Those who scoff at perpetual celibacy as unnatural or impossible do not know really what they are doing.
('36', 162, 3, 12, 326143) They fail to see that the line of thought which makes them talk as they do must necessarily lead, by strict logic, to prostitution and polygamy.
('36', 162, 3, 13, 326288) If the demand of nature is irresistible, how can a chaste life be required of married people?
('36', 162, 3, 14, 326382) And lastly, they forget the great number of marriages in which, it may be for several months or years, or even for life, one of the spouses is condemned to a real celibacy by the sickness or other disability of the partner.
('36', 162, 3, 15, 326606) For this reason alone, true monogamy rises or falls with the esteem that is paid to celibacy.

('36', 166, 1, 2, 332305) 183. LETTER TO DHIRENDRA CHANDRA LATIRY
('36', 166, 2, 3, 332345) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, August 5, 1926
('36', 166, 3, 4, 332383) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('36', 166, 3, 5, 332416) Here are my answers to your questions: (1) The aim of life should be self purification.
('36', 166, 3, 6, 332504) (2) The voidness of life is removed by filling it with self less service.
('36', 166, 3, 7, 332578) (3) Every wrong must carry its penalty.
('36', 166, 3, 8, 332618) But when a person attains sinlessness, there is no consciousness of penalty because there is no consciousness of person sinned.
('36', 166, 3, 9, 332746) You have to cease to think of the girl you have wronged and, that you will do when you appreciate the measure of the wrong and understand that she must be in the place of a blood sister.
('36', 166, 3, 10, 332933) (4) In any case, there must be no thought of marriage so long as you think of the girl.
('36', 166, 3, 11, 333021) (5) Selfishness can only be removed by devoted service of others without any expectations of reward.
('36', 166, 3, 12, 333122) (6) Animal passion can be restrained by realizing that we are men and not brutes.
('36', 166, 3, 13, 333204) We are men destined to control our passions because we have outlived the mere animal life.
('36', 166, 3, 14, 333295) (7) Concentration comes by devoting oneself to some single pure act of service.
('36', 166, 3, 15, 333375) (8) One can learn to endure sorrows and [mis]fortunes by realizing that these are the common lot of all mortals.
('36', 166, 3, 16, 333488) The wonder is that we have few[er] than many others.
('36', 166, 4, 17, 333541) Yours sincerely,
('36', 166, 5, 18, 333558) DHIRENDRA CHANDRA LATIRY C/O SAILENDRA NATH LATIRY, ESQ.

('36', 174, 3, 19, 345578) It is available in the form of powder and can safely be taken in place of fresh milk.
('36', 174, 3, 20, 345664) Besides, the worst coming to the worst, if the goat dies one day through an accident, the Horlicks bottle breaks and the contents of the Nestle tin turn out to be bad, you can certainly live on fruit on that day.

('36', 176, 7, 15, 348118) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, Tuesday, August 7, 1926
('36', 176, 8, 16, 348165) BHAISHRI JUGAL KISHORE, I have your letter.
('36', 176, 8, 17, 348209) You will have seen what I have said about the Bible in Young India.
('36', 176, 8, 18, 348277) You ought to be satisfied.
('36', 176, 8, 19, 348304) I have also seen what is said in the Vishwamitra.
('36', 176, 8, 20, 348354) I shall only say that if the children have to be taught the Bible, it had better be done by me.
('36', 176, 8, 21, 348450) If they are taught by me they shall get but one thing, viz., Ramanama, which is the essence of all religions.
('36', 176, 8, 22, 348560) If people abuse what I say or do, it cannot harm me or my principles.
('36', 176, 8, 23, 348630) How can truth be abused?
('36', 176, 8, 24, 348655) Its abuse turns into its right use.
('36', 176, 8, 25, 348691) That is why truth is given the highest place in the Upanishads.

('36', 177, 1, 2, 349016) 200. BULLOCK v.
('36', 177, 2, 3, 349032) Kaka Saheb writes: 1
('36', 177, 3, 4, 349053) Kaka Saheb’s argument deserves serious attention, especially these days when, almost every week, Navajivan carries an article on the best means of protecting cows.
('36', 177, 3, 5, 349217) Just as, if we stop consuming milk, however hard we strike in the cause of cow protection, people will never respond to our efforts, so also, if we stop utilizing the services of bullocks for agricultural and other purposes, it will be impossible to protect them.
('36', 177, 3, 6, 349481) No person in this world has found it possible to maintain something which is a source of constant economic loss.
('36', 177, 3, 7, 349594) That is why I have many times suggested that if dharma and economic interests cannot be reconciled, either the conception of that dharma is false or the economic interest takes the form of unmitigated selfishness, and does not aim at collective welfare.
('36', 177, 3, 8, 349848) True dharma always promotes legitimate economic pursuits.
('36', 177, 3, 9, 349906) For imperfect man, this is a fine test of whether what purports to be dharma is true dharma.
('36', 177, 3, 10, 349999) In big cities cows and buffaloes have become a burden from the point of view of general economy and that is why their slaughter is increasing day by day.
('36', 177, 3, 11, 350153) If we do not know the right use of cows and buffaloes in big cities, do what we will, we shall never be able to save them—let no one have any doubt about this.
('36', 177, 3, 12, 350313) At the moment it seems that we have reached a stage when we simply cannot do without railways.
('36', 177, 3, 13, 350408) If, however, we realize that railways have not been on the whole a blessing to the country we can restrict their use when we get power.
('36', 177, 3, 14, 350544) Similarly, even if we cannot banish the motor car altogether, we must limit the sphere of its use.
('36', 177, 3, 15, 350643) Everyone should feel that we simply cannot have our fields ploughed by machine and leave the bullocks entirely at the mercy of human beings.
('36', 177, 3, 16, 350784) The economic structure of the country will be worthy of our admiration and will endure only if it is in keeping with the conditions in the country.
('36', 177, 3, 17, 350932) Our wisdom and our culture will be judged from our ability to plan an economy which takes into account the conditions prevailing in the country.

('36', 177, 5, 19, 351093) Navajivan, 8 8 1926

('36', 178, 1, 2, 351430) 201. NATIONAL SCHOOLS
('36', 178, 2, 3, 351452) An experienced worker writes: 1
('36', 178, 3, 4, 351484) Let us first examine the analogy of the snake bite before considering the argument advanced.
('36', 178, 3, 5, 351577) An analogy is always a little dangerous because two things are rarely, if ever, similar in all respects.
('36', 178, 3, 6, 351682) And if there is absence of similarity in the essentials, the analogy cannot hold and becomes misleading.
('36', 178, 3, 7, 351787) In snake bite, there is hope of revival, the doctor has not declared the person dead; and if the body is cremated there can be no question of removing the poison.
('36', 178, 3, 8, 351950) Therefore it is sometimes considered advisable to keep the body for two or three days for we do not have the power to recreate a body which has been burnt.
('36', 178, 3, 9, 352106) But in the case of the so called national school which I want should either be reformed or closed down, there will not be any of these three considerations to be taken into account, that is to say, there will be no possibility of its acquiring a national character.
('36', 178, 3, 10, 352372) It is desirable that a school which has been pronounced dead after examination by a doctor and which being the creation of man can be revived, should be closed down.
('36', 178, 3, 11, 352538) The continuance of these schools results in the spread of falsehood among us; money collected in the name of national schools is spent on these pseudo national schools which is a betrayal of the trust of the donors; and the true national schools suffer in the estimation of the people because they are led to judge them from what they see in these pseudo national schools.
('36', 178, 3, 12, 352911) Those who collect funds for them lose their credit and money being received in the name of national schools stops coming in.
('36', 178, 3, 13, 353036) If there are to be such undesirable results, it is better to take up a real national school, however small, and concentrate all our attention on it to make it a success.
('36', 178, 3, 14, 353206) It would behove us and there will be truth and practical sense in it.
('36', 178, 3, 15, 353276) Just as no construction work is possible out of bricks made of sand spice together somehow, and if we continue with it there is greater burden and loss, an increase in the number of these so called national schools merely adds to our burden and harms our cause.
('36', 178, 3, 16, 353538) In the event of tide we can easily multiply the number of national schools even if there is only one true national school.
('36', 178, 3, 17, 353661) But to produce anything good from a large number of schools national in name only
('36', 178, 4, 18, 353743) 1The letter is not translated here.
('36', 178, 4, 19, 353779) The correspondent, while agreeing that the national schools which fell short of the ideal should be closed down, had argued that they should not be closed down merely on account of the hostility of parents.
('36', 179, 0, 1, 353986) 180 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 179, 1, 2, 354028) is an utter impossibility.
('36', 179, 1, 3, 354055) Not only that, if the need for national schools does arise at some future date, the first thing we shall have to do then will be to try to put an end to these pseudo national schools.
('36', 179, 2, 4, 354239) Therefore where either the parents or the teachers are opposed to the national ideal, the national school should certainly be closed down.
('36', 179, 2, 5, 354378) Where the parents are fired by national ideals and prove their feelings by giving adequate donations for the support of national schools, and, where the teachers being themselves believers in the national ideal are ceaselessly striving to enforce it, I can understand a relaxation of the discipline if the scholars are lukewarm about the ideal.
('36', 179, 2, 6, 354723) In such a case, it may be necessary to continue the school.
('36', 179, 2, 7, 354783) For we may hope some day to influence the scholars.
('36', 179, 2, 8, 354835) But at the time of writing these lines, I can think of no such school.
('36', 179, 3, 9, 354906) My own experience is that where the national ideal is found wanting, the fault lies at the door of the teacher.
('36', 179, 3, 10, 355018) The instance quoted is that of a school where the teachers are enthusiastic, the pupils indifferent and the parents hostile.
('36', 179, 3, 11, 355143) Where the parents object to their children learning hand spinning and wearing khadi and threaten to withdraw their children if untouchable children are admitted, I see nothing but waste of the people’s time and loss of self respect for a teacher to carry on his work.
('36', 179, 3, 12, 355411) If we conduct national schools in spite of the opposition of parents, we would be guilty of the same fault that we impute to the Christian missionaries.
('36', 179, 3, 13, 355564) We have no right to impart instruction to children against the wish of their parents and to create family dissensions.
('36', 179, 3, 14, 355683) Those pupils who are over 16 years of age and who understand their interest, who are capable of suffering hardships, do not stand in need of protection: They have become self reliant.
('36', 179, 3, 15, 355867) For such, wherever necessary, we should open schools and undoubtedly conduct the existing ones.
('36', 179, 3, 16, 355963) But do we have such pupils anywhere in India?
('36', 179, 3, 17, 356009) How many are they?
('36', 179, 3, 18, 356028) And where are the schools in which there are students who can be likened to godly, fearless, long suffering and yet wise and respectful Prahlad?
('36', 179, 3, 19, 356173) When myriads of such scholars are produced, India will overflow with new life and no one will want to know where swaraj is.
('36', 179, 4, 20, 356297) And in order to produce a harvest of such scholars, we need to conduct only true national schools even though they may have only a few scholars.
('36', 179, 4, 21, 356442) Where parents feel that they are obliging the teachers by
('36', 179, 5, 22, 356500) 1 This paragraph is taken from Young India, 2 9 1926.
('36', 180, 0, 1, 356554) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 181

('36', 180, 1, 3, 356919) We have now understood what non co operation is.
('36', 180, 1, 4, 356968) We are in a position to appraise its value.
('36', 180, 1, 5, 357012) The people are not ignorant of its dangers.
