('36', 183, 12, 25, 363389) 208. JUSTICE FROM SIX THOUSAND MILES
('36', 183, 13, 26, 363426) No conquest by force of arms is worth treasuring if it is not followed by cultural conquest, if the conquered do not hug their
('36', 184, 0, 1, 363553) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 185
('36', 184, 1, 2, 363598) chains and regard the conqueror as their benefactor.
('36', 184, 1, 3, 363651) The different forts of India are no doubt a continuous reminder of the British might.
('36', 184, 1, 4, 363737) But the silent conquest of the mind of educated India is a surer guarantee of British stability than the formidable forts, i.e., if the opinion expressed by the distinguished lawyers in Indian Daily Mail on the very modest proposal of Sir Hari Singh Gour for the establishment of a Supreme Court at Delhi is an index of that mind.
('36', 184, 1, 5, 364068) For, these eminent lawyers regard the proposal as premature, in that judgments of the Privy Council sitting six thousand miles away from India would command, in their opinion, greater respect and ensure greater impartiality.
('36', 184, 1, 6, 364293) This amazing opinion, I venture to say, has no foundation in fact.
('36', 184, 1, 7, 364360) But distance lends enchantment to the scene.
('36', 184, 1, 8, 364405) Members of the Privy Council are, after all, human beings.
('36', 184, 1, 9, 364464) They have been found to betray political bias.
('36', 184, 1, 10, 364511) Their decisions in cases involving questions of custom are often distortions of the reality, not because they are perverse, but because it is not possible for mortals to know everything.
('36', 184, 1, 11, 364698) A less trained lawyer having a direct knowledge of a local custom is better able to appraise evidence on it than those who, no matter what their attainments are, know nothing of local conditions.
('36', 184, 2, 12, 364894) The distinguished lawyers moreover state that expenses will not be less because the final court of appeal is brought down to Delhi.
('36', 184, 2, 13, 365026) It does not say much for the patriotism of these eminent gentlemen, if they mean that the fees should be on the same scale in poor India as in rich England.
('36', 184, 2, 14, 365183) A Scotch friend once told me that Englishmen were probably the most extravagant in the world in their tastes and requirements.
('36', 184, 2, 15, 365310) He told me that hospitals in Scotland were far less expensively fitted than in England, though they were in no way inferior in usefulness to those in England.
('36', 184, 2, 16, 365469) Or does a legal argument increase in weight with an increase in the fees charged?
('36', 184, 3, 17, 365551) The third argument pressed into service in order to oppose the proposed change is that Indian judges will not command the same weight as the wigged ones in White Hall.
('36', 184, 3, 18, 365719) If this was not an argument advanced by distinguished lawyers, it would be laughed out.
('36', 184, 3, 19, 365807) Is respect for judgments commended by their impartiality, or thelocation, or the birth, or the colour of the skin, of judges?
('36', 184, 3, 20, 365933) And if it is the seat or the birth or the pigment that determines the weight to be attached to judges’ decisions, is it not high time that the superstition was removed by removing the seat and appointing judges of Indian birth?
('36', 184, 3, 21, 366161) Or does the argument presuppose partiality on the part of
('36', 185, 0, 1, 366219) 186 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 185, 1, 2, 366261) judges of Indian birth?
('36', 185, 1, 3, 366285) One does sometimes hear of poor people under stress of ignorance desiring an English Collector in the place of an Indian.
('36', 185, 1, 4, 366407) But greater fearlessness and sanity are surely to be expected of experienced lawyers.
('36', 185, 1, 5, 366493) But while, in my humble opinion, none of the three arguments advanced against the proposal has any force, the deciding reason for having our Supreme Court in India is that our self respect demands it.
('36', 185, 1, 6, 366694) Just as we cannot breathe with other’s lungs, be they ever so much more powerful, so may we not borrow or buy justice from England.
('36', 185, 1, 7, 366826) We must take pride in being satisfied with the work our own judges may give us.
('36', 185, 1, 8, 366906) Trials by jury often result, all over the world, in defeating justice.
('36', 185, 1, 9, 366977) But people everywhere gladly submit to the drawback for the sake of the more important result of the cultivation of an independent spirit among people and the justifiable sentiment of being judged by one’s own peers.
('36', 185, 1, 10, 367194) But sentiment is at a discount in legal circles.
('36', 185, 1, 11, 367243) And yet it is sentiment that rules the world.
('36', 185, 1, 12, 367289) Economics and every other consideration is often flung to the winds when sentiment predo minates.
('36', 185, 1, 13, 367387) Sentiment can be and must be regulated.
('36', 185, 1, 14, 367427) It cannot be, ought never to be, eradicated.
('36', 185, 1, 15, 367472) If it is not wrong to cherish patriotic feeling, it is surely not wrong to remove the final court of appeal to Delhi.
('36', 185, 1, 16, 367590) Just as good government is no substitute for self government, good justice, if foreign, is no substitute for homemade justice.
('36', 185, 2, 17, 367717) Young India, 12 8 1926

('36', 186, 1, 2, 368534) 210. ‘TOWARDS MORAL BANKRUPTCY’ VII
('36', 186, 2, 3, 368570) The chapter on perpetual continence is followed by chapters on the duty and indissolubility of marriage.
('36', 186, 2, 4, 368675) Whilst the author contends that perpetual continence is the highest state, it is not possible for the multitude for whom marriage must be regarded as a duty.
('36', 186, 2, 5, 368833) He shows if the function and limitations of marriage are rightly understood, there never can be any advocacy of contraceptives.
('36', 186, 2, 6, 368961) It is the wrong moral training that has brought about the prevalent moral indiscipline.
('36', 186, 2, 7, 369049) Having dealt with the opinion of ‘advanced’ writers ridiculing marriage the author says:
('36', 186, 3, 8, 369138) Happily for future generations, this opinion of pseudo moralists and of writers who are often utterly lacking in moral sense, and equally so sometimes in the real literary spirit, is very far from being that of the true psychologists and sociologists of our time; and in nothing is the rupture more complete between the noisy world of the press, the novel, and the stage, and that other world where thought is cultivated, and the mysterious elements of our psychological and social life are studied in detail.
('36', 186, 3, 9, 369648) M. Bureau rejects the argument of free love.
('36', 186, 3, 10, 369693) He holds that” marriage is the union of man and woman, the association for life, the communication of divine and human rights of law”.
('36', 186, 3, 11, 369828) Marriage is not a ‘‘mere civil contract” but a sacrament, a ‘‘moral obligation”.
('36', 186, 3, 12, 369909) It has succeeded in” making the gorilla stand erect”.
('36', 186, 4, 13, 369963) It is a great mistake to imagine that everything is permissible to those lawfully married and even supposing that husband and wife ordinarily respect the moral law as to transmission of life, it is untrue that it is lawful to add
('36', 186, 5, 14, 370193) other modes of sexual intercourse which please them.

('36', 187, 1, 2, 371139) The author then combats the theory of individual liberty to contract or break the marriage bond at will or to live frankly a life of indulgence without its consequent obligation.
('36', 187, 1, 3, 371318) He insists on mono gamy and says:
('36', 187, 2, 4, 371352) It is untrue that the individual is at liberty to contract marriage or to remain in selfish celibacy, as he pleases; still less are duly married people free to agree together to the rupture of their union.
('36', 187, 2, 5, 371558) Their freedom is shown when they choose each other, and each is bound to choose only with full knowledge, after careful thought, the one with whom he believes he can assume the responsibilities of the new life he is entering.
('36', 187, 2, 6, 371784) But as soon as the marriage has been accomplished and consummated, the act performed involves, far away and in all directions, incalculable consequences which extend infinitely beyond the two persons’ who have brought them about.
('36', 187, 2, 7, 372014) These consequences may be unperceived, in a time of anarchic individualism such as ours, by the spouses themselves, but their importance is certified by the grave sufferings which come upon the whole body social, as soon as the stability of the home is shaken, as soon as the variable caprice of the sensual appetite takes the place of the beneficent discipline of the positive monogamic union.
('36', 187, 2, 8, 372409) To one who is conscious of these indefinitely extended repercussions and these subtle connections, it matters little to know that, since all human institutions are subject to the universal law of evolution, that of marriage must certainly, like all the rest, undergo in its turn necessary transformations, since there can be no doubt that progress in this direction can only take the form of eventually drawing more closely the marriage bond.
('36', 187, 2, 9, 372852) The attacks now made on the rule of the indissolubility of marriage” when divorce is asked for by mutual consent” will only bring into more prominent relief the social value of a rule against which protest is made, and as the years roll by this rule, which for some centuries, when its social value could not yet be appreciated, was simply a prescription of religious discipline, will appear more and more as a principle as beneficial to the individual as it is salutary for society at large.
('36', 187, 3, 10, 373345) The rule of indissolubility is not an arbitrary adornment; on the contrary, it is bound up with the most delicate mechanism of the individualand collective social life; and since people talk about evolution, they should ask on what condition this indefinite progress of the race which all agree to desire, is possible.
('36', 187, 3, 11, 373664) The deepening of the sense of responsibility, the training of the individual towards autonomous discipline willingly consented to, the growth of patience and charity, the control of selfishness, the maintenance of the emotional life against the elements that make for dissolution and the impulse of passing caprice—all these are dements in man’s interior life which we are entitled to consider the absolute and permanent conditions of all higher social
('36', 188, 0, 1, 374117) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 189
('36', 188, 1, 2, 374162) culture, and on this account exempt from all such disorder as might result from a serious change in economic conditions.
('36', 188, 1, 3, 374283) To tell the truth, economic progress is itself closely bound up with general social progress, for economic security and success depend in the long run on the sincerity and loyalty of our social co operation.
('36', 188, 1, 4, 374491) Every economic modification which ignores these fundamental conditions is self condemned.
('36', 188, 1, 5, 374581) If we wish, therefore, to take up the study, at once both moral and social, of the absolute value of the various methods of sexual relations, the following question is decisive: What method is the best adapted to the deepening and strengthening of our whole social life?
('36', 188, 1, 6, 374852) Which is the most capable, at the different periods of life, of developing to the utmost the sense of responsibility, self abnegation and sacrifice, of most effectively restraining undisciplined selfishness and capricious frivolity?

('36', 189, 1, 2, 377017) 211. TRIUMPH OF CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE
('36', 189, 2, 3, 377052) Pundit Malaviyaji’s triumph is a national victory.
('36', 189, 2, 4, 377103) Disrupted and demoralized though we are at the present moment, Punditji has shown that there is still courage left in us to defy the might of the mightiest empire.
('36', 189, 2, 5, 377267) To have issued notice light heartedly against one of the oldest and most respected and best known of India’s public servants was an insolent exhibition of power.

('36', 189, 2, 7, 377608) It was still wrong to have dealt summarily with a man of Punditji’s position in the Indian world.

('36', 189, 2, 9, 378033) In every one of his public speeches Punditji has put emphasis upon the desirability of peace.
('36', 189, 2, 10, 378127) But the Government is too disdainful of public opinion even to think of any such courteous action.
('36', 189, 2, 11, 378226) It expected Punditji and Dr. Moonje to take the order with due and humble submission.

('36', 209, 4, 6, 414329) 238. ‘TOWARDS MORAL BANKRUPTCY’ VIII
('36', 209, 5, 7, 414366) It is now time to conclude this series of articles.
('36', 209, 5, 8, 414418) It is not necessary to pursue M. Bureau in his examination of the doctrine of Malthus who startled his generation by his theory of over population and his advocacy of birth control if the human species was not to be extinct.
('36', 209, 5, 9, 414643) Malthus, however, advocated continence, whereas Neo Malthusianism advocates not restraint but the use of chemical and mechanical means to avoid the consequences of animal indulgence.
('36', 209, 5, 10, 414826) M. Bureau heartily accepts the doctrine of birth control by moral means, i.e., self restraint, and, as we have seen, rejects and vigorously condemns the use of chemical or mechanical means.
('36', 209, 5, 11, 415016) The author then examines the condition of working classes and the proportion of birth among them and finally closes the book by examining the means of checking the practice of grossest immoralities under the name of individual freedom and even humanity.
('36', 209, 5, 12, 415270) He suggests organized attempt to guide and regulate the public opinion and advocates State interference, but finally relies upon quickening of the religious life.
('36', 209, 5, 13, 415433) Moral bankruptcy cannot be met or arrested by ordinary methods, most certainly not when immorality is claimed as a virtue and morality condemned as a weakness, superstition or even immorality.
('36', 209, 5, 14, 415626) For many advocates of contraceptives do indeed condemn continence as unnecessary and even harmful.
('36', 209, 5, 15, 415725) In this state of things religious aid is the only effective check upon licensed vice.
('36', 209, 5, 16, 415811) Religion here may not be taken in its narrow, parochial sense.
('36', 209, 5, 17, 415874) True religion is the greatest disturbing factor in life, whether individual or collective.
('36', 209, 5, 18, 415965) A religious awakening constitutes a revolution, a transformation, a regeneration.
('36', 209, 5, 19, 416047) And nothing but some such dynamic force can positively prevent the moral catastrophe towards which, in M. Bureau’s estimation, France seems to be moving.
('36', 209, 5, 20, 416201) But we must here leave the author and his book; French conditions are not Indian conditions.
('36', 209, 5, 21, 416294) Ours is a somewhat different
('36', 210, 0, 1, 416323) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 211
('36', 210, 1, 2, 416368) problem.
('36', 210, 1, 3, 416377) Contraceptives are not universal in India.
('36', 210, 1, 4, 416420) Their use has hardly touched the educated classes.
('36', 210, 1, 5, 416471) The use of contraceptives in India is, in my opinion, unwarranted by any single condition that can be named.
('36', 210, 1, 6, 416580) Do middle class parents suffer from too many children?
('36', 210, 1, 7, 416635) Individual instances will not suffice to make out a case for excessive birth rate among the middle classes.
('36', 210, 1, 8, 416743) The cases in India where I haveobserved the advocacy of these methods are those of widows and young wives.
('36', 210, 1, 9, 416850) Thus in the one case it is illegitimate birth that is to be avoided, not the secret intercourse.
('36', 210, 1, 10, 416947) In the other, it is again pregnancy that is to be feared, and not the rape, of a girl of tender age.
('36', 210, 1, 11, 417048) Then there remains the class of diseased weak effeminate young men who would indulge in excesses with their own wives or others’ wives and would avoid the consequences of acts which they know to be sinful.
('36', 210, 1, 12, 417254) The cases of men or women in full vigour of life desiring intercourse and yet wishing to avoid the burden of children are, I make bold to say, rare in this ocean of Indian humanity.
('36', 210, 1, 13, 417436) Let them not parade their cases to justify and advocate a practice that in India, if it became general, is bound to ruin the youth of the country.
('36', 210, 1, 14, 417583) A highly artificial education has robbed the nation’s youth of physical and mental vigour.
('36', 210, 1, 15, 417674) We are offspring in many cases of child marriages.
('36', 210, 1, 16, 417725) Our disregard of the laws of health and sanitation has undermined our bodies.
('36', 210, 1, 17, 417803) Our wrong and deficient dietary composed of corroding spices has produced a collapse of the digestive apparatus.
('36', 210, 1, 18, 417916) We need, not lessons in the use of contraceptives and helps to our being able to satisfy our animal appetite, but continuous lessons to restrain that appetite, in many cases even to the extent of absolute continence.
('36', 210, 1, 19, 418133) We need to be taught by precept and example that continence is perfectly possible and imperatively necessary if we are not to remain mentally and physically weak.
('36', 210, 1, 20, 418296) We need to be told from the housetop that if we will not be a nation of manikins, we must conserve and add to the limited vital energy we are daily dissipating.
('36', 210, 1, 21, 418457) Our young widows need to be told not to sin secretly but come out boldly and openly to demand marriage which is their right as much as that of young widowers.
('36', 210, 1, 22, 418616) We need to cultivate public opinion that shall make child marriages impossible.
('36', 210, 1, 23, 418696) The vacillation, and the disinclination to do hard and sustained work, the physical inability to perform strenuous labours, collapses of enterprises brilliantly begun, the want of origina lity, one notices so often, are due largely to excessive indulgence.
('36', 210, 1, 24, 418953) I hope young men do not deceive themselves into the belief that, when there is no procreation, the mere indulgence does not matter, does not
('36', 211, 0, 1, 419094) 212 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 211, 1, 2, 419136) weaken.
('36', 211, 1, 3, 419144) Indeed the sexual act, with the unnatural safeguard against procreation, is likely to be far more exhausting than such act performed with a full sense of the responsibility attached to it.
('36', 211, 2, 4, 419333) The mind is its own place, and in itself
('36', 211, 3, 5, 419374) Can make a heaven of hell, a hell of heaven.
('36', 211, 3, 6, 419419) If we begin to believe that indulgence in animal passion is necessary, harmless and sinless, we shall want to give reins to it and shall be powerless to resist it.
('36', 211, 3, 7, 419583) Whereas, if we educate ourselves to believe that such indulgence is harmful, sinful, unnecessary and can be controlled, we shall discover that self restraint is perfectly possible.
('36', 211, 3, 8, 419764) Let us beware of the strong wine of libertinism that the intoxicated West sends us under the guise of new truth and so called human freedom.
('36', 211, 3, 9, 419905) Let us, on the contrary, listen to the sober voice from the West, that through the rich experience of its wise men at times percolates to us, i.e., if we have outgrown the ancient wisdom of our forefathers.
('36', 211, 4, 10, 420112) Charlie Andrews has sent me an informing article on” Genera tion and Regeneration” written by William Loftus Hare and printed in The Open Court (March 1926).
('36', 211, 4, 11, 420270) It is a closely reasoned scientific essay.
('36', 211, 4, 12, 420313) He shows that all bodies perform two functions: ‘namely, internal reproduction for the building up of the body and external reproduction for the continuance of the species.’ These processes he names regeneration and generation, respectively.
('36', 211, 5, 13, 420555) The regenerative process—internal reproduction—is fundamental for the individual and, therefore, necessary and primary; ‘the generative process is due to a superfluity of cells and is therefore secondary ....
('36', 211, 5, 14, 420764) The law of life, then, at this level is to feed the germ cells, firstly, for regeneration, and, secondly, for generation.
('36', 211, 5, 15, 420886) In case of deficiency, regeneration must take the first place and generation be suspended.
('36', 211, 5, 16, 420977) Thus, we may learn the origin of the suspension of reproduction and follow it to its later phases of human continence and asceticism generally.
('36', 211, 5, 17, 421121) Inner re production can never be suspended except at the cost of death, the normal origin of which is thus also discerned.
('36', 211, 6, 18, 421244) After describing the biological process of regeneration the writer states:
('36', 211, 7, 19, 421319) Among civilized human beings sexual intercourse is practised vastly more than is necessary for the production of the next generation and is carried on at the expense of internal reproduction, bringing disease, death and more in its train.
('36', 212, 0, 1, 421558) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 213
('36', 212, 1, 2, 421603) No one who knows anything of Hindu philosophy can have difficulty in following this paragraph from Mr. Hare’s essay:
('36', 212, 2, 3, 421720) The process of regeneration is not and cannot be mechanistic in character, but like the primitive fission, is vitalistic.
('36', 212, 2, 4, 421842) That is to say, it exhibits intelligence and will.
('36', 212, 2, 5, 421893) To suppose that life separates differentiates and segregates by a process that is purely mechanistic is inconceivable.
('36', 212, 2, 6, 422012) True, these fundamental processes are so far removed from our present conscious ness as to seem to be uncontrolled by the human or animal will.
('36', 212, 2, 7, 422156) But a moment’s reflection will show that just as the will of the fully developed human being directs his external movements and actions in accordance with the guidance of the intellect—this, indeed, being its function so the earlier processes of the gradual organization of the body must, within the limits provided by environment be allowed to be directed by a kind of will guided by a kind of intelligence.
('36', 212, 2, 8, 422565) This is now known to psychologists as” the uncon scious.” It is a part of ourself, disconnected from our normal daily thinking, but intensely awake and regard in regard to its own functions—so much so that it never for a moment subsides into sleep as the consciousness does.
('36', 212, 2, 9, 422840) Who can measure the almost irreparable harm done to the unconscious and more permanent part of our being by the sexual act indulged for its own sake?
('36', 212, 3, 10, 422990) The nemesis of reproduction is death.
('36', 212, 3, 11, 423028) The sexual act is essentially katabolic (or a movement towards death) in the male and in parturition of the offspring it is katabolic for the female.
('36', 212, 3, 12, 423178) Hence the writer contends:
('36', 212, 4, 13, 423205) Virility, vitality and immunity from disease are the normal lot of nearly or quite continent persons.
('36', 212, 4, 14, 423307) Withdrawal of germ cells from their upward regenerative course for generative or merely indulgent purposes deprives the organs of their replenishing stock of life, to their cost slowly and ultimately.
('36', 212, 4, 15, 423508) It is these physical facts which constitute the basis of a personal sexual ethic, counselling moderation, if not restraint—at any rate, explaining the origin of restraint.
('36', 212, 4, 16, 423680) The author, as can be easily imagined, is opposed to birth control by chemical and mechanical means.
('36', 212, 4, 17, 423781) He says:
('36', 212, 5, 18, 423790) It removes all prudential motives for self restraint and makes it possi ble for sexual indulgence in marriage to be limited only by the diminution of desire or the advance of old age.
('36', 212, 5, 19, 423974) Apart from this, however, it inevitably has an influence outside the marriage relation.
('36', 212, 5, 20, 424062) It opens the door for irregular, promiscuous and unfruitful unions, which from the point of view of modern industry, sociology and politics, are full of danger.
('36', 212, 5, 21, 424223) I cannot go into these
('36', 213, 0, 1, 424246) 214 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 213, 1, 2, 424288) It is sufficient to say that by contraception, inordinate sexual indulgence both in and out of marriage is facilitated and, if I am right in my foregoing physiological arguments, evil must come to both individuals and the race.
('36', 213, 1, 3, 424516) Let the Indian youth treasure in their hearts the quotation with which M. Bureau’s book ends:
('36', 213, 2, 4, 424610) The future is for the nations who are chaste.

('36', 215, 4, 7, 428895) THE WHEEL IN MUNICIPAL SCHOOLS
('36', 215, 5, 8, 428926) There are 108 girls and 41 boys spinning in the schools under the Lucknow Municipal Board.
('36', 215, 5, 9, 429017) There are 93 wheels in the girls’ schools and 15 in the boys’ schools.
('36', 215, 5, 10, 429088) The former spin 27 tolas and the latter 4 tolas per month.
('36', 215, 5, 11, 429147) Each wheel costs the municipality Rs. 2 per month.
('36', 215, 5, 12, 429198) The Superintendent of Education considers the progress ‘quite satisfactory beginning to start with, though not very encouraging’.
('36', 215, 5, 13, 429328) It can be considered satisfactory only in the sense that it may be better than nothing.
('36', 215, 5, 14, 429416) But in my opinion the output of yarn is ridiculously small and the expense per charkha is monstrously large.
('36', 215, 5, 15, 429525) Indeed there should be hardly any, apart from the initial outlay.
('36', 215, 5, 16, 429591) Nothing is stated as to the quality of yarn.
('36', 215, 5, 17, 429636) I must repeat what I have said before.
('36', 215, 5, 18, 429675) The takli is the thing for schools and it should be only introduced when the existing staff has learnt carding and spinning.
('36', 215, 5, 19, 429800) Spinning in schools can never become a success unless the teachers realize its national importance, take pleasure in it, and by their own zeal make it interesting for the pupils.

('36', 216, 4, 8, 431174) Today Hindi Navajivan enters its sixth year.
('36', 216, 4, 9, 431219) Although it is running at a loss, it is being continued by the love of friends.
('36', 216, 4, 10, 431299) I have read what Jamnalalji has written.
('36', 216, 4, 11, 431340) If Hindi Navajivan serves a purpose, it must go on ; but it must then be self supporting.
('36', 216, 4, 12, 431430) I appeal to the readers to make sure that the paper does not have to depend on the charity of friends.
('36', 216, 4, 13, 431533) There used to be errors of language in Hindi Navajivan.
('36', 216, 4, 14, 431589) I think they have now been done away with.
('36', 216, 4, 15, 431632) Two Hindi lovers from North India do the translation for Hindi Navajivan.
('36', 216, 4, 16, 431706) The risk of errors has, therefore, considerably lessened.
('36', 216, 4, 17, 431764) The readers on their part will no doubt fulfil their duty during this year.

('36', 218, 5, 6, 433897) 248. LETTER TO ESTHER MENON
('36', 218, 6, 7, 433925) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, August 20, 1926
('36', 218, 7, 8, 433964) MY DEAR CHILD,
('36', 218, 8, 9, 433979) I have your letter.
('36', 218, 8, 10, 433999) I did not misunderstand your remark about typewriters.
('36', 218, 8, 11, 434054) On the contrary, I liked it.
('36', 218, 8, 12, 434083) The literal meaning of an ‘ashram’ is an abode, but the associations about the ashram are these: It should be simple.
('36', 218, 8, 13, 434201) It should not be merely a teaching institution.
('36', 218, 8, 14, 434249) It should contain predominantly those who are pledged to perpetual continence.
('36', 218, 8, 15, 434328) It should have associations of sannyasa, meaning detachment from the world.
('36', 218, 8, 16, 434404) It should, therefore, be a voluntarily poor organization.
('36', 218, 8, 17, 434462) There should, therefore, be rigid simplicity about it.
('36', 218, 8, 18, 434517) Its object must invariably be formation of character with a view to self realization.
('36', 218, 8, 19, 434603) The idea of master and servant is wholly repugnant to such an institution.
('36', 218, 8, 20, 434678) All men and women in an ashram are expected to do bodily labour and all enjoy an equal status.
('36', 218, 8, 21, 434773) The idea of superiority has no place in it.
('36', 218, 8, 22, 434817) The head of an ashram is in the place of a parent and he is expected to regard the rest as his own children.
('36', 218, 8, 23, 434926) I wonder if I have now given you fairly the characteristics of an ashram.
('36', 218, 8, 24, 435000) It grieves me whenever I find that a medical man is weak or ailing.
('36', 218, 8, 25, 435068) It is a perpetual reminder to us that medicine is such an incomplete, such an unreliable, and such an empirical science.
('36', 218, 8, 26, 435189) If we think about it with sufficient detachment, we would at once realize its inherent weakness by understanding that there is no such thing as an absolute cure.
('36', 218, 8, 27, 435351) The most potent drugs admit of innumerable exceptions.
('36', 218, 8, 28, 435406) The most successful operation leaves literally and in the
('36', 218, 9, 29, 435464) 1 The context is not ascertainable.
('36', 219, 0, 1, 435500) 220 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 219, 1, 2, 435542) spirit a scar behind.
('36', 219, 1, 3, 435564) It would certainly be a good thing, if you could hasten your departure for Denmark.
('36', 219, 1, 4, 435648) Change of climate will be the best cure.
('36', 219, 1, 5, 435689) What you say about fasting is quite true.
('36', 219, 1, 6, 435731) It has no absolute value and it certainly does not produce the slightest spiritual effect if the motive behind it is not really spiritual.
('36', 219, 1, 7, 435870) Fasting with a mixed motive ends with purely material results.
('36', 219, 1, 8, 435933) But fasting for the sake of unfoldment of the spirit is a discipline I hold to be absolutely necessary at some stage or other in the evolution of an individual.
('36', 219, 1, 9, 436094) I always considered Protestantism to be deficient in this particular.
('36', 219, 1, 10, 436164) Every other religion of any importance appreciates the spiritual value of fasting.
('36', 219, 1, 11, 436247) Crucifixion of the flesh is a meaningless term unless one goes voluntarily through pangs of hunger.
('36', 219, 1, 12, 436347) For one thing, identif ication with the starving poor is a meaningless term without the experience behind.
('36', 219, 1, 13, 436454) But I quite agree that even an eighty days’ fast may fail to rid a person of pride, selfishness, ambitions and the like.
('36', 219, 1, 14, 436575) Fasting is merely a prop.
('36', 219, 1, 15, 436601) But as a prop to a tottering structure is of inestimable value, so is the prop of fasting of inestimable value for a struggling soul.

('36', 220, 3, 4, 437528) 250. LETTER TO REHANA TYABJI
('36', 220, 4, 5, 437557) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, August 21, 1926
('36', 220, 5, 6, 437596) DEAR SISTER 1, It was a delight to receive your letter, it would seem, after ages.
('36', 220, 5, 7, 437679) Do you want me to write to Sir Henry Lawrence directly or to prepare a note for you which you can send?
('36', 220, 5, 8, 437783) Whilst your answer is quite good, he must have all the satisfaction that one can give him in the way of statistics.
('36', 220, 5, 9, 437899) After all the trouble one may take, it is just possible what may appear to us to be solid and tangible may not appear so to him.
('36', 220, 5, 10, 438028) But that does not matter as the inspirer of The Song Celestial 2 would say.
('36', 220, 5, 11, 438104) We must act with detachment and leave the results to God.
('36', 220, 5, 12, 438162) I observe that, as behoves a good girl, your postscript is as long as your letter and, perhaps, more important.
('36', 220, 5, 13, 438274) Please tell the sceptical sister that the revival of the spinning wheel has actually rescued from destruction many arts and crafts.
('36', 220, 5, 14, 438406) Does she think that there was no art in India before we received silk thread from China and Paris which we began doing only a hundred years ago or less?
('36', 220, 5, 15, 438559) When spinning and waving were at their height, we were in possession of the highest art and all the art on fabric one sees now is a copy of the Indian original.
('36', 220, 5, 16, 438720) Personally, I do not mind the use of Chinese silk for embroidery.
('36', 220, 5, 17, 438786) But those who are afraid of art destruction may use as much as they like of Chinese thread so long as the background is hand spun khaddar.
('36', 220, 5, 18, 438925) No amount of travelling and appeals to newspapers, etc., can possibly rescue Indian art from destruction if we cannot rescue ourselves as a nation from destruction.
('36', 220, 5, 19, 439090) Revival of Indian art will only come when we develop love enough for our country to enable us to cling to one another and sink our differences and to sacrifice our all for the sake of the country.
('36', 220, 5, 20, 439287) The best way, therefore, to preserve and revive the Indian art is for us to become sufficiently Indian ourselves.
('36', 220, 5, 21, 439401) But all this

('36', 221, 5, 9, 440038) 251. MY NOTES
('36', 221, 6, 10, 440052) NATIONAL SCHOOLS
('36', 221, 7, 11, 440069) There seems to be some misunderstanding regarding the article in which I wrote about National Schools in the Navajivan of August 8. The Principal of the Rashtriya Vinay Mandir in Bombay has written to me as follows:
('36', 221, 8, 12, 440285) You have given it as your opinion in that article that national schools should be closed now, and so one of the donors of the Vinay Mandir says that he need give us nothing now.
('36', 221, 8, 13, 440463) The passage which has been thus misunderstood read as follows:
('36', 221, 9, 14, 440526) Where the parents are fired by national ideals and prove their adhesion by giving adequate donations for the support of national schools, and, where the teachers being themselves believers in the national ideal are ceaselessly striving to enforce it, I can understand a relaxation of the discipline if the scholars are lukewarm about the ideal.
('36', 221, 9, 15, 440871) In such a case, it may be necessary to continue the school.
('36', 221, 9, 16, 440931) For we may hope some day to influence the scholars.
('36', 221, 9, 17, 440983) But at the time of writing these lines, I can think of no such school.
('36', 221, 10, 18, 441054) The last sentence of this paragraph has been misunderstood.
('36', 221, 10, 19, 441114) It has been taken to mean that I do not regard any of the national schools fit enough to be continued.
('36', 221, 10, 20, 441217) There is another sentence in that paragraph, the first one, which states what type of school should be closed down:
('36', 221, 11, 21, 441333) 1 Theis paragraph is taken from Young India, 2 9 1926.
('36', 222, 0, 1, 441388) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 223
('36', 222, 1, 2, 441433) Where either the parents or the teachers are opposed to the national ideal, the school should certainly be closed.
('36', 222, 2, 3, 441548) In the case of the Vinay Mandir in Bombay, as in the case of many other such schools, we know that the parents and teachers are in agreement with the ideals of national education.
('36', 222, 2, 4, 441728) They want national schools to be run in accordance with the ideal of national education as defined by the Congress.
('36', 222, 2, 5, 441844) Schools which are so run need not be closed down.
('36', 222, 2, 6, 441894) The sentences which followed were intended to point out that in such cases it would not be wrong, even if the pupils obstinately refused to wear khadi and fulfil other conditions, to keep the schools going and so give the pupils an opportunity to change.
('36', 222, 2, 7, 442149) I stated at the conclusion of the paragraph,” I can think of no such school.” What I meant was that, if there were any national schools where both the parents and the teachers were in agreement with its ideals and active in promoting them and yet the pupils obstinately disregarded the rules about khadi, etc., I should certainly like to know their names.
('36', 222, 2, 8, 442505) As regards the Rashtriya Vinay Mandir in Bombay, my impression is that there even the pupils are filled with the national spirit and wear khadi and spin.
('36', 222, 2, 9, 442659) There can be no question of closing down such a school.
('36', 222, 2, 10, 442715) I hope that generous hearted men will continue to help such schools.
('36', 222, 3, 11, 442784) [From Gujarati]
('36', 222, 4, 12, 442800) Navajivan, 22 8 1926

('36', 225, 5, 17, 447389) A WISE STEP
('36', 225, 6, 18, 447401) The manager of the khadi store conducted in the office of the Pranidaya Dhyanpracharak Sangh, Davengere, Mysore, reports that the municipal council of that place has removed the octroi duty imposed on imports of khadi.
('36', 225, 6, 19, 447620) This is an example to be copied by every municipality.
('36', 225, 6, 20, 447675) It is the least that municipalities can do for the revival of the ancient industry.
('36', 225, 6, 21, 447759) Let me repeat for the thousandth time that khadi means cloth woven on a handloom out of hand spun yarn.

('36', 227, 1, 2, 449115) As against 3,379 persons who enrolled themselves as members only 1,231, i.e., 36 per cent have paid their quota of yarn to date.
('36', 227, 1, 3, 449244) Assam with only l p.c.
('36', 227, 1, 4, 449267) full subscribers comes by far the last on the list.
('36', 227, 1, 5, 449319) Andhra is the next offender with 24 p.c.
('36', 227, 1, 6, 449360) Burma tops the list wth 83 p.c., but it is no wonder since it had only 6 members to start with.
('36', 227, 2, 7, 449456) These figures show that people do not like regularity, they do not like to work steadily for the country.
('36', 227, 2, 8, 449562) The spirit of sustained sacrifice is lacking.
('36', 227, 2, 9, 449608) No one need imagine that with monetary subscriptions the conditions will be much better.
('36', 227, 2, 10, 449697) Where is the public worker who has had no painful experience of arrears?
('36', 227, 2, 11, 449770) I remember the complaints of old Congress Secretaries when the A.I.C.C. subscription used to be a lump sum.
('36', 227, 2, 12, 449878) Negligence is ingrained among many workers.
('36', 227, 2, 13, 449922) Public work has not yet risen from the status of a pastime or patronage to that of a primary duty.
('36', 227, 2, 14, 450021) And yet for one who desires a healthy social and public life, public service is as much a duty as is service done to oneself or to one’s family.
('36', 227, 2, 15, 450166) May not the ancient five sacrifices be renamed sacrifice for self, family, village, nation and humanity?
('36', 227, 2, 16, 450271) That life only is worth living in which there is a harm onious correlation, no antagonism, among the several sacrifices.
('36', 227, 2, 17, 450392) The spinning subscription is a national sacrifice of the lightest measure, not in conflict with the requirements of humanity, and certainly not in conflict with those of the village, family or the individual.
('36', 227, 3, 18, 450601) For me, therefore, the lesson that this study in figures teaches is not one of despair, nor of revising the nature of the subscription or the method of paying it.
('36', 227, 3, 19, 450764) The more I study the spinning movement, the more convinced I become of the soundness of requiring and giving steady daily labour of half an hour at least at the spinning wheel and of keeping up the present rate of subscription.
('36', 227, 3, 20, 450992) Even if the 1,231 members keep up the regular supply, without fuss, without interruption, the discipline will revolutionize their lives and the subscribers will be found to be fit instruments for national service when the supreme test comes, as it must some day.
('36', 227, 4, 21, 451255) The largest number of steady workers is derived today from this body of regular spinners.
('36', 227, 4, 22, 451345) The statistics I am collecting and publishing, as regularly as I can get them, must open the eyes of all unbiased thinkers to the usefulness of the only immediate remedy for the growing distress of the poor millions and to the only real link between the cultured few and the starving many.
('36', 227, 4, 23, 451635) Babu Rajendra Prasad has well said in his eloquent defence of khaddar:
('36', 228, 0, 1, 451706) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 229
('36', 228, 1, 2, 451751) But people may say why should we pay this higher price?
('36', 228, 1, 3, 451807) What after all is the good of reviving this dead industry?
('36', 228, 1, 4, 451866) Only those can put this question who have not sufficiently realized the grinding poverty of the masses of the people of this country.
('36', 228, 1, 5, 452000) All a priori economics is mute in the appalling
('36', 228, 2, 6, 452048) presence of this chill penury which freezes the genial current of the soul.
('36', 228, 2, 7, 452124) I will give only one figure which is a rough figure but which is none the less reliable.
('36', 228, 2, 8, 452213) In 1922, we distributed no less than Rs. 26,000 by way of wages to weavers and spinners.
('36', 228, 2, 9, 452302) In 1925 we paid no less than Rs. 46,000 out of which Rs. 28,000 was paid to spinners alone—spinners who could not have earned anything if they did not spin.
('36', 228, 2, 10, 452459) These figures relate only to the organization under the direct control of the Congress in this province.
('36', 228, 2, 11, 452564) They do not include the figures of the Gandhi Kutir whose work until recently was even more extensive than that of the Congress Khaddar Bhandar.
('36', 228, 2, 12, 452709) I ask in all solemnity what other organization is there in this province which can afford to distribute over a lakh to people who would otherwise earn nothing and to whom it gives what it gives not by way of charity but as wages honestly earned?
('36', 228, 2, 13, 452955) Khaddar is really a life giving industry and to revive it is to furnish food to countless starving persons.
('36', 228, 2, 14, 453063) It blesses those who give and those who receive it, as it is not mere charity, and creates in the recipient a sense of self respect while at the same time making the distributor humble.
('36', 228, 2, 15, 453249) And what is true of Bihar is true of every province.
('36', 228, 2, 16, 453302) The A.I.S.A. is operating with over Rs. 18,00,000 throughout the whole of India.
('36', 228, 2, 17, 453383) The bulk of the returns goes directly into the pockets of those who would otherwise be workless.
('36', 228, 2, 18, 453480) Let the sceptics peruse the figures.
('36', 228, 2, 19, 453517) If they have better use for the money, better employment for the workless paupers, let them say so.
('36', 228, 2, 20, 453617) If not, it is up to them to lend a helping hand to this great and growing movement which is as much moral and economic as it is political.
('36', 228, 2, 21, 453756) Its moral and economic effect is immediate and tangible, its political effect is distant and derivable from the first two, not independent of them.
('36', 228, 2, 22, 453904) Let those who are in arrears beware!
('36', 228, 2, 23, 453941) At the end of the year, they will find their names struck off, if they do not wake up and spin and send the yarn they have hitherto neglected to Spin and send.
('36', 228, 2, 24, 454101) Debts of honour have priority over those enforceable in a court of law.

('36', 229, 1, 2, 454294) 259. CURSE OF CHILD MARRIAGE
('36', 229, 2, 3, 454323) Mrs. Margaret E. Cousins has sent me notes of a tragic case that appears to have just occurred in Madras and has arisen out of a child marriage, the girl being 13 years and the ‘husband’ 26. Hardly had the pair lived together for 13 days when the girl died of burning.
('36', 229, 2, 4, 454592) The jury have found that she committed suicide owing to the unbearable and inhuman solicitations of the so called husband.
('36', 229, 2, 5, 454715) The dying deposition of the girl would go to show that the ‘husband’ had set fire to her clothes.
('36', 229, 2, 6, 454813) Passion knows no prudence, no pity.
('36', 229, 2, 7, 454849) But how the girl died is beside the point.
('36', 229, 2, 8, 454892) The indisputable facts are: (1) that the girl was married when she was only 13; (2) that she had no sexual desire inasmuch as she resisted the advances of the ‘husband’; (3) that the ‘husband’ did make cruel advances; (4) and that she is now no more.
('36', 229, 3, 9, 455143) It is irreligion, not religion, to give religious sanction to a brutal custom.
('36', 229, 3, 10, 455222) The smritis bristle with contradictions.
('36', 229, 3, 11, 455263) The only reasonable deduction to be drawn from the contradictions is that the texts that may be contrary to known and accepted morality, more especially, to the moral precepts enjoined in the smritis themselves, must be rejected as interpolations.
('36', 229, 3, 12, 455511) Inspiring verses on self restraint could not be written at the same time and by the same pen that wrote the verses encouraging the brute in man.
('36', 229, 3, 13, 455656) Only a man innocent of self restraint and steeped in vice could call it a sin not to marry a girl before she reached the age of monthly periods.
('36', 229, 3, 14, 455801) It should be held sinful to marry a girl for several years after the periods begin.
('36', 229, 3, 15, 455885) There cannot be even the thought of marriage before the periods begin.
('36', 229, 3, 16, 455956) A girl is no more fit to bear children on beginning the periods than a lad is to procreate as soon as he grows the first hair on his upper lip.
('36', 229, 4, 17, 456100) The custom of child marriage is a moral as well as a physical evil.
('36', 229, 4, 18, 456168) For it undermines our morals and induces physical degeneration.
('36', 229, 4, 19, 456232) By countenancing such customs we recede from God as well as swaraj.
('36', 229, 4, 20, 456300) A man who has no thought of the tender age of a girl has none of God.
('36', 229, 4, 21, 456370) And undergrown men have no capacity for fighting battles of freedom or, having gained it, of retaining it.
('36', 229, 4, 22, 456477) Fight for swaraj means not mere political awakening but an all round awakening—social, educational, moral, economic and political.
('36', 230, 0, 1, 456608) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 231
('36', 230, 1, 2, 456653) Legislation is being promoted to raise the age of consent.
('36', 230, 1, 3, 456712) It may be good for bringing a minority to book.
('36', 230, 1, 4, 456760) But it is not legislation that will cure a popular evil, it is enlightened public opinion that can do it.
('36', 230, 1, 5, 456866) I am not opposed to legislation in such matters but I do lay greater stress on cultivation of public opinion.
('36', 230, 1, 6, 456976) The Madras case would have been impossible if there had been a living public opinion against child marriages.
('36', 230, 1, 7, 457086) The young man in question is not an illiterate labourer but an intelligent educated typist.
('36', 230, 1, 8, 457178) It would have been impossible for him to marry or touch the girl if public opinion had been against the marriage or the consummation of the marriage of girls of tender age.
('36', 230, 1, 9, 457351) Ordinarily, a girl under 18 years should never be given in marriage.

('36', 230, 4, 12, 457454) PANDIT MALAVIYAJI AND THE BENGAL GOVERNMENT
('36', 230, 5, 13, 457498) The Government of Bengal may well congratulate itself upon the courage it has shown in retracing its steps and dropping the proceedings against Pandit Malaviyaji and Dr. Moonje for their civil disobedience.
('36', 230, 5, 14, 457705) 1 But one could wish that there was grace about the withdrawal of these proceedings.
('36', 230, 5, 15, 457790) The Standing Counsel for the Government of Bengal made a statement which, I think, was highly offensive.
('36', 230, 5, 16, 457895) There is no regret shown on behalf of the Government, no apology offered to the distinguished patriots, but, on the contrary, a veiled suggestion that there was possibly some connection between Panditji’s presence in Calcutta and the riots that took place although the Standing Counsel is obliged to admit that there was nothing offensive or provocative in Panditji’s speech on the strength of which the prohibition order was taken out.
('36', 230, 5, 17, 458332) Surely, it was up to the officials who took the proceedings to see the full text of the speech before applying for an order under Section 144, especially when the order was to be against persons so well known in public life as Pandit Malaviyaji and Dr. Moonje.
('36', 230, 5, 18, 458593) If it was a private party that had acted so hastily as the Government of Bengal seem to have done in this case, that party would have rendered itself liable to an action for damages.
('36', 230, 5, 19, 458776) If public opinion was well organized and strong, it could bring to
('36', 230, 6, 20, 458843) 1 Vide” Triumph of Civil Disobedience” 12 8 1926.
('36', 231, 0, 1, 458893) 232 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 231, 1, 2, 458935) book a Government that acted so rashly and recklessly as the Bengal Government have done.
('36', 231, 1, 3, 459025) In the face of that proceedings is it any wonder that complaint is often heard that proceedings are often thoughtlessly, hastily, and sometimes even vindictively, taken against innocent persons in virtue of arbitrary powers taken by the Government under laws in the framing of which they have had the most part?
('36', 231, 2, 4, 459337) ‘SQUEEZING OUT’
('36', 231, 3, 5, 459353) A letter from South Africa states:
('36', 231, 4, 6, 459388) The policy of squeezing out or” civilizing labour” in all Government Departments is proceeding apace and in the Railway Department at Pietermaritzburg and Ladysmith hundreds of Indians have been given notice, in some cases of thirteen days only, to transfer to Durban or get out of the service.
('36', 231, 4, 7, 459683) This is being done with people who have given 25 to 30 years to the service at one and the same place.
('36', 231, 4, 8, 459786) To these poor illiterate people who have given the best part of their lives to the services, a transfer is a change to a new world and I am made to understand that in a Large number of cases they are leaving the service and getting repatriated to India.
('36', 231, 4, 9, 460040) The alternative of transfer to Durban is really no alternative to leaving the service.
('36', 231, 4, 10, 460127) And those who do go to Durban must ultimately come under the ban when the ‘civilizing’ process reaches Durban.
('36', 231, 4, 11, 460238) What hurts one however is not the notices but the indecent hurry with which the policy of extirpation of the Asiatic is being pursued in spite of the fact that very soon a conference is to sit to consider the question of the status of Asiatics in South Africa.
('36', 231, 4, 12, 460499) But let us wait, prepare the atmosphere for the coming South African deputation and hope for the best.

('36', 232, 3, 9, 462059) ITS AWFUL CONSEQUENCES
('36', 232, 4, 10, 462082) A correspondent sends me a long article on child marriage and enforced widowhood in Bengal.
('36', 232, 4, 11, 462174) He says:
('36', 232, 5, 12, 462183) You are surely aware that the condition of Hindu society in other provinces is no better, if not worse, than that prevailing in Bengal.
('36', 232, 5, 13, 462319) Early marriage and girl widowhood exist in a specially virulent form amongst the depressed classes of Hindu society.
('36', 232, 5, 14, 462436) In Bengal it is very frequent amongst Dam, Chamar, Namasudra, Kaibarta (fishermen) classes.
('36', 232, 5, 15, 462528) These people on the other hand form the bulk of Hindu population in Bengal.
('36', 232, 5, 16, 462604) I wish I had time and opportunity to study and prepare similar figures for other provinces.
('36', 232, 5, 17, 462696) The article bristles with figures which are in the main included in the summary which I reproduced a fortnight ago fromSir Gangaram’s statistics.
('36', 232, 5, 18, 462842) 1 The following conclusions drawn by the writer are interesting and instructive:
('36', 232, 6, 19, 462923) It is sapping the vitality of thousands of our promising boys and girls on whom the future of our society entirely rests.
('36', 232, 6, 20, 463045) It is bringing into existence every year thousands of weaklings both boys and girls—who are born of immature parenthood.
('36', 232, 6, 21, 463166) It is a very fruitful source of appalling child mortality and stillbirths that now prevail in our society.
('36', 232, 6, 22, 463273) It is bringing into existence thousands of girl widows every year who in their turn are a source of corruption and dangerous infection to the society.
('36', 232, 6, 23, 463424) It is a very important cause of the gradual and steady decline of Hindu society in point of (1) number, (2) physical strength and courage and (3) morality.

('36', 233, 1, 2, 463684) 261. ‘WHY ONLY YOURS?’
('36', 233, 2, 3, 463707) Lala Shamal of Hissar writes:
('36', 233, 3, 4, 463737) Some time ago I read an article by you in Young India 1 headed” The Cobwebs of Ignorance”.
('36', 233, 3, 5, 463828) In this article you said inter alia that the spinning wheel was necessary for the economic salvation of India and that therefore it was necessary that every Indian worked it either by way of sacrifice or otherwise.
('36', 233, 3, 6, 464043) You also said there that it was the gateway of spiritual salvation for yourself.
('36', 233, 3, 7, 464124) But why for yourself only?
('36', 233, 3, 8, 464151) Let us examine this proposition in the light of two great civilizations of the earth, viz., that of the East (Aryan) and that of the West (Grecian).
('36', 233, 3, 9, 464300) Excepting perhaps Kabir and Nanak, the two great rishis of India in the middle ages, who have gone much higher and have symbolized the charkha with the great force of the universe (cosmic energy, life or Prana) every rishi in India either in the middle ages or in ancient times has pointed out that the charkha was the gateway to woman’s salvation.
('36', 233, 4, 10, 464649) The Upanishads say that the Lord of Creation desiring the creation produced at first a pair—life and food—and with these two forces He created the sun and the moon as life and food respectively and so on till the whole creation was made.
('36', 233, 4, 11, 464887) Man and woman were produced as life and food, respectively.
('36', 233, 4, 12, 464947) These two forces united together made the whole (world).
('36', 233, 4, 13, 465004) The following Vedic Mantra is recited just before homa and saptapadi:
('36', 233, 5, 14, 465074) “O bride!
('36', 233, 5, 15, 465084) look here, I have brought these clothes for you.
('36', 233, 5, 16, 465133) These are sacred clothes made by devis (women) of my country by carding the cotton and by spinning and weaving with their own hands.
('36', 233, 5, 17, 465266) Wear these with faith and get yourself entitled to perform the yajna with me.
('36', 233, 5, 18, 465344) I pray that the same devis may continue to supply you with such clothes and may continue to wear them for lifelong years.
('36', 233, 6, 19, 465466) Thus according to the ancient Aryan philosophy one who has not understood the charkha cannot understand his self or the universe and cannot realize Brahman just as one who has not understood vyashti (individual) can never realize samashti (whole).
('36', 233, 6, 20, 465714) Now let us see what the Western (Greek) civilization, of which Christianity and Islam are but later developments, says in this matter.
('36', 233, 6, 21, 465849) Everyone knows the lines:” When Adam delved and Eve span who was then the gentleman?” According to this the duty of the husband was to till the ground and that of the wife was to spin and weave.
('36', 233, 7, 22, 466044) 1 Dated 27 5 26; Vide” Cobwebs of Ignorance”, 16 5 1926.
('36', 234, 0, 1, 466101) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 235
('36', 234, 1, 2, 466146) Wife comes from a root meaning to weave just as the name Uma, the consort of Shiva, means in Sanskrit one who weaves.
('36', 234, 1, 3, 466264) Thus the Western philosophy regarding charkha seems also to take us to the same idea as the Aryan philosophy.
('36', 234, 1, 4, 466374) Now nationality is the outcome of two forces united together, viz, politics and religion.
('36', 234, 1, 5, 466464) One is nothing without the other.
('36', 234, 1, 6, 466498) While the former is the establishment of a spirit of equality outside, the latter is the realization of the spirit of oneness within.
('36', 234, 1, 7, 466632) Economic salvation as a branch of politics can do no good unless it is joined with the other force of religion.
('36', 234, 1, 8, 466744) I wish I could say with my correspondent that the charkha is the gateway to the salvation of all.
('36', 234, 1, 9, 466842) But he must recognize my limitations.
('36', 234, 1, 10, 466880) I have to write as well for sceptics as for believers.
('36', 234, 1, 11, 466935) The authorities and arguments addressed by Lala Shamlal will not, I fear, appeal to the sceptic.
('36', 234, 1, 12, 467032) The latter will say and from his standpoint correctly, that the texts in support of the religious value of the charkha are produced from an outworn civilization.
('36', 234, 1, 13, 467194) He will argue that if a rishi were to write the Vedas today, he will draw his spiritual illustrations from the steam engine or, better still, the electric motor, the wireless and the like and the rishi of the future will think nothing of wireless and even the aeroplanes.
('36', 234, 1, 14, 467466) His spiritual vocabulary will with the etheric doubles and thought waves cutting through space in fractions of time denoted by specially invented words representing perhaps a thousandth part of a second.
('36', 234, 1, 15, 467670) The spiritual value of the charkha can only appeal to those who believe with me that this civilization denoted by all insane rush after destroying the limitations of space imposed upon man by nature are coming to an end, even as possibly mightier civilizations based upon attempts to find happiness in multiplicity of material pursuits and comforts have perished.
('36', 234, 1, 16, 468034) If Lala Shamlal takes the spiritual message of the charkha to the villages, he will not need my authority.
('36', 234, 1, 17, 468141) For, I have derived mine from them.
('36', 234, 2, 18, 468177) Young India, 26 8 1926

('36', 236, 1, 2, 470115) 264. LETTER TO TULSI MAHER
('36', 236, 2, 3, 470142) THE ASHRAM,
('36', 236, 3, 4, 470154) SABARMATI, Friday, Sravana Krishna 4, August 27, 1926
('36', 236, 4, 5, 470208) BHAI TULSI MAHER, I feel happy whenever I get a letter from you.
('36', 236, 4, 6, 470273) You are doing very good work.
('36', 236, 4, 7, 470303) Send me a few pieces by way of samples from the varieties of cloth being woven there.
('36', 236, 4, 8, 470389) What does a charkha cost there?
('36', 236, 4, 9, 470421) From where do you get the wood?
('36', 236, 4, 10, 470453) Is the spindle made locally?
('36', 236, 4, 11, 470482) If yes, what does it cost?
('36', 236, 4, 12, 470509) How many charkhas are plying?
('36', 236, 4, 13, 470539) What is the rate of payment for spinning?

('36', 242, 3, 5, 479196) Your diet should contain some greens.

('36', 242, 3, 15, 479940) When I fast I always mix some salt in the water which I drink.
('36', 242, 3, 16, 480003) Whey made from mildly fermented curds is quite all right as a substitute for milk.

('36', 242, 3, 20, 480238) Everyone should fix his own standard on the basis of his experience.
('36', 242, 3, 21, 480307) Wheat, mill, one green and a lemon—nothing else is required.
('36', 242, 3, 22, 480368) The sugar present in wheat ‘and milk is enough for our purpose.
('36', 242, 3, 23, 480432) I think this covers all your questions.

('36', 246, 5, 8, 485087) 281. NOTES
('36', 246, 6, 9, 485098) A GREAT INDUSTRIALIST
('36', 246, 7, 10, 485120) The death of Mr. Ratan Tata removes from our midst a great industrialist.
('36', 246, 7, 11, 485194) Jamshedpur is the greatest Indian enterprise of the greatest Indian firm.
('36', 246, 7, 12, 485268) The late Mr. Ratan Tata was a noted member of the great house of the Tatas.
('36', 246, 7, 13, 485344) I had the honour of coming in close contact with him when he invited me to visit Jamshedpur in connection with some trouble with his employees.
('36', 246, 7, 14, 485488) It was an agreeable surprise to me to find him full of sympathy for his employees and ready to concede everything that could be legitimately urged on their behalf.
('36', 246, 7, 15, 485652) He created in my mind the impression of being a just and generous employer.
('36', 246, 7, 16, 485728) His solicitude for the prosperity of the industry seemed to me to be independent of the added wealth it might bring to the distinguished house.
('36', 246, 7, 17, 485872) I tender my condolences to the members of the deceased’s family.
('36', 246, 8, 18, 485937) WHY OBLIGED?
('36', 246, 9, 19, 485950) A correspondent justifying the weakness of his yarn says:” We are obliged to buy waste cotton in the market at almost the same price as good cotton.” Why obliged?
('36', 246, 9, 20, 486113) Surely, if good cotton is not available at a particular place, it should be procured from places where it is available.
('36', 246, 9, 21, 486233) Bengal, Bihar and Orissa get their good cotton from Wardha.
('36', 246, 9, 22, 486293) Manchester gets its supplies from India, Uganda, Egypt and America.
('36', 246, 9, 23, 486361) Why cannot the correspondent get his from a neighbouring district or province?
('36', 246, 9, 24, 486440) There is no excuse for members of the All India Spinners’ Association to spin bad yarn.
('36', 246, 9, 25, 486528) An English proverb has it that things that are worth doing are worth doing well.

('36', 253, 1, 2, 501551) literature I have felt compelled to glance through and the copious correspondence my review of M. Bureau’s book has given rise to demand a public discussion of a question which is of paramount interest to society.
('36', 253, 1, 3, 501765) A Malabar correspondent writes:
('36', 253, 2, 4, 501797) In your review of Monsieur Bureau’s book it is stated that there is no case on record of celibacy or long abstention producing any evil effects on us.
('36', 253, 2, 5, 501948) In my own case, however, three weeks seem to be the utmost limit of beneficial abstention.
('36', 253, 2, 6, 502039) At the end of that period I usually feel a heaviness of body, a restlessness both of body and mind, leading to bad temper.

('36', 253, 5, 18, 503435) vital product in our system.
('36', 253, 5, 19, 503464) The instances quoted by the correspondent are typical.
('36', 253, 5, 20, 503519) In several such cases I have observed hasty generalizations from insufficient data.
('36', 253, 5, 21, 503603) Ability to retain and assimilate the vital fluid is a matter of long training.
('36', 253, 5, 22, 503682) It must be so, as it gives a strength to body and mind such as no other process does with equal effect.
('36', 253, 5, 23, 503786) Drugs and mechanical contrivances may keep the body in a tolerable condition but they sap the mind and make it too weak to resist the play of a multitude of passions which like so many deadly foes surround every human being.
('36', 253, 5, 24, 504011) Too often do we expect results in spite of practices which are calculated to retard, if not to defeat, them.

('36', 254, 1, 14, 505609) Marriage no doubt was the remedy in that second case, as in the vast majority of cases marriage is the most natural and desirable state when one finds oneself even against one’s will living the married life in one’s daily thought.
('36', 254, 1, 15, 505840) The potency of thought unsuppressed but unembodied is far greater than that of thought embodied, that is, translated into action.
('36', 254, 1, 16, 505970) And, when the action is brought under due control, it reacts upon and regulates the thought itself.
('36', 254, 1, 17, 506070) Thought thus translated into action becomes a prisoner and is brought under subjection.

('36', 255, 3, 18, 508211) 287. LETTER TO PRABHUDAS BHIKHABHAI
('36', 255, 4, 19, 508247) September 2, 1926
('36', 255, 5, 20, 508265) BHAISHRI PRABHUDAS, I have your letter.
('36', 255, 5, 21, 508305) You may rest assured that I do not belittle pranayama.
('36', 255, 5, 22, 508360) But what can be achieved through pranayama can also be achieved through other means and, therefore, I do not look upon it as indispensable.

('36', 257, 5, 7, 511034) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, September 3, 1926
('36', 257, 6, 8, 511075) DEAR FRIEND, I thank you for your latest letter 1. You may certainly share all my letters with any friend you like subject to the proviso that they do not find their way to the Press.
('36', 257, 6, 9, 511259) Not that I mind it, but it can do no good whatsoever and may possibly do harm to the cause both you and I are trying to serve.
('36', 257, 6, 10, 511386) I do not share your fear that the Mussalmans will fight any just solution.
('36', 257, 6, 11, 511461) It will, however, very largely depend upon Hindu prudence, Hindu moderation and absolute fairplay.
('36', 257, 6, 12, 511560) Why do you say that Islam and democracy are incompatible?
('36', 257, 6, 13, 511618) On the contrary, were not the early Califs among the most democratic sovereigns the world has ever seen?
('36', 257, 6, 14, 511723) But a clash of arms will not move me.
('36', 257, 6, 15, 511761) Any real movement for freedom is like new birth and all its attendant travail.
('36', 257, 6, 16, 511840) If we have to go through a purgatory, we must face it for the priceless boon.
('36', 257, 6, 17, 511918) As a matter of fact, that clash is now taking place on a miniature scale and it may be found to be sufficient for teaching wisdom to both the parties.
('36', 257, 6, 18, 512069) Already innocent blood has been spilt by the gallon.
('36', 257, 6, 19, 512122) By preference in education, I mean every backward section should be specially encouraged by special grants of scholarships.
('36', 257, 6, 20, 512246) It would be the inevitable duty of the state, if it is to represent all classes, to begin with the weakest.
('36', 257, 6, 21, 512354) To spend freely upon the real education of
('36', 257, 7, 22, 512397) 1 Vide Appendix”Letter from Norman Leys”, 9 8 1926.

('36', 258, 1, 2, 512494) the backward classes will be ultimately to provide the safest cure for discontent.
('36', 258, 1, 3, 512577) I know that the present discontent on the part of either side comes from consciousness of weakness.
('36', 258, 1, 4, 512677) Hindus feel their weakness in physical strength and endurance.
('36', 258, 1, 5, 512740) Mussalmans feel their weakness in education and earthly possessions.
('36', 258, 1, 6, 512809) So, I look upon the present feud between the two as a healthy sign in a way.
('36', 258, 1, 7, 512886) It is really unconsciously a battle for freedom.
('36', 258, 1, 8, 512935) It was possible for them to have avoided this if they could have assimilated the programme of 1920. But the energy and the national consciousness that were called into being in 1920 could not possibly remain dormant and, as they could not find their way in a healthy channel, they have taken the unhealthy course of internecine bloody feud.
('36', 258, 1, 9, 513276) I have not a shadow of doubt that, at the end of it, we shall feel stronger and purer because there are people who do not want this feud, who believe in non violence as the final rock and who have not lost their heads during the turmoil.
('36', 258, 1, 10, 513514) The fear expressed by you in your final paragraph is certainly not groundless.

('36', 258, 1, 14, 513858) In that case, history would be merely repeating itself.
('36', 258, 1, 15, 513914) But even that should not frighten a reformer, You cannot wrap yourself in cotton wool and fight freedom’s battle.
('36', 258, 1, 16, 514028) Nor need the spectre of the I.C.S. men refusing to work frighten one.
('36', 258, 1, 17, 514098) But, in spite of my strong indictment of the I.C.S. men, I have sufficient faith in their good nature as men having the upper hand when the demora lizing artificial prestige and protection these estimable men enjoy have been removed.

('36', 269, 0, 1, 530579) 270 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 269, 1, 2, 530621) The signatories are mistaken in thinking that I have gone into retirement.
('36', 269, 1, 3, 530696) I have imposed upon myself a year’s abstention from all avoidable public engagements.
('36', 269, 1, 4, 530782) The year is fast drawing to a close.
('36', 269, 1, 5, 530819) The reasons for abstention were fully stated at the time.
('36', 269, 1, 6, 530877) My health and the requirements of the Ashram necessitated restfrom toilsome travelling and taxing public engagements.
('36', 269, 1, 7, 530995) If I have not interfered in the Council matters, it is because I have, perhaps, no aptitude for them—certainly, I have no faith in the Councils giving us swaraj.
('36', 269, 1, 8, 531157) I have ceased to meddle in Hindu Muslim quarrels because my meddling at this juncture, I am convinced, can only do harm.
('36', 269, 1, 9, 531278) Then there remain untouchability, national educational institutions and the spinning wheel.
('36', 269, 1, 10, 531370) To these I am giving all the attention I am capable of giving.
('36', 269, 2, 11, 531433) Therefore, I venture to suggest to the friends that what to them appears to be my inaction is really concentrated action.
('36', 269, 3, 12, 531555) I do not in the least share their pessimism.
('36', 269, 3, 13, 531600) The Hindu Muslim quarrels are in a way, unknown to us, a fight for swaraj.
('36', 269, 3, 14, 531675) Each party is conscious of its impending coming.
('36', 269, 3, 15, 531724) Each wants to be found ready and fit for swaraj when it comes.
('36', 269, 3, 16, 531787) Hindus think that they are physically weaker than the Mussalmans.
('36', 269, 3, 17, 531853) The latter consider them selves to be weak in educational and earthly equipment.
('36', 269, 3, 18, 531934) They are now doing what all weak bodies have done hitherto.
('36', 269, 3, 19, 531994) This fighting therefore, however unfortunate it may be, is a sign of growth.
('36', 269, 3, 20, 532071) It is like the Wars of the Roses.
('36', 269, 3, 21, 532105) Out of it will rise a mighty nation.
('36', 269, 3, 22, 532142) A better than the bloody way was opened out to us in 1920, but we could not assimilate it.
('36', 269, 3, 23, 532233) But even a bloody way is better than utter helplessness and unmanliness.
('36', 269, 4, 24, 532306) Even the ugly duel between Motilalji and Lalaji is part of the same struggle.
('36', 269, 4, 25, 532384) Let the enemies of India’s freedom gloat over their differences.
('36', 269, 4, 26, 532449) These patriots will be working under the same flag long before the gloating is over.
('36', 269, 4, 27, 532534) They are both lovers of their country.
('36', 269, 4, 28, 532573) Lalaji sees no escape from communalism.
('36', 269, 4, 29, 532613) Panditji cannot brook even the thought of it.
('36', 269, 4, 30, 532659) Who shall say that only one is right?
('36', 269, 4, 31, 532697) Both attitudes are a response to the prevailing atmosphere.
('36', 269, 4, 32, 532757) Lalaji who was born to public life with swaraj on his lips is no hater of it now.
('36', 269, 4, 33, 532839) He proposes to mount to it through communalism which he considers to be an inevitable stage in our evolution.
('36', 269, 4, 34, 532949) Panditji thinks that communalism blocks the way and he therefore proposes to ignore it even as auto suggestionists ignore disease seeing that health, not ‘illth’, is the law of life.
('36', 269, 4, 35, 533132) The nation can ill afford to do without Sir Abdur Rahim as
('36', 270, 0, 1, 533191) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 271
('36', 270, 1, 2, 533236) without Hakim Saheb Ajmal Khan.
('36', 270, 1, 3, 533268) Sir Abdur Rahim, who wrote the weighty minute with Gokhale on the Islington Commission, is no enemy of his country.
('36', 270, 1, 4, 533384) Who shall blame him if he thinks that the country cannot progress without the Mussalmans competing with the Hindus on equal terms?
('36', 270, 1, 5, 533515) He may be wrong in his methods.
('36', 270, 1, 6, 533547) But he is none the less a lover of freedom.
('36', 270, 1, 7, 533591) Whilst, therefore, I can make room in my mind for all these various schools of thought, for me there is only one way.
('36', 270, 1, 8, 533709) I have no faith in communalism even as a stage, or perhaps, better still, I have no fitness for work on that stage.
('36', 270, 1, 9, 533825) I must, therefore, hold myself in reserve till the storm is over and the work of rebuilding has commenced.
('36', 270, 1, 10, 533932) I can but watch from a safe distance the struggle that goes on in the Councils.
('36', 270, 1, 11, 534012) I honour those who have faith in them for prosecuting the programme with zeal.
('36', 270, 1, 12, 534091) It is educated India which is split up into parties.
('36', 270, 1, 13, 534144) I confess my incompetence to bring these parties together.
('36', 270, 1, 14, 534203) Their method is not my method.
('36', 270, 1, 15, 534234) I am trying to work from bottom upward.
('36', 270, 1, 16, 534274) To an onlooker, it is exasperatingly slow work.
('36', 270, 1, 17, 534322) They are working from top downward—a process more difficult and complicated than the former.
('36', 270, 1, 18, 534415) The millions for whom the signatories have claimed to write are uninterested in the party complications which are above their heads.
('36', 270, 1, 19, 534548) For them there is only the spinning wheel.
('36', 270, 1, 20, 534591) To paraphrase a celebrated proverb the wheels of God spin slowly but most effectively.
('36', 270, 1, 21, 534678) I am engaged in attending to these tiny wheels of God.
('36', 270, 1, 22, 534733) Let the signatories and the others who care note that they are ceaselessly moving.
('36', 270, 1, 23, 534816) Their efficiency is daily and visibly growing.
('36', 270, 1, 24, 534863) And when the storm is blown over, the parties are united, Hindus, Mussalmans, Brahmins, non Brahmins, the suppressors and the suppressed have joined hands, they will find that the country has been prepared by silent hands for effecting not a punitive and violent boycott,.
('36', 270, 1, 25, 535136) but a health giving, non violent, constructive boycott of foreign cloth.
('36', 270, 1, 26, 535209) The nation must exhibit some universal strength and power, be they ever so little.
('36', 270, 1, 27, 535292) That is this boycott of foreign cloth.
('36', 270, 1, 28, 535331) The signatories regard themselves as my followers.
('36', 270, 1, 29, 535382) I invite them to follow the lead of the charkha.
('36', 270, 1, 30, 535431) I have not ceased to lead that little, simple wheel which daily hums to me the distress of the masses.
('36', 270, 1, 31, 535534) For better or for worse, I have staked my all on the charkha, for it represents to me Daridranarayana, God of and in the poor and in the downtrodden.
('36', 270, 2, 32, 535684) Young India, 9 9 1926

('36', 274, 7, 17, 541830) 315. PLIGHT OF SCHOOL CHILDREN
('36', 274, 8, 18, 541861) One who knows what she is writing about says:
('36', 274, 9, 19, 541907) Until our boys learn to conserve their vital forces India will never have the men she should have.
('36', 274, 9, 20, 542006) For nearly 17 years I have had charge of boys’ schools in India.
('36', 274, 9, 21, 542071) It is appalling to see the number of boys—Hindu, Mahommedan and Christian—who begin school life full of energy and enthusiasm and hope and end in physical wrecks.
('36', 274, 9, 22, 542234) In literally hundreds of cases, I have traced this directly to self abuse, sodomy or early marriage.
('36', 274, 9, 23, 542335) I have today the names of 42 boys guilty of sodomy and not a boy is over 13 years of age.
('36', 274, 9, 24, 542425) Masters and house fathers will deny that the conditions exist but if the right tactics are used the trouble will be discovered and nearly always the boys will confess.
('36', 274, 9, 25, 542593) A large per cent of the boys confess to having been taught by men—often their own relatives.
('36', 274, 9, 26, 542686) This is no fanciful picture.
('36', 274, 9, 27, 542715) It is truth suppressed by many
('36', 274, 10, 28, 542746) 1 From the postmark
('36', 275, 0, 1, 542766) 276 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
