('36', 283, 1, 15, 564798) It is the finest and cheapest education that can be devised for them.
('36', 283, 1, 16, 564868) Cheapest because it is immediately remunerative.
('36', 283, 1, 17, 564917) And if we want universal education in India, the primary education consists not in a knowledge of the three R’s but in a knowledge of hand spinning and all it implies.
('36', 283, 1, 18, 565085) And when through it the hand and the eye are properly trained, the boy or the girl is ready to receive instruction in the three R’s.
('36', 283, 1, 19, 565218) This I know would appear to some to be utterly absurd and to others to be totally unworkable.
('36', 283, 1, 20, 565312) But those who so think do not know the condition of the millions.
('36', 283, 1, 21, 565378) Nor do they know what it means to educate the millions of children of Indian peasantry.
('36', 283, 1, 22, 565466) And this much needed education cannot be given unless educated India which is responsible for the political awakening in the country will appreciate the dignity of labour and unless every young man would consider it his imperative duty to learn the art of hand spinning and then re introduce it in the village.
('36', 283, 2, 23, 565777) Young India, 9 9 1926
('36', 284, 0, 1, 565799) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 285
('36', 284, 1, 2, 565844) 320. OUT OF THE FRYING PAN
('36', 284, 2, 3, 565871) The report on the condition of returned emigrants stranded in Calcutta submitted to the Council of the Imperial Indian Citizenship Association makes painful reading.
('36', 284, 2, 4, 566037) It appears that there are over 2,000 returned emigrants in Calcutta living in squalid surroundings.
('36', 284, 2, 5, 566137) They are from Fiji, Trinidad, Surinam and British Guiana.”The desire to visit their motherland and the rumour that India had obtained self government were the two chief reasons which led them to leave their birth place.” But they find that their own people in their villages will not have them and so they want to go back to the place where they have come from.” ‘Anywhere out of India’ is their cry”.
('36', 284, 2, 6, 566539) Meantime they are eking out a miserable existence in Calcutta.”They all looked famished.
('36', 284, 2, 7, 566628) Their lot is the lowest ebb of human misery.” The Act that the majority of these men are Colonial born aggravates their misery.
('36', 284, 2, 8, 566756) The reader will not appreciate the full meaning of being ‘Colonial born’.
('36', 284, 2, 9, 566830) These men are neither Indian nor Colonial.
('36', 284, 2, 10, 566873) They have no Indian culture in the foreign lands they go to, save what they pick up from their uncultured half dis Indianized parents.
('36', 284, 2, 11, 567008) They are not Colonial in that they are debarred access to the Colonial, i.e., Western, culture.
('36', 284, 2, 12, 567104) They are therefore out of the frying pan into fire.
('36', 284, 2, 13, 567156) There at least they had some money and a kind of a home.
('36', 284, 2, 14, 567213) Here they are social lepers, not even knowing the language of the people.
('36', 284, 3, 15, 567287) Therefore, the report suggests that it is the clear duty of the Government to send them back to the most suitable Colony that would receive them.
('36', 284, 3, 16, 567433) The tropical Colonies must be glad to have them in preference to raw recruits who have to be initiated.
('36', 284, 3, 17, 567537) The duty is clearly the Government’s.
('36', 284, 3, 18, 567575) For they alone can carry on negotiations with the various Colonies.
('36', 284, 3, 19, 567643) This duty should have been discharged long ago.
('36', 284, 3, 20, 567691) The Imperial Citizenship Association has made the following appeal to the Government:
('36', 284, 4, 21, 567777) With reference to returned Indian emigrants from Fiji, British Guiana, Trinidad and other Colonies now stranded in Calcutta, the Council of the Imperial Indian Citizenship Association, through a representative specially sent from here for the purpose, has made investigations on the spot, and in the light of those investigations, I have the honour to submit the following recommendations for the immediate consideration of the Government of India: l.
('36', 284, 4, 22, 568229) The Government of Fiji should be requested to extend the duration of the moratorium for free passages to freed indentured labourers from 1930 to 1935.
('36', 285, 0, 1, 568380) 286 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 285, 1, 2, 568422) 2. The returned Indian emigrants from British Guiana of whom there are several hundreds now in Calcutta and elsewhere and who are anxious to go back should be included in the Government of India’s scheme of emigration of 500 families to British Guiana.
('36', 285, 1, 3, 568675) 3. The Government of India should, without further delay, establish Emigrants’ Depots in Bombay, Calcutta and Madras.
('36', 285, 1, 4, 568793) These Depots should be organized on the basis of the Indian Emigrants, Friendly Society which was established in Calcutta in 1921 and was dissolved in 1923. This Society looked after the interests of emigrants in every way and was managed by a local committee of both officials and non officials and was very largely financed by the Government of India.
('36', 285, 1, 5, 569147) In view of the fact that another boat with several hundreds of emigrants is expected in Calcutta next month, my Council hopes that the Government of India will realize the gravity of the situation and act in a manner which will not only relieve the distress now prevalent but also effectively prevent further congestion and suffering.
('36', 285, 1, 6, 569482) For the time being, it will be enough if the stranded men get the relief asked for.
('36', 285, 1, 7, 569566) But the innocent looking appeal raises broad and fundamental questions which must not be discussed in this brief notice of the special circumstances brought to light by the report.
('36', 285, 1, 8, 569747) They must not be allowed to confuse the one clear issue which awaits immediate treatment.
('36', 285, 1, 9, 569837) The broad questions however are: l.
('36', 285, 1, 10, 569873) The whole of the emigration policy.
('36', 285, 1, 11, 569909) 2. The special case of British Guiana and Fiji.
('36', 285, 1, 12, 569957) 3. The scope of the friendly societies referred to in the appeal.
('36', 285, 1, 13, 570023) 4. The duty of the nation by the outgoing and returning emigrants.
('36', 285, 1, 14, 570090) The consideration of these questions requires a more favourable occasion and a more thorough treatment than can be given them at the present moment.
('36', 285, 2, 15, 570239) Young India, 9 9 1926
('36', 286, 0, 1, 570261) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 287

('36', 294, 7, 19, 583032) BHAISHRI KAKA, Your letter to Swami about your health did not alarm me, but your letter to me did.
('36', 294, 7, 20, 583131) I will certainly have a talk with Swami; but, as
('36', 295, 0, 1, 583180) 296 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 295, 1, 2, 583222) they say, too many midwives attending on a woman in labour make the delivery more difficult, and so I am of the view that when one friend is guiding a person with great love and intelligently, others may express an opinion if they feel inclined to and leave the matter there.
('36', 295, 1, 3, 583498) I believe that for many reasons the right of advising you in regard to your health belongs chiefly to Swami.
('36', 295, 1, 4, 583607) He is, moreover, an intelligent person and, therefore, I don’t feel anxious either.
('36', 295, 1, 5, 583691) There may be differences of opinion in certain matters and I make a suggestion in passing, but don’t press my view.
('36', 295, 1, 6, 583807) There is hardly any science as imperfect as the science of medicine, and, in a matter in which we are guided mostly by inferences, to press one’s view on a man who is following a certain line, and thereby create doubt in his mind, will be like spoiling the mendicant’s chances for both things, as the saying goes.
('36', 295, 1, 7, 584121) I am not particularly enamoured of Mussoorie.
('36', 295, 1, 8, 584167) We are poor people and I, therefore, do believe that we should draw the line somewhere.
('36', 295, 1, 9, 584255) As to where and when to draw it, there can be of course no fixed rule which can be applied to everyone.
('36', 295, 1, 10, 584359) All of us here will discuss with Swami what should be done in your case, and finally abide by his decision.
('36', 295, 1, 11, 584467) There is biting cold in the air here these days.
('36', 295, 1, 12, 584516) The sky is all the time overcast with clouds and the river is full to the banks.
('36', 295, 1, 13, 584597) Tanasukha’s letter had no effect on me.

('36', 296, 5, 14, 585728) 337. A TALK
('36', 296, 6, 15, 585740) [After October 10, 1926] 1
('36', 296, 7, 16, 585767) On reading Narahari’s report, the cultivators of Bardoli might feel with me as an accused person is said to have felt listening to his lawyer’s speech, Tears flowed from his eyes as he listened.
('36', 296, 7, 17, 585962) On the magistrate asking him why he was crying, the accused replied that in truth he did not know that he was as innocent as the lawyer had made him out to be.
('36', 296, 7, 18, 586122) I wonder if the cultivators who have read Narahari’s report ask themselves how they are still alive though they are as poor as they are described in it.
('36', 296, 7, 19, 586275) We should not rest content with this report.
('36', 296, 7, 20, 586320) People cannot manage to live even in the manner you have described them as living.
('36', 296, 7, 21, 586403) If what you say is indeed true, there should be decrease in the number of villages and the fact of such decrease should be proved.
('36', 296, 7, 22, 586534) A given state of affairs is bound to have certain consequences.
('36', 296, 7, 23, 586598) We should collect evidence to show how many persons in Bardoli live on money earned outside, how many persons have left the place and gone elsewhere and how many fields have passed into the hands of big landlords.
('36', 296, 7, 24, 586812) We do not follow up the reports which we hear and ascertain their truth.
('36', 296, 7, 25, 586885) I have much to say about this report.
('36', 296, 7, 26, 586923) We cannot start a struggle on its basis.
('36', 296, 7, 27, 586964) It is a good one as a collection of statistics.
('36', 296, 7, 28, 587012) It may even do as a lawyer’s rejoinder, but I do not think it can serve as a basis for comparison.

('36', 297, 1, 4, 587539) If we start a struggle to force the Government to revise the method which they have followed so far, it will be a long one.

('36', 297, 5, 15, 588418) The experiences of others, valuable though they are, cannot avail me at the present moment for, as I fancy, God has cut out my work and has left me no choice but to do the work.

('36', 299, 3, 9, 590634) 342. SATYAGRAHA—TRUE AND FALSE
('36', 299, 4, 10, 590665) [September 12, 1926] 1
('36', 299, 5, 11, 590688) There are many forms of satyagraha, of which fasting may or may not be one, according to the circumstances of the case.
('36', 299, 5, 12, 590808) A friend has put the following poser:
('36', 299, 6, 13, 590846) A man want to recover money another owes him.
('36', 299, 6, 14, 590892) He cannot do so by going to law as he is a non co operator, and the debtor in the intoxication of the power of his wealth pays him no heed, and refuses even to accept arbitration.
('36', 299, 6, 15, 591072) If in these circumstances, the creditor sits dharna at the debtor’s
('36', 299, 7, 16, 591140) door, would it not be satyagraha?
('36', 299, 7, 17, 591174) The fasting creditor seeks to injure no one by his fasting.
('36', 299, 7, 18, 591234) Ever since the golden ageof Rama, we have been following this method.
('36', 299, 7, 19, 591304) But I am told you regard this as intimidation.
('36', 299, 7, 20, 591351) If you do, will you
('36', 299, 8, 21, 591371) kindly explain?
('36', 299, 8, 22, 591387) I know the correspondent.
('36', 299, 8, 23, 591413) He has written from the purest motive.
('36', 299, 8, 24, 591452) But I have no doubt that he is mistaken in his interpretation of satyagraha.
('36', 299, 8, 25, 591529) Satyagraha can never be resorted to for personal gain.
('36', 299, 8, 26, 591584) If fasting with a view to recovering money is to be encouraged, there would be no end of scoundrels blackmailing people by resorting to these means.
('36', 299, 8, 27, 591733) I know that many such people are to be met with in the country.
('36', 299, 8, 28, 591797) It is not right to argue that those who rightly resort to fasting need not be condemned because it is abused in a few cases.
('36', 299, 8, 29, 591922) Any and everyone may not draw his own distinction between fasting—satya graha—true and false.
('36', 299, 8, 30, 592016) What one regards as true satyagraha may very likely be otherwise.
('36', 299, 8, 31, 592082) Satyagraha, therefore, cannot be resorted to for personal gain, but only for the good of others.
('36', 299, 8, 32, 592179) A satyagrahi should
('36', 299, 9, 33, 592199) 1 The original, in Gujarati, appeared in Navajivan, 12 9 1926. The English translation is by Mahadev Desai.
('36', 300, 0, 1, 592307) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 301
('36', 300, 1, 2, 592352) always be ready to undergo suffering and pecuniary loss.
('36', 300, 1, 3, 592409) That there would not be wanting dishonest people to reap an undue advantage from the boycott of law courts practised by good people was a contingency not unexpected at the inception of non co operation.
('36', 300, 1, 4, 592612) It was then thought that the beauty of non co operation lay just in taking those risks.
('36', 300, 1, 5, 592700) But satyagraha in the form of fasting cannot be undertaken as against an opponent.
('36', 300, 1, 6, 592783) Fasting can be resorted to only against one’s nearest and dearest, and that solely for his or her good.
('36', 300, 1, 7, 592887) In a country like India, where the spirit of charity or pity is not lacking, it would be nothing short of an outrage to resort to fasting for recovering money.
('36', 300, 1, 8, 593047) I know people who have given away money, quite against their will, but out of a false sense of pity.
('36', 300, 1, 9, 593148) The satyagrahi has, therefore, to proceed warily in a land like ours.
('36', 300, 1, 10, 593218) It is likely that some men may succeed in recovering money due to them by resorting to fasting; but instead of calling it a triumph of satyagraha, I would call it a triumph of duragraha or violence.
('36', 300, 1, 11, 593417) The triumph of satyagraha consists in meeting death in the insistence on truth.
('36', 300, 1, 12, 593497) A satyagrahi is always unattached to the attainment of the object of satyagraha; one seeking to recover money cannot be so unattached.
('36', 300, 1, 13, 593632) I am therefore clear that fasting for the sake of personal gain is nothing short of intimidation and the result of ignorance.
('36', 300, 2, 14, 593758) Young India, 30 9 1926
('36', 300, 3, 15, 593781) 343. A DILEMMA
('36', 300, 4, 16, 593796) A correspondent writes: 1
('36', 300, 5, 17, 593822) It is likely that the statement,”it would be preferable to use Eng lish cloth rather than use cloth made in Indian mills”, was quoted 2
('36', 300, 6, 18, 593958) from Hind Swaraj.
('36', 300, 6, 19, 593976) In the logical context in which the remark occurs, Iwould say today the same thing which I did in 1908. 3 It is a statement
('36', 300, 7, 20, 594100) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('36', 300, 7, 21, 594137) The correspondent had requested Gandhiji to explain the reason which had led to the change in his attitude towards textile mills in India.
('36', 300, 7, 22, 594276) In Hind Swaraj, Gandhiji had stated that it might be in the interest of the country to continue to import cloth from Manchester for some time longer rather than set up mills in the country itself, but in 1921 he had adopted the attitude that India should herself produce all the cloth required to meet her needs, even supporting Indian mills, if necessary.
('36', 300, 7, 23, 594633) 2 By Balukaka Kanetkar, at a meeting in Poona 3 Hind Swaraj was written in 1909.
('36', 301, 0, 1, 594714) 302 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 301, 1, 2, 594756) of principle, and it may not be possible to act upon it in certain circumstances.
('36', 301, 1, 3, 594838) I, therefore, drew the readers’ attention to this point in the Hindi edition of Hind Swaraj.
('36', 301, 1, 4, 594931) 1 What I have stated there is also correct in our present circumstances.
('36', 301, 1, 5, 595004) If we had not allowed ourselves to be caught in the snare of mills, if the question had merely been whether we should set up new mills and use what we suppose would be swadeshi cloth or to continue to import and use foreign cloth, I would prefer the latter course, because I do not believe that the mill industry is an activity which deserves to be spread in other parts of the world.
('36', 301, 1, 6, 595389) We could produce cloth even if we had no mill industry, produce enough to meet our needs.
('36', 301, 1, 7, 595479) We have seen from experience that we do not have to spend much time in this work.
('36', 301, 1, 8, 595561) I do not, therefore, believe that the mill industry serves any social purpose or benefits the people in any way.
('36', 301, 1, 9, 595674) But the problem is quite different, the position being exactly the opposite.
('36', 301, 1, 10, 595751) We have quite a large number of mills in the country.
('36', 301, 1, 11, 595805) It is not possible today to persuade their owners to wind them up.
('36', 301, 1, 12, 595872) Boycott of foreign cloth is not only desirable but essential; it is our duty to bring it about; we have the right to do so.
('36', 301, 1, 13, 595996) In doing that duty, we should makeuse of a means which is readily available to us.
('36', 301, 1, 14, 596079) Not to do so would augur lack of intelligence in us.
('36', 301, 1, 15, 596132) Dharma is not an absolute thing which does not change even when circumstances have changed.
('36', 301, 1, 16, 596224) If people living on the Equator follow what is dharma for people near the North Pole, they would probably be guilty of adharma 2. There is only one absolute dharma, and that is contained in God, otherwise known as truth.
('36', 301, 1, 17, 596445) The dharma of beings, who are governed by their circumstances and whose strength is limited, changes from hour to hour.
('36', 301, 1, 18, 596565) The ground on which their dharma rests is unchanging, and that is truth or, if one prefers, non violence; but, as one stands firm on this ground, there will necessarily be many changes in what dharma requires in actual practice.
('36', 301, 1, 19, 596794) We should understand the problem of mills in this light.
('36', 301, 1, 20, 596851) Otherwise, we have no reason to welcome the spread of an industry which induces cultivators to leave their fields to go to cities and live there, with their families, in narrow, dark cells without any regard for morality.
('36', 301, 1, 21, 597073) Even looking at it from the point of view of the rich, we see
('36', 301, 2, 22, 597135) 1 From the preface to the Hindi edition published in 1921, the correspondent had quoted:”My views in regard to mills have undergone this much change.
('36', 301, 2, 23, 597285) In view of the present predicament of India, we should produce in our own country all the cloth that we need even by supporting, if necessary, mills in India rather than buy cloth made in Manchester.” 2Opposite of dharma
('36', 302, 0, 1, 597506) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 303
('36', 302, 1, 2, 597551) no very elevating scenes which are due to the mill industry.
('36', 302, 1, 3, 597612) It is not an ennobling ideal merely to earn money and distribute it among a small number of share holders.
('36', 302, 1, 4, 597719) But, as the body seems to us a filthy thing when we think of it in the abstract and still we tolerate it because we cannot dispense with it, so also we should tolerate mills since in our present circumstances we cannot get rid of them, and if they serve our purpose, avail ourselves of their benefit to bring about boycott of foreign cloth.
('36', 302, 1, 5, 598060) If they do not serve even this purpose, if we discover that on the contrary they hinder our efforts to bring about such boycott, then their destruction may be considered desirable, nay necessary.

('36', 303, 8, 16, 600277) 346. LETTER TO MALCOLM MUGGERIDGE
('36', 303, 9, 17, 600311) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, September 12, 1926
('36', 303, 10, 18, 600353) DEAR FRIEND, I thank you for your letter.
('36', 303, 10, 19, 600395) I have not read the book referred to by you.
('36', 303, 10, 20, 600440) My own personal experience and those of many others is
('36', 303, 11, 21, 600495) 1 Writing on July 28, after a silence of over 12 years, Drew described inter alia his visit to the Press at Phoenix where Indian Opinion was being printed and his meeting Manilal Gandhi whose devoted labours for his father’s weekly he commended (S.N. 10788).
('36', 304, 0, 1, 600754) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 305
('36', 304, 1, 2, 600799) at variance with the quotation sent by you.
('36', 304, 1, 3, 600843) But I think there is difference between the author’s standpoint and that of my friends and my own.
('36', 304, 1, 4, 600942) When abstinence is practised”under the false idea that the instinct is but a low pleasure” it may produce”irritability and the weakening of love”.
('36', 304, 1, 5, 601089) But when abstinence is practised for the purpose of self realization, for the purpose of husbanding vitality and for the seeking, basing [sic] love not on physical pleasure but upon soul contact, it soothes one’s nerves and purifies and therefore strengthens the bond between the two.
('36', 304, 1, 6, 601374) Most of the ills that you describe spring, in my opinion, from a wrong view of love and a wrong view of sexual relation.
('36', 304, 1, 7, 601495) Under my own plan husband and wife need not liveseparately, that is, under separate roofs, but they certainly ought not to share the same room and lock themselves in.
('36', 304, 1, 8, 601662) Long course of habit blinds us to the ugliness of men and women passing nights after nights in privacy, without any moral purpose whatsoever.
('36', 304, 1, 9, 601804) In doing so we become less even than animals.
('36', 304, 1, 10, 601850) I can see nothing wrong in husband and wife seeking privacy only for sexual act which they will perform in due humility and purely for the sake of procreation.
('36', 304, 1, 11, 602010) There will, I know, still be animal pleasure left in the act.
('36', 304, 1, 12, 602072) I would call that lawful animal pleasure.
('36', 304, 1, 13, 602114) And if we could only set our thought right and strive, in spite of the present practice to the contrary, to shape our own in accordance with the thought, I doubt not that restraint will not only be easy, but the most natural thing in the world.
('36', 304, 1, 14, 602359) I may have the handsomest girl as my sister and if the custom of kissing my sister is in vogue and in accordance with it I kiss my sister, surely no lustful thought will spring up in my breast.

('36', 310, 6, 12, 612205) INDIAN TEXT BOOKS
('36', 310, 7, 13, 612223) What it means to prepare real text books for India’s children may be somewhat realized from the following quotation from a letter from Mr. Gregg who is at present teaching hill children on Mr. Stokes’s farm in Kotgarh near Simla.
('36', 310, 7, 14, 612453) He says:
('36', 310, 8, 15, 612462) My time has been much occupied in preparing a re arrangement of the text books in both mathematics and physics for my pupils, such as will conform to their experience.
('36', 310, 8, 16, 612630) All English text books, and even the Indian ones, are apparently written for city bred children and presuppose familiarity with machinery and manufactured apparatus of all kinds.
('36', 310, 8, 17, 612809) These children here have never seen automobiles, steam engines, electric lights, pumps, water pipes, or even bullock carts.
('36', 310, 8, 18, 612933) So the assumptions, pictures, technical terms and arrangement of the text books of physics, and even of much of mathematics can have no reality and therefore no interest or educational value for them.
('36', 310, 8, 19, 613134) Gradually, therefore, I am putting together what will be in effect a text book on science and mathematics for Indian village children.
('36', 310, 8, 20, 613269) Since most of the children of India are in the villages, I hope it will be useful.
('36', 310, 8, 21, 613352) But Mr. Gregg’s letter opens up a much wider question.
('36', 310, 8, 22, 613407) What is
('36', 310, 9, 23, 613415) 1 Not reproduced here.
('36', 310, 9, 24, 613438) This was about a spinning demonstration by the students of primary schools of Shahabad district held on August 27. 2 Not reproduced here.
('36', 310, 9, 25, 613576) This gave an account of the progress of spinning work in the various schools.

('36', 311, 1, 2, 613696) true of urbanized, exploiting and wealthy countries likeEngland and America cannot be true of an India predominantly rural, pauperized and exploited.
('36', 311, 1, 3, 613846) For India a multiplicity of text books means depriv ation of the vast majority of village children of the means of instruc tion.
('36', 311, 1, 4, 613975) Text books, therefore, in India must mean, principally and for the lower standards, text books for teachers, not pupils.
('36', 311, 1, 5, 614096) Indeed, I am not sure that it is not better for the children to have much of the preliminary instruction imparted to them vocally.

('36', 311, 3, 10, 614907) 355. STUDENTS’ DUTY
('36', 311, 4, 11, 614927) A Lahore correspondent writes a pathetic letter in scholarly Hindi.
('36', 311, 4, 12, 614995) I give a free rendering of the main parts of the letter:
('36', 311, 5, 13, 615052) Hindu Muslim feuds and the feverish activity over the Council elections have thrown the non co operating students off their balance.
('36', 311, 5, 14, 615185) They have sacrificed much for the country.
('36', 311, 5, 15, 615228) Its service is their watchword.
('36', 311, 5, 16, 615260) They are today without a helmsman.
('36', 311, 5, 17, 615295) They cannot enthuse over Councils.
('36', 311, 5, 18, 615330) They do not want to take part in the Hindu Muslim feud.
('36', 311, 5, 19, 615386) They are therefore drifting towards a life of aimlessness and worse.
('36', 311, 5, 20, 615455) Must they be allowed thus to drift?
('36', 311, 5, 21, 615491) Pray remember that ultimately you are responsible for this result.
('36', 311, 5, 22, 615558) For, though nominally they obeyed the Congress call, in reality it was you they obeyed.
('36', 311, 5, 23, 615646) Is it not up to you now to guide them?
('36', 311, 5, 24, 615685) Man can make a trough, can he lead unwilling horses to it?

('36', 311, 5, 26, 615840) If they obeyed my call, what is there to prevent them [from] doing so now?
('36', 311, 5, 27, 615915) I am speaking with no uncertain
('36', 312, 0, 1, 615947) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 313
('36', 312, 1, 2, 615992) voice to all who will listen, to take up the gospel of the charkha.

('36', 312, 2, 22, 617588) Young India, 16 9 1926
('36', 312, 3, 23, 617611) 356. INFLUENCE OF ATTITUDES
('36', 312, 4, 24, 617639) I have been very interested in your articles in Young India on the
('36', 312, 5, 25, 617706) subject of birth control.
('36', 312, 5, 26, 617732) I expect you have read J. A. Hadfield’s book Psychology and Morals.
('36', 312, 5, 27, 617800) I want to draw your attention to this passage from it:
('36', 312, 6, 28, 617855) “We, therefore, speak of sexual pleasure when the expression of this instinct is alien to our moral sense; and we speak of sexual joy when the expression of this instinct is in conformity with the sentiment of love.
('36', 312, 6, 29, 618071) The too profuse breeders punish not only the poor children they breed, but also humanity in general.” 1
('36', 312, 7, 30, 618175) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here from Malcolm Muggeridge’s letter; vide also”Letter to Malcolm Muggeridge”, 12 9 1926.
('36', 313, 0, 1, 618297) 314 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 313, 1, 2, 618339) So writes a correspondent.
('36', 313, 1, 3, 618366) The letter to me is a study in mental attitudes and their influence.
('36', 313, 1, 4, 618435) Mind takes a rope to be a snake and the man with that mentality turns pale and runs away or takes up a stick to belabour the fancied snake.
('36', 313, 1, 5, 618575) Another mistakes a sister for wife and has animal passion rising in his breast.
('36', 313, 1, 6, 618655) The passion subsides, the moment he discovers his mistake.
('36', 313, 1, 7, 618714) And so in the case quoted by the correspondent.
('36', 313, 1, 8, 618762) No doubt, whilst”abstinence is practised under the false idea that the instinct is but a low pleasure”, it is likely”to produce irritability and the weakening of love”.
('36', 313, 1, 9, 618931) But if abstinence is practised with the desire to strengthen the bond of love, to purify it and to conserve the vital energy for a better purpose, instead of promoting irritability, it will promote equanimity, and instead of loosening the bond of affection, strengthen it.
('36', 313, 1, 10, 619204) Love based upon indulgence of animal passion is at best a selfish affair and likely to snap under the slightest strain.
('36', 313, 1, 11, 619324) And why should the sexual act be a sacrament in the human species, if it is not that among the lower animals?
('36', 313, 1, 12, 619434) Why should we not look at it as what it is in reality, i.e., a simple act of procreation to which we are helplessly drawn for the perpetuation of the species?
('36', 313, 1, 13, 619593) Only a man having been gifted with a free will to a limited extent exercises the human prerogative of self denial for the sake of the well being of the species, for the sake of the nobler purpose, to which he is born, than his brother animals.
('36', 313, 1, 14, 619837) It is the force of habit which makes us think the sexual act to be necessary and desirable for the promotion of love, apart from procreation, in spite of innumerable experiences to the contrary that it does not deepen love, that it is in no way necessary for its retention or enrichment.
('36', 313, 1, 15, 620125) Indeed, instances can be quoted in which that bond has grown stronger with abstinence.
('36', 313, 1, 16, 620212) No doubt abstinence must be a voluntary act undertaken for mutual moral advancement.
('36', 313, 2, 17, 620297) Human society is a ceaseless growth, an unfoldment in terms of spirituality.
('36', 313, 2, 18, 620374) If so, it must be based on ever increasing restraint upon the demands of the flesh.
('36', 313, 2, 19, 620458) Thus, marriage must be considered to be a sacrament imposing discipline upon the partners restricting them to the physical union only among themselves and for the purpose only of procreation when both the partners desire and are prepared for it.
('36', 313, 2, 20, 620704) Then, in either case supposed by the correspondent, there would be no question of sexual act outside the desire for procreation.
('36', 313, 3, 21, 620833) There is an end to all argument if we start, as my correspondent has started, with the premise that sexual act is a necessity outside of the
('36', 314, 0, 1, 620974) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 315
('36', 314, 1, 2, 621019) purpose of procreation.
('36', 314, 1, 3, 621043) The premise is vitiated in the presence of authentic instances that can be cited of complete abstinence having been practised by some of the highest among mankind in all climes.
('36', 314, 1, 4, 621221) It is no argument against the possibility or desirability of abstinence to say that it is difficult for the vast majority of mankind.
('36', 314, 1, 5, 621355) What was not possible for the vast majority a hundred years ago has been found possible today.
('36', 314, 1, 6, 621450) And what is a hundred years in the cycle of time open to us for making infinite progress?
('36', 314, 1, 7, 621540) If scientists are right, it was but yesterday that we found ourselves endowed with the human body.
('36', 314, 1, 8, 621639) Who knows, who dare prescribe, its limitations?
('36', 314, 1, 9, 621687) Indeed, every day we are discovering the infiniteness of its city 1 for good as well as evil.
('36', 314, 2, 10, 621781) If the possibility and desirability of abstinence be admitted, we must find out and devise the means of attaining it.
('36', 314, 2, 11, 621899) And as I have said in a previous article 1, life must be remodelled, if we are to live under restraint and discipline.
('36', 314, 2, 12, 622018) We may not, as the vulgar saying goes, have the cake and eat it.
('36', 314, 2, 13, 622083) If we would impose restraint upon the organs of procreation, we must impose it upon all the others.
('36', 314, 2, 14, 622183) If the eye and the ear and the nose and the tongue, the hands and the feet are let loose, it is impossible to keep the primary organ under check.
('36', 314, 2, 15, 622329) Most cases of irritability, hysteria, and even insanity which are wrongly ascribed to attempts at continence will in truth be found traceable to the incontinence of the other senses.
('36', 314, 2, 16, 622512) No sin, no breach of Nature’s laws, goes unpunished.
('36', 314, 3, 17, 622565) I must not quarrel about words.
('36', 314, 3, 18, 622597) If self control be an interference with Nature precisely in the same sense as contraceptives, be it so.
('36', 314, 3, 19, 622701) I would still maintain that the one interference is lawful and desirable because it promotes the well being of the individuals as well as society, whereas the other degrades both and, therefore, unlawful.
('36', 314, 3, 20, 622906) Self control is the surest and the only method of regulating the birth rate.
('36', 314, 3, 21, 622983) Birth control by contraceptives is race suicide.
('36', 314, 4, 22, 623032) Lastly, if the mine owners are in the wrong and still win, they will do so not because the miners over breed, but because the miners have not learnt the lesson of restraint all along the line.
('36', 314, 4, 23, 623225) If miners had no children, they would have no incentive for any betterment and they will have no provable cause for a rise in wages.
('36', 314, 4, 24, 623358) Need they drink, gamble, smoke?
('36', 314, 4, 25, 623390) Will it be any answer to say that mine owners do all these things and yet have the upper hand?

('36', 315, 3, 15, 624624) 357. ANTI CONSCRIPTION
('36', 315, 4, 16, 624647) The following innocent manifesto 1 has been issued in Europe by a speciall ad hoc committee whose address is 11, Abbey Road, Enfield, Middlesex, England.
('36', 315, 4, 17, 624801) Its Hon.
('36', 315, 4, 18, 624810) Secretary is Mr. H. Runham Brown:
('36', 315, 5, 19, 624844) During the War people in all the countries determined to throw off for ever the yoke of militarism, and, when peace came, the League of Nations was welcomed as the offspring of this hope.
('36', 315, 5, 20, 625032) It is our duty to see that the terrible suffering of the War does not recur.
('36', 315, 5, 21, 625109) We call for some definite step towards complete disarmament, and the demilitarizing of the mind of civilized nations.
('36', 315, 5, 22, 625227) The most effective measure towards this would be the universal abolition of conscription.
('36', 315, 5, 23, 625317) We therefore ask the League of Nations to propose the abolition of compulsory military service in all countries as a first step towards true disarmament..
('36', 315, 5, 24, 625472) It is our belief that conscript armies, with their large corps of professional officers, are a grave menace to peace.
('36', 315, 5, 25, 625590) Conscription involves the degradation of human personality, and the destruction of liberty.
('36', 315, 5, 26, 625682) Barrack life, military drill, blind obedience to commands, however unjust and foolish they may be, and deliberate training for slaughter undermine respect for the
('36', 315, 6, 27, 625845) 1 This carried the signatures, among others, of Gandhiji and other prominent Indian leaders.
('36', 316, 0, 1, 625938) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 317
('36', 316, 1, 2, 625983) individual, for democracy and human life.
('36', 316, 1, 3, 626025) It is debasing human dignity to force men to give up their lives, or to inflict death against their will, or without conviction as to the justice of their action.
('36', 316, 1, 4, 626188) The State which thinks itself entitled to force its citizens to go to war will never pay proper regard to the value and happiness of their lives in peace.
('36', 316, 1, 5, 626343) Moreover, by conscription the militarist spirit of aggressiveness is implanted in the whole male population at the most impressionable age.
('36', 316, 1, 6, 626483) By training for war men come to consider war as unavoidable and even desirable.
('36', 316, 1, 7, 626563) By the universal abolition of conscription, war will be made less easy.
('36', 316, 1, 8, 626635) The Government of a country which maintains conscription has little difficulty in declaring war, for it can silence the whole population by a mobilization order.
('36', 316, 1, 9, 626797) When Governments have to depend for support upon the voluntary consent of their peoples, they must necessarily exercise caution in their foreign policies.
('36', 316, 1, 10, 626952) In the first draft of the Covenant of the League of Nations, President Wilson 1 proposed to make conscription illegal in all affiliated countries.
('36', 316, 1, 11, 627099) It is our duty to restore the original spirit which created the League, a pint shared by many of those who fought in the war, and professed by many of the statesmen of the countries concerned.
('36', 316, 1, 12, 627292) By the universal abolition of conscription we can take a decisive step towards peace and liberty.
('36', 316, 1, 13, 627390) We therefore call upon all men and women of goodwill to help create in all countries a public opinion which will induce Governments and the League of Nations to take this definite step to rid the world of the spirit of militarism, and to open the way to a new era of freedom within nations and of fraternity between them.
('36', 316, 1, 14, 627712) The manifesto is signed by well known men and women from England, Finland, France, Germany, India, Sweden, Holland, Czecho slovakia, Belgium, Spain, Switzerland, Denmark, Austria, Japan and Norway.
('36', 316, 1, 15, 627910) The first step towards the abolition of the military spirit is no doubt abolition of conscription.
('36', 316, 1, 16, 628009) But the reformers will have to put up an immense struggle to secure State action in the desired direction.
('36', 316, 1, 17, 628116) Each is afraid and distrustful 2 of his neighbour.

('36', 316, 3, 20, 628209) The Council of the All India Spinners’ Association that was held recently, discussing the desirability of announcing a definite

('36', 317, 0, 1, 628464) 318 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 317, 1, 2, 628506) Khadi Service, appointed a small committee to draft the constitution and circulate it for opinion among khadi workers.
('36', 317, 1, 3, 628625) The best and cheapest method of circulating the constitution is through the medium of the Press.
('36', 317, 1, 4, 628722) The draft constitution is published below.
('36', 317, 1, 5, 628765) I hope that all those who are interested in khadi will send their considered opinion as early as possible.
('36', 317, 1, 6, 628872) I invite specially the opinion of teachers and students in national educational institutions.
('36', 317, 1, 7, 628966) There is in this Khadi Service almost limitless scope.
('36', 317, 1, 8, 629021) Those who are satisfied with mere livelihood derived from service of the millions will find this Khadi Service to be attractive and all satisfying.
('36', 317, 1, 9, 629169) The opinion of teachers and students will be most valuable in enabling the Council to fix an acceptable constitution.
('36', 317, 1, 10, 629287) The following is the translation of the draft constitution.
('36', 317, 2, 11, 629347) KHADI SERVICE
('36', 317, 3, 12, 629361) There shall be under the All India Spinners’ Association a service called the ‘Khadi Service’.
('36', 317, 3, 13, 629456) No one shall in future be accepted as a member of that service who does not hold a certificate from the Technical Department of the Association at present situated at the Satyagraha Ashram, Sabarmati.
('36', 317, 4, 14, 629657) QUALIFICATIONS OF CANDIDATES
('36', 317, 5, 15, 629686) No one who has not completed his 16th year, who has not a competent knowledge of the vernacular of his province, and of arithmetic, and who does not produce a certificate of good conduct and health, shall be admitted for instruction in the Technical Department.
('36', 317, 6, 16, 629948) INSTRUCTION
('36', 317, 7, 17, 629960) The course of instruction shall be not less than two years and shall include: (a) all the processes that cotton has to go through up to weaving, that is, gathering, ginning, carding, spinning and weaving; (b) a knowledge of Hindi or Hindustani, where candidates come from a province where Hindi or Hindustani is not the vernacular; (c) a knowledge of book keeping—indigenous and Western.
('36', 317, 7, 18, 630348) When the candidate has obtained a certificate of competency to the foregoing he will be sent to a khadi karyalaya in any of the provinces to gain practical experience for one season which extends to nearly 8 months.
('36', 317, 7, 19, 630564) Any candidate who has obtained a satisfactory
('36', 318, 0, 1, 630610) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 319
('36', 318, 1, 2, 630655) certificate from the head of the depot to which he has been sent for practical experience shall be enrolled as a member of the Khadi Service, provided, however, that no one shall be so enrolled who has either broken down in character or health during the course of instruction.
('36', 318, 1, 3, 630933) Any person so enrolled will be liable to serve in any depot wherever he is required by the Association.
('36', 318, 1, 4, 631037) The salary shall be per month Rs. .
('36', 318, 1, 5, 631073) subject to such increase as may be fixed from time to time by the Khadi Service Board to be appointed by the Association.
('36', 318, 1, 6, 631195) Every candidate who wishes to avail himself of the Khadi Service shall be required on joining to sign the contract of service to be framed by the said board.
('36', 318, 2, 7, 631353) MISCELLANEOUS
('36', 318, 3, 8, 631367) Persons who do not wish to join the Khadi Service may also be admitted for instruction in the Technical Department.
('36', 318, 3, 9, 631483) Preference, however, will always be given to those who wish to enter the Khadi Service.
('36', 318, 3, 10, 631571) There will be a short course of 3 months for those who merely want to learn hand spinning and all the antecedent processes, that is, ginning, carding and sliver making.
('36', 318, 3, 11, 631740) Every applicant for instruction whose application has been accepted will be required to deposit return fare for the place from which he or she comes, plus Rs. 3 to be utilized for his or her return in the event of his or her being dismissed from any cause whatsoever.
('36', 318, 4, 12, 632008) SCHOLARSHIP
('36', 318, 5, 13, 632020) A monthly scholarship of Rs. 12 for board, and free lodging, shall be given to those candidates for instruction who are thought to the entire satisfaction of the Director of the Technical Department to be too poor to pay for their board.
('36', 318, 5, 14, 632258) No monetary payment will be made where the Department is able to conduct a common boarding house for candidates.
('36', 318, 6, 15, 632371) RESERVATION
('36', 318, 7, 16, 632383) The Council reserves the right to alter or amend the constitution from time to time and frame by laws, fix the terms of service, rules of discipline and deal with other matters not covered by the constitution.
('36', 318, 7, 17, 632593) Nothing in this constitution shall affect the rights of those who are already in the employment of the A.I.S.A.

('36', 320, 4, 5, 634382) MY DEAR CHILD, The Roman Catholic fast which you refer to in your letter is really no fasting at all, but there is or there was a real fast also amongst them.
('36', 320, 4, 6, 634541) However, whether they have or they had or not is of no consequence to us.

('36', 320, 4, 9, 634767) In spite of most devout attention to every word ascribed to Jesus in the New Testament and in spite of my having read in a humble spirit all about Jesus, I have really not seen any fundamental distinction between him and the other great teachers.

('36', 320, 4, 11, 635124) That is the teaching you have imbibed from childhood and you would read everything else with that unconscious conviction.
('36', 320, 4, 12, 635246) Nobody taught me in my childhood to differentiate.
('36', 320, 4, 13, 635297) I have therefore grown without bias one way or the other.
('36', 320, 4, 14, 635355) I can pay equal homage to Jesus, Muhammed, Krishna, Buddha, Zoroaster and others that may be named.
('36', 320, 4, 15, 635455) But this is not a matter for argument.
('36', 320, 4, 16, 635494) It is a matter for each one’s deep and sacred conviction.
('36', 320, 4, 17, 635552) I have no desire whatsoever to dislodge you from the exclusive homage you pay to Jesus.
('36', 320, 4, 18, 635640) But I would like you to understand and appreciate the other inclusive position.
('36', 320, 4, 19, 635720) What Menon has told you about the pecuniary difficulty is quite correct.
('36', 320, 4, 20, 635793) But so is your remark 1. You will come here if God makes the way clear for you.

('36', 323, 1, 2, 639151) 365. LETTER TO SHEWAKRAM KARAMCHAND
('36', 323, 2, 3, 639187) THE ASHRAM,
('36', 323, 3, 4, 639199) SABARMATI, September 17, 1926
('36', 323, 4, 5, 639229) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('36', 323, 4, 6, 639262) Here are my answers: 1. I have simply cited the instance of George Muller as I have heard.
('36', 323, 4, 7, 639353) I believe in the possibility of a heart prayer being answered in the manner George Muller’s is supposed to have been.
('36', 323, 4, 8, 639471) It does not mean that George Muller did not work for his daily bread.
('36', 323, 4, 9, 639541) He prayed for the support of a philanthropic institution which he conducted.
('36', 323, 4, 10, 639618) His life otherwise was a most strenuous life.
('36', 323, 4, 11, 639664) But it is said of him that he never stretched forth his hand for begging except to God.
('36', 323, 4, 12, 639752) 2. I have not studied the miracles from the miraculous standpoint.
('36', 323, 4, 13, 639819) I neither believe nor disbelieve them.
('36', 323, 4, 14, 639858) I hold that they ought not to affect our conduct one way or the other.
('36', 323, 4, 15, 639929) 3. I think it is highly probable that the period of our life is fixed, that is to say, the number of breaths we are to take, but that it is possible for us to regulate the duration of breaths and thus apparently prolong life.
('36', 323, 4, 16, 640155) This is a question of which I have not made any study and I do not allow it to worry me.
('36', 323, 4, 17, 640244) I have, therefore, given you not my own experience or positive belief but that belief of some people which has commended itself to me.
('36', 323, 4, 18, 640379) 4. They have no doubt a cooling effect.
('36', 323, 4, 19, 640419) But they are also in a way stimulants.
('36', 323, 4, 20, 640458) But you should know that at the present moment I am not myself discarding at least goat’s milk.
('36', 323, 4, 21, 640554) But my belief in the advisability, wherever health permits, of avoiding milk and its products—curds, etc.,—for the sake of making brahmacharya easier to practise remains unchanged.
('36', 323, 4, 22, 640735) 5. It is a fact that I forgo the last meal if I have not been able to take it before sunset.
('36', 323, 4, 23, 640828) It is a good, rule for a brahmachari to follow.
('36', 323, 4, 24, 640876) 6. I do take walking exercise regularly.
('36', 323, 4, 25, 640917) I keep myself fit for work by regular habits and by a proper selection of food and observing moderation in the quantity I fake and by exercising restraint upon the other senses.
('36', 323, 4, 26, 641095) 7. Monday is a day of silence for me.
('36', 323, 4, 27, 641133) I do edit Young India at least partly on Mondays but, since the operation, I have not been
('36', 324, 0, 1, 641224) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 325
('36', 324, 1, 2, 641269) fasting on Mondays.
('36', 324, 1, 3, 641289) I do recommend a weekly fast to young men who lead busy lives and who are not particular about the quality and the quantity of the food they take.
('36', 324, 1, 4, 641436) A weekly fast wisely managed is a help rather than a hindrance to the performance of all work, especially when it is mental.
('36', 324, 1, 5, 641561) 8. A teacher best serves his pupils by living an absolutely exemplary life in every particular and by completely identifying himself with his pupils.
('36', 324, 2, 6, 641711) Yours sincerely, SJT.
('36', 324, 2, 7, 641733) SHEWAKRAM KARAMCHAND TEACHER M.A.V. SCHOOL OLD SUKKUR

('36', 324, 4, 9, 641816) 366. LETTER TO B. N. MAZUMDAR
('36', 324, 5, 10, 641846) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, September 17, 1926
('36', 324, 6, 11, 641888) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter for which I thank you.
('36', 324, 6, 12, 641943) Let us not confuse the issue by raising the question of divorce.
('36', 324, 6, 13, 642008) The only question to be considered is whether a widow should have the same right and free choice as the widower, and, secondly, whether a girl of tender years, even 15, who has been practically forcibly raped and after the rape becomes, according to the present mistaken belief, a widow, should have the right to marry, or if you like, to remarry a properly qualified person or not.
('36', 324, 6, 14, 642391) I would like you not to be shocked at the use of the word rape in this connection.
('36', 324, 6, 15, 642474) I want you to be shocked at what is today happening in our society.
('36', 324, 6, 16, 642542) Today the chastity which we impute to widows has been discovered to be amiss.
('36', 324, 6, 17, 642620) Secret vice that is corrupting society and which now and then sees light of day should be a sufficient warning to us against taking the name of purity, religion, morality in connection with widowhood.
('36', 324, 6, 18, 642821) What we need to be protected against is not the absolutely necessary remarriage of young widows but the inhuman lust of men in Hindu society.

('36', 330, 1, 2, 650262) 375. MY NOTES
('36', 330, 2, 3, 650276) PERENNIAL QUESTIONS
('36', 330, 3, 4, 650296) A reader of Navajivan charged with spiritual aspiration insists on his questions being answered through Navajivan.
('36', 330, 3, 5, 650411) I feel some hesitation and am also doubtful whether Navajivan is the appropriate place for answering these questions, which moreover are not new.
('36', 330, 3, 6, 650557) They have troubled people since time immemorial.
('36', 330, 3, 7, 650606) Nevertheless, I cannot bring myself to reject the correspondent’s request.
('36', 330, 3, 8, 650681) I, therefore, venture to reproduce here his questions and my answers to them.
('36', 330, 4, 9, 650759) Should one meditate on God?
('36', 330, 4, 10, 650787) One has to do this so that one may know God through the intellect and feel His presence in the heart.
('36', 330, 5, 11, 650889) If meditation is essential, how should it be done?
('36', 330, 5, 12, 650940) All transcending and without form, God cannot be apprehended even through meditation.
('36', 330, 5, 13, 651026) Meditating on the impersonal is hard for embodied beings.
('36', 330, 5, 14, 651084) So one should meditate on a manifestation of God in personal form.
('36', 330, 5, 15, 651151) In this age and in this country, that form is Daridranarayana.
('36', 330, 5, 16, 651214) The only way of meditating on Him is to serve the poor.
('36', 330, 5, 17, 651270) There may be different ways of serving the poor, but in India the root cause of poverty is idleness and unemployment.
('36', 330, 5, 18, 651388) In order that people may shake off their laziness, we should spin ourselves and persuade them also to spin and thereby provide them innocent employment.
('36', 330, 5, 19, 651541) With every breath we take, we should utter this name, Daridranarayana, and should see him in our imagination pleased and smiling with satisfaction with every revolution of the spinning wheel.
('36', 330, 6, 20, 651733) What are the attributes of God?
('36', 330, 6, 21, 651765) The answer to this question is included in what is stated above, and it does not, therefore, require a separate answer.
('36', 330, 6, 22, 651885) But let me repeat it and say that He alone knows His attributes, or, rather, that those who have been able to know them have not succeeded in expressing them in words.
('36', 330, 6, 23, 652053) He is beyond the reach of language; the language in which He can be adequately described has not yet been discovered.
('36', 330, 6, 24, 652171) So it is that we worship Him as Matsya 1, Varah 2, Narsimha 3, or in human form 4, as suits the temperament of each of us.
('36', 330, 6, 25, 652294) In doing this, all of us
('36', 330, 7, 26, 652319) 1 Incarnation of Vishnu as Fish 2 Incarnation of Vishnu as Boar 3 Incarnation of Vishnu as Man lion 4 Incarnation of Vishnu as Rama and Krishna
('36', 331, 0, 1, 652463) 332 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 331, 1, 2, 652505) simultaneously follow and do not follow truth.
('36', 331, 1, 3, 652552) We follow it from our point of view, but do not follow it from the point of view of others who disagree with us.
('36', 331, 1, 4, 652665) In the eyes of God, we both follow and do not follow truth.
('36', 331, 2, 5, 652725) SPINNING WHEEL AND SELF PURIFICATION
('36', 331, 3, 6, 652762) A worker writes from Vedchhi: 1
('36', 331, 4, 7, 652794) One is rewarded according to one’s faith.
('36', 331, 4, 8, 652836) A Farahad breaking stones for a living got a Shirin.
('36', 331, 4, 9, 652889) The spinning wheel will have the power which we put into it.
('36', 331, 4, 10, 652950) If the sacred mantra and similar verbal symbols have immense power in them, it is because we have absolute faith in their power and do tapascharya in order that our faith may bear fruit.
('36', 331, 4, 11, 653137) In the same way, if we try to spread the use of the spinning wheel with the faith that we shall thereby serve the poor and purify both society and ourselves, and if we do tapascharya, even lay down our lives, in order that our faith may be rewarded, it certainly will be rewarded.
('36', 331, 5, 12, 653418) Something like this has happened in Vedchhi.
('36', 331, 5, 13, 653463) Propaganda against the drink evil can succeed only if carried on in this spirit.
('36', 331, 5, 14, 653544) A drink addict will not respond if we simply ask him to give up drinking.
('36', 331, 5, 15, 653618) It is a language which he does not understand.
('36', 331, 5, 16, 653665) If, however, we live as his neighbour and, by our example, persuade him to employ himself in useful work, he would give up drinking.
('36', 331, 5, 17, 653798) The drink addicts in Vedchhi seem to have responded to such an appeal.
('36', 331, 5, 18, 653869) We would succeed in all other places if we worked with similar patience and faith.
('36', 331, 6, 19, 653952) But I should like to say one thing to all workers so that they may be vigilant.
('36', 331, 6, 20, 654032) The change which we see now will prove illusory and disappear in a few days if the work is not kept up.
('36', 331, 6, 21, 654136) To ensure that the transformation in the lives of the people becomes permanent, the workers in the respective villages should remain alert and go on with their work without stopping or relaxing their effort.
('36', 331, 8, 22, 654344) 1The letter is not translated here.
('36', 331, 8, 23, 654380) The correspondent had described the transformation in the lives of Chodharas in the Bardoli taluka in Gujarat since the spinning wheel had been introduced among them.

('36', 332, 7, 8, 654800) [BOMBAY, September 19, 1926]
('36', 332, 8, 9, 654829) He maintains that improvement of the masses is becoming progressively more acute every year, and his remedy is to encourage the peasant, who is unemployed for a great portion of the year while the weather is unpropitious, to take to spinning as a means of increasing his income, and of preventing the exploitation of India by the overseas manufacturer.
('36', 332, 8, 10, 655182) Foreign manufacturers take £40,000,000 from India annually for cotton cloth, and this can be saved if my charkha (spinning wheel) movement receives adequate support.
('36', 332, 9, 11, 655348) He admitted that the foreign cloth, or the mill cloth of India, was a better and cheaper textile than the homespun; but when asked whether his movement as a remonstrance against the overwhelming forces of labour saving machinery and mass production was not as futile as the action of those who destroyed labour saving machinery in England to keep up the number of hand workers, he demurred, adding that Indian philosophy was such that his movement was bound to succeed.
('36', 332, 9, 12, 655818) (A millowner’s subsequent rejoinder to this contention was:”But how can it succeed when hand spinning can only earn one third of what can be earned daily by mill hands at incomparably easier work?”) In reply to questions, Gandhiji said the movement was”deeply religious”, though without ritual—but propagated by some literature and the holding of meetings.

('36', 335, 1, 2, 659595) 381. LETTER TO A. W. BAKER 1

('36', 337, 9, 22, 663676) 386. HAND SPINNING IN MYSORE
('36', 337, 10, 23, 663705) The Director of Industries in Mysore, Mr. Z. Meccai, has prepared an interesting note on hand spinning in Mysore.
('36', 337, 10, 24, 663819) I publish
('36', 337, 11, 25, 663829) 1 It appears this was sent care of Motilal Nathusha.
('36', 337, 11, 26, 663882) 2 From the postmark 3 ibid.
('36', 338, 0, 1, 663910) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 339
('36', 338, 1, 2, 663955) the following condensation of the notes: 1
('36', 338, 2, 3, 663998) I congratulate the Mysore authorities upon the encouragement they are giving to the revival of the only universals cottage industry of India.
('36', 338, 2, 4, 664140) I commend to their attention the experience of the All India Spinners’ Association.
('36', 338, 2, 5, 664224) It has found by experiment and observation that it is advisable to introduce hand ginning simultaneously with hand spinning.
('36', 338, 2, 6, 664349) This is easiest in the districts where cotton is grown.
('36', 338, 2, 7, 664405) Where it is not grown but where it is possible to grow, encouragement should be given to grow it locally.
('36', 338, 2, 8, 664511) Machine ginned and machine pressed cotton loses its vitality and is more difficult to treat with the hand bow than hand ginned cotton.
('36', 338, 2, 9, 664646) In several parts of India, the spinners take seed cotton.
('36', 338, 2, 10, 664704) Spinners should also be encouraged to do their own carding.
('36', 338, 2, 11, 664764) The performance by the spinner of the two processes doubles his wage.
('36', 338, 2, 12, 664834) With a view to increasing the strength of hand spun yarn, the State should undertake periodically to test the hand spun yarn and publish results.
('36', 338, 2, 13, 664980) Indeed, the whole subject needs to be treated in a scientific manner.
('36', 338, 2, 14, 665050) And who can be more fitted to do so than a State like Mysore?

('36', 338, 4, 16, 665135) 387. NON RESISTANCE TRUE AND FALSE
('36', 338, 5, 17, 665170) America is the home of inter racial conflict on a vast scale.
('36', 338, 5, 18, 665232) There are earnest men and women in that land of enterprises who are seeking to solve the difficult problem along the lines of non resistance.
('36', 338, 5, 19, 665374) One such American 2 friend sends me a paper called the Inquiry which contains an interesting discussion on the doctrine of non resistance.
('36', 338, 5, 20, 665513) It consists of instances that might possibly be grouped under non resistance.
('36', 338, 5, 21, 665591) I select three samples:
('36', 338, 6, 22, 665615) A Chinese student related his experiences at the State University from which he was about to graduate.
('36', 338, 6, 23, 665718) His reception there had been anything but friendly for the most part, although a few men had gone out of their way to befriend him one of them even inviting the Chinese to his home for a week end.
('36', 338, 6, 24, 665915) On the other hand, a fellow student who occupied a room next to his made himself particularly obnoxious, throwing shoes against his door and
('36', 338, 7, 25, 666056) 1 This is not reproduced here.

('36', 338, 7, 27, 666202) 2 This was a mistake.
('36', 338, 7, 28, 666224) The sender was not an American but an Indian; vide”A Correction”, 7 10 1926.
('36', 339, 0, 1, 666301) 340 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 339, 1, 2, 666343) indulging in other pranks.
('36', 339, 1, 3, 666370) The Chinese overheard this student express horror on finding that an American had taken him home to introduce him to his mother and sister, and immediately he made up his mind that he would teach this student to respect him, not for his own sake, but for the sake of his dear motherland.
('36', 339, 1, 4, 666658) So he went out of his way to be friendly to his neighbour.
('36', 339, 1, 5, 666717) Every day he gave him a smiling good morning though at first he received no response.
('36', 339, 1, 6, 666803) He ignored every insult, but tried to make himself pleasant and useful.
('36', 339, 1, 7, 666875) When he knew his neighbour to be hard up he casually invited him to go to a movie with him.
('36', 339, 1, 8, 666967) Gradually they talked together more often and found that they had several interests in common.
('36', 339, 1, 9, 667062) After a while this student invited him to his home.
('36', 339, 1, 10, 667114) “We have become warm friends,” concluded the Chinese.”I have since spent many holidays and week ends at his home; and on leaving the university I shall know that one of my fellow students at least will regretfully miss me.” The secretary of a railroad Young Men’s Christian Association brought one evening into the building twelve Danes, working on the railroad, who had no place to sleep.
('36', 339, 1, 11, 667504) The English speaking men, under the sway of racial antipathy, began to object and protested against the foreigners being brought in.
('36', 339, 1, 12, 667637) Among these newcomers however was a skilled musician, who, while the Americans were presenting their objections to the secretary, began to play upon the accordion.
('36', 339, 1, 13, 667801) He discoursedsweet music, which soon had its effect.
('36', 339, 1, 14, 667854) The ire on the faces of the native born soon began to vanish; the censure died on their lips; their hearts were softened; and that night they sat up late listening to the foreigner playing—Peter Roberts, The New Immigration.
('36', 339, 2, 15, 668079) Macmillan Co., 1922, p.
('36', 339, 2, 16, 668103) 300. There is a colony of Japanese in X, California.
('36', 339, 2, 17, 668156) Several years ago some real estate agents sought to sell a considerable amount of land to other Japanese, and the white people were aroused at the thought of a great influx of these people.
('36', 339, 2, 18, 668346) Meetings were held and a big sign was put on the main boulevard which read:”No Japanese wanted here.” The old resident Japanese of X, who had lived on good terms with the white people being members of their Farmers’ Association, went to the white people and, after consultation finally agreed with them that a further increase in the Japanese population would not be a Good thing.
('36', 339, 2, 19, 668727) The sign was changed to read:”No more Japanese wanted here.” The person who tells this story contends that this action advanced the solidarity of the community and improved relations between the whites and the Japanese in that place, as witness the following: “The Japanese of X, learning that the American church was in financial
('36', 340, 0, 1, 669058) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 341
('36', 340, 1, 2, 669103) difficulties offered to give a definite amount yearly for its support, in addition to carrying on their own Japanese church work.” Now the first easily comes under true non resistance.
('36', 340, 1, 3, 669288) The second is more an instance of presence of mind than non resistance.
('36', 340, 1, 4, 669360) The third, from the facts as stated, is an instance, if not of cowardice, as contended by some of the debators, certainly of selfishness.
('36', 340, 1, 5, 669498) The resident Japanese population in order to retain their earthly possessions agreed to the prohibition of further Japanese immigration.
('36', 340, 1, 6, 669635) It may have been sound policy.
('36', 340, 1, 7, 669666) It may have been the only policy advisable.
('36', 340, 1, 8, 669710) But it was not non resistance.
('36', 340, 1, 9, 669741) Non resistance is restraint voluntarily undertaken for the good of society.
('36', 340, 1, 10, 669817) It is, therefore, an intensely active, purifying, inward force.
('36', 340, 1, 11, 669881) It is often antagonistic to the material good of the non resister.
('36', 340, 1, 12, 669948) It may even mean his utter material ruin.
('36', 340, 1, 13, 669990) It is rooted in internal strength, never weakness.
('36', 340, 1, 14, 670041) It must be consciously exercised.
('36', 340, 1, 15, 670075) It, therefore, presupposes ability to offer physical resistance.
('36', 340, 1, 16, 670140) In the last instance, therefore, the Japanese would have non resisted, if they had left all their possessions rather than surrendered the rights of prospective immigrants.
('36', 340, 1, 17, 670312) They might also have suffered death [by] lynching without even mental retaliation and thus melted the hearts of their persecutors.
('36', 340, 1, 18, 670443) It was no victory of truth that, without any inconvenience to themselves, they were able to retain their property.
('36', 340, 1, 19, 670558) In terms of non resistance, their contribution to the American church in its difficulty was a bribe, by no means a token of goodwill or a free gift.
('36', 340, 1, 20, 670707) The acquisition of the spirit of non resistance is a matter of long training in self denial and appreciation of the hidden forces within ourselves.
('36', 340, 1, 21, 670855) It changes one’s outlook upon life.
('36', 340, 1, 22, 670891) It puts different values upon things and upsets previous calculations.
('36', 340, 1, 23, 670962) And when once it is set in motion, its effect, if it is intensive enough, can overtake the whole universe.
('36', 340, 1, 24, 671069) It is the greatest force because it is the highest expression of the soul.
('36', 340, 1, 25, 671144) All need not possess the same measure of conscious non resistance for its full operation.
('36', 340, 1, 26, 671234) It is enough for one person only to possess it, even as one general is enough to regulate and dispose of the energy of millions of soldiers who enlist under his banner though they know not the why and wherefore of his dispositions.
('36', 340, 1, 27, 671466) The monkeys of one Rama were enough to confound the innumerable host armed from head to foot of the ten headed Ravana.
('36', 340, 2, 28, 671585) Young India, 23 9 1926

('36', 341, 1, 2, 671650) 388. NO FAITH IN PRAYER
('36', 341, 2, 3, 671674) Here is a letter written by a student to the Principal of a national institution asking to be excused from attending its prayer meetings:
('36', 341, 3, 4, 671812) I beg to state that I have no belief in prayer, as I do not believe in anything known as God to whom I should pray.
('36', 341, 3, 5, 671928) I never feel any necessity of supposing a god for myself.
('36', 341, 3, 6, 671986) What do I lose if I do not care for Him and calmly and sincerely work my own schemes?
('36', 341, 4, 7, 672072) So far as congregational prayer is concerned, it is of no use.
('36', 341, 4, 8, 672135) Can such a huge mass of men enter, into any mental concentration upon a thing, however trifling it may be?
('36', 341, 4, 9, 672242) Are the little and ignorant children, expected to fix their fickle attention on the subtlest ideas of our great scriptures, God and soul and equality of all men and many other high sounding phrases?
('36', 341, 4, 10, 672441) This great performance is required to be done at a particular time at the command of a particular man.
('36', 341, 4, 11, 672544) Can love for the so called Lord take its root in the hearts of boys by any such mechanical function?
('36', 341, 4, 12, 672645) Nothing can be more repugnant to reason than to expect the same behaviour from men of every temperament.
('36', 341, 4, 13, 672750) Therefore, prayer should not be a compulsion.
('36', 341, 4, 14, 672796) Let those pray who have a taste for it and those avoid who dislike it.
('36', 341, 4, 15, 672867) Anything done without conviction is an immoral and degrading action.
('36', 341, 4, 16, 672936) Let us first examine the worth of the last idea.
('36', 341, 4, 17, 672985) Is it an immoral and degrading act to submit to discipline before one begins to have conviction about its necessity?
('36', 341, 4, 18, 673102) Is it immoral and degrading to study subjects according to the school syllabus if one has no conviction about its utility?
('36', 341, 4, 19, 673225) May a boy be excused from studying his vernacular if he has persuaded himself that it is useless?
('36', 341, 4, 20, 673323) Is it not truer to say that a school boy has no conviction about the things he has to learn or the discipline he has to go through?
('36', 341, 4, 21, 673455) His choice is exhausted if he had it, when he elected to belong to an institution.
('36', 341, 4, 22, 673538) His joining one means that he will willingly submit to its rules and regulations.
('36', 341, 4, 23, 673620) It is open to hint to leave it, but he may not choose what or how he will learn.
('36', 341, 5, 24, 673701) It is for teachers to make attractive and intelligible what to the pupils may at first appear repulsive or uninteresting.
('36', 341, 6, 25, 673823) It is easy enough to say, ‘I do not believe in God.’ For God permits all things to be said of Him with impunity.
('36', 341, 6, 26, 673936) He looks at our acts.
('36', 341, 6, 27, 673958) And any breach of His law carried with it, not its vindictive, but its purifying, compelling, punishment.
('36', 341, 6, 28, 674064) God’s existence cannot be, does not need to be, proved.
('36', 341, 6, 29, 674120) God is.
('36', 341, 6, 30, 674128) If He is not felt, so much the worse for us.
('36', 341, 6, 31, 674173) The absence of feeling is a disease which we shall some
('36', 342, 0, 1, 674229) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 343
('36', 342, 1, 2, 674274) day throw off nolens volens.
('36', 342, 1, 3, 674303) But a boy may not argue.
('36', 342, 1, 4, 674328) He must, out of a sense of discipline, attend prayer meetings if the institution to which he belongs requires such attendance.
('36', 342, 1, 5, 674455) He may respectfully put his doubts before his teachers.
('36', 342, 1, 6, 674511) He need not believe what does not appeal to him.
('36', 342, 1, 7, 674560) But if he has respect for his teachers, he will do without believing what he is asked to do, not out of fear, not out of churlishness, but with the knowledge that it is right for him so to do and with the hope that what is dark to him today will some day be made clear to him.
('36', 342, 1, 8, 674837) Prayer is not an asking.
('36', 342, 1, 9, 674862) It is a longing of the soul.
('36', 342, 1, 10, 674891) It is a daily admission of one’s weakness.
('36', 342, 1, 11, 674934) The tallest among us has a perpetual reminder of his nothingness before death, disease, old age, accidents, etc.
('36', 342, 1, 12, 675047) We are living in the midst of death.
('36', 342, 1, 13, 675084) What is the value of”working for our own schemes” when they might be reduced to naught in the twinkling of an eye, or when we may be equally swiftly and unawares be taken away from them?
('36', 342, 1, 14, 675271) But we may feel strong as a rock, if we could truthfully say:”We work for God and His schemes.” Then all is as clear as daylight.
('36', 342, 1, 15, 675401) Then nothing perishes.
('36', 342, 1, 16, 675424) All perishing is then only what seems.
('36', 342, 1, 17, 675463) Death and destruction have then, but only then, no reality about them.
('36', 342, 1, 18, 675534) For death or destruction is then but a change.
('36', 342, 1, 19, 675581) An artist destroys his picture for creating a better one.
('36', 342, 1, 20, 675639) A watch maker throws away a bad spring to put in a new and useful one.
('36', 342, 1, 21, 675710) A congregational prayer is a mighty thing.
('36', 342, 1, 22, 675753) What we do not often do alone, we do together.
('36', 342, 1, 23, 675800) Boys do not need conviction.
('36', 342, 1, 24, 675829) If they merely attend in obedience to the call to prayer without inward resistance, they feel the exaltation.
('36', 342, 1, 25, 675939) But many do not.
('36', 342, 1, 26, 675956) They are even mischievous.
('36', 342, 1, 27, 675983) All the same the unconscious effect cannot be resisted.
('36', 342, 1, 28, 676039) Are there not boys who at the commencement of their career were scoffers but who subsequently became mighty believers in the efficacy of congrega tional prayer?
('36', 342, 1, 29, 676200) It is a common experience for men who have no robust faith to seek the comfort of congregational prayer.
('36', 342, 1, 30, 676305) All who flock to churches, temples, or mosques are not scoffers or humbugs.
('36', 342, 1, 31, 676381) They are honest men and women.
('36', 342, 1, 32, 676412) For them congregational prayer is like a daily bath, a necessity, of their existence.
('36', 342, 1, 33, 676498) These places of worship are not a mere idle superstition to be swept away at the first opportunity.
('36', 342, 1, 34, 676598) They have survived all attacks up to now and are likely to persist to the end of time.
('36', 342, 2, 35, 676685) Young India, 23 9 1926

('36', 343, 1, 2, 676750) 389. RELIGION OF VOLUNTEERS
('36', 343, 2, 3, 676778) After showing that in this land of many religions, a volunteer is hard put to it to find a common denominator of conduct, a correspondent thus eloquently described the religion of a volunteer: 1
('36', 343, 3, 4, 676973) Stripped of the eloquence, this religion of Truth again resolves itself into its component parts—Hinduism, Islam, Christianity, etc.
('36', 343, 3, 5, 677106) For Truth will appear to most sincere and conscientious Hindus, Mussalmans and Christians as Hinduism, Islam and Christianity, respectively, as they believe them.
('36', 343, 3, 6, 677269) The golden rule of conduct, therefore, is mutual toleration seeing that we will never all think alike and that we shall always see Truth in fragment and from different angles of vision.
('36', 343, 3, 7, 677455) Conscience is not the same thing for all.
('36', 343, 3, 8, 677497) Whilst, therefore, it is a good guide for individual conduct, imposition of that conduct upon all will be an insufferable interference with everybody else’s freedom of conscience.
('36', 343, 3, 9, 677677) It is a much abused term.
('36', 343, 3, 10, 677703) Have all people a conscience?
('36', 343, 3, 11, 677733) Has a cannibal a conscience?
('36', 343, 3, 12, 677762) Must he be allowed to act according to the dictates of his conscience which tells him that it is his duty to kill and eat his fellows?
('36', 343, 3, 13, 677897) Now the etymological meaning of conscience is ‘true knowledge’.
('36', 343, 3, 14, 677961) The dictionary meaning is ‘faculty distinguishing between right and wrong and influencing conduct accordingly’.
('36', 343, 3, 15, 678073) Possession of such a faculty is possible only for a trained person, that is, one who has undergone discipline and learnt to listen to the inner voice.
('36', 343, 3, 16, 678224) But even amongst the most conscientious persons, there will be room enough for honest differences of opinion.
('36', 343, 3, 17, 678334) The only possible rule of conduct in any civilized society is therefore mutual toleration.
('36', 343, 3, 18, 678425) It can be inculcated among and practised by all irrespective of their status and training.
('36', 343, 4, 19, 678516) Young India, 23 9 1926

('36', 344, 3, 5, 679178) 391. RETURNED EMIGRANTS
('36', 344, 4, 6, 679202) I appreciate the anxiety of Pandit Benarsidas 1 to save the unfortunate people from another disappointment by those who were domiciled in Fiji being sent to British Guiana.
('36', 344, 4, 7, 679375) Though the difference between the two countries is great, the experiment is worth trying if the Fiji men desire to go on British Guiana and if that Government will take them notwithstanding the knowledge that they belong to Fiji.
('36', 344, 4, 8, 679605) So far as the Colonial borns are concerned, I feel sure that though they may have a knowledge of what is known as kitchen Hindustani, they will not be happy except in the Colonies.
('36', 344, 4, 9, 679786) The vital issues referred to by Pandit Benarsidas must be dealt with later.
