('36', 350, 3, 4, 689871) SABARMATI,
('36', 350, 4, 5, 689882) Friday, Bhadra Vad 3 [September 24, 1926] 1
('36', 350, 5, 6, 689926) BHAISHRI LAKSHMIDAS, I have to reply to two letters from you, one about the boycott of British goods and the other concerning the deputation from South Africa.
('36', 350, 5, 7, 690086) On reading the pamphlet about boycott, [I feel that] you have written it with a courage worthy of you.
('36', 350, 5, 8, 690189) But I have not been impressed by your argument.
('36', 350, 5, 9, 690237) I may not, on principle, agree with the idea of boycotting British goods, but I would certainly understand it if it was feasible and of benefit from a practical point of view.
('36', 350, 5, 10, 690413) You have not been able to prove either its feasibility or its practical utility.
('36', 350, 5, 11, 690494) On the contrary, after reading your pamphlet I feel that the boycott of British goods will be of no benefit even from the practical point of view.
('36', 350, 5, 12, 690641) I am sure you will not want me to go into reasons.
('36', 350, 5, 13, 690692) From you I would expect suggestions which are practicable.
('36', 350, 5, 14, 690751) You are intelligent and would not, I believe, strike a blow which would fail in its aim.
('36', 350, 5, 15, 690840) This blow which you have struck, I am afraid, has certainly failed in its aim.
('36', 350, 5, 16, 690919) We or the people wanted representatives from South Africa to visit this country.
('36', 350, 5, 17, 691000) The Indian residents in South Africa also wanted that we should extend a welcome even to an enemy if we have invited him to our tent.
('36', 350, 5, 18, 691134) The Conference 2 has been arranged because of the agitation here, and these gentlemen are here in connection with it.
('36', 350, 5, 19, 691252) It is our clear duty to extend a welcome to them.
('36', 350, 5, 20, 691302) By doing so, we strengthen our position so that we should be able to tell them what we feel about their laws.
('36', 350, 5, 21, 691412) We cannot refuse to have anything to do with them by arguing that they have been invited here only by the Government and that we have nothing to do in the matter.
('36', 350, 5, 22, 691575) We can certainly advance such an argument against anything done in defiance of public opinion.
('36', 350, 5, 23, 691670) I was, therefore, surprised to read your letter.

('36', 353, 12, 19, 695294) 407. DIFFICULTIES OF A SPINNER
('36', 353, 13, 20, 695325) A voluntary spinner writes as follows: 3
('36', 353, 14, 21, 695366) This is a reasonable request.
('36', 353, 14, 22, 695396) It is not necessary for the Spinners’ Association to start a new journal for the purpose; but the difficulties of the kind mentioned by the spinner could be solved through
('36', 353, 15, 23, 695568) 1 The source has 26 which, however, was not a Saturday.
('36', 353, 15, 24, 695624) 2. From the postmark 3 The letter is not translated here.
('36', 353, 15, 25, 695682) The correspondent had suggested that the All India Spinners’ Association should maintain contacts with spinners and help them to solve their problems.
('36', 354, 0, 1, 695833) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 355
('36', 354, 1, 2, 695878) Navajivan and Young India.
('36', 354, 1, 3, 695905) Whoever experiences any difficulties in spinning or wishes to ask any questions concerning it may certainly write; his questions will be answered in Navajivan.
('36', 354, 1, 4, 696065) The trouble is that the spinners do nothing to get their problems solved and do not write to me either because of their laziness or indifference or, sometimes, for fear lest they should add to my burden.
('36', 354, 1, 5, 696269) A sacrificial spinner cannot afford to be either lazy or careless.
('36', 354, 1, 6, 696336) To be concerned for me is to do injustice both to me and to this movement.
('36', 354, 1, 7, 696411) I can easily request others to solve problems which I cannot solve myself.
('36', 354, 1, 8, 696486) Anyone, therefore, who has problems may write without the slightest hesitation, only remembering one condition, namely, that the letters should be written in ink and the correspondent should explain his problem briefly and in legible handwriting, and without argument.
('36', 354, 1, 9, 696755) It will be easier for me if the envelope bears the words”About Spinning”.
('36', 354, 1, 10, 696829) Now the letter given above has raised one problem which can be solved here.
('36', 354, 1, 11, 696905) Blowing water spray is intended to moisten every thread on the hank.
('36', 354, 1, 12, 696974) This process is essential for increasing the strength of the yarn.
('36', 354, 1, 13, 697041) It has been found to do so to the extent of 20 per cent.
('36', 354, 1, 14, 697098) No one, therefore, should remove the yarn from the real without first blowing water spray on it.
('36', 354, 1, 15, 697195) The easiest and the best method of serving the aim behind blowing is to keep the reel immersed in water for three to five minutes and move the hand over it to, moisten it.
('36', 354, 1, 16, 697367) This will moisten every part of the thread to the right degree.
('36', 354, 1, 17, 697431) The reel will last longer if it is made wholly of wood, instead of having strings round it.
('36', 354, 1, 18, 697523) The cotton strings used for this purpose will get soiled and then wear out if the reel is immersed in water frequently.
('36', 354, 1, 19, 697643) If the yarn is not removed from the reel soon after immersing the latter into water but left on it for twelve hours, every coil on the reel would suck in moisture.
('36', 354, 1, 20, 697807) Our purpose would be served better if the yarn is carefully spread out on the reel before the latter is immersed into water.
('36', 354, 1, 21, 697932) Moving the hand on the yarn after immersing the reel in water will moisten the yarn more quickly.
('36', 354, 2, 22, 698030) [From Gujarati]
('36', 354, 3, 23, 698046) Navajivan, 26 9 1926

('36', 362, 6, 27, 716306) 1 Young India, 30 9 1926, pp.
('36', 363, 0, 1, 716336) 364 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('36', 363, 1, 3, 716439) Whilst the conclusions of Babu Bijay Bihari are infirm, the facts he has set forth are well worth consideration by everyone who wishes well to this country.

('36', 363, 2, 5, 716698) In Bengal, according to the census of 1921, out of every 1,000 persons only 68 live in towns.
('36', 363, 2, 6, 716792) Outside Calcutta and the metropolitan districts of Howrah, the 24 Parganas and Hooghly, there are three towns containing over 30,000 people.
('36', 363, 2, 7, 716933) It will not therefore be unreasonableto hold that of 46,695,536 of the population of the British territory in Bengal, scarcely more than about 13 lakhs of people are urban and the rest live mainly in the villages.
('36', 363, 2, 8, 717147) Therefore the writer naturally contends:
('36', 363, 3, 9, 717188) To develop the village and to secure for its inhabitants that sufficiency of comforts which is essential even in a country where only a little suffices, to organize it as a living entity in the body politic of the constitution is the crucial problem before the country.
('36', 363, 3, 10, 717458) The utterance of Sir Horace Plunkett that”we must have home before home rule” is true of Bengal as much as of Ireland to which he addressed it.
('36', 363, 3, 11, 717602) One need not ignore the effect of the form of government and the need for a change in it to be convinced of the paramount and supreme necessity of attempts to rehabilitate the ‘home’ in the villages.
('36', 363, 3, 12, 717802) In that scheme of rehabilitation the cottage industry is not merely helpful, but absolutely essential.
('36', 363, 3, 13, 717905) The author has no difficulty in showing that India was, at one time, not very remote, happy and prosperous.
('36', 363, 3, 14, 718013) He thus quotes Elphinstone:
('36', 363, 4, 15, 718041) All the descriptions of the parts of India visited by the Greeks give the idea of a country teeming with population and enjoying the highest degree of prosperity.
('36', 363, 4, 16, 718204) He has less difficulty in showing that the prosperity was mainly due to the one single industry of spinning and weaving.
('36', 363, 4, 17, 718325) But today hand spinning needs resurrection and weaving, though still an important cottage industry, does not need the same attention.
('36', 363, 4, 18, 718459) Today, there is no prosperity to note.
('36', 363, 4, 19, 718498) Three fourths of the people are dependent solely upon cultivation.
('36', 363, 4, 20, 718565) In Dacca and Faridpur 92% and in Midnapur 74% of the cultivable land is now under cultivation.
('36', 363, 4, 21, 718660) The average under cultivation per head of the agricultural population is respectively, .72, .73 and .84 acres for the three districts.
('36', 363, 4, 22, 718795) Thus there is little margin left for additional cultivation.
('36', 364, 0, 1, 718856) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 365
('36', 364, 1, 2, 718901) peasantry that is solely dependent on agriculture can possibly live on less than one acre of land.
('36', 364, 1, 3, 719000) The real average is far below the average given, because in the calculation are included are huge tracts owned by rich zamindars.
('36', 364, 2, 4, 719130) It is no wonder, therefore, that one of the highest officials of the Government had to declare that in this country half the people did not know what it was to have two meals a day.
('36', 364, 3, 5, 719312) The seriousness of the situation was expressed by the Famine Commission so long ago as 1877 78 thus: A main cause of the disastrousconsequences of Indian famines and one of the greatest difficulties in the way of providing relief in an effectual shape is to be found in the fact that the great mass of the people directly depend on agriculture and that there is no other industry from which any considerable part of the population derives support.
('36', 364, 3, 6, 719760) The failure of the usual rains deprives the labouring class as a whole, not only of the ordinary supplies of food obtainable at prices within their reach but also of the sole employment by which they can earn the means of procuring it.
('36', 364, 3, 7, 719996) The complete remedy, say the Commissioners, for this condition of things will be found only in the development of industries other than agriculture and independent of the fluctuations of the seasons.
('36', 364, 3, 8, 720196) The writer shows too that the bulk of the peasantry is occupied only during four months of the year.
('36', 364, 4, 9, 720297) The clerks, the officials, the lawyers, the doctors, the politicians, the teachers and all who believe themselves educated in English do not come up even to one per cent of the population.
('36', 364, 4, 10, 720486) I have remarked that the writer is weak in his conclusions.
('36', 364, 4, 11, 720546) The weakness in my opinion is derived from the fact that he has collected all possible cottage industries.
('36', 364, 4, 12, 720653) As a recital it is good enough.
('36', 364, 4, 13, 720685) But it does not solve the problem which needs a speedy solution.
('36', 364, 4, 14, 720750) For the vast bulk of the population, as also the worker in the villages, a museum of industries is simply bewildering.
('36', 364, 4, 15, 720869) They should have one universal industry.
('36', 364, 4, 16, 720910) And by a process of exclusion, one arrives at the irresistible conclusion that the only universal industry for the millions is spinning and no other.
('36', 364, 4, 17, 721060) That does not mean that other industries do not matter or are useless.
('36', 364, 4, 18, 721131) Indeed, from the individual standpoint, any other industry would be more remunerative than spinning.
('36', 364, 4, 19, 721232) Watch making will be no doubt most remunerative and fascinating industry.
('36', 364, 4, 20, 721306) But how many can engage in it?
('36', 364, 4, 21, 721337) Is it of any use to the millions of villagers?
('36', 364, 4, 22, 721384) But if the villagers can reconstruct their home, begin to live again as their fore fathers did, if they begin to make
('36', 365, 0, 1, 721502) 366 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 365, 1, 2, 721544) good use of their idle hours, all else, all the other industries will revive as a matter of course.
('36', 365, 1, 3, 721644) It is no use putting before famishing men a multiplicity of raw foods and expecting them to make their choice.
('36', 365, 1, 4, 721755) They would not know what to do with them.
('36', 365, 1, 5, 721797) They will probably rush after the most tempting and perish in the attempt.
('36', 365, 1, 6, 721872) I remember once in my life being nearly lynched whilst I was distributing rations to famished people.
('36', 365, 1, 7, 721974) I had to enclose and guard myself and the provisions before I could distribute what I had been given for distribution.

('36', 365, 1, 9, 722284) They may not all take it up.

('36', 372, 3, 21, 735378) He cannot have a private life; it is my firm view that the public has a right to know everything about his life.
('36', 372, 3, 22, 735491) Shri Shivji is a public worker and has been running an institution for young men and women and for widows.
('36', 372, 3, 23, 735598) The activities of the Madhada Ashram were many sided, and that is why I have, as a matter of duty and with great pain, given publicity to the most important aspect of the conclusions of the inquiry I had instituted.
('36', 372, 4, 24, 735814) Bhai Shivji and his friends will be pained by this.
('36', 372, 4, 25, 735866) I can give them only one consolation, and that is to assure them that I have felt, and still feel, much more deeply pained by the impression which has been produced on my mind by the affair than they would feel by my writing this.
('36', 372, 4, 26, 736097) I do not wish to see anyone in this world morally degraded.
('36', 372, 4, 27, 736157) I feel ashamed to see even one person fall.
('36', 372, 4, 28, 736201) I am of the view
('36', 373, 0, 1, 736218) 374 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 373, 1, 2, 736260) that when an individual falls the whole society falls.
('36', 373, 1, 3, 736315) If I could have avoided writing this, I would certainly have kept silent.
('36', 373, 1, 4, 736389) I prefer silence in such matters.
('36', 373, 1, 5, 736423) But does anyone always get what would make him happy?
('36', 373, 1, 6, 736477) I regard myself as a true friend of Shri Shivji.
('36', 373, 1, 7, 736526) This article does not mean that I have washed my hands of this affair.
('36', 373, 1, 8, 736597) I have given him sufficient time.
('36', 373, 1, 9, 736631) I am ready to give still more time if required.
('36', 373, 1, 10, 736679) If any of Shri Shivji’s friends can show me that I am in error, I will be grateful to him and will be happy to admit my mistake.
('36', 373, 1, 11, 736808) If Shri Shivji or any of his friends wishes to write something by way of reply to this, I will publish the whole reply provided it is reasonably short.
('36', 373, 1, 12, 736960) I should like to tell Shri Shivji’s friends that even if a hundred thousand persons believe a person to be innocent but one individual can prove his guilt, then the evidence of those hundred thousand does not avail.
('36', 373, 1, 13, 737176) I find it necessary to say this in order that people may not write to me the kind of letters which I have been lately receiving for publication

('36', 378, 10, 17, 744876) 435. VEGETARIANISM
('36', 378, 11, 18, 744895) A correspondent is born in a meat eating family.
('36', 378, 11, 19, 744944) He has successfully resisted the pressure from his parents to return to the flesh pot.
('36', 378, 11, 20, 745031) But, he says, in a book I have before me:
('36', 378, 12, 21, 745073) I read the opinion of Swami Vivekananda on the subject and feel a good deal shaken in my belief.
('36', 378, 12, 22, 745170) The Swami holds that for Indians in their present state flesh diet is a necessity and he advises his friends to eat flesh freely.
('36', 378, 12, 23, 745300) He even goes so far as to say”If you incur any sin thereby throw it upon me; I will bear it.” I am now in a fix whether to eat flesh or not.
('36', 379, 0, 1, 745441) 380 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 379, 1, 2, 745483) This blind worship of authority is a sign of weakness of mind.
('36', 379, 1, 3, 745546) If the correspondent has such a deep seated conviction that flesh eating is not right, why should he be moved by the opinion to the contrary of the whole world?
('36', 379, 1, 4, 745707) One needs to be slow to form convictions, but once formed they must be defended against the heaviest odds.
('36', 379, 1, 5, 745814) As for the opinion of the great Swami, I have not seen the actual writing but I fear the correspondent has correctly quoted him.
('36', 379, 1, 6, 745943) My opinion is well known.
('36', 379, 1, 7, 745969) I do not regard flesh food as necessary for us at any stage and under any clime in which it is possible for human beings ordinarily to live.
('36', 379, 1, 8, 746110) I hold flesh food to be unsuited to our species.
('36', 379, 1, 9, 746159) We err in copying the lower animal world if we are superior to it.
('36', 379, 1, 10, 746226) Experience teaches that animal food is unsuited to those who would curb their passions.
('36', 379, 1, 11, 746314) But it is wrong to over estimate the importance of food in the formation of character or in subjugating the flesh.
('36', 379, 1, 12, 746429) Diet is a powerful factor not to be neglected.
('36', 379, 1, 13, 746476) But to sum up all religion in terms of diet, as is often done in India, is as wrong as it is to disregard all restraint in regard to diet and to give full reins to one’s appetite.
('36', 379, 1, 14, 746656) Vegetarianism is one of the priceless gifts of Hinduism.
('36', 379, 1, 15, 746713) It may not be lightly given up.
('36', 379, 1, 16, 746745) It is necessary therefore to correct the error that vegetarianism has made us weak in mind or body or passive or inert in action.
('36', 379, 1, 17, 746875) The greatest Hindu reformers have been the activest in their generation and they have invariably been vegetarians.
('36', 379, 1, 18, 746990) Who could show greater activity than, say, Sankara or Dayanand in their times?
('36', 379, 1, 19, 747069) But my correspondent must not accept me as his authority.
('36', 379, 1, 20, 747127) The choice of one’s diet is not a thing to be based on faith.
('36', 379, 1, 21, 747189) It is a matter for everyone to reason out for himself.
('36', 379, 1, 22, 747244) There has grown up especially in the West an amount of literature on vegetarianism which any seeker after truth may study with profit.
('36', 379, 1, 23, 747379) Many eminent medical men have contributed to this literature.
('36', 379, 1, 24, 747441) Here, in India, we have not needed any encouragement for vegetarianism.
('36', 379, 1, 25, 747513) For it has been hitherto accepted as the most desirable and the most respectable thing.
('36', 379, 1, 26, 747601) Those, however, who like the correspondent feel shaken, may study the growing movement towards vegetarianism in the West.
('36', 379, 2, 27, 747723) Young India, 7 10 1926
('36', 380, 0, 1, 747746) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 381
('36', 380, 1, 2, 747791) 436. LETTER TO AMY JACQUES GARVEY
('36', 380, 2, 3, 747825) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, May 12, 1926
('36', 380, 3, 4, 747861) DEAR FRIEND, I had the 2nd volume of”The Philosophy and Opinions of Marcus Garvey” 1 or”Africa for Africans” for which I thank you.

('36', 380, 6, 8, 748179) 437. THE SAME OLD ARGUMENT
('36', 380, 7, 9, 748206) After reciting the evils from which we are suffering and after dealing with the improvements he would make in agriculture, a correspondent writes: 2
('36', 380, 8, 10, 748355) This is the old argument restated.
('36', 380, 8, 11, 748390) The correspondent forgets that to make India like England and America is to find some other races and places of the earth for exploitation.
('36', 380, 8, 12, 748530) So far it appears that the Western nations have divided all the known races outside Europe for exploitation and that there are no new worlds to discover.
('36', 380, 8, 13, 748684) Among the exploited, India is the greatest victim.
('36', 380, 8, 14, 748735) Japan is taking the share of the spoils no doubt.
('36', 380, 8, 15, 748785) But if India and China refuse to be exploited what will happen to the exploiters?
('36', 380, 8, 16, 748867) And if the Western nations plus Japan are likely to come to grief in the event of India and China refusing to be exploited, what can be the fate of India trying to ape the West?
('36', 380, 8, 17, 749045) Indeed, the West had had a surfeit of industrialism and exploitation.
('36', 380, 8, 18, 749115) If they who are suffering from the disease are unable to find a remedy
('36', 380, 9, 19, 749186) 1 Marcus Garvey was the Chairman of the Fourth International Convention of the Negro Peoples of the World.
('36', 380, 9, 20, 749293) 2 Not reproduced here.
('36', 380, 9, 21, 749316) The correspondent had argued that modern civilization including steamships, railways, machinery and large scale production should be accepted.
('36', 381, 0, 1, 749459) 382 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 381, 1, 2, 749501) to correct the evils, how shall we, mere novices, be able to avoid them?
('36', 381, 1, 3, 749574) The fact is that this industrial civilization is a disease because it is all evil.
('36', 381, 1, 4, 749657) Let us not be deceived by catchwords and phrases.
('36', 381, 1, 5, 749707) I have no quarrel with steamships or telegraphs.
('36', 381, 1, 6, 749756) They may stay, if they can, without the support of industrialism and all it connotes.
('36', 381, 1, 7, 749842) They are not an end.
('36', 381, 1, 8, 749863) We must not suffer exploitation for the sake of steamships and telegraphs.
('36', 381, 1, 9, 749938) They are in no way indispensable for the permanent welfare of the human race.
('36', 381, 1, 10, 750016) Now that we know the use of steam and electricity, we should be able to use them on due occasion and after we have learnt to avoid industrialism.
('36', 381, 1, 11, 750162) Our concern is, therefore, to destroy industrialism at any cost.
('36', 381, 2, 12, 750227) The correspondent has suggested the remedy without knowing it himself.
('36', 381, 2, 13, 750298) For he admits that India has lived till now when other nations have perished because”she has adapted herself to changing conditions”.
('36', 381, 2, 14, 750432) Adaptability is not imitation.
('36', 381, 2, 15, 750463) It means power of resistance and assimilation.
('36', 381, 2, 16, 750510) India has withstood the onslaughts of other civilizations because she has stood firm on her own ground.
('36', 381, 2, 17, 750614) Not that she has not made changes.
('36', 381, 2, 18, 750649) But the changes she has made have promoted her growth.
('36', 381, 2, 19, 750704) To change to industrialism is to court disaster.
('36', 381, 2, 20, 750753) The present distress is undoubtedly insufferable.
('36', 381, 2, 21, 750803) Pauperism must go.
('36', 381, 2, 22, 750822) But industrialism is no remedy.
('36', 381, 2, 23, 750854) The evil does not lie in the use of bullock carts.
('36', 381, 2, 24, 750905) It lies in our selfishness and want of consideration for our neighbours.
('36', 381, 2, 25, 750978) If we have no love for our neighbours, no change however revolutionary can do us any good.
('36', 381, 2, 26, 751069) And if we love our neighbours, the paupers of India, for their sakes, we shall use what they make for us; for their sakes we, who should know, shall not engage in an immoral traffic with the West in the shape of buying the foreign fineries and taking them to the villages.
('36', 381, 3, 27, 751342) If we would but think seriously and persistently, we shall discover that before we make any other changes, the one great change to make is to discard foreign cloth and reinstate the ancient cottage industry of hand spinning.
('36', 381, 3, 28, 751567) We must thus restore our ancient and health giving industry if we would resist industrialism.
('36', 381, 4, 29, 751661) I do not fight shy of capital.
('36', 381, 4, 30, 751692) I fight capitalism.
('36', 381, 4, 31, 751712) The West teaches one to avoid concentration of capital, to avoid a racial war in another and deadlier form.
('36', 381, 4, 32, 751820) Capital and labour need not be antagonistic to each other.
('36', 381, 4, 33, 751879) I cannot picture to myself a time when no man shall be richer than another.
('36', 381, 4, 34, 751955) But I do picture to myself a time when the rich will spurn to enrich themselves at the expense of the poor and the
('36', 382, 0, 1, 752070) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 383
('36', 382, 1, 2, 752115) poor will cease to envy the rich.
('36', 382, 1, 3, 752149) Even in a most perfect world, we shall fail to avoid inequalities, but we can and must avoid strife and bitterness.
('36', 382, 1, 4, 752265) There are numerous examples extant of the rich and the poor living in perfect friendliness.
('36', 382, 1, 5, 752357) We have but to multiply such instances.
('36', 382, 1, 6, 752397) India’s destiny lies not along the bloody way of the West, of which she shows signs of tiredness, but along the bloodless way of peace that comes from a simple and godly life.
('36', 382, 1, 7, 752573) India is in danger of losing her soul.
('36', 382, 1, 8, 752612) She cannot lose it and live.
('36', 382, 1, 9, 752641) She must not, therefore, lazily and helplessly say,”I cannot escape the onrush from the West.” She must be strong enough to resist it for her own sake and that of the world.
('36', 382, 2, 10, 752815) Young India, 7 10 1926
('36', 382, 3, 11, 752838) 438. SORROWS OF GIRL WIVES
('36', 382, 4, 12, 752865) “A Hindu lady from Bengal” writes: 1
('36', 382, 5, 13, 752902) Whether the picture drawn here is true to life or overdrawn, the substance is surely true.
('36', 382, 5, 14, 752993) I do not need to search for evidence in support.
('36', 382, 5, 15, 753042) I know a medical man enjoying a large practice having married and taken to himself, an elderly widower, a girl who was young enough to be his daughter.

('36', 388, 7, 8, 763410) 448. IS THIS HUMANITY? I 1
('36', 388, 8, 9, 763437) [October 10, 1926] 2
('36', 388, 9, 10, 763458) The Ahmedabad Humanitarian League has addressed me a letter from which I take the relevant portions:
('36', 388, 10, 11, 763559) The talk of the whole city of Ahmedabad is the destruction of 60 dogs on his mill premises at the instance of Seth.
('36', 388, 10, 12, 763675) Many a humanitarian heart is considerably agitated over the incident.
('36', 388, 10, 13, 763745) When Hinduism forbids the taking of the life of any living being, when it declares it to be a sin, do you think it right to kill rabid dogs for the reason that they would bite human beings and by biting other dogs make them also rabid?
('36', 388, 10, 14, 763981) Are not the man who actually destroys the dogs as also the man at whose instance he does so both sinners?
('36', 388, 10, 15, 764087) A deputation of three gentlemen from our Society waited on the Seth on the 28th ultimo.
('36', 388, 10, 16, 764175) He confessed in the course of the interview that he had to take the course in question to save human life.
('36', 388, 10, 17, 764282) He also said:”I myself had no sleep on the night I took that decision.
('36', 388, 10, 18, 764353) I met Mahatmaji the next morning and ascertained his view in the matter.
('36', 388, 10, 19, 764426) He said, ‘What else could be done?’” Is that a fact?
('36', 388, 10, 20, 764479) And if so, what does it mean?
('36', 388, 10, 21, 764509) We hope you will express your views in the matter and set the whole controversy at rest and prevent humanitarianism from beingendangered by the shocks given to it by distinguished men like the Seth.
('36', 388, 10, 22, 764708) The Ahmedabad Municipality, we have heard, is soon going to have before it a resolution for the castration of stray dogs.
('36', 388, 10, 23, 764830) Is it proper?
('36', 388, 10, 24, 764844) Does religion
('36', 388, 11, 25, 764858) 1 This is the first of a series of eight Gujarati articles published in Navajivan.
('36', 388, 11, 26, 764941) These were later translated by Mahadev Desai into English and published in Young India.
('36', 388, 12, 27, 765029) 2 The articles are placed under the date of publication in Navajivan.
('36', 389, 0, 1, 765099) 390 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 389, 1, 2, 765141) sanction the castration of an animal?
('36', 389, 1, 3, 765179) We should be thankful if you would give your opinion in this matter also.
('36', 389, 1, 4, 765253) Ahmedabad knows the name of the mill owner, but as Navajivan is being read outside Ahmedabad also, I have omitted to mention his name in accordance with my practice to avoid personalities whilst discussing a principle.
('36', 389, 1, 5, 765472) The question raised by the Humanitarian Society is an intricate one.
('36', 389, 1, 6, 765541) I had been thinking of discussing the question ever since and even before the incident, but on second thought dropped the idea.
('36', 389, 1, 7, 765669) But the letter of the Society now compels me, makes it my duty, to enter into a public discussion of the question.
('36', 389, 2, 8, 765784) I must say that my relations with the mill owner, have been sweet, and, if I may say so, friendly.
('36', 389, 2, 9, 765883) He came to me and expressed his distress in having had to order destruction of the dogs, and asked my opinion about it.
('36', 389, 2, 10, 766003) He also said:”When the Government, the Municipality and the Mahajan all alike failed to guide me, I was driven to this course.” I gave him the reply that the Society’s letter attributes to me.
('36', 389, 3, 11, 766196) I have since thought over the matter and feel that my reply was quite proper.
('36', 389, 3, 12, 766274) Imperfect, erring mortals as we are, there is no course open to us but the destruction of rabid dogs.
('36', 389, 3, 13, 766376) At times we may be faced with the unavoidable duty of killing a man who is found in the act of killing people.
('36', 389, 4, 14, 766487) If we persist in keeping stray dogs undisturbed, we shall soon be faced with the duty of either castrating them or killing them.
('36', 389, 4, 15, 766616) A third alternative is that of having a special pinjrapole for dogs.
('36', 389, 4, 16, 766685) But it is out of the question.
('36', 389, 4, 17, 766716) When we cannot cope with all the stray cattle in the city, the very proposal of having a pinjrapole for dogs seems to me to be chimerical.
('36', 389, 4, 18, 766855) There can be no two opinions on the fact that Hinduism regards killing a living being as sinful.
('36', 389, 4, 19, 766952) I think all religions are agreed on the principle.
('36', 389, 4, 20, 767003) There is generally no difficulty in determining a principle.
('36', 389, 4, 21, 767064) The difficult comes in when one proceeds to put it into practice.
('36', 389, 4, 22, 767130) A principle is the expression of a perfection, and as imperfect beings like us cannot practise perfection, we devise every moment limits of its compromise in practice; So Hinduism has laid down that killing for sacrifice is no ahimsa (violence).
('36', 389, 4, 23, 767376) This is only a half truth.
('36', 389, 4, 24, 767403) Violence will be violence for all time, and all violence is sinful.
('36', 389, 4, 25, 767471) But what is inevitable is not regarded as a sin, so much so that the science of daily
('36', 390, 0, 1, 767557) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 391
('36', 390, 1, 2, 767602) practice has not only declared the inevitable violence involved in killing for sacrifice as permissible, but even regarded it as meritorious.
('36', 390, 1, 3, 767744) But unavoidable violence cannot be defined.
('36', 390, 1, 4, 767788) For it changes with time, place and person.
('36', 390, 1, 5, 767832) What is regarded as excusable at one time may be inexcusable at another.
('36', 390, 1, 6, 767905) The violence involved in burning fuel or coal in the depth of winter to keep the body warm may be unavoidable and, therefore, a duty for weak bodied man, but fire unnecessarily lit in midsummer is clearly violence.
('36', 390, 1, 7, 768120) We recognize the duty of killing microbes by the use of disinfectants.
('36', 390, 1, 8, 768191) It is violence and yet a duty.
('36', 390, 1, 9, 768222) But why go even as far as that?
('36', 390, 1, 10, 768254) The air in a dark, closed room is full of little microbes, and the introduction of light and air into it by opening it is destruction indeed.
('36', 390, 1, 11, 768396) But it is ever a duty to use that finest of disinfectants—pure air.
('36', 390, 1, 12, 768464) These instances can be multiplied.
('36', 390, 1, 13, 768499) The principle that applies in the instances cited applies in the matter of killing rabid dogs.
('36', 390, 1, 14, 768594) To destroy a rabid dog is to commit the minimum amount of violence.
('36', 390, 1, 15, 768662) A recluse, who is living in a forest and is compassion incarnate, may not destroy a rabid dog.
('36', 390, 1, 16, 768757) For in his compassion he has the virtue of making it whole.
('36', 390, 1, 17, 768817) But a city dweller who is responsible for the protection of lives under his care and who does not possess the virtues of the recluse, but is capable of destroying a rabid dog, is faced with a conflict of duties.
('36', 390, 1, 18, 769029) If he kills the dog, he commits a sin.
('36', 390, 1, 19, 769068) If he does not kill it, he commits a graver sin.
('36', 390, 1, 20, 769117) So he prefers to commit the lesser one and save himself from the graver.
('36', 390, 1, 21, 769190) I believe myself to be saturated with ahimsa—non violence.
('36', 390, 1, 22, 769249) Ahimsa and Truth are as my two lungs.
('36', 390, 1, 23, 769287) I cannot live without them.
('36', 390, 1, 24, 769315) But I see every moment, with more and more clearness, the immense power of ahimsa and the littleness of man.
('36', 390, 1, 25, 769424) Even the forest dweller cannot be entirely free from violence, in spite of his limitless compassion.
('36', 390, 1, 26, 769525) With every breath he commits a certain amount of violence.
('36', 390, 1, 27, 769584) The body itself is a house of slaughter, and therefore moksha and Eternal Bliss consist in perfect deliverance from the body and, therefore, all pleasure, save the joy of moksha, is evanescent, imperfect.
('36', 390, 1, 28, 769789) That being the case, we have to drink, in daily life, many a bitter draught of violence.
('36', 390, 1, 29, 769878) It is therefore a thousand pities that the question of stray dogs, etc., assumes such a monstrous proportion in this sacred land of ahimsa.
('36', 390, 1, 30, 770018) It is my firm conviction that we are propagatinghimsa
('36', 391, 0, 1, 770072) 392 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 391, 1, 2, 770114) in the name of ahimsa owing to our deep ignorance of the great principle.
('36', 391, 1, 3, 770188) It may be a sin to destroy rabid dogs and such others as are liable to catch rabies.
('36', 391, 1, 4, 770273) But we are responsible, the mahajan is responsible, for this state of things.
('36', 391, 1, 5, 770351) The mahajan may not allow the dogs to stray.
('36', 391, 1, 6, 770396) It is a sin, it should be a sin, to feed stray dogs, and we should save numerous dogs if we had legislation making every stray dog liable to be shot.
('36', 391, 1, 7, 770546) Even if those who feed stray dogs consented to pay a penalty for their misdirected compassion we should be free from the curse of stray dogs.
('36', 391, 1, 8, 770688) Humanity is a noble attribute of the soul.
('36', 391, 1, 9, 770731) It is not exhausted with saving a few fish or a few dogs.
('36', 391, 1, 10, 770789) Such saving may even be sinful.
('36', 391, 1, 11, 770821) If I have a swarm of ants in my house, the man who proceeds to feed them will be guilty of a sin.
('36', 391, 1, 12, 770919) For God has provided their grain for the ants, but the man who feeds them might destroy me and my family.
('36', 391, 1, 13, 771025) The mahajan may feel itself safe and believe that it has saved their lives by dumping dogs near my field, but it will have committed the greater sin of putting my life in danger.
('36', 391, 1, 14, 771204) Humaneness is impossible without thought, discrimination, charity, fearlessness, humility and clear vision.
('36', 391, 1, 15, 771312) It is no easy thing to walk on the sharp sword edge of ahimsa in this world which is so full of himsa.
('36', 391, 1, 16, 771415) Wealth does not help; anger is the enemy of ahimsa; and pride is a monster that swallows it up.
('36', 391, 1, 17, 771511) In this strait and narrow observance of this religion of ahimsa one has often to know so called himsa as the truest form of ahimsa.
('36', 391, 1, 18, 771643) Things in this world are not what they seem and do not seem as they really are.
('36', 391, 1, 19, 771723) Or if they are seen as they are, they so appear only to a few who have perfected themselves after ages of penance.
('36', 391, 1, 20, 771838) But none has yet been able to describe the reality, and no one, can.
('36', 391, 2, 21, 771907) Young India, 21 10 1926
('36', 391, 3, 22, 771931) 449. LETTER TO V. A. SUNDARAM

('36', 392, 8, 14, 772699) DEAR FRIEND, You will not misunderstand me for telling you that I must not send you any message for your forthcoming paper.
('36', 392, 8, 15, 772823) 1 The increasing bitterness has made me sad.
('36', 392, 8, 16, 772868) Multiplication of newspapers multiplies bitterness.
('36', 392, 8, 17, 772920) Of late, therefore, I have ceased to send messages to newspapers, especially new ones.
('36', 392, 8, 18, 773007) I refused only two weeks ago to send a message of simple good wishes to Dr. Satyapal on his enterprise.
('36', 392, 8, 19, 773111) 2 I did likewise for a nationalist weekly in U.P. 3 If I could I would dissuade you from your enterprise at this juncture and feel that I had done a true friend’s duty.

('36', 394, 1, 2, 775160) 454. WILL
('36', 394, 2, 3, 775170) [October 10, 1926]
('36', 394, 3, 4, 775189) This is my last testament, and by this I revoke all wills executed by me heretofore.
('36', 394, 3, 5, 775274) I do not possess any property of my own.
('36', 394, 3, 6, 775315) If, after my death, any article is found to be of my ownership, I bequeath the same to the Trustees of the Satyagraha Ashram, namely, Shri R. J. Jhaveri 1, B. Jamnlalji 2, M. H. Desai 3, I. A. K. Bawazeer 4 and C. K. Gandhi 5, or the Trustees of the said Satyagraha Ashram at the time of my demise and thereafter to the Trustees thereof from time to time as my heirs.
('36', 394, 3, 7, 775683) I also bequeath to the aforesaid Trustees all my rights in whatever books and whatever articles I have written or I may write hereafter, and also appoint them to administer my affairs after my death if and when necessary.
('36', 394, 3, 8, 775905) The income derived from the said books and articles or from the copyrights thereof and the property found to be of my ownership is to be used for carrying out the objects of the Satyagraha Ashram according to their discretion.
('36', 394, 3, 9, 776132) If any of the afore mentioned Trustees resigns or dies during my lifetime or after my death, the surviving Trustees may carry on the duties under this Will and can appoint a new Trustee to fill up the vacancy if they so desire.
('36', 394, 3, 10, 776360) I reserve my right to add to or alter this Will.
('36', 394, 3, 11, 776409) This Will has been executed by me in a sound state of mind and of my free will at Sabarmati Satyagraha Ashram, Asho Sud 4, Samvat 1982. Witnesses: MOHANDAS KARAMCHAND GANDHI DESAI VALJI GOVINDJI CHHOTELAL JAIN

('36', 396, 5, 10, 778350) 458. RACE ARROGANCE
('36', 396, 6, 11, 778370) A German correspondent who is interested in obliterating race distinctions sends me an article showing the wrong done by white Europe to the Abyssinians and the Riffs and the injustice that is being daily perpetrated against the Negro in the United States of America in the name of and for the sake of maintaining white superiority.
('36', 396, 6, 12, 778703) From the article, I cull the following three instances:
('36', 396, 7, 13, 778759) There were Christian clergymen the other day voyaging to the”Holy Land”.
('36', 396, 7, 14, 778832) A clergyman from the Southern States announced himself.
('36', 396, 7, 15, 778888) His white fellow clergymen would not let him travel with them.
('36', 396, 7, 16, 778951) The passage was refunded and compensation was paid and thus they got rid of the”coloured man”.
('36', 396, 8, 17, 779046) In South Carolina (U.S.A.) a white man stole a motor car.
('36', 396, 8, 18, 779104) He got four weeks.
('36', 396, 8, 19, 779123) The same Court of Justice condemned a Negro to three years’ penal servitude for stealing a bicyle.
('36', 396, 8, 20, 779222) A Delaware (U.S.A.)”coloured” man was sentenced to death for committing rape on a white girl.
('36', 396, 8, 21, 779316) At Alabama (U.S.A.) two whites were fined $.
('36', 396, 8, 22, 779361) 250 each for committing rape on coloured girls.
('36', 396, 8, 23, 779409) If the white man is cursed with the pride of race, we are cursed with the pride of birth.
('36', 396, 8, 24, 779499) Our treatment of the so called untouchablesis no better than that of coloured people by the white man.
('36', 396, 8, 25, 779602) I have cited the examples to show that the material achievements of the West have made no material difference in their morality—the final test of any civilization.
('36', 396, 9, 26, 779766) Young India, 14 10 1926
('36', 397, 0, 1, 779790) 398 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 397, 1, 2, 779832) 459. A CATECHISM
('36', 397, 2, 3, 779849) I gladly publish this catechism 1. But I must not enter into a long reply even though I should fail to satisfy the able catechist.
('36', 397, 2, 4, 779980) 1. What I have pleaded for is that parents who commit the sin of”marrying” their daughters of tender age should expiate for the sin by remarrying these daughters, should they become widowed while they are yet in their teens.
('36', 397, 2, 5, 780205) 2 If the girls become widowed at a ripe age, it is their concern whether they would remarry or remain widowed.
('36', 397, 2, 6, 780316) If I were called upon to state what the rule should be,.
('36', 397, 2, 7, 780373) I should say the same rule should apply to women as to men.
('36', 397, 2, 8, 780433) If a fifty year old widower may remarry with impunity, it should be open to the widow of that age to do likewise.
('36', 397, 2, 9, 780547) That in my opinion both will be sinning by remarriage is quite another matter.
('36', 397, 2, 10, 780626) I should any day subscribe to a reform in the Hindu law making sinful the remarriage of a widow or a widower who voluntarily married after maturity.
('36', 397, 2, 11, 780775) 2. All I have advocated is abolition of the fifth varna.
('36', 397, 2, 12, 780832) 3 The untouchables should, therefore, merge in the fourth division.
('36', 397, 2, 13, 780900) The reorganization of the four divisions, the abolition of artificial inequalities and of subdivisions is a separate branch of reform.
('36', 397, 2, 14, 781035) Interdining means dining off the same plate.
('36', 397, 2, 15, 781080) If I eat a biscuit cooked by Vishnu, Solomon, Ismail and Company, I do not interdine.
('36', 397, 2, 16, 781166) 3. I call myself a sanatani Hindu 4, because I believe in the Vedas, the Upanishads, the Puranas and the writings left by the holy reformers.
('36', 397, 2, 17, 781308) This belief does not require me to accept as authentic everything that passes as Shastras.
('36', 397, 2, 18, 781399) I reject everything that contradicts the fundamental principles of morality.
('36', 397, 2, 19, 781476) I am not required to accept the ipse dixit or the interpretations of pundits.
('36', 397, 2, 20, 781554) Above all I call myself
('36', 397, 3, 21, 781578) 1 Not reproduced here.
('36', 397, 3, 22, 781601) This was a long letter by an”Assistant Executive Engineer” raising four basic issues.
('36', 397, 3, 23, 781687) 2 The correspondent, referring to Gandhiji’s article”Supressed Humanity”, 19 8 1926, had asked what his prescription would be for widows of 15 years of age or above.
('36', 397, 3, 24, 781853) 3 The correspondent had sought to know why caste reform should not involve inter dining.
('36', 397, 3, 25, 781942) 4 The correspondent had asked, citing what Gandhiji had written in”Curse of Child Marriage”, 26 8 1926, why he termed himself a”Hindu” and at the same time denied the authority of the Shastras.
('36', 397, 3, 26, 782136) The correspondent had charged Gandhiji, in the light of his articles”Defending Child Marriage”, 9 9 1926 and”The Hydra headed Monster”, 29 7 1926, with intolerance of which Gandhiji had considered Swami Dayanand and the Arya Samajists guilty.
('36', 398, 0, 1, 782379) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 399
('36', 398, 1, 2, 782424) a sanatani Hindu, so long as Hindu society in general accepts me as such.
('36', 398, 1, 3, 782498) In a concrete manner he is a Hindu who believes in God, immortality of the soul, transmigration, the law of Karma and moksha, and who tries to practise truth and ahimsa in daily life, and therefore practises cow protection in its widest sense and understands and tries to act according to the law of varnashrama.
('36', 398, 1, 4, 782811) I must not be drawn into controversy about Swami Dayanand.
('36', 398, 2, 5, 782870) Young India, 14 10 1926
('36', 398, 3, 6, 782894) 460. TYRANNY OF WORDS
('36', 398, 4, 7, 782916) A correspondent thus writes on my article”No Faith in Prayer” published in Young India dated September 23rd:
('36', 398, 5, 8, 783025) In your article bearing the above caption you hardly do justice to the”boy” or to your own position as a great thinker.
('36', 398, 5, 9, 783145) It is true that the expressions used by the writer in his letter are not all happy but of his clarity of thought there is no doubt.
('36', 398, 5, 10, 783277) It is also very evident that he is not a boy as the
('36', 398, 6, 11, 783329) word is understood.
('36', 398, 6, 12, 783349) I should be much surprised to find him under twenty.
('36', 398, 6, 13, 783402) Even if he is young he seems to show sufficient intellectual development not to be treated in the manner of”A boy may not argue”.
('36', 398, 6, 14, 783532) The writer of the letter is a rationalist while you are a believer, two age old types, with age old conflict.
('36', 398, 6, 15, 783642) The attitude of the one is, ‘Let me be convinced and I shall believe’, that of the other is, ‘Believe and conviction shall come’.
('36', 398, 6, 16, 783772) The first appeals to reason, the second appeals to authority.
('36', 398, 6, 17, 783834) You seem to thank that agnosticism is but a passing phase among all young people and that faith comes to them sooner or later.
('36', 398, 6, 18, 783961) There is the well known case of Swami Vivekanandato support your view.
('36', 398, 6, 19, 784032) You therefore proceed to prescribe a compulsory dose of prayer to the”boy” for his own good.
('36', 398, 6, 20, 784125) Your reasons are twofold.
('36', 398, 6, 21, 784151) Firstly, prayer for its
('36', 398, 7, 22, 784175) own sake, as a recognition of one’s own littleness, and mightiness and goodness of the supposed higher being; Secondly, for its utility, for the solace
('36', 398, 8, 23, 784327) it bring to those who want to be solaced.
('36', 398, 8, 24, 784369) l shall dispose of the second argu ment first.
('36', 398, 8, 25, 784416) Here it is recommended as a sort of staff to the weak.
('36', 398, 8, 26, 784471) Such are the trials of life, and such is their power to shatter the reason of men that a great many people may need prayer and faith sometimes.
('36', 398, 8, 27, 784615) They have a right to it and they are welcome to it.
('36', 398, 8, 28, 784667) But there have been and there are always some true rationalists—few no doubt—who have never felt the necessity of either.
('36', 398, 8, 29, 784789) There is also the class of people who while they are not aggressive doubters are
('36', 398, 9, 30, 784870) 1 ibid.
('36', 399, 0, 1, 784878) 400 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 399, 1, 2, 784920) indifferent to religion.
('36', 399, 1, 3, 784945) As all people do not ultimately require the help of prayer and as those who feel its necessity are free to take to it and do take to it, when required,
('36', 399, 2, 4, 785097) compulsion in prayer from the point of utility cannot be upheld.
('36', 399, 2, 5, 785162) Compulsory physical exercise and education may be necessary for physical and mental development of a person, not so the belief in God and prayer for the moral side.
('36', 399, 2, 6, 785327) Some of the world’s greatest agnostics have been the most moral men.
('36', 399, 2, 7, 785396) To these I suppose you would recommend prayer for its own sake, as an expression of humility, in fact your first argument.
('36', 399, 2, 8, 785519) Too much has been made of this humility.
('36', 399, 2, 9, 785560) So vast is knowledge that even the greatest scientists have felt humble sometimes, but their general trait has been that of masterful
('36', 399, 3, 10, 785694) inquiry, their faith in their own powers has been as great as their conquests of nature.
('36', 399, 3, 11, 785783) Had it not been so we should still be scratching earth with bare fingers for roots, nay, we should have been wiped the surface of the earth.
('36', 399, 3, 12, 785924) During the Ice Age when human beings were dying of cold and when fire was first discovered, your prototype in that age must have taunted the discoverer with ‘What is the use of your schemes, of what avail are they against the power and wrath of God?’ The humble have been promised the Kingdom of God hereafter.
('36', 399, 3, 13, 786235) We do not know whether they will get it, but there on this earth their portion is serfdom.
('36', 399, 3, 14, 786326) To revert to the main point, your assertion about”accept the belief and the faith shall come” is too true, terribly true.
('36', 399, 3, 15, 786448) Much of the religious fanaticism of this world can be traced directly to the kind of teaching.
('36', 399, 3, 16, 786543) Provided you catch them young enough, and keep at them repeatedly and long enough, you can make a good majority of human beings believe in anything.
('36', 399, 3, 17, 786692) That is how your orthodox Hindu or fanatical
('36', 399, 4, 18, 786737) Mahommedan is manufactured.
('36', 399, 4, 19, 786765) There are of course always a small few in either community who will outgrow these beliefs that have been forced upon them.
('36', 399, 4, 20, 786888) Do you know that if the Hindus and the Mahommedans stopped studying their scriptures until they reached maturity, they would not be such fanatical believers in their dogmas and would cease to quarrel for their sake?
('36', 399, 4, 21, 787104) Secular education is the remedy for the Hindu Muslim riots, but you will not be able to appreciate the solution, for you are not made that way.
('36', 399, 4, 22, 787248) Great as our debt is to you for setting an unprecedented example in courage, action and sacrifice in this country, where people have been always much afraid, when the final judgment is passed on your work it will be said that
('36', 399, 5, 23, 787474) your influence gave a great setback to intellectual progress in this country.
('36', 399, 5, 24, 787552) I do not know the meaning of boy”as the word is ordinarily understood”, if a 20 year old lad is not a boy.
('36', 399, 5, 25, 787659) Indeed I would call all school going persons boys and girls, irrespective of their ages.
('36', 399, 5, 26, 787748) But whether the doubting student may be called a boy or a man, my
('36', 400, 0, 1, 787814) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 401
('36', 400, 1, 2, 787859) argument must stand.
('36', 400, 1, 3, 787880) A student is like a soldier (and a soldier may be 40 years old) who may not argue about matters of discipline when he has put himself and chooses to remain under it.
('36', 400, 1, 4, 788046) A soldier may not remain a unit in his regiment and have the option of doing or not doing things he is asked to do.
('36', 400, 1, 5, 788162) Similarly a student, no matter how wise or old he is, surrenders when he joins a school or a college the right of rejecting its discipline.
('36', 400, 1, 6, 788302) Here there is no underrating or despising the intelligence of the student.
('36', 400, 1, 7, 788377) It is an aid to his intelligence for him to come voluntarily under discipline.
('36', 400, 1, 8, 788456) But my correspondent willingly bears the heavy yoke of the tyranny of words.
('36', 400, 1, 9, 788533) He scents”compul sion” in every act that displeases the doer.
('36', 400, 1, 10, 788595) But there is compulsion and compulsion.
('36', 400, 1, 11, 788635) We call self imposed compulsion self restraint.
('36', 400, 1, 12, 788683) We hug it and grow under it.
('36', 400, 1, 13, 788712) But compulsion to be shunned even at the cost of life is restraint superimposed upon us against our wills and often with the object of humiliating us and robbing us of our dignity as men and boys if you will.
('36', 400, 1, 14, 788921) Social restraints generally are healthy and we reject them to our own undoing.
('36', 400, 1, 15, 789000) Submission to crawling orders is unmanly and cowardly.
('36', 400, 1, 16, 789055) Worse still is submission to the multitude of passions that crowd round us every moment of our lives ready to hold us their slaves.
('36', 400, 1, 17, 789187) But the correspondent has yet another word that holds him in its chains.
('36', 400, 1, 18, 789260) It is the mighty word”rationalism”.
('36', 400, 1, 19, 789296) Well, I had a full dose of it.
('36', 400, 1, 20, 789327) Experience has humbled me enough to let me realize the specific limitations of reason.
('36', 400, 1, 21, 789414) Just as matter misplaced becomes dirt, reason misused becomes lunacy.
('36', 400, 1, 22, 789484) If we would but render unto Caesar that which is Caesar’s, all would be well.
('36', 400, 1, 23, 789562) Rationalists are admirable beings, rationalism is a hideous monster when it claims for itself omnipotence.
('36', 400, 1, 24, 789669) Attribution of omnipotence to reason is as bad a piece of idolatry as is worship of stock and stone believing it to be God.
('36', 400, 1, 25, 789793) Who has reasoned out the use of prayer?
('36', 400, 1, 26, 789833) Its use is felt after practice.
('36', 400, 1, 27, 789865) Such is the world’s testimony.
('36', 400, 1, 28, 789896) Cardinal Newman never surrendered his reason, but he yielded a better place to prayer when he humbly sang”one step enough for me”.
('36', 400, 1, 29, 790027) Sankara was a prince among reasoners.
('36', 400, 1, 30, 790065) There is hardly anything in the world’s literature to surpass Sankara’s rationalism.
('36', 400, 1, 31, 790150) But he yielded the first place to prayer and faith.
('36', 400, 1, 32, 790202) The correspondent has made a hasty generalization from the fleeting and disturbing events that are happening before us.
('36', 400, 1, 33, 790322) But everything on this earth lends itself to abuse.
('36', 400, 1, 34, 790374) It seems to be a law
('36', 401, 0, 1, 790395) 402 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 401, 1, 2, 790437) governing everything pertaining to man.
('36', 401, 1, 3, 790477) No doubt religion has to answer for some of the most terrible crimes in history.
('36', 401, 1, 4, 790558) But that is the fault not of religion but of the ungovernable brute in man.
('36', 401, 1, 5, 790634) He has not yet shed the effects of his brute ancestry.
('36', 401, 1, 6, 790689) I do not know a single rationalist who has never done anything in simple faith and has based every one of his acts on reason.
('36', 401, 1, 7, 790815) But we all know millions of human beings living their more or less orderly lives because of their childlike faith in the Maker of us all.
('36', 401, 1, 8, 790953) That very faith is a prayer.
('36', 401, 1, 9, 790982) The”boy” on whose letter I based my article belongs to that vast mass of humanity and the article was written to steady him and his fellow searchers, not to disturb the happiness of rationalists like the correspondent.
('36', 401, 1, 10, 791201) But he quarrels even with the bent that is given to the youth of the world by their elders and teachers.
('36', 401, 1, 11, 791306) But that it seems is an inseparable handicap (if it be one) of impressionable age.
('36', 401, 1, 12, 791389) Purely secular education is also an attempt to mould the young mind after a fashion.
('36', 401, 1, 13, 791474) The correspondent is good enough to grant that the body and the mind may be trained and directed.
('36', 401, 1, 14, 791572) Of the soul which makes the body and the mind possible, he has no care, or perhaps he is in doubt as to its existence.
('36', 401, 1, 15, 791691) But his disbelief cannot avail him.
('36', 401, 1, 16, 791727) He cannot escape the consequence of his reasoning.
('36', 401, 1, 17, 791778) For, why may not a believer argue on the correspondent’s own ground and say he must influence the soul of boys and girls even as the others influence the body and the intelligence?
('36', 401, 1, 18, 791959) The evils of religious instruction will vanish with the evolution of the true religious spirit.
('36', 401, 1, 19, 792055) To give up religious instruction is like letting a field lie fallow and grow weeds for want of the tiller’s knowledge of the proper use of the field.
('36', 401, 1, 20, 792205) The correspondent’s excursion into the great discoveries of the ancients is really irrelevant to the subject under discussion.
('36', 401, 1, 21, 792332) No one questions, I do not, the utility or the brilliance of those discoveries.
('36', 401, 1, 22, 792412) They were generally a proper field for the use and exercise of reason.
('36', 401, 1, 23, 792483) But they, the ancients, did not delete from their lives the predominant function of faith and prayer.
('36', 401, 1, 24, 792585) Works without faith and prayer are like an artificial flower that has no fragrance.
('36', 401, 1, 25, 792669) I plead not for the suppression of reason, but for a due recognition of that in us which sanctifies reason itself.
('36', 401, 2, 26, 792784) Young India, 14 10 1926

('36', 402, 9, 19, 794159) 463. IMPROVISED METHOD OF TESTING
('36', 402, 10, 20, 794193) The head master of Dondaicha school inquires whether there is an improvised method of testing the strength and the count of yarn.
('36', 402, 11, 21, 794323) 1 The report, not given here, furnished details of production of yarn by the pupils and the accounts of the takli class.
('36', 402, 12, 22, 794444) 2 The report had said:”Carding will be taken in hand after one month, when agricultural pursuits of boys are over.” 3 The report, not reproduced here, was of the exhibition organized by the Bihar Provincial Khadi Department between September 15 and 23. It gave a gist of the speech by F. C. Temple, who had presided over the inaugural function.
('36', 402, 12, 23, 794789) It was attended, among others, by Rajendra Prasad .
('36', 403, 0, 1, 794841) 404 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 403, 1, 2, 794883) Here is a recipe:
('36', 403, 2, 3, 794901) Take from the yarn at random 4 yards and make a reel two feet in circumference.
('36', 403, 2, 4, 794981) This will be one foot in length and hang it stretched to a peg so as not to get untwisted.
('36', 403, 2, 5, 795072) Hang at the other end regulated weights.
('36', 403, 2, 6, 795113) You are ready to measure the test when the strand snaps by the weight.
('36', 403, 3, 7, 795184) Weigh the broken strand in a fine scale.
('36', 403, 3, 8, 795225) Now one tola is 100 ratis.
('36', 403, 3, 9, 795252) If the reel weighs approximately 18_ ratis the yarn is count 1. If the reel weighs less the fraction of 18 ratis will be the count of yarn.
('36', 403, 3, 10, 795392) Thus if the 4 yards weigh 3 ratis, since 3 ratis is 1/6th of 18, the count is 6. In the absence of fine scales and very small weights, the strands may be more yards, where a waste of yarn is not of much consequence.
('36', 403, 3, 11, 795608) (Broken yarn may be used for making wicks, etc.) The convenient length is 21 yards and its multiples, 42, 84. The following table should be memorized: 7000 grains = 1 lb.
('36', 403, 3, 12, 795779) = 38 8/9 tolas 180 grains = 1 tola 840 yards yarn = 1 lease.
('36', 403, 3, 13, 795840) Therefore: 7000 grains Weight of hank of 840 yards = Count.
('36', 403, 3, 14, 795900) (in grains) Or 38 8/9 tolas Weight of hank in tolas = Count.
('36', 403, 4, 15, 795961) Or Yards X 10 Tolas X 216 = Count.
('36', 403, 5, 16, 795996) To arrive at the test remember:
('36', 403, 6, 17, 796028) 315 tolas X length =100 test.
('36', 403, 8, 18, 796058) One round = 2 lengths.
('36', 403, 9, 19, 796081) To find the unevenness of a given quantity of yarn made up into strands:
('36', 403, 10, 20, 796154) Find the counts of six strands selected anyhow from your hank.
('36', 403, 11, 21, 796217) Total the counts and divide by six.
('36', 403, 11, 22, 796253) You have the average count.
('36', 404, 0, 1, 796281) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 405
('36', 404, 1, 2, 796326) Take the difference between the highest and the lowest counts.
('36', 404, 1, 3, 796389) Then The difference X 100 = unevenness p.c.
('36', 404, 1, 4, 796433) the average Deduct the unevenness percentage from 100 and you have the percentage of evenness.
('36', 404, 1, 5, 796528) Thus if six strands show respectively 16, 18, 15, 20, 22, and 17 counts, the total is 108; 108 = 18. 6 Now the lowest count is 15 and the highest is 22. The difference is 7. Therefore 7 X 100 = 39 nearly unevenness.
('36', 404, 1, 6, 796744) 18 Therefore 100 39 = 61 evenness.
('36', 404, 1, 7, 796779) Young India, 14 10 1926

('36', 409, 1, 2, 802977) 473. IS THIS HUMANITY? II
('36', 409, 2, 3, 803003) [October 17, 1926]
('36', 409, 3, 4, 803022) When I wrote the article on this subject I knew that I was adding one more to my already heavy burden of troubles.
('36', 409, 3, 5, 803137) But it could not be helped.
('36', 409, 3, 6, 803165) Angry letters are now pouring in.
('36', 409, 3, 7, 803199) At an hour when after a hard day’s work I was about to retire to bed, three friends invaded me, infringed the religion of ahimsa in the name of humanity, and engaged me in a discussion on it.
('36', 409, 3, 8, 803391) They had come in the name of humanity.
('36', 409, 3, 9, 803430) How could I refuse to see them?
('36', 409, 3, 10, 803462) So I met them.
('36', 409, 3, 11, 803477) One of them, I saw, betrayed anger, bitterness and arrogance.
('36', 409, 3, 12, 803539) He did not seem to me to have come with a view to getting his doubts solved.
('36', 409, 3, 13, 803616) He had come rather to correct me.
('36', 409, 3, 14, 803650) Everyone has a right to do so, but whoever undertakes such a mission must know my position.
('36', 409, 3, 15, 803742) This friend had taken no trouble to understand my position.
('36', 409, 3, 16, 803802) But he was not to blame for it.
('36', 409, 3, 17, 803834) This impatience which is but a symptom of violence is to be found everywhere.
('36', 409, 3, 18, 803912) The violence in this case was painful to me as it was betrayed by an advocate of non violence.
('36', 409, 3, 19, 804007) He claimed to be a Jain.
('36', 409, 3, 20, 804032) I have made a fair study of Jainism.
('36', 409, 3, 21, 804069) This visitor’s ahimsa was a distortion of the reality as I have known it in Jainism.
('36', 409, 3, 22, 804154) But the Jains have no monopoly of ahimsa.
('36', 409, 3, 23, 804196) It is not the exclusive peculiarity of any religion.
('36', 409, 3, 24, 804249) Every religion is based on ahimsa, its application is different in different religions.
('36', 409, 3, 25, 804337) I do not think that the Jains of today practise ahimsa in any better way than others.
('36', 409, 3, 26, 804423) I can say this because of my acquaintance with Jains, which is so old that many take me to be a Jain.
('36', 409, 3, 27, 804525) Mahavir was an incarnation of compassion, of ahimsa.
('36', 409, 3, 28, 804578) How I wish his votaries were votaries also of his ahimsa!
('36', 409, 3, 29, 804636) Protection of little creatures is indeed an essential part of ahimsa, but it does not exhaust itself with it.
('36', 409, 3, 30, 804746) Ahimsa begins with it.
('36', 409, 3, 31, 804769) Besides protection may not always mean mere refraining from killing.
('36', 409, 3, 32, 804838) Torture or participation, direct or indirect, in the unnecessary multiplication of those that must die is himsa The multiplication of dogs is unnecessary.
('36', 409, 3, 33, 804993) A roving dog without an owner is a danger to society and a swarm of them is a menace to its very existence.
('36', 410, 0, 1, 805101) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 411
('36', 410, 1, 2, 805146) If we want to keep dogs in towns or villages in a decent manner, no dog should be suffered to wander.
('36', 410, 1, 3, 805248) There should be no stray dogs even as we have no stray cattle.
('36', 410, 1, 4, 805311) Humanitarian societies should find a religious solution of such questions.
('36', 410, 1, 5, 805386) But can we take individual charge of these roving dogs?
('36', 410, 1, 6, 805442) And if we cannot, can we have a pinjarapole for them?
('36', 410, 1, 7, 805496) If both these things are impossible, there seems to me to be no alternative except to kill them.
('36', 410, 1, 8, 805593) Connivance or putting up with the status quo is no ahimsa, there is no thought or discrimination in it.
('36', 410, 1, 9, 805697) Dogs will be killed whenever they are a menace to society.
('36', 410, 1, 10, 805756) I regard this as unavoidable in the life of a householder.
('36', 410, 1, 11, 805815) To wait until they get rabid is not to be merciful to them.
('36', 410, 1, 12, 805875) We can imagine what the dogs would wish if a meeting could be called of them, from what we would wish under the same circumstances.
('36', 410, 1, 13, 806007) We will not choose to live anyhow.
('36', 410, 1, 14, 806042) That many of us do so is no credit to us.
('36', 410, 1, 15, 806084) A meeting of wise men will never resolve that men may treat one another as they treat rabid or stray dogs.
('36', 410, 1, 16, 806191) What shall we expect of them if there were to be some beings loasing it over us as we do over dogs?
('36', 410, 1, 17, 806291) Would we not rather prefer to be killed than to be treated as dogs?
('36', 410, 1, 18, 806359) We offend against dogs as a class by suffering them to stray and live on crumbs or savings from our plates that we throw at them and we injure our neighbours also by doing so.
('36', 410, 1, 19, 806535) I admit that there is the duty of suffering dogs to live even at the cost of one’s life.
('36', 410, 1, 20, 806624) But that religion is not for the householder who desires to live, who procreates, who would protect society.
('36', 410, 1, 21, 806733) The householder can but practise the middle path of taking care of a few dogs.
('36', 410, 1, 22, 806812) Our domestics of today are the wild animals of yesterday.
('36', 410, 1, 23, 806870) The buffalo is a domestic only in India.
('36', 410, 1, 24, 806911) It is a sin to domesticate wild animals inasmuch as man does so for his selfish purposes.
('36', 410, 1, 25, 807001) That he has domesticated the cow and the buffalo is not out of mercy for them, it is for his own use.
('36', 410, 1, 26, 807103) He, therefore, does not allow a cow or a buffalo to stray.
('36', 410, 1, 27, 807162) The same duty is incumbent regarding dogs.
('36', 410, 1, 28, 807205) I am, therefore, strongly of opinion that, if we would practise the religion of humanity, we should have a law making it obligatory on those who would have dogs to keep them under guard, and not allow them to stray, and making all the stray dogs liable to be destroyed after a certain date.
('36', 410, 1, 29, 807496) If the mahajan has really any mercy for the dogs, it should take possession of all the stray dogs and distribute them to those who want
('36', 411, 0, 1, 807632) 412 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 411, 1, 2, 807674) to keep them.
('36', 411, 1, 3, 807688) It seems to me to be impossible to protect dogs as we can protect the cows.
('36', 411, 1, 4, 807764) But there is a regular science of dog keeping which the people in the West have formulated and perfected.
('36', 411, 1, 5, 807870) We should learn it from them and devise measures for the solution of our own problem.
('36', 411, 1, 6, 807956) The work cannot be done without patience, wisdom and perseverance.
('36', 411, 1, 7, 808023) So much about dogs.
('36', 411, 1, 8, 808043) But with ahimsa in its comprehensive aspect I propose to deal on another occasion.

('36', 414, 1, 2, 812563) 480. TOUGH QUESTION
('36', 414, 2, 3, 812583) A fair friend who has some faith in my wisdom and sincerity asks some knotty questions which I would fain avoid for fear of raising an indignant controversy on the part of some husbands jealous of their rights.
('36', 414, 2, 4, 812794) But jealous husbands would spare me, for they know that I happen to be one myself having led a fairly happy married life for the past forty years in spite of occasional jars.
('36', 414, 3, 5, 812969) The first question is apposite and timely (The original is in Marathi.
('36', 414, 3, 6, 813040) I have given a free rendering.):
('36', 414, 4, 7, 813073) Can a man or woman attain self realization by mere recitation of Ramanama and without taking part in national service?
('36', 414, 4, 8, 813192) I ask this question because some of my sisters say that they do not need to do anything beyond attending to family requirements and occasionally showing kindness to the poor.
('36', 414, 5, 9, 813367) This question has puzzled not only women but many men and has taxed me to the utmost.
('36', 414, 5, 10, 813453) I know that there is a school of philosophy which teaches complete inaction and futility of all effort.
('36', 414, 5, 11, 813557) I have not been able to appreciate that teaching unless, in order to secure verbal agreement, I were to put my own interpretation on it.
('36', 414, 5, 12, 813694) In my humble opinion, effort is necessary for one’s own growth.
('36', 414, 5, 13, 813758) It has to be irrespective of results.
('36', 414, 5, 14, 813796) Ramanama or some equivalent is necessary not for the sake of repetition but for the sake of purification, as an aid to effort, for direct guidance from above.
('36', 414, 5, 15, 813955) It is, therefore, never a substitute for effort.
('36', 414, 5, 16, 814004) It is meant for intensifying and guiding it in proper channel.
('36', 414, 5, 17, 814067) If all effort is vain, why family cares or an occasional help to the poor?
('36', 414, 5, 18, 814142) In this very effort is contained the germ of national service.
('36', 414, 5, 19, 814205) And national service, to me, means service of humanity, even as disinterested service of the family means the same thing.
('36', 414, 5, 20, 814327) Disinterested service of the family necessarily leads one to national service.
('36', 414, 5, 21, 814406) Ramanama gives one detachment and ballast and never throws one off one’s balance at critical moments.
('36', 414, 5, 22, 814508) Self realization I hold to be impossible without service of and identification with the poorest.
('36', 414, 5, 23, 814605) The second question is:
('36', 414, 6, 24, 814629) In Hinduism devotion of wife to her husband and her complete merger in him is the highest aim, never mind whether the husband is a fiend or an embodiment of love.
('36', 414, 6, 25, 814792) If this be the correct conduct for a wife, may she in the teeth of opposition by
('36', 415, 0, 1, 814873) 416 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 415, 1, 2, 814915) her husband undertake national service?
('36', 415, 1, 3, 814955) Or must she only go as far as the husband will permit her to go?
('36', 415, 1, 4, 815020) My ideal of a wife is Sita and of a husband Rama.
('36', 415, 1, 5, 815070) But Sita was no slave of Rama.
('36', 415, 1, 6, 815101) Or each was slave of the other.
('36', 415, 1, 7, 815133) Rama is ever considerate to Sita.
('36', 415, 1, 8, 815167) Where there is true love, the question asked does not occur.
('36', 415, 1, 9, 815228) Where there is no true love, the bond has never existed.
('36', 415, 1, 10, 815285) But the Hindu household of today is a conundrum.
('36', 415, 1, 11, 815334) Husbands and wives when they are married know nothing of one another.
('36', 415, 1, 12, 815404) Religious sanction fortified by custom and the even flow of the lives of the married people keep the peace in the vast majority of Hindu households.
('36', 415, 1, 13, 815553) But when either wife or husband holds views out of the ordinary, there is danger of jars.
('36', 415, 1, 14, 815643) In the case of the husband he has no scruples.
('36', 415, 1, 15, 815690) He does not consider himself under any obligation to consult his partner’s wishes.
('36', 415, 1, 16, 815773) He regards his wife as his property.
('36', 415, 1, 17, 815810) And the poor wife who believes in the husband’s claim often suppresses herself.
('36', 415, 1, 18, 815890) I think there is a way out.
('36', 415, 1, 19, 815918) Mirabai has shown the way.
('36', 415, 1, 20, 815945) The wife has a perfect right to take her own course and meekly brave the consequences when she knows herself to be in the right and when her resistance is for a nobler purpose.
('36', 415, 1, 21, 816122) The third question is: If a husband is, say, a meat eater and the wife considers meat eating an evil, may she follow her own bent?
('36', 415, 1, 22, 816253) May she even try by all loving ways to wean her husband from meat eating or the like?
('36', 415, 1, 23, 816339) Or is she bound to cook meat for her husband or worse still, is she bound to eat it, if the husband requires her?
('36', 415, 1, 24, 816453) If you say that the wife may take her own course, how can a joint household be run when the one compels and the other rebels?
('36', 415, 1, 25, 816579) This question is partly answered in the answer to the second.
('36', 415, 1, 26, 816641) A wife is not bound to be an accomplice in her husband’s crimes.
('36', 415, 1, 27, 816706) And when she holds anything to be wrong, she must dare to do the right.
('36', 415, 1, 28, 816778) But, seeing that the wife’s function is to manage the household and thus to cook, as the husband’s is to earn for the family, she is bound to cook meat for the family if both have been meat eaters before.
('36', 415, 1, 29, 816983) If, on the other hand, in a vegetarian family, the husband becomes a meat eater and seeks to compel the wife to cook for him, the wife is in no way bound to cook what offends her sense of right.
('36', 415, 1, 30, 817178) The peace of a household is a most desirable thing.
('36', 415, 1, 31, 817230) But it cannot be an end in itself.
('36', 415, 1, 32, 817265) For me, the married state is as much a state of discipline as any other.
('36', 415, 1, 33, 817338) Life is duty, a probation.
('36', 415, 1, 34, 817365) Married life is intended to promote mutual good both here and hereafter.
('36', 415, 1, 35, 817438) It is meant also to serve humanity.
('36', 416, 0, 1, 817474) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 417
('36', 416, 1, 2, 817519) When one partner breaks the law of discipline, the right accrues to the other of breaking the bond.
('36', 416, 1, 3, 817619) The breach here is moral and not physical.
('36', 416, 1, 4, 817662) It precludes divorce.
('36', 416, 1, 5, 817684) The wife or the husband separates but to serve the end for which they had united.
('36', 416, 1, 6, 817766) Hinduism regards each as absolute equal of the other.
('36', 416, 1, 7, 817820) No doubt a different practice has grown up, no one knows since when.
('36', 416, 1, 8, 817889) But so have many other evils crept into it.
('36', 416, 1, 9, 817933) This, however, I do know that Hinduism leaves the individual absolutely free to do what he or she likes for the sake of self realization for which and which alone he or she is born.
('36', 416, 2, 10, 818115) Young India, 21 10 1926
('36', 416, 3, 11, 818139) 481. KNOTTY PROBLEMS OF NON VIOLENCE
