('36', 416, 6, 17, 819029) 482. STAND FOR NON VIOLENCE
('36', 416, 7, 18, 819057) A friend sends me the following cutting from the New York Nation:
('36', 416, 8, 19, 819123) Some time ago (either in the latter part of 1924 or early in 1925) a band of twenty five American missionaries in China addressed the following appeal to the American Minister at Peking:
('36', 416, 9, 20, 819310) “The undersigned American missionaries are in China as messengers of the gospel of brotherhood and peace.
('36', 416, 9, 21, 819416) Our task is to lead men and women into a
('36', 416, 10, 22, 819457) 1 For the first article of the series, vide”Is This Humanity?
('36', 416, 10, 23, 819519)  I”, 10 10 1926.
('36', 417, 0, 1, 819536) 418 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 417, 1, 2, 819578) new life in Christ, which promotes brotherhood and takes away all occasions of war.
('36', 417, 1, 3, 819662) We, therefore, express our earnest desire that no form of military pressure, especially no foreign military force, be exerted to protect us or our property; and that in the event of our capture by lawless persons or our death at their hands, no money be paid for our release, no punitive expedition be sent out, and no indemnities be exacted.
('36', 417, 1, 4, 820005) We take this stand believing that the way to establish righteousness and peace is through bringing the spirit of personal good will to bear on all persons under all circumstances, even through suffering wrong without retaliation.”
('36', 417, 2, 5, 820236) The American Legation, however, replied that this petition was inconsistent with the necessity that exists for safeguarding Americans in China, and that therefore, no exception could or would be made in the procedure in case of emergencies with regard to the signers of the petition.
('36', 417, 2, 6, 820520) This is one of those instances in which two apparently contradictory positions are right at the same time.
('36', 417, 2, 7, 820627) For the brave missionaries there was no other attitude possible, though, nowadays, very few adopt it.
('36', 417, 2, 8, 820729) Was it not about China that a missionary deputation some thirty years ago waited on the late Lord Salisbury and asked the protection of the British gunboats for carrying their message to the unwilling Chinese?
('36', 417, 2, 9, 820939) Then the late noble Marquess had to tell the missi onaries that, if they sought the protection of the British arms, they must submit to international obligations and curb their missionary ardour.
('36', 417, 2, 10, 821135) He reminded them that the Christians of old, if they pene trated the remotest regions of the earth, expected no protection save from God and put their lives in constant danger.
('36', 417, 2, 11, 821312) In the case quoted by the New York Nation, the missionaries according to the report have reverted to the ancient practice.
('36', 417, 3, 12, 821435) The American Government, however, so long as it retains its present character, can only give the answer they are reported to have given.
('36', 417, 3, 13, 821572) That the answer betrays the evil of the modern system is another matter.
('36', 417, 3, 14, 821645) The American prestige depends not upon its moral strength but upon force.
('36', 417, 3, 15, 821719) But why should the whole armed force of America be mobilized for the so called vindication of its honour or name?
('36', 417, 3, 16, 821833) What harm can accrue to the honour of America if twenty five missionaries choose to go to China uninvited for the sake of deliver ing their message and get killed in the act?
('36', 417, 3, 17, 822008) Probably, it would be the best thing for their mission.
('36', 417, 3, 18, 822064) The American Government by its inter ference could only interrupt the full working of the law of suffering.
('36', 417, 3, 19, 822172) But self restraint of America would mean a complete change of
('36', 418, 0, 1, 822234) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 419
('36', 418, 1, 2, 822279) outlook.
('36', 418, 1, 3, 822288) Today, defence of citizenship is a defence of national com merce, i.e., exploitation.
('36', 418, 1, 4, 822374) That exploitation presupposes the use of force for imposing commerce upon an unwilling people.
('36', 418, 1, 5, 822469) Nations have in a sense, therefore, almost become gangs of robbers, whereas they should be a peaceful combination of men and women united for the common good of mankind.
('36', 418, 1, 6, 822639) In the latter case, their strength will lie not in their skill in the use of gunpowder, but in the possession of superior moral fibre.
('36', 418, 1, 7, 822774) The action of the twenty five missionaries is a dim shadow of reconstructed society or even reconstructed nations.
('36', 418, 1, 8, 822889) I do not know whether they carried out their principle into practice in every department of life.
('36', 418, 1, 9, 822987) I need hardly point out that in spite of the threat of the American Government to protect them against themselves, they could neutralize, indeed even frustrate, any effort at retaliation.
('36', 418, 1, 10, 823175) But that means complete self effacement.
('36', 418, 1, 11, 823216) And if one is to combat the fetish of force, it will only be by means totally different from those in vogue among the pure worshippers of brute force.
('36', 418, 1, 12, 823367) It must not be forgotten that, after all, there is a philosophy behind the modern worship of brute force with a history to back it.
('36', 418, 1, 13, 823499) The microscopic non militant minority has, indeed, nothing to fear from it, if only it has immovable faith behind it.
('36', 418, 1, 14, 823617) But faith in the possibility of holding together society without brute force seems somehow to be lacking.
('36', 418, 1, 15, 823723) Yet, if one person can pit himself against the whole world, why cannot two or more do likewise together?
('36', 418, 1, 16, 823828) I know the answer that has been given.
('36', 418, 1, 17, 823867) Time alone can show the possibilities of the revolution that is silently creeping upon us.
('36', 418, 1, 18, 823958) Speculation is waste of effort where action is already afoot.
('36', 418, 1, 19, 824020) Those who have faith will join the initial effort in which demonstrable results cannot be shown.

('36', 419, 5, 11, 825493) 484. NOTES
('36', 419, 6, 12, 825504) THE INDIAN DELEGATION
('36', 419, 7, 13, 825526) I have already expressed my opinion about Sir Mahomed Habibulla’s deputation.
('36', 419, 7, 14, 825604) It is a carefully made choice.
('36', 419, 7, 15, 825635) I am glad to find that it has been blessed by the public.
('36', 419, 7, 16, 825693) The question of the status of Indians overseas is perhaps the one question on which all parties are united.
('36', 419, 7, 17, 825801) Hindus, Mussalmans, Christians, Parsis, etc., speak with one voice.
('36', 419, 7, 18, 825869) European opinion coincides with the Indian.
('36', 419, 7, 19, 825913) The Government backs public opinion.

('36', 419, 7, 21, 826020) This remarkable unanimity of opinion cannot but react upon South African opinion.
('36', 419, 7, 22, 826102) But this unity need not be confined to the question of the status of Indians abroad.
('36', 419, 7, 23, 826187) Is it too much to wish to extend it to other equally natural and pure causes?
('36', 419, 7, 24, 826265) Or is unity possible only on questions remote in space from the actors?
('36', 419, 7, 25, 826337) True unity comes of itself.
('36', 419, 7, 26, 826365) No attempt had to be made for achieving unity of opinion on the South African question.
('36', 419, 7, 27, 826453) All instinctively thought alike.
('36', 419, 7, 28, 826486) Unity on other matters will also come instinctively when its time has come.
('36', 419, 7, 29, 826562) I am optimistic enough to think that it is coming sooner than many of us expect or imagine.
('36', 419, 7, 30, 826654) But let us return to the deputation.
('36', 419, 7, 31, 826691) The settlers in South Africa have in Mr. C. F. Andrews a link between the deputation and
('36', 420, 0, 1, 826780) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 421
('36', 420, 1, 2, 826825) themselves as also between the Union Government and themselves.

('36', 420, 1, 7, 827249) Moderation, firmness and unity combined with absolute adherence to truth should make victory easily possible.
('36', 420, 2, 8, 827359) CONGRESS EXHIBITION Exhibitions used formerly to be a feature of the National Congress.
('36', 420, 2, 9, 827447) They had then ceased to be.
('36', 420, 2, 10, 827475) The fashion was revived in Ahmedabad and has been since continued with progressive improvement.
('36', 420, 2, 11, 827571) The central feature of these exhibitions has been khaddar with all the hand processes through which cotton passes before it comes out as khaddar.
('36', 420, 2, 12, 827717) The feature of these exhibitions has been the inclusion of only those things which have been manufactured in India from start to finish.
('36', 420, 2, 13, 827854) They have, therefore, excluded so called swadeshi watches or harmoniums whose every part was imported from outside.
('36', 420, 2, 14, 827970) They have also excluded all mill spun yarn and mill woven cloth.
('36', 420, 2, 15, 828035) These exhibitions are meant for the encouragement of those things which are neglected and which deserve encouragement.
('36', 420, 2, 16, 828154) No one will hold an exhibition for showing faggots of wood which everyone knows and uses.

('36', 420, 2, 18, 828377) Faggots of ordinary wood would be excluded not out of any jealousy of them but because attention would be divided between extraordinary wood needing advertisement and protection and the wood that had no such need.
('36', 420, 2, 19, 828591) I was, therefore, surprised when a correspondent drew my attention to the Assam Exhibition Committee having included in the exhibits cotton fabrics woven on power looms and out of mill spun yarn.
('36', 420, 2, 20, 828787) The description of the items does not exclude even foreign cloth or yarn.

('36', 424, 1, 2, 833436) 492. IS THIS HUMANITY? III
('36', 424, 2, 3, 833463) [October 24, 1926]
('36', 424, 3, 4, 833482) Whilst I admit the possibility of having made a mistake in giving the opinion that the destruction by Mr. Ambalal’s order of sixty dogs was unavoidable, I do not regret having expressed that opinion.
('36', 424, 3, 5, 833682) The result so far is all to the good.
('36', 424, 3, 6, 833720) We shall perhaps now understand more clearly our duty to such animals.
('36', 424, 3, 7, 833791) Much wrong has been done partly out of ignorance, partly from hypocrisy and partly for fear of public opinion.
('36', 424, 3, 8, 833902) All that should now cease.
('36', 424, 3, 9, 833929) But if the good is to be maintained, a clear understanding is necessary between the readers and myself.
('36', 424, 3, 10, 834033) I have received quite a pile of letters on the subject, some friendly, some sharp and some bitter.
('36', 424, 3, 11, 834132) They do not seem to have understood my attitude on the destruction of dogs by Mr. Ambalal.
('36', 424, 3, 12, 834223) I have often had the misfortune to be misunderstood.
('36', 424, 3, 13, 834276) In South Africa my life was in peril over an action which was quite consistent with my avowed principles but which, as was proved later, was rashly regarded as contrary to them.
('36', 424, 3, 14, 834454) 1 The so called”Himalayan blunder” of Bardoli is a recent memory.
('36', 424, 3, 15, 834520) The Bombay Government very kindly imprisoned me at Yeravda and saved me the trouble of much writing by way of explaining and clearing my position.
('36', 424, 3, 16, 834667) The Bardoli decision, I still hold, was not wrong.
('36', 424, 3, 17, 834718) It was, on the contrary, an act of purest ahimsa and of invaluable service to the country.
('36', 424, 3, 18, 834809) I feel just as clear about my opinion regarding the present question.
('36', 424, 3, 19, 834879) I hold that the opinion is perfectly in accord with my conception of ahimsa.
('36', 424, 3, 20, 834956) The critics, whether friendly or hostile, should bear with me.
('36', 424, 3, 21, 835019) Some of the hostile critics have transgressed the limits of decorum.
('36', 424, 3, 22, 835088) They have made no attempt to understand my position.
('36', 424, 3, 23, 835141) It seems they cannot for a moment tolerate my opinion.
('36', 424, 3, 24, 835196) Now they must be one of two things.
('36', 424, 3, 25, 835232) They are either my teachers or they regard me as one.
('36', 424, 3, 26, 835286) In the latter case, they should be courteous and patient and should have faith in me and ponder over what I write.
('36', 424, 3, 27, 835401) In the former case, they should be indulgent to me and try to reason with me as lovingly and patiently as they can.
('36', 424, 3, 28, 835517) I teach the children under my care not by being angry with them, but I teach them, if at all, by loving them, by
('36', 424, 4, 29, 835630) 1 The reference is to the assaults made on Gandhiji in 1908 by his Indian followers under the belief that he had compromised with the Smuts Government; vide”Letter to Friends”, 10 2 1908.
('36', 425, 0, 1, 835818) 426 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 425, 1, 2, 835860) allowing for their ignorance, and by playing with them.
('36', 425, 1, 3, 835916) I expect the same love, the same consideration and the same sportsmanlike spirit from my angry teachers.
('36', 425, 1, 4, 836021) I have given my opinion with regard to the dogs with the best of motives and as a matter of duty.
('36', 425, 1, 5, 836119) If I am mistaken, let the critics who would teach me reason with me patiently and logically.
('36', 425, 1, 6, 836212) Angry and irrelevant argument will not convince me.
('36', 425, 1, 7, 836264) A gentleman called on me the other evening at a late hour.
('36', 425, 1, 8, 836323) He knew that my time was completely occupied.
('36', 425, 1, 9, 836369) He engaged me in a discussion, used hard and bitter language and poured vials of wrath on me.
('36', 425, 1, 10, 836463) I answered his questions in good humour and politely.
('36', 425, 1, 11, 836517) He has published the interview in a leaflet which he is selling.
('36', 425, 1, 12, 836582) It is before me.
('36', 425, 1, 13, 836599) It has crossed the limits of truth, obviously of decorum.
('36', 425, 1, 14, 836657) He had neither obtained my permission to publish the interview nor showed it to me before publication.
('36', 425, 1, 15, 836760) Does he seek to teach me in this manner?
('36', 425, 1, 16, 836801) He who trifles with truth cuts at the root of ahimsa.
('36', 425, 1, 17, 836855) He who is angry is guilty of himsa.
('36', 425, 1, 18, 836891) How can such a man teach me ahimsa?
('36', 425, 1, 19, 836927) Even so the hostile critics are doing me a service.
('36', 425, 1, 20, 836979) They teach me to examine myself.
('36', 425, 1, 21, 837012) They afford me an opportunity to see if I am free from the reaction of anger.
('36', 425, 1, 22, 837090) And when I go to the root of their anger, I find nothing but love.
('36', 425, 1, 23, 837157) They have attributed to me ahimsa as they understand it.
('36', 425, 1, 24, 837214) Now they find me acting in a contrary manner and are angry with me.
('36', 425, 1, 25, 837282) They once regarded me as a mahatma, they were glad that my influence on the people was according to their liking.
('36', 425, 1, 26, 837396) Now I am an alpatma (a little soul) in their opinion; my influence on the people they now regard as unwholesome and they are pained by the discovery; and as they cannot control themselves, they turn the feeling of pain into one of anger.
('36', 425, 2, 27, 837634) I do not mind this outburst of anger, as I appreciate the motive behind it.
('36', 425, 2, 28, 837710) I must try to reason with them patiently, and if they would help me in my attempt, I request them to calm their anger.
('36', 425, 2, 29, 837829) I am a votary of truth and seeker after it.
('36', 425, 2, 30, 837873) If I am convinced that I am mistaken I shall admit my mistake (as I always love to do), and shall promptly mend it.
('36', 425, 2, 31, 837989) It is the word of the scriptures that the mistakes of a votary of truth never harm anybody.
('36', 425, 2, 32, 838081) That is the glorious secret of truth.
('36', 425, 2, 33, 838119) Just a word to friendly critics: I have preserved your letters.
('36', 425, 2, 34, 838183) I usually reply to my correspondents individually.
('36', 425, 2, 35, 838234) But the number of letters I have received this time and have been still getting is so large and they are so inordinately long that I cannot possibly reply to them

('36', 426, 1, 2, 838442) individually.

('36', 426, 1, 5, 838583) I hope they will not press the request.
('36', 426, 1, 6, 838623) I shall try to answer all the arguments that are relevant as well as I can, and hope that that will satisfy them.

('36', 426, 1, 8, 838804) I shall now take up some of the letters before me.
('36', 426, 1, 9, 838855) A friend says:
('36', 426, 2, 10, 838870) You ask us not to feed stray dogs.
('36', 426, 2, 11, 838905) But we do not invite them.
('36', 426, 2, 12, 838932) They simply come.
('36', 426, 2, 13, 838950) How can they be turned back?
('36', 426, 2, 14, 838979) It will be time enough when there is a plethora of them.
('36', 426, 2, 15, 839036) But is there any doubt that feeding dogs cultivates the impulse of compassion and turning them away hardens our hearts?
('36', 426, 2, 16, 839156) We are all sinners.
('36', 426, 2, 17, 839176) Why should we not practise what little kindness we can?
('36', 426, 2, 18, 839232) It is from this false feeling of compassion that we encourage himsa in the name of ahimsa.
('36', 426, 2, 19, 839323) But as ignorance is no excuse before man made law, even so is it no excuse before the divine Law.
('36', 426, 2, 20, 839421) But let us analyse the argument.
('36', 426, 2, 21, 839454) We cast a morsel at the beggar come to our door, and feel that we have earned some merit, but we really thereby add to the numbers of beggars, aggravate the evil of beggary, encourage idleness and consequently promote irreligion.
('36', 426, 2, 22, 839684) This does not mean that we should starve the really deserving beggars.
('36', 426, 2, 23, 839755) It is the duty of society to support the blind and the infirm, but everyone may not take the task upon himself.
('36', 426, 2, 24, 839867) The head of the society, i.e., the mahajan or the State where it is well organized, should undertake the task, and the philanthropically inclined should subscribe funds to such an institution.
('36', 426, 2, 25, 840060) If the mahajan is pure minded and wise, it will carefully investigate the condition of beggars and protect the deserving ones.
('36', 426, 2, 26, 840187) When this does not happen, i.e., when relief is indiscriminate, scoundrels disguised as beggars get the benefit of it and the poverty of the land increases.
('36', 426, 2, 27, 840344) If it is thus a sin on the part of an individual to undertake feeding beggars, it is no less a sin for him to feed stray dogs.
('36', 426, 2, 28, 840471) It is a false sense of compassion.
('36', 426, 2, 29, 840506) It is an insult to the starving dog to throw a crumb at him.
('36', 426, 2, 30, 840567) Roving dogs do not indicate the civilization or compassion of the society, they betray on the contrary, the ignorance and lethargy of its members.
('36', 426, 2, 31, 840714) The lower animals are our brethren.
('36', 426, 2, 32, 840750) I include among them the lion and the tiger.
('36', 426, 2, 33, 840795) We do not know how to live with these carnivorous beasts and poisonous reptiles because of
('36', 427, 0, 1, 840886) 428 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 427, 1, 2, 840928) our ignorance.
('36', 427, 1, 3, 840943) When man knows himself better, he will learn to befriend even these.
('36', 427, 1, 4, 841012) Today he does not even know how to befriend a man of a different religion or from a foreign country.
('36', 427, 1, 5, 841113) The dog is a faithful companion.
('36', 427, 1, 6, 841146) There are numerous instances of the faithfulness of dogs and horses.
('36', 427, 1, 7, 841215) But that means that we should keep them and treat them with respect as we do our companions and not allow them to roam about.
('36', 427, 1, 8, 841341) By aggravating the evil of stray dogs we shall not be acquitting ourselves of our duty to them.
('36', 427, 1, 9, 841437) But if we regard the existence of stray dogs as a shame to us and, therefore, refuse to feed them, we shall be doing the dogs as a class a real service and make them happy.
('36', 427, 1, 10, 841610) What, then, can a humane man do for stray dogs?
('36', 427, 1, 11, 841658) He should set apart a portion of his income and send it on to a society for the protection of those animals if there be one.
('36', 427, 1, 12, 841783) If such a society is impossible—and I know it is very difficult even if it is not impossible—he should try to own one or more dogs.
('36', 427, 1, 13, 841915) If he cannot do so, he should give up worrying about the question of dogs and direct his humanity towards the service of other animals.
('36', 427, 1, 14, 842051) “But you are asking us to destroy them?” is the question angrily or lovingly asked by others.
('36', 427, 1, 15, 842145) Now, I have not suggested the extirpation of dogs as an absolute duty.
('36', 427, 1, 16, 842216) I have suggested the killing of some dogs as a”duty in distress” and under certain circumstances.
('36', 427, 1, 17, 842314) When the State does not care for stray dogs, nor does the mahajan, and when one is not prepared to take care of them oneself, then, and if one regards them as a danger to society, one should kill them and relieve them from a lingering death.
('36', 427, 1, 18, 842556) This is a bitter dose, I agree.
('36', 427, 1, 19, 842588) But it is my innermost conviction that true love and compassion consist in taking it.
('36', 427, 1, 20, 842674) The dogs in India are today in as bad a plight as the decrepit animals and men in the land.
('36', 427, 1, 21, 842766) It is my firm conviction that this sorry plight is due to our misconception of ahimsa, is due to our want of ahimsa.
('36', 427, 1, 22, 842883) Practice of ahimsa cannot have as its result impotence, impoverishment and famine.
('36', 427, 1, 23, 842966) If this is a sacred land we should not see impoverishment stalking it.
('36', 427, 1, 24, 843037) From this state of things some rash and impatient souls have drawn the conclusion that ahimsa is irreligion.
('36', 427, 1, 25, 843146) But I know that it is not ahimsa that is wrong, it is its votaries that are wrong.
('36', 427, 1, 26, 843229) Ahimsa is the religion of a Kshatriya.
('36', 427, 1, 27, 843268) Mahavira was a Kshatriya, Buddha was a Kshatriya, Rama and Krishna were Kshatriyas and all of them were votaries of ahimsa.
('36', 427, 1, 28, 843392) We want to propagate ahimsa in their
('36', 428, 0, 1, 843429) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 429
('36', 428, 1, 2, 843474) But today ahimsa has become the monopoly of timid Vaisyas 1
('36', 428, 2, 3, 843534) and that is why it has been besmirched.
('36', 428, 2, 4, 843574) Ahimsa is the extreme limit of forgiveness.
('36', 428, 2, 5, 843618) But forgiveness is the quality of the brave.
('36', 428, 2, 6, 843663) Ahimsa is impossible without fearlessness.
('36', 428, 2, 7, 843706) Cows we cannot protect, dogs we kick about and belabour with sticks, their ribs are seen sticking out, and yet we are not ashamed of ourselves and raise a hue and cry when a stray dog is killed.
('36', 428, 2, 8, 843901) Which of the two is better—that five thousand dogs should wander about in semi starvation living on dirt and excreta and drag on a miserable existence, or that fifty should die and keep the rest in a decent condition?

('36', 428, 2, 12, 844423) We must examine this position in another article.

('36', 437, 0, 1, 857511) 438 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 437, 1, 2, 857553) 508. NOTES
('36', 437, 2, 3, 857564) TO JOURNALIST FRIENDS
('36', 437, 3, 4, 857586) Applications for articles for journals and magazines in and out of India are daily pouring in upon me.
('36', 437, 3, 5, 857689) Things have come to such a pass that I must either leave Young India and Navajivan editing or respectfully refuse to write for other papers.
('36', 437, 3, 6, 857830) Since I must not, so long as there are enough subscribers and I have energy, give up Young India or Navajivan, I have been forced to stop writing for other papers.
('36', 437, 3, 7, 857994) The fact is I have not the ability to write at will on any and every subject.
('36', 437, 3, 8, 858072) My field is very limited and even on the subjects I am familiar with, I cannot always be original.
('36', 437, 3, 9, 858171) I have no false notions about the efficacy of my writings.
('36', 437, 3, 10, 858230) On the contrary I know that often the unwritten word is more forcible and truer than the written or the spoken word.
('36', 437, 3, 11, 858347) Let the sum of our acts speak.
('36', 437, 3, 12, 858378) The continuous multipli cation of ephemeral literature is growing into a terrible nuisance which I must not assist to increase, even if I cannot do anything to stop or regulate it.
('36', 437, 4, 13, 858559) A WARNING
('36', 437, 5, 14, 858569) Of late many young men have been coming to the Satyagraha Ashram, without warning, and without permission, either to stay for a short time or to be admitted as candidates for membership.
('36', 437, 5, 15, 858756) Much as the management would like to find room for all who choose to come, whether as visitors or candidate members, it is physically impossible even to make the attempt.
('36', 437, 5, 16, 858927) The Ashram is at present taxed to its utmost capacity and the management has been obliged to put off even friends who had sought previous permission and intended to find their own expenses.
('36', 437, 5, 17, 859117) It is improper for young men to come without notice and permission.
('36', 437, 5, 18, 859185) During the past fortnight, four such young men have come.
('36', 437, 5, 19, 859243) And what was more grievous still was that they did not even bring enough to pay their way back.
('36', 437, 5, 20, 859339) The last was an M.A., who said he came with the view of joining the Ashram, but on the way, altered his decision and thought he would stay for a few days and study the Ashram life.
('36', 437, 5, 21, 859520) He had brought with him no credentials and had not enough money on his person to buy a return ticket.
('36', 437, 5, 22, 859622) I had to harden my heart and tell him that he could not stay at the Ashram without having obtained previous permission.
('36', 437, 5, 23, 859742) It is incomprehensible to me that well educated young men should not know the ordinary court esies of life and the laws of hospitality.
('36', 437, 5, 24, 859878) I know that there is an evil
('36', 438, 0, 1, 859907) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 439
('36', 438, 1, 2, 859952) reputation about the Ashram.
('36', 438, 1, 3, 859981) Visitors who have come without notice have sometimes told me that they thought that the Ashram was the one place in India where people could go without permission and find a warm welcome.
('36', 438, 1, 4, 860169) It is therefore as well for young men to realize that the Ashrams cannot live up to any such expectation and that it is but an ordinary human institution striving to reach its ideals and ever failing to do so.
('36', 438, 1, 5, 860379) The members would be satisfied if it could be said of them that they had tried their best to realize the ideals they had subscribed to.
('36', 438, 2, 6, 860515) ABOUT FASTING
('36', 438, 3, 7, 860529) ‘A Precisionist’ writes:
('36', 438, 4, 8, 860554) A devoted ant careful filer as I am of your paper, I have to draw your attention to the following dictum in its issue of 30 9 26:”Fasting can be resorted to only against one’s nearest and dearest, and that for his or her good.” 1
('36', 438, 5, 9, 860784) From your previous writings, however, it would appear that there is one important exception to this.
('36', 438, 5, 10, 860885) Fasting or hunger striking in prison against humiliating treatment, as in case food is offered in an insulting manner, is also true satyagraha.
('36', 438, 5, 11, 861029) I wish you had not lost sight of this while writing to an enquirer on the ethics of”Satyagraha—True and False”.
('36', 438, 5, 12, 861141) If the instance quoted by ‘A Precisionist’ is an exception, I could quote many others.
('36', 438, 5, 13, 861228) A man may fast for penance, purification and for considerations of physical health.
('36', 438, 5, 14, 861312) More such instances can perhaps be given.
('36', 438, 5, 15, 861354) But in the first case, I have pointed out the limits of satyagrahic fasting, i.e., when you seek to influence people by fasting.
('36', 438, 5, 16, 861483) The so called exception is a dissimilar case.
('36', 438, 5, 17, 861529) There the protest was against the felt humiliation.
('36', 438, 5, 18, 861581) In“Satyagraha—True and False”, emphasis was put on the evil of fasting against a person to make him pay what the fast ing person considered was his due and the opponent considered not to be due.
('36', 438, 6, 19, 861776) HINDU AND HINDUISM
('36', 438, 7, 20, 861795) A correspondent who is a patient and diligent reader of Young India writes:
('36', 438, 8, 21, 861871) Replying to the catechism of ‘An Assistant Executive Engineer’ in your issue of 14 10 26 you say:”In a concrete manner he is a Hindu who believes in God, immortality of the soul, etc.”
('36', 438, 9, 22, 862056) On reading this I am tempted to confront you with your own writing of
('36', 438, 10, 23, 862126) 1 Vide”Satyagraha—True and False”, 12 9 1926. An English translation of this by Mahadev Desai appeared in Young India, 30 9 1926.
('36', 439, 0, 1, 862256) 440 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 439, 1, 2, 862298) nearly two years ago.
('36', 439, 1, 3, 862320) In Young India of April 24, 1924, p.
('36', 439, 1, 4, 862357) 136, 1 you wrote:”If I were asked to define the Hindu creed I should simply say: ‘Search after Truth through non violent means.
('36', 439, 1, 5, 862485) A man may not believe in God and still call himself a Hindu.
('36', 439, 1, 6, 862546) Hinduism is a relentless pursuit after Truth.’”
('36', 439, 2, 7, 862594) THE ITALICS IN BOTH QUOTATIONS ARE MINE.
('36', 439, 2, 8, 862635) I am surprised that the correspondent does not see the distinc tion between the two statements.
('36', 439, 2, 9, 862731) One refers to a Hindu in a concrete manner.
('36', 439, 2, 10, 862775) Denial of the existence of God is not a characteristic of Hinduism.
('36', 439, 2, 11, 862843) Millions of Hindus do believe in God.
('36', 439, 2, 12, 862881) Therefore one may say ‘there are Hindus who believe in God, etc.’ But ‘a man may not believe in God and still call himself a Hindu’.
('36', 439, 2, 13, 863014) In the second case I have attempted an exhaustive definition.
('36', 439, 2, 14, 863076) In the first case, I have given a fairly general illustration.
('36', 439, 2, 15, 863139) I, therefore, see no conflict between the two positions.
('36', 439, 3, 16, 863196) CUSTOMS EXACTIONS
('36', 439, 4, 17, 863214) A passenger who has recently returned from South Africa asked me if it was not possible to undo the evil of extortions that regularly take place in the Customs Department.
('36', 439, 4, 18, 863386) Although his luggage contained nothing taxable, he said he had to give a bribe in order to get the clearance in time.
('36', 439, 4, 19, 863504) I asked him if he would give enough time and trouble to the matter and face an inquiry.
('36', 439, 4, 20, 863592) He said he could not do so.
('36', 439, 4, 21, 863620) This attitude is normal and explains the existence of the exactions which are not only to be found in the customs but also on railways.
('36', 439, 4, 22, 863756) Whilst it is true that the public must be prepared to suffer temporary inconveniences, if they want redress, it is up to the authorities to pre vent so far as it is humanly possible exactions which poor people have to suffer.
('36', 439, 4, 23, 863982) It will not be a bad thing for some public spirited young men to submit themselves to these exactions and then report them to the proper quarters.
('36', 439, 4, 24, 864129) A few such cases will lessen the evil.
('36', 439, 4, 25, 864168) The only way to the eradication of the evil is no doubt an incorruptible public.
('36', 439, 4, 26, 864249) So long as there are people who would evade customs dues, so long will there be customs officials who will want their price.

('36', 440, 0, 1, 864436) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 441
('36', 440, 1, 2, 864481) 509. A BOON TO CULTIVATORS
('36', 440, 2, 3, 864508) Some months ago Sjt.
('36', 440, 2, 4, 864529) Ramachandran of Madras, an agricultural graduate, wrote to me to recommend his well lift for use in the Ashram.
('36', 440, 2, 5, 864641) He claimed for it great saving of labour to the animals used in the ordinary contrivances and also saving in cost.
('36', 440, 2, 6, 864756) The invention attracted me and I wrote to the inventor telling him that if he came himself and successfully installed the lift, the lift would be bought.
('36', 440, 2, 7, 864910) He promptly responded and his invention has been at work at the Ashram for over a month.
('36', 440, 2, 8, 864999) Everyone who knows anything of agriculture at the Ashram is thoroughly satisfied with the working of the lift.
('36', 440, 2, 9, 865110) To make assurance doubly sure, I had it examined by an engineer, who too considered the invention to be quite sound and extremely ingenious.
('36', 440, 2, 10, 865251) This is what the inventor has to say for his invention:
('36', 440, 3, 11, 865307) I am convinced that rapid extension of well irrigation for our dry lands which form 80 per cent of the arable lands in India is the real solution for the agricultural problem of India.
('36', 440, 3, 12, 865492) The income from dry land does not exceed Rs. 30 an acre, while the same land when irrigated from a well produced crops worth Rs. 200 to 1000 per acre, providing ample work for a number of families all the year round.
('36', 440, 3, 13, 865709) The chief difficulty in the way is that costly pairs of bullocks are necessary, they often suffer from yoke galls, badly deteriorate in health and that their efficiency is very low.
('36', 440, 3, 14, 865891) With a view to solve this difficulty, nearly 14 years ago I began my experiments and trials, and placed before the market this humble contrivance, now working on the Ashram well.
('36', 440, 3, 15, 866070) The new contrivance is only the ordinary kos known also as charas, mot or kavalai with reduced friction in the ramp or the inclined plane by the use of a trolley on a railed incline for generating power by the mere weight of an animal.
('36', 440, 3, 16, 866306) Just as a bicycle helps a man to go 12 miles an hour while he can walk only 3 miles an hour, this trolley helps the animal to do 4 times as much work as the same animal would do in the ordinary way.
('36', 440, 3, 17, 866505) This great reduction in friction has enabled only one animal instead of two to lift each time almost the same quantity of water as in the ordinary way, without any waste of energy in pulling.
('36', 440, 3, 18, 866697) This single animal being relieved from pulling lifts double the number of buckets per hour.
('36', 440, 3, 19, 866789) So the quantity of water lifted in the R. Lift should not be judged by the mere shape and size of the bucket nor by the effort and number of animals used, but by the actual capacity of the bucket multiplied by the number of buckets lifted per hour.
('36', 440, 3, 20, 867038) It has been tested and recorded all over India by experts that a good pair of bulls worth Rs. 300 to 400 lift only 1,600 gallons per hour from a depth of 20 feet.
('36', 440, 3, 21, 867201) I have been demonstrating in the Ashram as I have been doing elsewhere how a male buffalo (purchased by the Ashram for Rs. 31) has been lifting 2,000 gallons per hour (60 buckets of 32 gallons each per hour)
('36', 441, 0, 1, 867409) 442 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 441, 1, 2, 867451) from a depth of 34 feet, whereas two costly bullocks in our time honoured lift can draw a little over 1,000 gallons per hour (30 buckets of 35 gallons each per hour).
('36', 441, 1, 3, 867618) I have demonstrated and convinced more than 20 officers of the Madras Agricultural and Industrial Departments in vain at an enormous cost to me during the last 11 years.
('36', 441, 1, 4, 867788) Dr. Clouston during my demonstration of this lift at Nagpur admitted and highly appreciated the simplicity of the mechanism, high efficiency and the humane mode of applying animal power.
('36', 441, 2, 5, 867975) The cost of the whole appliance is Rs. 275 for a depth of 50 feet, but Sjt.
('36', 441, 2, 6, 868051) Ramachandran says that if the lift became popular, the price could be further reduced.
('36', 441, 2, 7, 868138) For the depth of 30 ft.
('36', 441, 2, 8, 868162) it costs only Rs. 230. With a suitable organization the lift could be made available to any cultivator in India for Rs. 150. I have also suggested that if the patent rights are given up or if the parts that can be locally had are so made or purchased, there might be still further reduction.
('36', 441, 2, 9, 868454) Add to the present cost of the R. Lift the cost of a male buffalo, say Rs. 30. The whole lift would cost no more than Rs. 305. The cost of a pair of bullocks would range from Rs. 300 to 400. The greatest saving is however effected in the monthly expenditure.
('36', 441, 2, 10, 868713) The upkeep of a pair of bullocks would be Rs. 50 to 60, whereas that of a male buffalo would be Rs. 20 to 25. The greatest use of the invention lies in the immense saving of labour to animals, and a still greater lies in the work that can be taken from the male buffalo who for want of use is in the vast majority of cases cruelly left to perish where he is not actually butchered.
('36', 441, 3, 11, 869095) The wonder, therefore, is that this invention has not attracted the attention of the Government.
('36', 441, 3, 12, 869192) Ramachandran has many bitter complaints to make about the indifference of the authorities whom he approached.
('36', 441, 3, 13, 869302) But I have preferred not to make any but a passing reference to his complaints.
('36', 441, 3, 14, 869382) Let those who wish visit the Ashram and see the lift at work at the Ashram every morning.
('36', 441, 3, 15, 869472) As much water is not required at the present moment, the lift is not kept at work the whole day.
('36', 441, 3, 16, 869569) But it will be working between 8 and 10 a.m.
('36', 441, 3, 17, 869614) always, and will be in charge of the inventor himself who will gladly explain all about it.
('36', 441, 4, 18, 869706) A friend writing to me about the Agricultural Exhibition in Poona says:
('36', 441, 5, 19, 869778) I see here piles of machinery and tools most of which we can never use.
('36', 441, 6, 20, 869850) I miss the thing which is a boon to man and animal in India.
('36', 441, 6, 21, 869911) I mean the
('36', 441, 7, 22, 869922) Ramachandran Lift.
('36', 442, 0, 1, 869941) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 443
('36', 442, 1, 2, 869986) I do not know enough of agriculture, as the friend does, to warrant his enthusiasm, but I know enough to be able to say that this lift requires examination by everyone who is at all interested in the agricultural problems of India.

('36', 446, 3, 4, 876735) DEAR FRIEND, 1. When I pray, I do not ask for anything but I simply think of some of the verses or hymns which I fancy for the moment.
('36', 446, 3, 5, 876870) 2. The relation between God and myself is not only at prayer but, at all times, that of master and slave in perpetual bondage.
('36', 446, 3, 6, 876997) 3. Prayer is to me the intense longing of the heart to merge myself in the Master.
('36', 446, 3, 7, 877080) If a man does not pray, evidently he has no longing; there is no feeling of helplessness and when there is no helplessness, there is no need for help.

('36', 446, 3, 10, 877469) 5. Lawyers, etc., are invited and expected to spin by way of sacrifice and encouragement.
('36', 446, 3, 11, 877559) As the leaders do, so will the followers.
('36', 446, 3, 12, 877601) I spin because through my spinning, I expect to be able to, so far as a single individual is able to, move the mass to spin for their own sake and get rid of their idleness.

('36', 448, 1, 2, 879618) 519. IS THIS HUMANITY? IV
('36', 448, 2, 3, 879644) [October 31, 1926] Taking life may be a duty.
('36', 448, 2, 4, 879690) Let us consider this position.
('36', 448, 2, 5, 879721) We do destroy as much life as we think is necessary for sustain ing the body.
('36', 448, 2, 6, 879799) Thus for food we take life, vegetable and other, and for health we destroy mosquitoes and the like by the use of disinfectants, etc., and we do not think that we are guilty of irreligion in doing so.
('36', 448, 2, 7, 879999) This is as regards one’s own self.
('36', 448, 2, 8, 880034) But for the sake of others, i.e., for the benefit of the species, we kill carnivorous beasts.
('36', 448, 2, 9, 880128) When lions and tigers pester their villages, the villagers regard it a duty to kill them or have them killed.
('36', 448, 2, 10, 880238) Even man slaughter may be necessary in certain cases.
('36', 448, 2, 11, 880292) Suppose a man runs amuck and goes furiously about sword in hand, and kill ing anyone that comes his way, and no one dares to capture him alive.
('36', 448, 2, 12, 880436) Anyone who dispatches this lunatic will earn the gratitude of the community and be regarded a benevolent man.
('36', 448, 2, 13, 880546) From the point of view of ahimsa it is the plain duty of everyone to kill such a man.
('36', 448, 2, 14, 880632) There is, indeed, one exception if it can be so called.
('36', 448, 2, 15, 880688) The yogi who can subdue the fury of this dangerous man may not kill him.
('36', 448, 2, 16, 880761) But we are not here dealing with beings who have almost reached perfection; we are considering the duty of the society, of the ordinary erring human beings.
('36', 448, 2, 17, 880918) There may be a difference of opinion as regards the apposite ness of my illustrations.
('36', 448, 2, 18, 881005) But if they are inadequate, others can be easily imagined.
('36', 448, 2, 19, 881064) What they are meant to show is that refraining from taking life can in no circumstances be an absolute duty.
('36', 448, 2, 20, 881173) The fact is that ahimsa does not simply mean non killing.
('36', 448, 2, 21, 881231) Himsa means causing pain to or killing any life out of anger or from a selfish purpose, or with the intention of injuring it.
('36', 448, 2, 22, 881357) Refraining from so doing is ahimsa.
('36', 448, 2, 23, 881393) The physician who prescribes bitter medicine causes you pain but does no himsa.
('36', 448, 2, 24, 881473) If he fails to prescribe bitter medicine when it is necessary to do so, he fails in his duty of ahimsa.
('36', 448, 2, 25, 881577) The surgeon who, from fear of causing pain to his patient, hesitates to amputate a rotten limb is guilty of himsa.
('36', 448, 2, 26, 881692) He who refrains from killing a murderer who is about to kill his ward (when he cannot prevent him otherwise)earns no merit, but commits a sin, he practises no ahimsa but himsa out of a fatuous sense of ahimsa.
('36', 448, 2, 27, 881902) Let us now examine the root of ahimsa.
('36', 448, 2, 28, 881941) It is uttermost selfless 
('36', 449, 0, 1, 881967) 450 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 449, 1, 2, 882009) Selflessness means complete freedom from a regard for one’s body.
('36', 449, 1, 3, 882075) When some sage observed man killing numberless creatures, big and small, out of a regard for his own body, he was shocked at his ignorance.
('36', 449, 1, 4, 882215) He pitied him for thus forgetting the deathless soul, encased within the perishable body, and for thinking of the ephemeral physical pleasure in preference to the eternal bliss of the spirit.
('36', 449, 1, 5, 882407) He therefrom deduced the duty of complete self efface ment.
('36', 449, 1, 6, 882467) He saw that if man desired to realize himself, i.e., truth, he could do so only by being completely detached from the body, i e., by making all other beings feel safe from him.
('36', 449, 1, 7, 882644) That is the way of ahimsa.
('36', 449, 1, 8, 882671) A realization of this truth shows that the sin of himsa consists not in merely taking life, but in taking life for the sake of one’s perishable body.
('36', 449, 1, 9, 882821) All destruction therefore involved in the process of eating, drinking, etc., is selfish and, therefore, himsa.
('36', 449, 1, 10, 882932) But man regards it to be unavoidable and puts up with it.
('36', 449, 1, 11, 882990) But the destruction of bodies of tortured creatures being for their own peace cannot be regarded as himsa, or the unavoidable destruction caused for the purpose of protecting one’s wards cannot be regarded as himsa.
('36', 449, 1, 12, 883206) This line of reasoning is liable to be most mischievously used used but that is not because the reasoning is faulty, but because of the inherent frailty of man to catch at whatever pretexts he can get to deceive himself to satisfy his selfishness or egoism.
('36', 449, 1, 13, 883464) But that danger may not excuse one from defining the true nature of ahimsa.
('36', 449, 1, 14, 883540) Thus, we arrive at the following result from the foregoing: 1. It is impossible to sustain one’s body without the destruction of other bodies to some extent.
('36', 449, 1, 15, 883698) 2. All have to destroy some life (a) for sustaining their own bodies; (b) for protecting those under their care; or (c) sometimes for the sake of those whose life is taken.
('36', 449, 1, 16, 883871) 3. (a) and (b) in (2) mean himsa to a greater or less extent.
('36', 449, 1, 17, 883933) (c) means no himsa, and is therefore ahimsa.
('36', 449, 1, 18, 883978) Himsa in (a) and (b) is unavoidable.
('36', 449, 1, 19, 884015) 4. A progressive ahimsaist will, therefore, commit the himsa con tained in (a) and (b) as little as possible, only when it is unavoi dable, and after full and mature deliberation and having exhausted all reme dies to avoid it.
('36', 449, 1, 20, 884242) The destruction of dogs that I have suggested came under (4) and can, therefore, be resorted to only when it is unavoidable, when there is no other remedy and after mature deliberation.
('36', 449, 1, 21, 884428) But I have not the slightest doubt that refraining from that destruction when it is
('36', 450, 0, 1, 884512) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 451
('36', 450, 1, 2, 884557) unavoidable is worse than destruction.
('36', 450, 1, 3, 884596) And, therefore, although there can be no absolute duty to kill dogs, etc., it becomes a necessary duty for certain people at certain times and under certain circumstances.
('36', 450, 1, 4, 884768) I shall now try to take up one by one some of the questions that have been asked me.
('36', 450, 1, 5, 884853) Some correspondents demand personal replies, and in case I fail to do so threaten to publish their views.
('36', 450, 1, 6, 884959) It is impossi ble for me to reach every individual correspondent by a perso nal reply.
('36', 450, 1, 7, 885046) Those that are necessary I shall deal with here.
('36', 450, 1, 8, 885095) I have no right, nor desire, to stop people from carrying on the controversy in other papers.
('36', 450, 1, 9, 885189) I may remind the correspondents, however, that threats and impatience have no place in a sober and religious discussion.
('36', 450, 1, 10, 885310) A correspondent asks:
('36', 450, 2, 11, 885332) How did you hit upon the religion of destroying dogs at the old age of 57?
('36', 450, 2, 12, 885407) If it had occurred to you earlier than this, why were you silent so long?
('36', 450, 2, 13, 885481) Man proclaims a truth only when he sees it and when it is necessary, no matter even if it be in his old age.
('36', 450, 2, 14, 885590) I have long recognized the duty of killing such animals within the limits laid down above, and have acted up to it on occasions.
('36', 450, 2, 15, 885719) In India the villagers have long recognized the duty of destroying intruding dogs.
('36', 450, 2, 16, 885802) They keep dogs who scare away intruders and kill them if they do not escape with their lives These watch dogs are purposely maintained with a view to protecting the village from other dogs, etc., as also from thieves and robbers whom they attack fearlessly.
('36', 450, 2, 17, 886060) The dogs have become a nui sance only in cities, and the best remedy is to have a law against stray dogs.
('36', 450, 2, 18, 886166) That will involve the least destruction of dogs and ensure the protection of citizens.
('36', 450, 2, 19, 886253) Another correspondent asks:
('36', 450, 3, 20, 886281) Do you expect to convince people by logical argument in a matter like that of ahimsa?
('36', 450, 3, 21, 886367) The rebuke contained in this is not without some substance.
('36', 450, 3, 22, 886427) But I wanted to convince no one.
('36', 450, 3, 23, 886460) Being a student and practiser of ahimsa, I have had to give expression to my views when the occasion demanded it.
('36', 450, 3, 24, 886574) I have an opinion based on experience that logic and reasoning have some place, no doubt very small, in a religious discussion.
('36', 450, 3, 25, 886702) Young India, 4 11 1926

('36', 455, 5, 19, 894136) The subscriptions for the new year of the All India Spinners Association are coming in but not as fast as they might be.
('36', 455, 5, 20, 894257) It is hoped that the subscribers this year will make it a point to improve the qua lity of their yarn in strength, evenness and fineness.

('36', 456, 4, 15, 896575) 528. PRECARIOUS CONDITION IN SOUTH AFRICA
('36', 456, 5, 16, 896617) The latest mail from South Africa has brought me a batch of papers which show the precarious condition of the Indian settlers in that sub continent.
('36', 456, 5, 17, 896766) Trade licenses are an eternal problem.
('36', 456, 5, 18, 896805) The adm inistrative reins are being daily tightened.
('36', 456, 5, 19, 896858) Hitherto, in Natal, it has been a fairly recognized rule not to touch old licenses under the wide discretionary powers given to licensing officers except for cases of grave insanitation or breach of conditions imposed by the officers.
('36', 456, 5, 20, 897093) But that sound rule is gradually being disregarded and even renewals are being arbitrarily refused.
('36', 456, 5, 21, 897193) The case sent to me is pathetic and refers to an old lady Mrs. Sophia Bhayla.
('36', 456, 5, 22, 897271) The Secretary of the S. A. Con 
('36', 456, 6, 23, 897303) 1 Vide”Improvised Method of Testing”, 14 10 1926.

('36', 457, 1, 2, 897395) gress in introducing the case says:
('36', 457, 2, 3, 897431) This poor lady with five children has been ruined through the caprice of the licensing officer and to avoid being put in jail by her creditors, it is highly likely that she will have to seek the protection of the law of insolvency.
('36', 457, 2, 4, 897663) The judges of the appellate courts showed their sympathy for the poor woman but declared themselves powerless, being bound under the statute not to interfere with the discretion vested by the legislature in the licensing officers, except when they can be proved to have been bribed or incapable of exercising the powers vested in them.
('36', 457, 2, 5, 897999) Here is what the principal judgment says:
('36', 457, 3, 6, 898041) The licensing officer refused her license after she had held it for many years and it would appear that the refusal is based on the ground that this lady had not paid the dues which it is said she should have paid to the Town Council of Estcourt.
('36', 457, 3, 7, 898288) At first sight it would appear that that was somewhat harsh for the licensing officer, who happens to be town clerk and town treasurer and holds other offices as well, because of the knowledge that he had as town treasurer and town clerk, he should say as licensing officer: “Well, you had trouble with my employers, the Town Council, and you have not paid your rates or the dues which are payable and, therefore, I will not grant you a renewal of this license.” That does appear to one’s mind to be inequitable.
('36', 457, 3, 8, 898801) If this lady had committed an offence against the bye laws, there was a ready remedy for that by prosecuting her or by proceeding against her according to the law if she had broken any contract.
('36', 457, 3, 9, 898996) Thus, the judges though willing were unable to redress a mani fest wrong.
('36', 457, 3, 10, 899070) When a law is bad, a judge is helpless unless he resigns.
('36', 457, 3, 11, 899128) Such heroic action is not to be expected in these days.
('36', 457, 3, 12, 899184) But the Government is not powerless.
('36', 457, 3, 13, 899221) Town Councils, composed as they are of rival traders, are not to be expected to do justice.
('36', 457, 3, 14, 899313) They will generally use the powers given to them for crushing their rivals, but the central administration can certainly render aid in such glaring cases.
('36', 457, 3, 15, 899468) The Round Table Conference will be a mockery, if even cases of manifest hardship remain unredressed.
('36', 457, 3, 16, 899569) The Class Areas Bill may be shelved for ever but if the spirit animating it survives, the position of the settlers will in no wise be better than if the Bill had been passed.
('36', 457, 3, 17, 899744) An empty victory will be worse than a proper defeat.
('36', 457, 3, 18, 899797) For in the noise of it, the cry of the anguish of the sufferers may be hushed and they may be denied even the solace of sympathy.

('36', 460, 3, 13, 905349) A correspondent writes thus passionately:

('36', 460, 5, 15, 905544) congregational prayer.
('36', 460, 5, 16, 905567) At the end of the article, referring to churches, temples and mosques you say, “These places of worship are not a mere idle superstition to be swept away at the first opportunity.
('36', 460, 5, 17, 905747) They have survived all attacks up to now and are likely to persist to the end of time.
('36', 460, 6, 18, 905834) On reading this I asked myself: Attacks by whom?
('36', 460, 6, 19, 905883) Surely those attacks were not made by atheists or scoffers or humbugs, to anything like the extent to which the opposing sects of God believers are known to have attacks the places of worship of one another.
('36', 460, 6, 20, 906091) In fact, most, if not all, of the attacks you speak of were perpetrated by ‘godly’ zealots, in the name and for the glory of each one’s own God.
('36', 460, 6, 21, 906236) It would be insulting your knowledge of world history to
('36', 460, 7, 22, 906293) cite instances.
('36', 460, 8, 23, 906309) Secondly, I asked myself: Is it true—is it strictly correct to say, that these places of worship have survived all attacks?
('36', 460, 8, 24, 906433) Again the answer is: Surely not.
('36', 460, 8, 25, 906466) Witness the site at Kashi (or Benares) where had stood the temple of Vishvanath for long centuries, since even before Lord Buddha’s time—but where now stands dominating the ‘Holy City’ a mosque built out of the ruins of
('36', 460, 9, 26, 906686) 1 Vide “No Faith in Prayer”.

('36', 461, 2, 3, 906917) Aurangzeb.
('36', 461, 2, 4, 906928) Again, it is not the ‘unbelieving’ British, but the terrible believer, Ibn Saud, and his Wahabi hosts, that are responsible for the recent demolition and desecration of many places of worship in the Hedjaz (Muslims’ ‘Holy Land’), over which Mussalman Indians are just now so loudly lamenting, and which the Nizam of Hyderabad—alone of all Muslim rulers in the world—has vainly tried to restore with his money.
('36', 461, 3, 5, 907338) Do these facts mean nothing to you Mahatmaji?

('36', 461, 4, 20, 908974) It defies analysis.

('36', 461, 4, 22, 909208) Hence the significant assurance in the Bhagavad Gita: “ I make return according to the spirit in which men worship Me.” 1

('36', 464, 2, 6, 912584) 535. PREFACE TO” SHRIMAD RAJCHANDRA” November 5, 1926
('36', 464, 3, 7, 912638) INTRODUCTION When Shri Revashanker Jagjivan, whom I regard as an elder brother, asked me for a foreword to this 3 edition of Shrimad Rajchandra’s 4 letters and writings, I could not refuse his request.
('36', 464, 3, 8, 912840) As I tried to think what I could say in such a foreword, I felt that it would serve two purposes if I gave the few chapters of my reminiscences of Rajchandra which I wrote in the Yeravda jail 5: one, that as my attempt, though incomplete, was undertaken purely in a spirit of religious devotion, it might help other mumukshus 6 like me, and two, that those who did not know Shrimad Rajchandra in life might know a little about him and so find it easier to understand some of his writings.
('36', 464, 3, 9, 913329) The chapters which follow leave the story incomplete.
('36', 464, 3, 10, 913383) I do not think that I can complete it, for, even if I get time, I do not feel inclined to go much further than the point where I left off.
('36', 464, 3, 11, 913522) I, therefore, wish to complete the last chapter, which had remained unfinished, and include in it a few things.
('36', 464, 3, 12, 913634) In these chapters I have not touched upon one aspect of the subject which I think I should place before the readers.
('36', 464, 3, 13, 913751) Some people assert that Shrimad was the twenty fifth Tirthankar 7. Some others believe that he has attained moksha.
('36', 464, 3, 14, 913867) Both these beliefs, I think, are improper.
('36', 464, 3, 15, 913910) Either those who hold them do not know Shrimad or their definitions of Tirthankar or liberated soul are different from the com monly accepted ones.
('36', 464, 3, 16, 914058) We may not lower the standard of truth even
('36', 464, 4, 17, 914102) 1 On November 2 2 Members of the Royal Agricultural Commission with whom Gandhiji discussed the benefits of the spinning wheel and khadi 3 Second edition.
('36', 464, 4, 18, 914257) It cannot be ascertained when the first edition was published.
('36', 464, 4, 19, 914320) 4 Rajchandra Ravjibhai Mehta 5 Gandhiji was in this jail from March 1922 to February 1924. 6 Seekers after moksha, deliverance from phenomenal existence as the supre me end of life 7 A soul that has risen to perfection and teaches the way to others.
('36', 464, 4, 20, 914570) Jains believe in 24 such Tirthankars, of whom Mahavira, a contemporary of the Buddha, was the last.
('36', 465, 0, 1, 914670) 466 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 465, 1, 2, 914712) for the sake of those whom we love dearly.
('36', 465, 1, 3, 914755) Moksha is a condition of supreme value.
('36', 465, 1, 4, 914795) It is the highest state of the atman 1. It is so rare a condition that to attain it much more effort and patience are necessary than, say, for emptying the sea drop by drop with a blade of grass.
('36', 465, 1, 5, 914991) A perfect description of that state is impossible.
('36', 465, 1, 6, 915042) A Tirthankar will naturally command, without seeking them, the powers which belong to the state immediately preceding moksha.
('36', 465, 1, 7, 915168) One who has attained freedom while still living in this body will suffer from no physical disease.
('36', 465, 1, 8, 915267) In a body untroubled by desire there can be no disease.
('36', 465, 1, 9, 915323) There can be no disease where there is no attachment.
('36', 465, 1, 10, 915377) Where there is desire there is attachment and while there is attachment moksha is impossible.
('36', 465, 1, 11, 915471) Shrimad had not attained the total freedom from attachment which should characterize a mukta purusha 2 or the vibhuti which belongs to a Tirthankar.
('36', 465, 1, 12, 915620) He had such freedom and such powers in a much larger measure than the ordinary man or woman, and so in common speech we may describe him as one who was free from attachment or who possessed superhuman powers.
('36', 465, 1, 13, 915829) I am sure, however, that Shrimad had not attained to the perfect freedom from attachment which we attribute to a mukta purusha or acquired the vibhuti which we believe that a Tirthankar would manifest.
('36', 465, 1, 14, 916031) I do not say this with the intention of pointing out any shortcoming in a great character worthy of our highest reverence; I say it in order to do justice both to him and to the cause of truth.
('36', 465, 1, 15, 916225) We are all worldly creatures, whereas Shrimad was not.
('36', 465, 1, 16, 916280) We shall have to wander from existence to existence, whereas Shrimad may have only one life more to live.
('36', 465, 1, 17, 916386) We are perhaps running away from moksha, while Shrimad was flying towards it with the speed of wind.
('36', 465, 2, 18, 916487) This was no small achievement.
('36', 465, 2, 19, 916518) Even so, I must say that he had not attained the supreme state so beautifully described by him.
('36', 465, 2, 20, 916614) He himself said that he had come upon the Sahara in his journey and that he had failed to cross the desert.
('36', 465, 2, 21, 916722) Shrimad Rajchandra, however, was a rare being.
('36', 465, 2, 22, 916769) His writings are the quintessence of his experiences.
('36', 465, 2, 23, 916823) Anyone who reads them, reflects over them and follows them in his life will find the path to moksha easier; his yearning for sense pleasures will become progressively weaker, he will become disinterested in the affairs of this world, will cease to be attached to the life of the body and devote himself to the welfare of the atman.
('36', 465, 3, 24, 917155) 1 The self 2 A liberated person
('36', 466, 0, 1, 917187) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 467
('36', 466, 1, 2, 917232) The reader will see from this that Shrimad’s writings are meant only for those who are qualified to study them.
('36', 466, 1, 3, 917344) All readers will not find them interesting.
('36', 466, 1, 4, 917388) Those who are inclined to be critical will get material for criticism.
('36', 466, 1, 5, 917459) But those who have faith will find these writings of absorbing interest.
('36', 466, 1, 6, 917532) I have always felt that Shrimad’s writings breathe the spirit of truth.
('36', 466, 1, 7, 917604) He did not write a single word in order to show off his knowledge.
('36', 466, 1, 8, 917671) His aim in his writings was to share his inward bliss with his readers.
('36', 466, 1, 9, 917743) I am sure that anyone who wishes to free himself from inner conflicts and is eager to know his duty in life will gain much from Shrimad’s writings, whether such a reader is a Hindu or belongs to another faith.
('36', 466, 2, 10, 917953) And, hoping that the few reminiscences of Shrimad’s life which I have written down will help the reader who is qualified to read his writings, I give them here as part of this Foreword.
('36', 466, 3, 11, 918139) SOME REMINISCENCES OF RAYCHANDBHAI
('36', 466, 4, 12, 918174) CHAPTER 1: INTRODUCTORY
('36', 466, 5, 13, 918198) Today is the birth anniversary of the late Shrimad Rajchandra, whose reminiscences I have started writing, that is, it is the Kartiki Purnima 1, Samvat 1979. I am not attempting to write a biography of Shrimad; such an attempt is beyond my capacity.
('36', 466, 5, 14, 918448) I do not have with me the material needed for a biography.
('36', 466, 5, 15, 918507) If I wanted to write one, I would spend some time in his birth place, the port of Vavania 2, examine the house in which he lived, see the places which were the scenes of his childhood play and wanderings, meet his childhood friends, visit the school which he attended, interview his friends, disciples and relatives and gather from them all information which was likely to be useful; only after I had done all this would I start writing the biography.
('36', 466, 5, 16, 918959) But I have not visited these places or become acquainted with such persons.
('36', 466, 5, 17, 919035) And now I have begun to doubt even my capacity for writing these reminiscences.
('36', 466, 5, 18, 919115) I remember to have remarked more than once that, if I had the time, I would write such reminiscences.
('36', 466, 5, 19, 919217) One of his disciples, for whom I feel the highest respect, heard me say this, and I have undertaken this attempt mainly to satisfy him.
('36', 466, 5, 20, 919353) I would be happy,
('36', 466, 6, 21, 919371) 1 The full moon day of Kartika; the day corresponded to November 4, 1922.
('36', 466, 7, 22, 919445) 2 In Saurashtra
('36', 467, 0, 1, 919461) 468 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 467, 1, 2, 919503) in any case, to write these reminiscences of Shrimad Rajchandra, whom I used to call Raychandbhai or the Poet, out of my love and respect, and explain their significance to mumukshus.
('36', 467, 1, 3, 919687) As it is, however, my attempt is merely intended to satisfy a friend.
('36', 467, 1, 4, 919757) To be able to do justice to these reminiscences of his life, I should be well acquainted with the Jain way, which I must admit I am not.
('36', 467, 1, 5, 919894) I will, therefore, write them from an extremely restricted point of view.
('36', 467, 1, 6, 919968) I will content myself with a record of my memories of him and of the events in his life which had left an impression on me, and with a discussion of what I learned from those occasions.
('36', 467, 1, 7, 920154) The benefit which I thus derived, or some benefit similar to that, will perhaps be derived by the reader who is a mumukshu from a perusal of these reminiscences.
('36', 467, 1, 8, 920316) I have used the word mumukshu advisedly.
('36', 467, 1, 9, 920357) This attempt at writing my reminiscences is not intended for all classes of readers.
('36', 467, 1, 10, 920442) Three persons have influenced me deeply, Tolstoy, Ruskin and Raychandbhai: Tolstoy through one of his books and through a little correspondence with him, Ruskin through one book of his, Unto This Last—which in Gujarati I have called Sarvodaya,—and Raychandbhai through intimate personal contact.
('36', 467, 1, 11, 920738) When I began to feel doubts about Hinduism as a religion, it was Raychandbhai who helped me to resolve them.
('36', 467, 1, 12, 920847) In the year 1893, I came into close contact with some Christian gentlemen in South Africa.
('36', 467, 1, 13, 920938) Their lives were pure, and they were devoted to their religion.
('36', 467, 1, 14, 921002) Their main work in life was to persuade followers of other faiths to embrace Christianity.
('36', 467, 1, 15, 921093) Though I had come into contact with them in connection with practical affairs, they began to feel solicitude for my spiritual welfare.
('36', 467, 1, 16, 921228) I realized that I had one duty: that until I had studied the teachings of Hinduism and found that they did not satisfy my soul, I should not renounce the faith in which I was born.
('36', 467, 1, 17, 921409) I, therefore, started reading Hindu and other scriptures.
('36', 467, 1, 18, 921467) I read books on Christianity and Islam.
('36', 467, 1, 19, 921507) I carried on correspondence with some friends I had made in London.
('36', 467, 1, 20, 921575) I placed my doubts before them.
('36', 467, 1, 21, 921607) I entered into correspondence with every person in India in whom I had some trust, Raychandbhai being the chief among them.
('36', 467, 1, 22, 921731) 1 I had already been introduced to him and a close bond had grown between us.
('36', 467, 1, 23, 921809) I had respect for him, and so I decided to get from him everything he could give.
('36', 467, 1, 24, 921891) The result was that I gained peace of mind.
('36', 467, 1, 25, 921935) I felt reassured that Hinduism could give me what I
('36', 467, 2, 26, 921987) 1Vide”Gandhiji’s Questions to Rajchandra and his Replies”, before 12 12 1926.
('36', 468, 0, 1, 922065) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 469

('36', 480, 3, 5, 947325) 542. IS THIS HUMANITY?—V 2
('36', 480, 4, 6, 947352) [November 7, 1926] 3
('36', 480, 5, 7, 947373) A friend writes a long letter mentioning his difficulties and pointing out what Jainism has to say to him, a shrawak, in the matter.
('36', 480, 5, 8, 947506) One of his questions is:
('36', 480, 6, 9, 947531) You say that if we can niether take individual charge of roving dogs nor have a pinjrapole for them, the only alternative is to kill them.
('36', 480, 6, 10, 947670) Does that
('36', 480, 7, 11, 947680) mean that every roving dog should be killed, although it may not be rabid?
('36', 480, 7, 12, 947755) Don’t you agree that we leave unmolested all harmful beasts, birds and reptiles, so long as they do not actually harm us?
('36', 480, 7, 13, 947877) Why should the dogs be an exception?
('36', 480, 7, 14, 947914) Where is the humanity of shooting innocent dogs whenever they are found roving?
('36', 480, 7, 15, 947994) How can one wishing well to all living beings do this?
('36', 480, 7, 16, 948049) The writer has misunderstood my meaning.
('36', 480, 7, 17, 948090) I would not suggest even the destruction of rabid dogs for the sake of it, much less that of innocent, roving dogs.
('36', 480, 7, 18, 948206) Nor have I said that these latter should be killed wherever they are found.
('36', 480, 7, 19, 948282) I have only suggested legislation to that effect, so that as soon as the law is made, humane people might wake up in the matter and devise measures for the better management of stray dogs.
('36', 480, 7, 20, 948471) Some of these might be owned, some might be put in quarantine.
('36', 480, 7, 21, 948534) The remedy, when it is taken, will be once for all.
('36', 480, 7, 22, 948586) Stray dogs do not drop down from heaven.
('36', 480, 7, 23, 948627) They are a sign of the idleness, indifference and ignorance of society.
('36', 480, 7, 24, 948699) When they grow into a nuisance, it is due to our ignorance and want of compassion.
('36', 480, 7, 25, 948782) A stray dog is bound to take to his heels if you do not feed him.
('36', 480, 7, 26, 948848) The measure that I have suggested is actuated no less by a consideration of the welfare of the dogs than by that of society.
('36', 480, 7, 27, 948973) It is the duty of a

('36', 481, 9, 26, 950980) There were, of course, no stray dogs there.

('36', 481, 9, 28, 951208) The measure was taken purely in the public interest.
('36', 481, 9, 29, 951261) Practically the next day all the dogs in London were found to be with collars and muzzles.
('36', 481, 9, 30, 951352) It was, therefore, necessary to kill only a very few.

('36', 482, 1, 2, 951544) The ideal of humanity in the West is perhaps lower, but their practice of it is very much more thorough than ours.
('36', 482, 1, 3, 951659) We rest content with a lofty ideal and are slow or lazy in its practice.

('36', 482, 1, 5, 951823) They are eloquent of our irreligion rather than of religion.
('36', 482, 1, 6, 951884) Here is a third question:
('36', 482, 2, 7, 951910) You have different definitions of religion for the individual and for society.
('36', 482, 2, 8, 951989) But why should not religion in both cases be the same?
('36', 482, 2, 9, 952044) The ideal ought to be the same for both.
('36', 482, 2, 10, 952085) That it may be impossible to carry it out is a different matter.
('36', 482, 2, 11, 952150) For, even in case of the individual, only the occasion can show how far he has been able to carry out his ideal in practice.
('36', 482, 2, 12, 952275) You yourself have said that your ideal is to save even a cruel animal at the risk of your life, but you could not say what you would actually do when faced by such an animal.
('36', 482, 2, 13, 952450) There is no reason why society should not similarly have a lofty ideal and leave the individuals free to practise it according to their capacity.
('36', 482, 2, 14, 952596) My definition of religion for the individual and for society is the same.
('36', 482, 2, 15, 952670) The ideal must always be the same, but the practice I have conceived to be different in the case of the individual and the society.
('36', 482, 2, 16, 952802) Truly speaking, practice differs in case of every individual.
('36', 482, 2, 17, 952864) I do not know of two men having the same extent of the practice of ahimsa, though their definition of ahimsa is the same.
('36', 482, 2, 18, 952986) The extent of practice in case of society is the average of the different capacities of its members.
('36', 482, 2, 19, 953087) Thus, for instance, where a section of the society is milk arian and the other fruitarain, the practice for the society extends to the use of milk and fruit.
('36', 482, 3, 20, 953245) The writer next sets out two Jain doctrines as follows:
('36', 482, 4, 21, 953301) Jainism is based on the doctrine of syadvada—manysidedness of
('36', 482, 5, 22, 953363) reality.
('36', 482, 5, 23, 953372) As is aptly said: ‘No absolute rule is correct; only the relative rule is the correct rule.’ Which means that an act which may be described as himsa
('36', 482, 6, 24, 953521) under certain circumstances may be ahimsa under other circumstances.
('36', 482, 6, 25, 953590) Man should always use his discrimination in determining his conduct.
('36', 482, 6, 26, 953659) There are two classes of Jains.
('36', 482, 6, 27, 953691) Sadhus (the monks) and shrawaks (the laity).
('36', 482, 6, 28, 953736) Their code of
('36', 482, 7, 29, 953750) conduct is thus defined: The sadhu is always non violent.
('36', 482, 7, 30, 953808) He may not eat to save himself, may not cook for himself, may not walk even a step for his own purpose—all his activity is for the welfare of the community and it should be as harmless as possible.
('36', 482, 7, 31, 954006) He has to avoid the 42 infringements laid down in the Shastras.
('36', 482, 7, 32, 954070) The sadhu is described as nirgrantha—free from bonds.
('36', 482, 7, 33, 954124) So far as I
('36', 482, 8, 34, 954136) know there is no sadhu today who can satisfy the definition of a sadhu given above.

('36', 486, 3, 4, 959934) DEAR FRIEND, I thank you for your letter.
('36', 486, 3, 5, 959976) 1 It may flatter my pride, but I hope I have none.
('36', 486, 3, 6, 960027) I am conscious of my unfitness and limitations.
('36', 486, 3, 7, 960075) If there was the slightest chance of successful intervention, my seclusion would not deter me.
('36', 486, 3, 8, 960170) But I see none.
('36', 486, 3, 9, 960186) I therefore remain still and pray.

('36', 486, 4, 12, 960432) I commend it to you.
