('36', 489, 0, 1, 963796) 490 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 489, 1, 2, 963838) APPENDICES
('36', 489, 2, 3, 963849) APPENDIX I
('36', 489, 3, 4, 963860) LETTER FROM NORMAN LEYS
('36', 489, 4, 5, 963884) BRAILSFORD,
('36', 489, 5, 6, 963896) NEAR DERBY, June 29, 1926
('36', 489, 6, 7, 963922) DEAR MR. GANDHI,
('36', 489, 7, 8, 963939) I am most grateful for your letter.
('36', 489, 7, 9, 963975) My great difficulty, in which I am most anxious for your advice, is this.
('36', 489, 7, 10, 964049) I am a member of the committee set up by the Independent Labour Party to determine what policy that party should pursue in regard to India.
('36', 489, 7, 11, 964189) The I.L.P is a constituent part of the Labour Party and contains the great majority of its most active members.
('36', 489, 7, 12, 964301) It is definitely anti Imperialist, by contrast with a group in the Labour Party which would have the party make no distinct break with past traditions.
('36', 489, 7, 13, 964453) Hitherto most of the things that the I.L.P. has urged the Labour Party to adopt, it has adopted.
('36', 489, 7, 14, 964550) But the time is near when there will be a struggle between I.L.P. ideas and Imperialist ideas in the L.P. When that struggle comes a great deal will depend on whether we can prove our policy to be practicable.
('36', 489, 7, 15, 964760) If for example our opponents can say “what is the use of arousing the enmity of British people in India for the sake of a policy which Indians themselves don’t want and wouldn’t act upon?”—then the people who say “let things go on as they are until Indians learn more sense” will prevail in the Labour Party.
('36', 489, 7, 16, 965069) And that would mean an end to any hope of fraternal relations for many years, since Labour Governments in this country would have no reason to behave to[wards] India differently from Conservative Governments.
('36', 489, 7, 17, 965278) For these reasons it does seem to me important that this committee should reach the right conclusions.
('36', 489, 7, 18, 965381) I ask you to tell me what these conclusions should be.
('36', 489, 7, 19, 965436) What should the next Labour Government do about India?
('36', 489, 7, 20, 965491) The obvious answer is that they should do as Indians themselves wish, and of course the ignorant among us are content with that answer.
('36', 489, 7, 21, 965627) Those who like me know a little more, know that in no country are those who love their country in agreement about even the chief political measures and steps to be taken.
('36', 489, 7, 22, 965798) And it is painfully evident that the disagreements in India are deeper and wider than usual.
('36', 489, 7, 23, 965891) Does that fact make the problem—our problem in this country, I mean not yours in your country— insoluble?
('36', 489, 7, 24, 965997) In answer I think we ought both to admit that in the cases of past nationalist movements success was attained only when some organized body of men had won the support of the great majority of those who were ready to make sacrificesfor their country’s liberty.
('36', 489, 7, 25, 966257) In Italy for example, national liberty was won only when the policy of Cavour and Garibaldi prevailed in the minds of the Italians over the policy of Mazzini.
('36', 489, 7, 26, 966416) (I believe Mazzini was right and Cavour wrong but that is irrelevent.)
('36', 490, 0, 1, 966487) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 491
('36', 490, 1, 2, 966532) Foreigners were able to help the Italians to independence only because there were conspicuous people to deal with who were known to have the support, not of all Italians but of so large a proportion of them that they could speak for Italy.
('36', 490, 1, 3, 966772) Nothing of that sort is apparently imaginable in India for many years.
('36', 490, 1, 4, 966843) What then can the friends of India do?
('36', 490, 1, 5, 966882) So far as I can see there are only two possible answers.
('36', 490, 1, 6, 966939) They can arbitrarily choose some group of men in India with definite views and a programme so fully and carefully worked out that its practicability is tolerably certain, adopt that policy and hope that its adoption by Socialist opinion in Britain will result in its gradually gaining ground in India until it can be acted on.
('36', 490, 1, 7, 967266) Or, they could simply frame a policy of their own, drafting a constitution which in their opinion would work and would also perhaps win support from men in India who find nothing to admire in one another’s proposals.
('36', 490, 1, 8, 967483) Which of these solutions do you prefer?
('36', 490, 1, 9, 967523) Or is there another, a third, outside my range of vision?
('36', 490, 1, 10, 967581) The second alternative appears presumptuous, but it must be remembered that we in this country have an unprecedented experience, not only of the operation of democratic institutions but of the framing of constitutions for other countries.
('36', 490, 2, 11, 967820) There is one isolated point you raise on which I should be specially grateful for further information.
('36', 490, 2, 12, 967923) You suggest that the British authorities may partly be responsible for the communal strife.
('36', 490, 2, 13, 968015) I can understand that an administrative act like the partition of Bengal might aggravate it.
('36', 490, 2, 14, 968108) But I cannot understand how any agent of government could possibly influence the people who actually engage in strife.
('36', 490, 2, 15, 968227) The important question to ask is what a Labour Government could do to put an end to those actions of its agents in India, whatever they may be, which increase hatred between Hindu and Muslim.
('36', 490, 2, 16, 968419) It obviously could not replace most of these agents by men sympathetic with Indian liberty.
('36', 490, 2, 17, 968511) What less drastic steps could it take?
('36', 490, 3, 18, 968550) If you are going to be so generous with your time and energy as to answer this letter, please do not trouble to follow my arguments in detail.
('36', 490, 3, 19, 968693) I have shown you whether my mind has been drawn by the facts, only because I could explain our perplexity in no other way.
('36', 490, 3, 20, 968816) In your answer I beg you to think of one thing only, how you would act if your name were not Gandhi but Leys, and God had given you some responsibility for coming to decisions which conceivably may become the decisions upon which some day a British Government may act.
('36', 490, 3, 21, 969085) What arguments would you use with those whose remedy is to leave alone?
('36', 490, 3, 22, 969157) And just what, as precisely as possible, would you advocate if in my place?
('36', 490, 3, 23, 969233) I hope the comparison between us, that suggests that in my place you might conceivably think as I do.
('36', 490, 3, 24, 969335) will not vex you.
('36', 490, 3, 25, 969353) If mankind is a single family, none of the differences between its members should prevent them from helping one another.
('36', 490, 3, 26, 969474) Yours sincerely, NORMAN LEYS
('36', 490, 4, 27, 969503) From a photos tat: S.N. 12168
('36', 491, 0, 1, 969533) 492 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 491, 1, 2, 969575) APPENDIX II LETTER FROM NORMAN LEYS
('36', 491, 2, 3, 969611) BRAILSFORD,
('36', 491, 3, 4, 969623) NEAR DERBY, August 9, 1926
('36', 491, 4, 5, 969650) DEAR MR. GANDHI, Your letter gives me real hope that with your help Socialists in this country may discover what it is their duty to do in regard to India.
('36', 491, 4, 6, 969806) But do not imagine that I am “called upon to lead or guide the I.L.P”.
('36', 491, 4, 7, 969877) I am merely one out of about a dozen members of that party who because they have had some special experience have been asked by their fellow members to explore and discover what the duty of the whole party is.
('36', 491, 4, 8, 970087) Will you allow the other members of the committee to read your letters, on condition that they must not get into print?
('36', 491, 4, 9, 970207) Your explanation of the difference between the various Indian parties and their programmes is most important.
('36', 491, 4, 10, 970317) It has cleared away one mystery from my mind.
('36', 491, 4, 11, 970363) Even more important is your prescription for the solution of the problem a Labour Government would have to meet in India.
('36', 491, 4, 12, 970485) You would have such a government choose some one person to first of all confer with the leaders of Indian opinion and then decide on a constitution and programme which his party would impose on India.
('36', 491, 4, 13, 970686) Public opinion would disapprove of a single person being given such a task.
('36', 491, 4, 14, 970762) But I see no reason against its being given to a committee of three or four persons.
('36', 491, 4, 15, 970847) There are of course immense difficulties in the way of your solution (which is identical with the second alternative in my last letter) but the great thing about it is that it is a real solution.
('36', 491, 4, 16, 971043) The difficulties are of two sorts.
('36', 491, 4, 17, 971078) One sort is inherent in British politics.
('36', 491, 4, 18, 971120) Committees with us are representative.
('36', 491, 4, 19, 971159) They are samples of a variety of types of mind.
('36', 491, 4, 20, 971207) But a committee to draw up a constitution for India would have to be composed of men with the same mind.
('36', 491, 4, 21, 971312) Important differences among its members would wreck its work.
('36', 491, 4, 22, 971374) A greater difficulty would be to get the Labour Government to entrust the task to men who would disregard everything but the needs of India.
('36', 491, 4, 23, 971515) The last Labour Government stultified itself by fear.
('36', 491, 4, 24, 971569) It was afraid, not only of its enemies but of its own programme.
('36', 491, 4, 25, 971634) I know Lord Oliver to be a true friend to India.
('36', 491, 4, 26, 971683) But I feel sure he would admit now that if he had risked his all in framing even in bare outlines, a really democratic constitution, and urging it on his cabinet, he would have done the right thing.
('36', 491, 4, 27, 971882) But even you cannot realize the storm it would create if the next Labour Government gave the Indian problem to be solved by men who sought a solution that would conform to two conditions and these two only, viz., that their constitution would work and that it would satisfy the bulk of Indian opinion.
('36', 491, 4, 28, 972184) Unless the I.L.P. leavens the whole Labour Party very rapidly the next Labour Government will leave India to some “safe” man, and, if it expects him, either alone or with one or two others, to make a constitution, will expect one that would buy off with compromises the less rabid imperialists.
('36', 491, 4, 29, 972479) The other sort of difficulty comes from your end.
('36', 491, 4, 30, 972529) You practically admit that
('36', 492, 0, 1, 972556) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 493
('36', 492, 1, 2, 972601) Muslims would resist by fighting if a democratic government were set up in India.
('36', 492, 1, 3, 972683) I believe that Islam and democracy are as incompatible as oil and water.
('36', 492, 1, 4, 972756) Do you expect that the rest of Indians would defend their political liberty against them?
('36', 492, 1, 5, 972846) Or are British troops to be called in?
('36', 492, 1, 6, 972885) In either case you must admit Muslim resistance would involve a kind of war, and that would mean that the blood of many innocents would be shed.
('36', 492, 2, 7, 973030) You put forward one suggestion that you think would help to diminish Muslim antagonism, “preference in education”.
('36', 492, 2, 8, 973145) Could you elaborate that idea?
('36', 492, 2, 9, 973176) We have a plan in this country whereby in secondary, i.e., more advanced, schools which get grants of public money, a large number of the scholars must be poor and must be given free education.
('36', 492, 2, 10, 973370) Is that the sort of thing you mean?
('36', 492, 2, 11, 973406) Would you have the constitution include clauses that would compel the Provincial Governments to give a proportion of such “free places” to Muslim children, according to the number of Muslims in the population?
('36', 492, 2, 12, 973616) Finally, there is insistent in my mind the dreadful question, to which I know there can be no answer, whether the inexperience of Indians will lead them to choose to represent them bad men, men who will deceive the people with flattery and others who will fill their own pockets.
('36', 492, 2, 13, 973896) We even in the Labour Party have many of the former class, no doubt some of the latter class.
('36', 492, 2, 14, 973990) If I were a member of a committee with the task of giving India self government—the idea is ridiculous of course—I should feel in my bones that the whole scheme might break down.
('36', 492, 2, 15, 974169) But I should also feel that the one chance of success lay in boldness, in throwing on the whole people of India more duties and more responsibility than they ask, in calling on them in effect to behave like free men.
('36', 492, 2, 16, 974386) Such a scheme most I.C.S. men would I suppose refuse to work.
('36', 492, 2, 17, 974448) Then would come the testing time.
('36', 492, 2, 18, 974482) I feel sure that Indians do exist to fill with efficiency the legislative, administrative and executive posts that will be vacant.
('36', 492, 2, 19, 974613) But will the Indian people choose these men and not others, or rather choose enough of them to enable the machinery of government to work well enough to prevent new tyrannies arising, whether a new Akbar or a new Curzon is no matter?
('36', 492, 2, 20, 974847) Most gratefully yours,
('36', 492, 3, 21, 974870) NORMAN LEYS [PS.]
('36', 492, 4, 22, 974888) It is quite impossible for me to visit India.
('36', 492, 4, 23, 974934) A number of much more important people in the party have of course done as you suggest and have done all they could to discover what Indians would wish a Labour Government to do in India.
('36', 492, 5, 24, 975122) From a photos tat: S.N. 12170
('36', 493, 0, 1, 975152) 494 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 493, 1, 2, 975194) APPENDIX III LETTER FROM NORMAN LEYS
('36', 493, 2, 3, 975231) September 20, 1926
('36', 493, 3, 4, 975250) DEAR MR. GANDHI, I cannot find anything to differ from in your letter, although of course differences in histories and environments always leave their marks.
('36', 493, 3, 5, 975408) I am most grateful for the time and thought you have given to my questions and shall not hesitate in future to consult you when perplexed about Indian affairs.
('36', 493, 3, 6, 975568) I have recently got to know one of your disciples, Tarini P. Sinha.
('36', 493, 3, 7, 975636) He has recently been on a speaking tour among the miners who live about thirty miles from our house.
('36', 493, 3, 8, 975737) Ten days ago he was arrested for something he had said.
('36', 493, 3, 9, 975793) I went to him as soon as I heard of the arrest.
('36', 493, 3, 10, 975841) His case has been postponed for a fortnight and he will come to our house from London on the way to the court.
('36', 493, 3, 11, 975952) I have little doubt he will be discharged acquitted 1. The only sentence that the police seem to have objected to was a criticism of patriotism and I have no doubt at all that he made it quite clear that what he condemned was not love of one’s own country but the hatred of or even the slighting of other countries.
('36', 493, 3, 12, 976268) In fact the real reason for his arrest seems to have been the language used by a very young Englishman who had been accompanying Mr. Sinha, and was in the habit of using vulgar terms of abuse and even encouraging the miners to injure those of their number who had accepted the terms of the mine owners.
('36', 493, 3, 13, 976571) If Mr. Sinha had been an Englishman he would have declined to continue to speak from the same platform as this man unless he gave better advice.
('36', 493, 3, 14, 976716) But I think this man is sorry now.
('36', 493, 3, 15, 976751) One feature of your movement that we on this side of the world also share is the idea of restricting personal expenditure to an equal part of the national income.
('36', 493, 3, 16, 976914) I have been trying to do it for years, and failing most of the time.
('36', 493, 3, 17, 976983) Besides personal difficulties there are those which arise from the fact that family expenses are the chief trouble—and women are always more conservative than men.
('36', 493, 3, 18, 977147) Also I don’t think the idea a good one for the young, who ought to have more than an equal share.
('36', 493, 3, 19, 977245) But some day I hope there will be a fraternity in this country of people who, while living outwardly in every way like those who have taken no vow, pledge themselves not to spend their money on themselves.
('36', 493, 3, 20, 977451) I think I remember Mr. Andrews saying he had sent you last year one of the copies of my book I had sent him for distribution.
('36', 493, 3, 21, 977577) It is called Kenya.
('36', 493, 3, 22, 977597) But if you have no copy please let me know, if you would be so good as to let me give you one.
('36', 493, 3, 23, 977692) You will let me sign myself as we Socialists do.
('36', 493, 3, 24, 977741) Yours fraternally,
('36', 493, 4, 25, 977760) NORMAN LEYS
('36', 493, 5, 26, 977772) From a photos tat: S.N. 12172
('36', 493, 6, 27, 977802) 1 The source has both the words.
('36', 494, 0, 1, 977835) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 495
('36', 494, 1, 2, 977880) APPENDIX IV
('36', 494, 2, 3, 977892) (AN APPEAL)
('36', 494, 3, 4, 977904) MAHATMAJI,
('36', 494, 4, 5, 977915) You will, perhaps, be surprised and even annoyed at this somewhat unusual mode of approach to one who has never denied accessibility to the humblest of his followers.
('36', 494, 4, 6, 978082) Our only excuse for this method of addressing you is to be found in the present deplorable condition of our national politics, the distressing divisions and cross divisions of parties and principles, the clash of personalities and the clang of prejudice.
('36', 494, 4, 7, 978337) You are, of course, not unaware of this nor can any other Indian heart bleed as freely as yours must be bleeding at the distressful spectacle presented by the country.
('36', 494, 4, 8, 978505) But what, perhaps, we venture to think, is unknown to you and what we seek with all respect to bring to your notice, by this communication addressed through the medium of the Press, is the unspoken anxiety and eagerness of millions of your countrymen who have been long waiting for a lead from you, the one Indian who is a national figure and is trusted by all the warring communities and feared as well as respected by the Government.
('36', 494, 4, 9, 978941) These your countrymen are unable to voice their sentiments and make their appeal to you because they respect the self denying ordinance you have imposed on yourself.
('36', 494, 4, 10, 979107) Sir, if it be not presumptuous in your eyes that we thus constitute ourselves their spokesmen and plead with you to resume the reins that you have voluntarily surrendered, will you permit us to make this appeal, in the name of the unspeaking masses of India, in the name of those who, while you were still at the helm, followed your orders and instructions without cavil or question, in the name of those sacred principles of liberty, equality and fraternity which are being trampled under foot simply because the one man who could hold up his head and withstand the onslaught of reactionarism in these days of distress and despair is not there at his post?
('36', 494, 5, 11, 979765) Sir, our reasons for this appeal cannot be unknown to you.
('36', 494, 5, 12, 979824) We have been your followers ever since you started the campaign of non violent non co operation and we have not ceased to believe in the central basis of your war against the present system of government.
('36', 494, 5, 13, 980029) The country, probably, was not prepared to submit to the rigorous self discipline, the relentless self denial that the pursuit of your great ideal necessarily involved; and so in sheer despair at the unreadiness of your countrymen and despite the unspeakable anguish to yourself, you elected rather to countermand the campaign commencing at Bardoli than to proceed further at the cost of repeated and innumerable Chauri Chauras.
('36', 494, 5, 14, 980458) With your incarceration, Sir, commenced the decay of the strident sentiment of national solidarity and of the determined resolve to win national freedom.
('36', 494, 5, 15, 980612) Your release and the subsequent developments of the political situation are much too well known to need recall.
('36', 494, 5, 16, 980724) But the nation has watched with breathless suspense the triumph after triumph of the forces of reaction, the surrender after surrender which you seemed to be making rather than permit the country to be cast into the unfathomable pit of irremediable wrongs.
('36', 494, 5, 17, 980981) There are many, however, who have never understood the sublime self sacrifice dictating your actions ever since

('36', 495, 2, 3, 981523) The more imperative reasons why the unquestioned leader of the Indian people should emerge at this critical juncture from his self imposed seclusion are also not lacking.
('36', 495, 2, 4, 981694) Besides the great, incalculable harm done to the soul of a country by foreign domination of the kind we are undergoing, India has today innumerable reasons to apprehend that, without a determined stand for their rights by her people, the interests of this country will be immolated on the altar of the greed of alien exploiters.

('36', 497, 5, 23, 989341) FEROZABAD,
('36', 497, 7, 24, 989352) SIR, There are certain statements in your article “Out of the Frying pan” published in the Young India of 9th Sept.
('36', 497, 7, 25, 989468) which require explanation at your hands.
('36', 497, 7, 26, 989509) You have quoted a passage from the report of Mr. S. A. Waiz to the l.I.C. Association which asserts that there were two ‘chief reasons’ which led the Colonial Indians to leave their land of birth: (l) The desire to visit the motherland and (2) The rumour that India had obtained self government.
('36', 497, 7, 27, 989805) Now as one who has been in close touch with many of
('36', 498, 0, 1, 989857) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 499
('36', 498, 1, 2, 989902) these returned emigrants for the last six years and who has visited their quarters not less than twenty times during this period, I can say that the second reason is pure fiction.
('36', 498, 1, 3, 990082) When I was entrusted with the work of looking after these emigrants by Mr. Andrews and yourself, one or two persons brought forward the same reason before me and I made a thorough enquiry into it and found it absolutely without any foundation.
('36', 498, 1, 4, 990326) Evidently Mr. Waiz has been misled by some of the clever people in Matiaburz.
('36', 498, 1, 5, 990404) Referring to the difficulties of these returned emigrants in India you say, “Here they are social lepers, not even knowing the language of the people.” First of all I must say that most of them do know the language of the people.
('36', 498, 1, 6, 990634) Surely they can express their ideas though not in grammatically correct Hindustani, I have myself talked with hundreds of these people in Matiaburz in Hindi and during my several visits to Matiaburz I did not come across a single Indian whom your phrase “not even knowing the language of the people” could apply.
('36', 498, 1, 7, 990947) I can definitely say that most of them have fair knowledge of speaking Hindustani.
('36', 498, 1, 8, 991030) Of course they do not know literary Hindi or Urdu.
('36', 498, 1, 9, 991081) Then there is one thing more that must not be forgotten, i.e., more than eighty per cent of the returned emigrants get absorbed in the villages of India and it is only less than twenty per cent who find their way to Matiaburz, and these people in Matiaburz have been offered opportunities for settlement many a time but they have all along refused to consider them.
('36', 498, 1, 10, 991447) There can be no doubt that a good many of those who are at present stranded in Matiaburz suffered at the hands of their caste people, the zamindars and the police and the pandits, but as I have said they form only a small percentage of the total number of the returned emigrants.
('36', 498, 1, 11, 991727) Thus your statement requires qualification.
('36', 498, 2, 12, 991771) You approve the policy of sending these returned emigrants to the “most suitable colony that would receive them”.
('36', 498, 2, 13, 991885) At present only British Guiana is ready to receive them and the Government of India is willing to send some of them to that Colony.
('36', 498, 2, 14, 992017) Indeed there is a steamer waiting at Calcutta for some days past.
('36', 498, 2, 15, 992083) It sails on 20th.
('36', 498, 2, 16, 992101) Do you approve of the idea of Fiji Indians being sent to British Guiana?
('36', 498, 2, 17, 992174) I ask this question because I am afraid that the Indian Government may take advantage of this statement of yours and despatch these Fiji Indians to British Guiana.
('36', 498, 2, 18, 992338) At present the number of British Guiana returned emigrants in Matiaburz does not exceed 300, while the number of Fiji returned is more than 600. I made an enquiry in Matiaburz 10 months ago and published my conclusions in the Chand of Allahabad.
('36', 498, 2, 19, 992584) Extracts from this article of mine were read by a member of the Fiji Legislative Council in a meeting of the Council and he moved a resolution that 500 of these Fiji people should be taken to Fiji.
('36', 498, 2, 20, 992782) The resolution was passed and was taken as a unanimous expression of opinion of the elected members of the Council.
('36', 498, 2, 21, 992898) Now the Governor of Fiji has written to the Secretary of State for the Colonies on this subject.
('36', 498, 2, 22, 992995) So there is just a possibility of Fiji returned emigrants being sent back to Fiji.
('36', 498, 3, 23, 993078) You have mentioned four fundamental questions raised by this problem of stranded emigrants in Matiaburz: (I) emigration policy, (2) special case of British Guiana and Fiji, (3) scope of the friendly societies and (4) the duty of the nation.

('36', 499, 1, 3, 993442) Now so far as the question of British Guiana returned emigrants being sent to that Colony is concerned, I entirely agree with you but I will not advise the Fiji Indians to be sent to British Guiana which has a climate very much worse than that of Fiji, which possesses an ideal climate.
('36', 499, 1, 4, 993729) Indeed the four fundamental questions raised by you are inter related and they require immediate attention.

('36', 499, 1, 6, 993953) Besides this thousands of Indians return from the Colonies every year and there is no doubt that the Matiaburz problem is not a temporary one, it will be recurring again and again for a long time to come.

('36', 499, 3, 17, 995364) APPENDIX VII
('36', 499, 4, 18, 995377) GANDHIJI’S QUESTIONS TO RAJCHANDRA AND HIS REPLIES 1
('36', 499, 5, 19, 995430) 1. Q. What is the Soul?
('36', 499, 5, 20, 995454) Does it perform actions?
('36', 499, 5, 21, 995479) Do past actions impede its progress or not?
('36', 499, 6, 22, 995523) A. (1) As there are physical objects like a pot, piece of cloth, etc., so there is an entity called the atman whose essence is knowledge.
('36', 499, 6, 23, 995661) The former are impermanent.
('36', 499, 6, 24, 995689) They cannot exist through all time in the same form.
('36', 499, 6, 25, 995742) The atman is an imperishable
('36', 499, 7, 26, 995771) entity which exists eternally in the same form.
('36', 499, 7, 27, 995819) Anything which is not the product of
('36', 499, 8, 28, 995856) 1 The translation of the questions is reproduced from The letter accompanying Rajchandra’s replies is dated Bombay, Saturday, Aso Vad 6, 1950 [October 20, 1894].
('36', 500, 0, 1, 996018) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 501
('36', 500, 1, 2, 996063) a combination of other elements is imperishable.
('36', 500, 1, 3, 996112) We cannot think of the atman as
('36', 500, 2, 4, 996144) being such a product, for, no matter in how many thousand different ways we combine material substances, such combinations cannot possibly produce life and conscio usness.
('36', 500, 2, 5, 996316) Every one of us can know from experience that by combining several elements we cannot produce in the compound a property which is not present in any of those elements.
('36', 500, 2, 6, 996484) We do not find knowledge to be the essence of physical substances.
('36', 500, 2, 7, 996551) If we change the forms of such substances and combine them, or if they change and combine by chance, the products will be of the same kind as they are; that is, they will be of a material nature and will not have knowledge as their essence.
('36', 500, 2, 8, 996792) It is not possible, then, that the atman, which the seers describe as having knowledge as
('36', 500, 3, 9, 996882) its essential character, can be produced by any combination of the elements (earth, water, air, space) of which physical substances like a pot, a piece of cloth, etc., are composed.
('36', 500, 3, 10, 997064) The atman has knowledge as its essential character, whereas material
('36', 500, 4, 11, 997133) substances are characterized by its absence.
('36', 500, 4, 12, 997178) These are the eternal natures of the two.
('36', 500, 5, 13, 997220) This and a thousand other reasons prove the atman to be imperishable.
('36', 500, 5, 14, 997290) Further reflection on the subject enables us to realize that the atman from its nature is imperishable.
('36', 500, 5, 15, 997394) There is, therefore, no error or logical difficulty in believing that the atman, the existence of which is the cause of our experiencing happiness and suffering which also withdraws itself from either, and which is conscious of something which thinks and impels, is characterized by awareness as its essential nature and that, in virtue of this nature, it is an imperishable entity which exists eternally; on the contrary, belief in the atman has this merit of accepting truth.
('36', 500, 6, 16, 997872) (2) When the atman has attained a state of knowledge, the state resulting from a true understanding of its essence, it is the karta 1 of that state, the state of illumination (determination of what it truly is) and of the resulting state of pure awareness, which is its true nature.
('36', 500, 6, 17, 998155) In a state of ignorance, it is the karta of the emotions of anger, love of honour, attachment, greed, etc., and when enjoying the fruits of these emotions, becomes, as the occasion may require, the karta of physical objects like a pot, a piece of cloth etc., that is, he is not the creator of the original substance of those objects, but is only the karta of the action of imposing some form on it.
('36', 500, 6, 18, 998554) This latter state is described in Jainism as karma, and in Vedanta as illusion or in other similar terms.
('36', 500, 6, 19, 998660) If we reflect carefully on the matter, we shall clearly see that the atman cannot be the karta of physical objects or emotions like anger, that it is karta only of the state of self realization.
('36', 500, 7, 20, 998855) (3) The karmas performed while in the state of ignorance are like seed in the beginning and grow into a tree in course of time; in other words, the atman has to
('36', 500, 8, 21, 999016) suffer the consequences of those karmas.
('36', 500, 8, 22, 999057) Just as contact with fire produces the experience of heat, the natural end of which is pain, so the atman, being the karta of
('36', 500, 9, 23, 999183) emotions of anger, etc., has to suffer, as consequence, pain in the form of birth, old
('36', 500, 10, 24, 999270) 1 Author, doer
('36', 501, 0, 1, 999285) 502 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('36', 501, 1, 2, 999327) age and death.
('36', 501, 1, 3, 999342) You should carefully reflect over this idea and ask me any question which may arise in your mind about it, for an understanding of the state from which the soul must withdraw itself and the effort to withdraw will bring deliverance to it.
('36', 501, 1, 4, 999581) 2. Q. What is God?
('36', 501, 1, 5, 999600) Is He the creator of the universe?
('36', 501, 2, 6, 999635) A. (1) You, I and others are souls suffering the bondage of karma.
('36', 501, 2, 7, 999702) The soul’s existence in its natural state, that is, in freedom from karma and purely as the atman that it is, is the state of being Ishvar.
('36', 501, 2, 8, 999842) 1 That which has the aishvarya 2 of knowledge, etc., may be described as Ishvar.
('36', 501, 2, 9, 999923) This Ishvarhood is the natural state of the atman, which is not revealed when it is engaged in karmas.
('36', 501, 2, 10, 1000026) When the atman however, realizes
('36', 501, 3, 11, 1000059) that being engaged in karma is not its real nature and fixes its attention on itself, then alone do omniscience, power etc., manifest themselves in it and we can see nothing among all the objects in the universe with greater power than the atman’s.
('36', 501, 3, 12, 1000308) It is, therefore, my positive belief that Ishvar is another name for atman and does not
('36', 501, 4, 13, 1000396) signify a different Being of greater power.
('36', 501, 5, 14, 1000440) (2) Ishvar is not the creator ot the universe, that is, atoms, space, etc., can be conceived only as imperishable entities and not as created from some other substance.
('36', 501, 5, 15, 1000609) If it is stated that they came into being from Ishvar, that, too, does not seem likely; for, if we believe that Ishvar is a spirit, how can atoms, space, etc., come into being from Him?
('36', 501, 5, 16, 1000795) For it is impossible that matter can come into existence from that which is spirit.
('36', 501, 5, 17, 1000879) If Ishvar is regarded as material, He will then lose His Ishvarhood; also, a spiritual entity like the soul cannot come into being from such an Ishvar.
('36', 501, 5, 18, 1001031) If we regard Him as being both matter and spirit, that only means that we are pleased to call the world, which is both matter and spirit, by another name, Ishvar.
('36', 501, 5, 19, 1001194) Instead of doing that, it is better to call the world the world: If we hold that atoms, space, etc., are imperishable entities and that Ishvar only awards the fruits of karma, this too, cannot be proved.
('36', 501, 5, 20, 1001398) Convincing reasons have been given in support of this view in Shatdarshan Samuchchaya 3.
('36', 501, 6, 21, 1001487) 3. Q. What is moksha?
('36', 501, 7, 22, 1001509) A. While the atman is in the state of ignorance, characterized by anger, etc., it
('36', 501, 8, 23, 1001591) is under the bondage of the body, and complete cessation of such a state, deliverance from it, is described by seers as moksha.
('36', 501, 8, 24, 1001719) A little reflection shows this to be logical
('36', 501, 9, 25, 1001764) and convincing.
('36', 501, 9, 26, 1001780) 4. Q. Is it possible for a person to know for certain, while he is still living, whether or not he will attain moksha.
('36', 501, 10, 27, 1001899) A. If our arms are tied with a rope wound several times round them and if the twists of the rope are loosened one after another, we feel the loosening of each twist
('36', 501, 11, 28, 1002064) 1 Ruler, God 2 Power 3 A philosophical treatise; Rajchandra had earlier sent a copy of it to Gandhiji.
('36', 502, 0, 1, 1002167) VOL. 36 : 8 JULY, 1926 10 NOVEMBER, 1926 503
('36', 502, 1, 2, 1002212) and in the end become conscious of the rope having been removed.
('36', 502, 1, 3, 1002277) In like manner as the innumerable bonds, the products of ignorance, which bind the atman loosen one by one, the latter becomes conscious of progressing towards moksha, and when the bonds are about to fall off, the atman shines forth with the light of its essence and
('36', 502, 2, 4, 1002544) knows beyond doubt that it is about to be delivered from the bonds of ignorance.
('36', 502, 2, 5, 1002625) While still dwelling in this body, it comes out of the state of ignorance, etc., and becomes conscious of its pure essence and of its absolute otherness and freedom from all relations.
('36', 502, 2, 6, 1002810) In other words, it is possible to experience the state of moksha even
('36', 502, 3, 7, 1002880) while living.
('36', 502, 3, 8, 1002894) 5. Q. It is said that after his death, a man may, according to his actions, be reborn as an animal, a tree or even a stone.
('36', 502, 3, 9, 1003018) Is this a fact?
('36', 502, 4, 10, 1003034) A. After the soul has left the body, it attains a state according to the merit it has earned through its actions; hence, it may be born even as a lower creature, or may have even to assume a body of earth 1 and, devoid of the other four senses suffer the fruits of its karma [through the sense of touch alone].
('36', 502, 4, 11, 1003345) This does not mean, however, that it becomes pure stone or earth.
('36', 502, 4, 12, 1003411) The soul assumes a body of stone, but, even then, it exists as soul, though its existence is not manifest to us.
('36', 502, 4, 13, 1003524) Since in that condition the other four senses are unmanifest, the soul may be described as having an earth body.
('36', 502, 4, 14, 1003637) In the course of time, the soul leaves such a body after it has enjoyed the fruits of its karmas and then the stone material exists merely as atoms and, because the soul has left it, does not possess the instinct of food, etc.
('36', 502, 4, 15, 1003864) In other words, the idea is not that stone itself, which is pure matter, becomes a soul.
('36', 502, 4, 16, 1003953) It is in order to enjoy the fruits of those karmas which, because of their hard nature, compels the soul to take on a body possessing only one sense, the sense of touch the other senses remaining unmanifest, that it is born in an earth body; it does not, however, become pure earth or stone.
('36', 502, 4, 17, 1004245) The body is like a garment to the soul, and is not its essence.
('36', 502, 5, 18, 1004309) [6. & 7.] 2 The answer to Q. 6 is contained in the reply given above as also the answer to Q. 7 which is that earth or stone as such cannot be the kartas of any karma.
('36', 502, 5, 19, 1004477) It is the soul which has entered them and lives in them that is the karta of karmas, and
('36', 502, 6, 20, 1004566) even so, the relation between the two is like milk and water.
('36', 502, 6, 21, 1004628) Just as, even when they are mixed, milk is milk and water is water, so also the soul through the binding effect of its karmas which confines it to the possession of one sense only, seems to have become stone or mere matter, but, in its essential nature, it is a soul and even in that state it possesses the instincts of hunger, fear etc., though they remain unmanifest.

('36', 503, 1, 2, 1005393) Commonly a Jain describes Jainism, a Buddhist describes Buddhism and a Vedantin describes Vedanta as Arya Dharma.
